line: A corridor at a sperm bank.

So if a photon is directed through a plane with two slits in it and either slit is observed it will not go through both slits. If it‰Ûªs unobserved it will, however, if it‰Ûªs observed after it‰Ûªs left the plane but before it hits its target, it will not have gone through both slits.
Agreed, what‰Ûªs your point?
There‰Ûªs no point, I just think it‰Ûªs a good idea for a tee-shirt.
Excuse me?
Hang on.

One across is Aegean, eight down is Nabakov, twenty-six across is MCM, fourteen down is‰Û_ move your finger‰Û_ phylum, which makes fourteen across Port-au-Prince. See, Papa Doc‰Ûªs capital idea, that‰Ûªs Port-au-Prince. Haiti.
Can I help you?
Yes. Um, is this the High IQ sperm bank?
If you have to ask, maybe you shouldn‰Ûªt be here.
I think this is the place.
Fill these out.
Thank-you. We‰Ûªll be right back.
Oh, take your time. I‰Ûªll just finish my crossword puzzle. Oh wait.
Leonard, I don‰Ûªt think I can do this.
What, are you kidding? You‰Ûªre a semi-pro.

No. We are committing genetic fraud. There‰Ûªs no guarantee that our sperm is going to generate high IQ offspring, think about that. I have a sister with the same basic DNA mix who hostesses at Fuddruckers.
Sheldon, this was your idea. A little extra money to get fractional T1 bandwidth in the apartment.

I know, and I do yearn for faster downloads, but there‰Ûªs some poor woman is going to pin her hopes on my sperm, what if she winds up with a toddler who doesn‰Ûªt know if he should use an integral or a differential to solve the area under a curve.
I‰Ûªm sure she‰Ûªll still love him.
I wouldn‰Ûªt.
Well, what do you want to do?
I want to leave.
Okay.
What‰Ûªs the protocol for leaving?
I don‰Ûªt know, I‰Ûªve never reneged on a proffer of sperm before.
Let‰Ûªs try just walking out.
Bye-bye
See you.
The stairs of the apartment building.
Are you still mad about the sperm bank?
No.
You want to hear an interesting thing about stairs?
Not really.
If the height of a single step is off by as little as two millimetres, most people will trip.
I don‰Ûªt care. Two millimetres? That doesn‰Ûªt seem right.
No, it‰Ûªs true, I did a series of experiments when I was twelve, my father broke his clavicle.
Is that why they sent you to boarding school?
No, that was the result of my work with lasers.
New neighbour?
Evidently.
Significant improvement over the old neighbour.
Two hundred pound transvestite with a skin condition, yes she is.
Oh, hi!
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi?
We don‰Ûªt mean to interrupt, we live across the hall.
Oh, that‰Ûªs nice.
Oh‰Û_ uh‰Û_ no‰Û_ we don‰Ûªt live together‰Û_ um‰Û_ we live together but in separate, heterosexual bedrooms.
Oh, okay, well, guess I‰Ûªm your new neighbour, Penny.
Leonard, Sheldon.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi. Well, uh, oh, welcome to the building.
Thankyou, maybe we can have coffee sometime.
Oh, great.
Great.
Great.
Great. Well, bye.
Bye.
Bye.
Bye.
Should we have invited her for lunch?
No. We‰Ûªre going to start Season Two of Battlestar Galactica.
We already watched the Season Two DVDs.
Not with commentary.
I think we should be good neighbours, invite her over, make her feel welcome.
We never invited Louis-slash-Louise over.
Well, then that was wrong of us. We need to widen our circle.
I have a very wide circle. I have 212 friends on myspace.
Yes, and you‰Ûªve never met one of them.
That‰Ûªs the beauty of it.
I‰Ûªm going to invite her over. We‰Ûªll have a nice meal and chat.
Chat? We don‰Ûªt chat. At least not offline.
Well it‰Ûªs not difficult, you just listen to what she says and then you say something appropriate in response.
To what end?
Hi. Again.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.
Hi.

Anyway, um. We brought home Indian food. And, um. I know that moving can be stressful, and I find that when I‰Ûªm undergoing stress, that good food and company can have a comforting effect. Also, curry is a natural laxative, and I don‰Ûªt have to tell you that, uh, a clean colon is just one less thing to worry about.
Leonard, I‰Ûªm not expert here but I believe in the context of a luncheon invitation, you might want to skip the reference to bowel movements.
Oh, you‰Ûªre inviting me over to eat?
Uh, yes.
Oh, that‰Ûªs so nice, I‰Ûªd love to.
Great.
So, what do you guys do for fun around here?
Well, today we tried masturbating for money.
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment.
Okay, well, make yourself at home.
Okay, thankyou.
You‰Ûªre very welcome.
This looks like some serious stuff, Leonard, did you do this?
Actually that‰Ûªs my work.
Wow.
Yeah, well, it‰Ûªs just some quantum mechanics, with a little string theory doodling around the edges. That part there, that‰Ûªs just a joke, it‰Ûªs a spoof of the Bourne-Oppenheimer approximation.
So you‰Ûªre like, one of those, beautiful mind genius guys.
Yeah.
This is really impressive.
I have a board. If you like boards, this is my board.
Holy smokes.
If by holy smokes you mean a derivative restatement of the kind of stuff you can find scribbled on the wall of any men‰Ûªs room at MIT, sure.
What?
Oh, come on. Who hasn‰Ûªt seen this differential below ‰ÛÏhere I sit broken hearted?‰Û
At least I didn‰Ûªt have to invent twenty-six dimensions just to make the math come out.
I didn‰Ûªt invent them, they‰Ûªre there.
In what universe?
In all of them, that is the point.
Uh, do you guys mind if I start?
Um, Penny, that‰Ûªs where I sit.
So, sit next to me.
No, I sit there.
What‰Ûªs the difference?
What‰Ûªs the difference?
Here we go.

In the winter that seat is close enough to the radiator to remain warm, and yet not so close as to cause perspiration. In the summer it‰Ûªs directly in the path of a cross breeze created by open windows there, and there. It faces the television at an angle that is neither direct, thus discouraging conversation, nor so far wide to create a parallax distortion, I could go on, but I think I‰Ûªve made my point.
Do you want me to move?
Well.
Just sit somewhere else.
Fine. (Wanders in circles, looking lost.)
Sheldon, sit!
Aaah!
Well this is nice. We don‰Ûªt have a lot of company over.
That‰Ûªs not true. Koothrapali and Wolowitz come over all the time.
Yes I now, but‰Û_
Tuesday night we played Klingon boggle until one in the morning.
Yes, I remember.
I resent you saying we don‰Ûªt have company.
I‰Ûªm sorry.
That is an antisocial implication.
I said I‰Ûªm sorry.
So, Klingon boggle?
Yeah, it‰Ûªs like regular boggle but, in Klingon. That‰Ûªs probably enough about us, tell us about you.
Um, me, okay, I‰Ûªm Sagittarius, which probably tells you way more than you need to know.

Yes, it tells us that you participate in the mass cultural delusion that the Sun‰Ûªs apparent position relative to arbitrarily defined constellations and the time of your birth somehow effects your personality.
Participate in the what?
I think what Sheldon‰Ûªs trying to say, is that Sagittarius wouldn‰Ûªt have been our first guess.
Oh, yeah, a lot of people think I‰Ûªm a water sign. Okay, let‰Ûªs see, what else, oh, I‰Ûªm a vegetarian, oh, except for fish, and the occasional steak, I love steak.
That‰Ûªs interesting. Leonard can‰Ûªt process corn.
Wu-uh, do you have some sort of a job?
Oh, yeah, I‰Ûªm a waitress at the Cheesecake Factory.
Oh, okay. I love cheesecake.
You‰Ûªre lactose intolerant.
I don‰Ûªt eat it, I just think it‰Ûªs a good idea.
Oh, anyways, I‰Ûªm also writing a screenplay. It‰Ûªs about this sensitive girl who comes to L.A. from Lincoln Nebraska to be an actress, and winds up a waitress at the Cheesecake Factory.
So it‰Ûªs based on your life?
No, I‰Ûªm from Omaha.
Well, if that was a movie I would go see it.
I know, right? Okay, let‰Ûªs see, what else? Um, that‰Ûªs about it. That‰Ûªs the story of Penny.
Well it sounds wonderful.
It was. Until I fell in love with a jerk.
What‰Ûªs happening.
I don‰Ûªt know.
Oh God, you know, four years I lived with him, four years, that‰Ûªs like as long as High School.
It took you four years to get through High School?
Don‰Ûªt.
I just, I can‰Ûªt believe I trusted him.
Should I say something? I feel like I should say something.
You? No, you‰Ûªll only make it worse.
You want to know the most pathetic part? Even though I hate his lying, cheating guts, I still love him. Is that crazy?
Yes.

No, it‰Ûªs not crazy it‰Ûªs, uh, uh, it‰Ûªs a paradox. And paradoxes are part of nature, think about light. Now if you look at Huygens, light is a wave, as confirmed by the double slit experiments, but then, along comes Albert Einstein and discovers that light behaves like particles too. Well, I didn‰Ûªt make it worse.
Oh, I‰Ûªm so sorry, I‰Ûªm such a mess, and on top of everything else I‰Ûªm all gross from moving and my stupid shower doesn‰Ûªt even work.
Our shower works.
Really? Would it be totally weird if I used it?
Yes.
No.
No?
No.
No.
It‰Ûªs right down the hall.
Thanks. You guys are really sweet.
Well this is an interesting development.
How so?
It has been some time since we‰Ûªve had a woman take her clothes off in our apartment.
That‰Ûªs not true, remember at Thanksgiving my grandmother with Alzheimer‰Ûªs had that episode.
Point taken. It has been some time since we‰Ûªve had a woman take her clothes off after which we didn‰Ûªt want to rip our eyes out.
The worst part was watching her carve that turkey.
So, what exactly are you trying to accomplish here?
Excuse me?
That woman in there‰Ûªs not going to have sex with you.
Well I‰Ûªm not trying to have sex with her.
Oh, good. Then you won‰Ûªt be disappointed.
What makes you think she wouldn‰Ûªt have sex with me, I‰Ûªm a male and she‰Ûªs a female?
Yes, but not of the same species.
I‰Ûªm not going to engage in hypotheticals here, I‰Ûªm just trying to be a good neighbour.
Oh, of course.
That‰Ûªs not to say that if a carnal relationship were to develop that I wouldn‰Ûªt participate. However briefly.
Do you think this possibility will be helped or hindered when she discovers your Luke Skywalker no-more-tears shampoo?
It‰Ûªs Darth Vader shampoo. (There is a knock on the door.) Luke Skywalker‰Ûªs the conditioner.
Wait till you see this.
It‰Ûªs fantastic. Unbelievable.
See what?
It‰Ûªs a Stephen Hawking lecture from MIT in 1974.
This is not a good time.
That‰Ûªs great, you guys have to go.
Why?
It‰Ûªs just not a good time.
Leonard has a lady over.
Yeah, right, your grandmother back in town?
No. And she‰Ûªs not a lady, she‰Ûªs just a new neighbour.
Hang on, there really is a lady here?
Uh-huh.
And you want us out because you‰Ûªre anticipating coitus?
I‰Ûªm not anticipating coitus.
So she‰Ûªs available for coitus?
Can we please stop saying coitus?
Technically that would be coitus interruptus.
Hey, is there a trick to getting it to switch from tub to shower. Oh. Hi, sorry. Hello!

Enchante Madamoiselle. Howard Wolowitz, Cal-Tech department of Applied Physics. You may be familiar with some of my work, it‰Ûªs currently orbiting Jupiter‰Ûªs largest moon taking high-resolution digital photographs.
Penny. I work at the Cheesecake Factory.
Come on, I‰Ûªll show you the trick with the shower.
Bon douche.
I‰Ûªm sorry?
It‰Ûªs French for good shower. It‰Ûªs a sentiment I can express in six languages.
Save it for your blog, Howard.
See-ka-tong-guay-jow.
In the bathroom.
Uh, there it goes, it sticks, I‰Ûªm sorry.
Okay. Thanks.
You‰Ûªre welcome, oh, you‰Ûªre going to step right, okay, I‰Ûªll‰Û_.
Hey, Leonard?
The hair products are Sheldon‰Ûªs.
Um, okay. Can I ask you a favour.
A favour? Sure, you can ask me a favour, I would do you a favour for you.
It‰Ûªs okay if you say no.
Oh, I‰Ûªll probably say yes.
It‰Ûªs just not the kind of thing you ask a guy you‰Ûªve just met.
Wow.
Leonard and Sheldon, Inside Leonard‰Ûªs car
I really think we should examine the chain of causality here.
Must we?

Event A. A beautiful woman stands naked in our shower. Event B. We drive half way across town to retrieve a television set from the aforementioned woman‰Ûªs ex-boyfriend. Query, on what plane of existence is there even a semi-rational link between these events?
She asked me to do her a favour, Sheldon.
Ah, yes, well that may be the proximal cause of our journey, but we both know it only exists in contradistinction to the higher level distal cause.
Which is?
You think with your penis.
That‰Ûªs a biological impossibility and you didn‰Ûªt have to come.
Oh, right, yes, I could have stayed behind and watched Wolowitz try to hit on Penny in Russian, Arabic and Farsi. Why can‰Ûªt she get her own TV.
Come on, you know how it is with break-ups.
No I don‰Ûªt. And neither do you.
Wuh, I, I broke up with Joyce Kim.
You did not break up with Joyce Kim, she defected to North Korea.

To mend her broken heart. This situation is much less complicated. There‰Ûªs some kind of dispute between Penny and her ex-boyfriend as to who gets custody of the TV. She just wanted to avoid having a scene with him.
So we get to have a scene with him?
No, Sheldon, there‰Ûªs not going to be a scene. There‰Ûªs two of us and one of him.
Leonard, the two of us can‰Ûªt even carry a TV.
Back at the apartment.
So, you guys work with Leonard and Sheldon at the University?
Uh, I‰Ûªm sorry, do you speak English?
Oh, he speaks English, he just can‰Ûªt speak to women.
Really, why?
He‰Ûªs kind of a nerd. Juice box?
Outside Penny‰Ûªs old apartment building.
I‰Ûªll do the talking.
Yeah.
Hi, I‰Ûªm Leonard, this is Sheldon.
Hello.
What did I just‰Û_. Uh, we‰Ûªre here to pick up Penny‰Ûªs TV.
Get lost.
Okay, thanks for your time.
We‰Ûªre not going to give up just like that.
Leonard, the TV is in the building, we‰Ûªve been denied access to the building, ergo we are done.
Excuse me, if I were to give up at the first little hitch I never would have been able to identify the fingerprints of string theory in the aftermath of the big bang.
My apologies. What‰Ûªs your plan.
It‰Ûªs just a privilege to watch your mind at work.
Come on, we have a combined IQ of 360, we should be able to figure out how to get into a stupid building.
What do you think their combined IQ is?
Just grab the door.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs ex-boyfriend‰Ûªs apartment.
This is it. (Knocks.) I‰Ûªll do the talking.
Good thinking, I‰Ûªll just be the muscle.
Yeah?
I‰Ûªm Leonard, this is Sheldon.
From the intercom.
How the hell did you get in the building?
Oh. We‰Ûªre scientists.
Tell him about our IQ.
Outside the apartment building. Leonard and Sheldon exit. They are not wearing trousers.
Leonard.
What?
My mom bought me those pants.
I‰Ûªm sorry.
You‰Ûªre going to have to call her.
On the stairs of Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs building.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm so sorry I dragged you through this.
It‰Ûªs okay. It wasn‰Ûªt my first pantsing, and it won‰Ûªt be my last.
And you were right about my motives, I was hoping to establish a relationship with Penny that might have some day led to sex.
Well you got me out of my pants.
Anyway, I‰Ûªve learned my lesson. She‰Ûªs out of my league, I‰Ûªm done with her, I‰Ûªve got my work, one day I‰Ûªll win the Nobel Prize and then I‰Ûªll die alone.
Don‰Ûªt think like that, you‰Ûªre not going to die alone.
Thank you Sheldon, you‰Ûªre a good friend.
And you‰Ûªre certainly not going to win a Nobel Prize.
Inside Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment.
This is one of my favourite places to kick back after a quest, they have a great house ale.
Wow, cool tiger.
Yeah, I‰Ûªve had him since level ten. His name is Buttons. Anyway, if you had your own game character we could hang out, maybe go on a quest.
Uh, sounds interesting.
So you‰Ûªll think about it?
Oh, I don‰Ûªt think I‰Ûªll be able to stop thinking about it.
Smooth.
We‰Ûªre home.
Oh, my God, what happened?
Well, your ex-boyfriend sends his regards and I think the rest is fairly self-explanatory.
I‰Ûªm so sorry, I really thought if you guys went instead of me he wouldn‰Ûªt be such an ass.
No, it was a valid hypothesis.
That was a valid hypothesis? What is happening to you?
Really, thank you so much for going and trying you‰Ûªre, uh, you‰Ûªre so terrific. Why don‰Ûªt you put some clothes on, I‰Ûªll get my purse and dinner is on me, okay?
Really? Great.
Thank you. You‰Ûªre not done with her, are you?
Our babies will be smart and beautiful.
Not to mention imaginary.
All five in Leonard‰Ûªs car.
Is Thai food okay with you Penny?
Sure.
We can‰Ûªt have Thai food, we had Indian for lunch.
So?
They‰Ûªre both curry based cuisines.
So?
They would be gastronomically redundant. I can see we‰Ûªre going to have to spell out everything for this girl.
Any ideas Raj? (He just looks at her with a worried expression.)
Turn left on Lake Street and head up to Colorado. I know a wonderful little sushi bar that has karaoke.
That sounds like fun.
Baby, baby don‰Ûªt get hooked on me. Uh, baby, baby don‰Ûªt get hooked on me.
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment. Sheldon, Leonard, Howard and Raj are present.
There you go, Pad Thai, no peanuts.
But does it have peanut oil?
Uh, I‰Ûªm not sure, everyone keep an eye on Howard in case he starts to swell up.
Since it‰Ûªs not bee season, you can have my epinephrine.
Are there any chopsticks?
You don‰Ûªt need chopsticks, this is Thai food.
Here we go.

Thailand has had the fork since the latter half of the nineteenth century. Interestingly they don‰Ûªt actually put the fork in their mouth, they use it to put the food on a spoon which then goes into their mouth.
Ask him for a napkin, I dare you. (There is a knock on the door.) I‰Ûªll get it.
Do I look puffy? I feel puffy.
Hey Leonard.
Oh, hi Penny.
Am I interrupting.
No.
You‰Ûªre not swelling, Howard.
No, no, look at my fingers, they‰Ûªre like Vienna sausages.
Sounds like you have company.
They‰Ûªre not going anywhere. (Closes door, staying in hallway.) So, you‰Ûªre coming home from work. That‰Ûªs great. How was work.
Well, you know, it‰Ûªs the Cheesecake Factory. People order cheesecake, and I bring it to them.
So, you sort of act as a carbohydrate delivery system.
Yeah, call it whatever you want, I get minimum wage. Yeah, anyways, I was wondering if you could help me out with something, I was‰Û_.
Yes.
Oh. Okay, great, I‰Ûªm having some furniture delivered tomorrow, and I may not be here, so‰Û_. (apartment door opens, Sheldon, Raj and Howard appear) Oh! Hel‰Û_hello!
(speaks a phrase in Russian).
I‰Ûªm sorry?
Haven‰Ûªt you ever been told how beautiful you are in flawless Russian?
No, I haven‰Ûªt.
Get used to it.
Yeah, I probably won‰Ûªt, but‰Û_ Hey Sheldon.
Hi.
Hey Raj! (Raj looks uncomfortable) Still not talking to me, huh?
Don‰Ûªt take it personally, it‰Ûªs his pathology, he can‰Ûªt talk to women.
He can‰Ûªt talk to attractive women, or in your case a cheesecake‰ÛÒscented Goddess!
So, there‰Ûªs gonna be some furniture delivered?
Yeah, yeah, if it gets here and I‰Ûªm not here tomorrow could you just sign for it and have them put it in my apartment.
Yeah, no problem.
Great, here‰Ûªs my spare key. Thank you.
Penny, wait.
Yeah?
Um, if you don‰Ûªt have any other plans, do you want to join us for Thai food and a Superman movie marathon?
A marathon? Wow, how many Superman movies are there?
You‰Ûªre kidding, right?
Yeah, I do like the one where Lois Lane falls from the helicopter and Superman swooshes down and catches her, which one was that?
One. (Raj raises one finger).
You realise that scene was rife with scientific inaccuracy.
Yes, I know, men can‰Ûªt fly.

Oh no, let‰Ûªs assume that they can. Lois Lane is falling, accelerating at an initial rate of 32 feet per second per second. Superman swoops down to save her by reaching out two arms of steel. Miss Lane, who is now travelling at approximately 120 miles per hour, hits them, and is immediately sliced into three equal pieces.
Unless, Superman matches her speed and decelerates.
In what space, sir, in what space? She‰Ûªs two feet above the ground. Frankly, if he really loved her, he‰Ûªd let her hit the pavement. It would be a more merciful death.
Excuse me, your entire argument is predicated on the assumption that Superman‰Ûªs flight is a feat of strength.

Are you listening to yourself, it is well established that Superman‰Ûªs flight is a feat of strength, it is an extension of his ability to leap tall buildings, an ability he derives from Earth‰Ûªs yellow Sun.
Yeah, and you don‰Ûªt have a problem with that, how does he fly at night.
Uh, a combination of the moon‰Ûªs solar reflection and the energy storage capacity of Kryptonian skin cells.
I‰Ûªm just going to go wash up.
I have 26 hundred comic books in there, I challenge you to find a single reference to Kryptonian skin cells.
Challenge accepted. (Tries door.) We‰Ûªre locked out.
Also, the pretty girl left.
Ground floor hallway of the apartment building. Leonard is signing for the delivery.

Okay, her apartment‰Ûªs on the fourth floor but the elevator‰Ûªs broken so you‰Ûªre going to have to (delivery man leaves) oh, you‰Ûªre just going to be done, okay, cool, thanks. I guess we‰Ûªll just bring it up ourselves.
I hardly think so.
Why not?
Well, we don‰Ûªt have a dolly, or lifting belts, or any measurable upper body strength.

We don‰Ûªt need strength, we‰Ûªre physicists. We are the intellectual descendents of Archimedes. Give me a fulcrum and a lever and I can move the Earth, it‰Ûªs just a matter‰Û_ (starts to move package) I don‰Ûªt have this‰Û_ I don‰Ûªt have this I don‰Ûªt have this.
Archimedes would be so proud.
Do you have any ideas?
Yes, but they all involve a green lantern and a power ring.
Easy, easy (package falls) Okay! Now we‰Ûªve got an inclined plane. The force required to lift is reduced by the sine of the angle of the stairs, call it thirty degrees, so about half.
Exactly half.
Exactly half. Let‰Ûªs push. Okay, see, it‰Ûªs moving, this is easy, all in the math.
What‰Ûªs your formula for the corner.
What? Oh, okay, uh, okay, yeah, no problem, just come up here and help me pull and turn.
Ah, gravity, thou art a heartless bitch.
You do understand that our efforts here will in no way increase the odds of you having sexual congress with this woman?
Men do things for women without expecting sex.
Yeah, those are men who just had sex.
I‰Ûªm doing this to be a good neighbour. In any case, there‰Ûªs no way it could lower the odds.
Almost there, almost there, almost there. (Lets go of package, it starts to slip down)
No we‰Ûªre not, no we‰Ûªre not, no we‰Ûªre not.
Inside Penny‰Ûªs apartment. They are laying the package down on the floor.
Watch your fingers. Watch your fingers. Oh God, my fingers!
You okay?
No, it hurt‰Û_ (looking around) Great Caesar‰Ûªs Ghost, look at this place?
So Penny‰Ûªs a little messy.

A little messy? The Mandelbrot set of complex numbers is a little messy, this is chaos. Excuse me, explain to me an organisational system where a tray of flatware on a couch is valid. I‰Ûªm just inferring that this is a couch, because the evidence suggests the coffee table‰Ûªs having a tiny garage sale.
Did it ever occur to you that not everyone has the compulsive need to sort, organise and label the entire world around them?
No.
Well they don‰Ûªt. Hard as it may be for you to believe, most people don‰Ûªt sort their breakfast cereal numerically by fibre content.
Excuse me, but I think we‰Ûªve both found that helpful at times.
Come on, we should go.
Hang on.
What are you doing?
Straightening up.
Sheldon, this is not your home.
This is not anyone‰Ûªs home, this is a swirling vortex of entropy.
When the transvestite lived here, you didn‰Ûªt care how he kept the place.
Because it was immaculate, I mean, you open that man‰Ûªs closet, it was left to right, evening gowns, cocktail dresses, then his police uniforms.
What were you doing in his closet?
I helped run some cable for a webcam.
Hey guys.
Oh, hey Penny, this just arrived, we just brought this up, just now.
Great. Was it hard getting it up the stairs?
(sucks in breath)
No.
No?
No.
No.
Well, we‰Ûªll get out of your hair.
Oh, great, thank you again (she throws her jacket over the back of the sofa).
Penny, I just want you to know that, you don‰Ûªt have to live like this. I‰Ûªm here for you.
What‰Ûªs he talking about?
It‰Ûªs a joke.
I don‰Ûªt get it.
Yeah, he didn‰Ûªt tell it right.
Sheldon?
The living room. Leonard enters carrying a light sabre.
Sheldon? Hello?
Penny‰Ûªs apartment, penny is sleeping, Sheldon is cleaning. Leonard enters.
Sheldon!
Sssshhhh! Penny‰Ûªs sleeping.
Are you insane, you can‰Ûªt just break into a woman‰Ûªs apartment in the middle of the night and clean.
I had no choice. I couldn‰Ûªt sleep knowing that just outside my bedroom was our living room, and just outside our living room was that hallway, and immediately adjacent to that hallway was‰Û_ this.
Do you realise that if Penny wakes up, there is no reasonable explanation as to why we‰Ûªre here?
I just gave you a reasonable explanation.
No, no. You gave me an explanation, it‰Ûªs reasonableness will be determined by a jury of your peers.
Don‰Ûªt be ridiculous. I have no peers.
Sheldon, we have to get out of here.
You might want to speak in a lower register.
What?
Evolution has made women sensitive to high pitched noises while they sleep, so that they‰Ûªll be roused by a crying baby. If you want to avoid waking her, speak in a lower register.
That‰Ûªs ridiculous. (Penny snores again.)
No, (lowering his voice dramatically,) that‰Ûªs ridiculous.
Fine. I accept your premise, now please let‰Ûªs go.
I am not leaving until I‰Ûªm done.
O-o-o-oh! (Collapses against wall).
If you have time to lean, you have time to clean.
Oh, what the hell.
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs living room, morning. Sheldon enters, singing to himself.
Morning.
Morning.
I have to say, I slept splendidly. Granted, not long, but just deeply and well.
I‰Ûªm not surprised. A well known folk cure for insomnia is to break into your neighbour‰Ûªs apartment and clean.
Sarcasm?
You think?
Granted, my methods may have been somewhat unorthodox, but I think the end result will be a measurable enhancement of Penny‰Ûªs quality of life.
You know what, you‰Ûªve convinced me, maybe tonight we should sneak in and shampoo her carpet.
You don‰Ûªt think that crosses a line?
Yes! For God‰Ûªs sake, Sheldon, do I have to hold up a sarcasm sign every time I open my mouth.
You have a sarcasm sign?
No, I do not have a sarcasm sign.
Do you want some cereal. I‰Ûªm feeling so good today I‰Ûªm going to choose from the low fibre end of the shelf. Hello, Honey Puffs.
Son of a Bitch!
Penny‰Ûªs up.
You sick, geeky bastards!
How did she know it was us?
I may have left a suggested organisational schematic for her bedroom closet.
Leonard!
God, this is going to be bad.
Goodbye, Honey Puffs, hello Big Bran.
You came into my apartment last night when I was sleeping?
Yes, but, only to clean.
Really more to organise, you‰Ûªre not actually dirty, per se.
Give me back my key.
I‰Ûªm very, very sorry.
Do you understand how creepy this is.
Oh, yes, we discussed it at length last night.
In my apartment, while I was sleeping.
And snoring. And that‰Ûªs probably just a sinus infection, but it could be sleep apnoea, you might want to see an otolaryngologist. It‰Ûªs a throat doctor.
And what kind of doctor removes shoes from asses?
Depending on the depth, that‰Ûªs either a proctologist or a general surgeon. (Leonard holds up a sign reading ‰ÛÏSarcasm‰Û) Oh!
God!

Okay, look, no Penny, I think what you‰Ûªre feeling is perfectly valid, and maybe a little bit later today when you‰Ûªre feeling a little bit less, for lack of a better word, violated, maybe we could talk about this some more.
Stay away from me.
Sure, that‰Ûªs another way to go.

Penny, Penny, just to clarify because there will be a discussion when you leave, is your objection solely to our presence in the apartment while you were sleeping, or do you also object to the imposition of a new organisational paradigm. (Penny stares in disbelief, then leaves.) Well that was a little non-responsive.
You are going to march yourself over there right now and apologise. (Sheldon laughs.) What‰Ûªs funny?
That wasn‰Ûªt sarcasm?
No.
Wooh, boy, you are all over the place this morning. (Knocks on Penny‰Ûªs door.) I have a masters and two PhD‰Ûªs, I should not have to do this.
What?

I am truly sorry for what happened last night, I take full responsibility. And I hope that it won‰Ûªt colour your opinion of Leonard, who is not only a wonderful guy, but also, I hear, a gentle and thorough lover. (Penny closes door in his face.) I did what I could.
The stairwell. Raj is coming up the stairs, he meets Penny who is going down.

Hey Raj. (Raj stands looking uncomfortable.) Hey, listen, I don‰Ûªt know if you heard about what happened last night with Leonard and Sheldon, but I‰Ûªm really upset about it, I mean they just, they let themselves into my place, and then they cleaned it, I mean can you even believe that? How weird is that?

character: Raj (internally, while Penny continues to talk)
line: Ooh, she‰Ûªs standing very close to me. Oh my, she does smell good. What is that, vanilla?

You know, where I come from, someone comes into your house at night, you shoot, okay? And you don‰Ûªt shoot to wound. I mean, alright, my sister shot her husband, but it was an accident, they were drunk. What was I saying?

She‰Ûªs so chatty. Maybe my parents are right. Maybe I‰Ûªd be better off with an Indian girl. We‰Ûªd have the same cultural background, and my wife would sing to my children the same lullabies my mother sang to me.
It‰Ûªs obvious that they meant well, but I‰Ûªm just, I‰Ûªm having a really rough time, like I said, I broke up with my boyfriend, and it‰Ûªs just freaking me out.
I mean, just because most of the men I‰Ûªve known in my life happen to be jerks, doesn‰Ûªt mean I should just assume Leonard and Sheldon are. Right?
She asked me a question. I should probably nod. (Does.)
That‰Ûªs exactly what I thought. Thank you for listening. You‰Ûªre a doll. (She hugs him.)
Oh-oh. Turn your pelvis. (Does.)
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs living room. Howard is there, playing on a dance video game.
Grab a napkin, homie. You just got served.
It‰Ûªs fine. You win.
What‰Ûªs his problem?
His imaginary girlfriend broke up with him.
Been there.
Hello. Sorry I‰Ûªm late. But I was in the hallway, chatting up Penny.
Really? You? Rajesh Koothrapali, spoke to Penny?
Actually, I was less the chatter than the chattee.
What did she say? Is she still mad at me?
Well, she was upset at first, but, probably because her sister shot somebody. Then there was something about you and‰Û_ then she hugged me.
She hugged you? How did she hug you? (Raj hugs Howard.) Is that her perfume I smell?
intoxicating, isn‰Ûªt it?
The hallway, Leonard puts a note under Penny‰Ûªs door. It opens.
Hi.
Oh.
What‰Ûªs going on?

Um, here‰Ûªs the thing. (Reads from note.) Penny. Just as Oppenheimer came to regret his contributions to the first atomic bomb, so too I regret my participation in what was, at the very least, an error in judgement. The hallmark of the great human experiment is the willingness to recognise one‰Ûªs mistakes. Some mistakes, such as Madame Curie‰Ûªs discovery of Radium turned out to have great scientific potential even though she would later die a slow, painful death from radiation poisoning. Another example, from the field of ebola research‰Û_.
Leonard.
Yeah.
We‰Ûªre okay. (Kisses him on cheek. Closes door. Leonard looks happy, walks back across hallway and straight into the apartment door.)
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. Sheldon and Leonard are trying to construct furniture.
Six two inch dowels.
Check.
One package, Phillips head screws.
Check.
Guys, seriously, I grew up on a farm, okay, I rebuilt a tractor engine when I was like twelve, I think I can put together a cheap Swedish media centre.
No, please, we insist, it‰Ûªs the least we can do considering.
Considering what? How great this place looks?
Oh boy, I was afraid of this.
What?
These instructions are a pictographic representation of the least imaginative way to assemble these components. This right here is why Sweden has no space program.
Well, uh, it looked pretty good in the store.
It is an inefficient design, for example Penny has a flat screen TV, which means all the space behind it is wasted.
We could put her stereo back there.
And control it how?
Run an infra-red repeater, photocell here, emitter here, easy peasy.

character: Howard (after Raj whispers in his ear)
line: Good point, how you gonna cool it?
Hey guys, I got this.
Hang on Penny. How about fans, here and here?
Also inefficient, and might be loud.
How about liquid coolant? Maybe a little aquarium pump here, run some quarter inch PVC‰Û_
Guys, this is actually really simple.
Hold on, honey, men at work. The PVC comes down here, maybe a little corrugated sheet metal as a radiator here.
Oh, really, show me where we put a drip tray, a sluice and an overflow reservoir?
And if water is involved we‰Ûªre going to have to ground the crap out of the thing.
Guys, it‰Ûªs hot in here, I think I‰Ûªll just take off all my clothes.
Oh, I‰Ûªve got it. How about if we replace panels A, B and F and crossbar H with aircraft grade aluminium.
Right, then the entire thing‰Ûªs one big heat sink.
Perfect, Leonard, why don‰Ûªt you and Sheldon go down to the junk yard and pick up about six square metres of scrap aluminium, Raj and I will run down to my lab and get the oxy-acetaline torch.
Meet back here in an hour?
Done.
Got it. (They all leave).
Okay, this place does look pretty good.
Robert Cohen & Dave Goetsch
Chuck Lorre & Bill Prady
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment. Sheldon, Leonard, Howard and Raj are using laptops. All are wearing microphone headsets.
Alright, just a few more feet, and‰Û_. here we are gentlemen, the Gates of Elzebub.
Good lord!
Oooh.
Don‰Ûªt panic, this is what the last 97 hours have been about.
Stay frosty, there‰Ûªs a horde of armed goblins on the other side of that gate guarding the Sword of Azeroth.
Warriors, unsheathe your weapons, magic wielders raise your wands.
Lock and load.
Raj, blow up the gates.
Blowing the gates. Control, shift, B! Oh, my God, so many goblins!
Don‰Ûªt just stand there, slash and move, slash and move.
Stay in formation.
Leonard, you‰Ûªve got one on your tail.
That‰Ûªs alright, my tail‰Ûªs prehensile, I‰Ûªll swat him off.
I‰Ûªve got him Leonard. Tonight I spice my meat with goblin blood!
Raj, no, it‰Ûªs a trap, they‰Ûªre flanking us!
Oooh, he‰Ûªs got me.
Sheldon, he‰Ûªs got Raj, use your sleath spell. Sheldon! Sheldon!
I‰Ûªve got the Sword of Azeroth!
Forget the sword, Sheldon, help Raj.
There is no more Sheldon, I am the Swordmaster!
Leonard look out!
Dammit man, we‰Ûªre dying here.
Goodbye, peasants.
The bastard teleported.
He‰Ûªs selling the Sword of Azeroth on ebay.
You betrayed us for money, who are you?
I‰Ûªm a rogue knight elf, don‰Ûªt you people read character descriptions? Wait, wait, wait, somebody just clicked ‰ÛÏbuy it now.‰Û
I am the Swordmaster!
The same.
Wooh, I‰Ûªm all sweaty, anybody want to log on to second life and go swimming, I just built a virtual pool.
No, I can‰Ûªt look at you or your avatar right now.
Sounds like your neighbour‰Ûªs home.
Excuse me.
Don‰Ûªt forget the mail you took accidentally on purpose so you‰Ûªd have an excuse to talk to her.
Oh, right, right right right right.
Stealing snail mail, very old school, I like it.
Penny, the mailman did it again, he‰Û_ (looks up to see Penny kissing a hunky man) Oh! Sorry.
Um, no, hi Leonard, this is Doug, Doug, this is my neighbour Leonard.
What‰Ûªs up bro.
Not much. Bro.
Is, is everything okay.
Uh, yeah, uh, I just, I got your mail again, here.
Thank you, I‰Ûªve got to talk to that mailman.
Oh no, that‰Ûªs probably not such a good idea. Civil servants have a documented propensity to, you know, snap.
Okay, well, thank you, again.
No problem. Bye. Oh, and, bye, bro! (Returns to apartment).
Penny for your thoughts.
What‰Ûªs the matter.
No, I‰Ûªm fine. Penny‰Ûªs fine, the guy she‰Ûªs kissing is really fine and‰Û_
Kissing, what kind of kissing? Cheeks? Lips? Chaste? French?
What is wrong with you?
I‰Ûªm a romantic.
Please don‰Ûªt tell me that your hopeless infatuation is devolving into pointless jealousy.
No, I‰Ûªm not jealous, I‰Ûªm just a little concerned for her. I didn‰Ûªt like the look of the guy that she was with.
Because he looked better than you?
Yeah. He was kinda dreamy.

Well, at least now you can retrieve the black box from the twisted smouldering wreckage that was once your fantasy of dating her, and analyse the data so that you don‰Ûªt crash into geek mountain again.
I disagree, love is not a sprint, it‰Ûªs a marathon. A relentless pursuit that only ends when she falls into your arms. Or hits you with the pepper spray.
Well, I‰Ûªm done with Penny. I‰Ûªm going to be more realistic and go after someone my own speed.
Like who?
I don‰Ûªt know. Olivia Geiger?
The dietician at the cafeteria with the limp and the lazy eye?
Yeah.

Well, I don‰Ûªt think you have a shot there. I have noticed that Lesley Winkle recently started shaving her legs. Now, given that winter is coming one can only assume that she is signalling sexual availability.
I don‰Ûªt know, you guys work in the same lab.
So?
There are pitfalls, trust me, I know. When it comes to sexual harassment law I‰Ûªm‰Û_ a bit of a self-taught expert.
Look, Howard, if I were to ask Lesley Winkle out it would just be for dinner, I‰Ûªm not going to walk into the lab, ask her to strip naked and dance for me.
Oh, then you‰Ûªre probably okay.
Howard and Lesley‰Ûªs lab.
Hello Lesley.
Hi Leonard.
Lesley I would like to propose an experiment.
Goggles, Leonard.
Right. Lesley, I would like to propose an experiment.
Hang on. I‰Ûªm trying to see how long it takes a five hundred kilowatt oxygen iodine laser to heat up my cup o‰Ûª noodles.
Pfff, I‰Ûªve done it, about two seconds, 2.6 for minestrone. Anyway, I was thinking more of a bio-social exploration with a neuro-chemical overlay.
Wait, are you asking me out?
I was going to characterise it as the modification of our colleague/friendship paradigm, with the addition of a date-like component. But we don‰Ûªt need to quibble over terminology.
What sort of experiment would you propose?

There is a generally accepted pattern in this area, I would pick you up, take you to a restaurant, then we would see a movie, probably a romantic comedy featuring the talents of Hugh Grant or Sandra Bullock.
Interesting. And would you agree that the primary way we would evaluate either the success or failure of the date would be based on the bio-chemical reaction during the goodnight kiss.
Heartrate, pheromones, etc, yes.
Well, why don‰Ûªt we just stipulate that the date goes well and move to the key variable.
You mean, kiss you now?
Yes.
Can you define the parameters of the kiss?
Closed mouth but romantic. Mint?
Thank you. (Takes mint). Shall I count down from three?
No, I think it needs to be spontaneous.
What do you think.
You proposed the experiment, I think you should present your findings first.
Fair enough. On the plus side, it was a good kiss, reasonable technique, no extraneous spittle. On the other hand, no arousal.
None?
None.
Ah. Well, thank you for your time.
Thank you.
None at all?
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs flat. Sheldon, Raj and Howard are playing Jenga.
Sheldon, if you were a robot, and I knew and you didn‰Ûªt, would you want me to tell you?
That depends. When I learn that I‰Ûªm a robot, will I be able to handle it?
Maybe, although the history of science-fiction is not on your side.
Uh, let me ask you this. When I learn that I‰Ûªm a robot, would I be bound by Asimov‰Ûªs three laws of robotics?
You might be bound by them right now.
That‰Ûªs true. Have you ever harmed a human being, or through inaction allowed a human being to come to harm?
Of course not.
Have you ever harmed yourself, or allowed yourself to be harmed except in cases where a human being would have been endangered?
Well, no.
I smell robot.
Hey, what‰Ûªs going on.
The internet‰Ûªs been down for half an hour.
Also, Sheldon may be a robot.
So, how did it go with Lesley?
Oh, we tried kissing, but the earth didn‰Ûªt move. I mean any more than the 383 miles that it was going to move anyway.
Oh, I‰Ûªve seen that look before. This is just going to be two weeks of moping and tedious emo songs, and calling me to come down to pet stores to look at cats. I don‰Ûªt know if I can take it.
You could power down.
Well, as usual, Wolowitz has the solution. I happen to know a place where there are plenty of eligible women, and Leonard could have his pick.
A salsa class. The four guys and a random fat bloke salsa opposite five middle-aged women.
Remember the Latin hips. Shoulders stay still, and we sway. One two three. Five six seven.
I think Mrs Tishman‰Ûªs got her eye on you. I‰Ûªve been there, you‰Ûªre in for a treat.
The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Oh, good lord.
You don‰Ûªt know me, you don‰Ûªt wear my chains‰Û_ God, that‰Ûªs a good song.
If you‰Ûªre compiling a mix CD for a double suicide. (Leonard is taking supplies out of a bag) Oh, I hope that scratching post is for you.
I know what you‰Ûªre thinking, I‰Ûªve taken your asthma into account. There‰Ûªs a feline geneticist in San Diego who has developed the cutest little hypo-allergenic calicos.
Leonard, listen to me‰Û_
I‰Ûªve been thinking about names, I‰Ûªm kind of torn between Einstein, Newton and Sergeant Fuzzyboots.
Leonard, do you really think you can satisfy your need for a relationship with a genetically altered cat?
Maybe, if it‰Ûªs a cute little cuddly cat.
Oh, come on, Leonard! This is obviously about Penny.
It doesn‰Ûªt matter. The woman‰Ûªs not interested in me, the woman rejected me.

Okay, look, I think that you have as much of a chance of having a sexual relationship with Penny as the Hubble Telescope does of discovering at the centre of every black hole is a little man with a flashlight searching for a circuit breaker. Nevertheless, I do feel obligated to point out to you that she did no reject you. You did not ask her out.
You‰Ûªre right. I didn‰Ûªt ask her out, I should ask her out.
No. No, now that was not my point. My point was, don‰Ûªt buy a cat.
No, but you‰Ûªre right. I should march over there and ask her out.
Oh, goody, we‰Ûªre getting a cat.
The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny‰Ûªs door.
Ah, hey Leonard.
Good afternoon Penny, so hi, hey. Uh‰Û_ I was wondering if you had plans for dinner.
Uh, do you mean dinner tonight?
There is an inherent ambiguity in the word dinner. Technically it refers to the largest meal of the day whenever it is consumed, so, to clarify here, by dinner I mean supper.
Supper?
Or dinner. I was thinking six thirty, if you can go, or a different time.
Uh, six thirty‰Ûªs great.
Really? Great!
Yeah, I like hanging out with you guys.
Us guys?
You know, Sheldon, Howard, Raj, who all‰Ûªs coming?

They‰Û_. might all be there. Or a subset of them might be there, uh, algebraically speaking there are too many unknowns, for example Sheldon had Quizznos for lunch, sometimes he finds that filling, other times he doesn‰Ûªt, it‰Ûªs no fault of Quizznos, they have a varied menu.
Okay, whatever, it sounds like fun.
Great. Did we say a time?
Six thirty.
And that‰Ûªs still good for you.
It‰Ûªs fine.
Cos it‰Ûªs not carved in stone.
No, six thirty‰Ûªs great.
I‰Ûªll get my chisel.
Why?
To‰Û_ carve the‰Û_ okay, I‰Ûªll see you six thirty.
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
How do I look?
Could you be more specific?
Can you tell I‰Ûªm perspiring a little?
No. The dark crescent-shaped patterns under your arms conceal it nicely. What time is your date?
Six thirty.
Perfect, that gives you two hours and fifteen minutes for that dense molecular cloud of Aramis to dissipate.
Is it too much?
Not if you‰Ûªre a rugby team.
By the way, if it should ever come up, you didn‰Ûªt join us because you stuffed yourself with a chicken carbonara sub at Quizznos.
Why would I join you?
No reason. Oh, you know what, maybe this isn‰Ûªt such a good idea.
Oh, no, no, no, well now, there‰Ûªs always the possibility that alcohol and poor judgement on her part might lead to a nice romantic evening.
You‰Ûªre right, alcohol, poor judgement, it could go well.

Of course, there‰Ûªs the other possibility that this date kicks off a rather unpleasant six months of the two of you passing awkwardly in the hall until one of you breaks down and moves to another zip code.
You could have stopped at ‰ÛÏit could go well.‰Û
If I could of, I would of.

I mean, I‰Ûªm a perfectly nice guy. There‰Ûªs no reason we couldn‰Ûªt go to the restaurant and have a lovely dinner. Maybe take a walk afterwards, talk about things we have in common, ‰ÛÏyou love pottery? I love pottery!‰Û You know, there‰Ûªs a pause, we both know what‰Ûªs happening, I lean in, we kiss, it‰Ûªs a little tentative at first but then I realise, she‰Ûªs kissing me back, and she‰Ûªs biting my lower lip, you know, she wants me, this thing is going the distance, we‰Ûªre going to have sex! Oh God! Oh, my God!
Is the sex starting now?
I‰Ûªm having a panic attack.
Oh, okay, well then, calm down.
If I could calm down I wouldn‰Ûªt be having a panic attack, that‰Ûªs why they call it a panic attack.
Alright, alright, well, just, sit down, yes, sit down, now close your eyes.
Why?
Just do it.
Okay.
Now try to increase your alpha-wave activity.
What?

It‰Ûªs a bio-feedback technique, it‰Ûªs relaxation through brain-wave manipulation, I read a paper about it in the Journal of American Neuroscience, it was a little sparsely sourced but I think the basic science is valid, I probably have it here somewhere.
Oh, who am I kidding, I can‰Ûªt go through with this, you need to call her and cancel.
Me?
Yes.
What should I tell her.
I don‰Ûªt know. Tell her I‰Ûªm sick.
Okay.
Not the kind of illness that will make her want to come over and take care of me, but nothing so critical that she‰Ûªll feel uncomfortable going out with me in the future if I want to try this again.
Got it. So I‰Ûªm assuming nothing venereal. I‰Ûªll just tell her that you had a routine colonoscopy and haven‰Ûªt quite bounced back.
Give me the phone.
But I thought you wanted to cancel?
I can‰Ûªt because if I don‰Ûªt show up she‰Ûªll still be expecting you.
Why would she be expecting me?
Stop asking me all these questions, I need to take another shower.
A restaurant.
So are the rest of the guys meeting us here?
Oh, yeah, no. Turns out that Raj and Howard had to work, and Sheldon had a colonoscopy and he hasn‰Ûªt quite bounced back yet.
Ooh, my uncle just had a colonoscopy.
You‰Ûªre kidding, well, then, that‰Ûªs something we have in common.
How?
We both have people in our lives who‰Û_ want to nip intestinal polyps in the bud.
So, what‰Ûªs new in the world of physics?
Nothing.
Really, nothing?

Well, with the exception of string theory, not much has happened since the 1930‰Ûªs, and you can‰Ûªt prove string theory, at best you can say ‰ÛÏhey, look, my idea has an internal logical consistency.‰Û
Ah. Well I‰Ûªm sure things will pick up.
What‰Ûªs new at the Cheesecake Factory?
Oh, uh, not much. We do have a chocolate key lime that‰Ûªs moving pretty well.
Good. Good. And what about your, uh, hallway friend.
Doug? Oh, yeah, I dunno, I mean, he‰Ûªs nice and funny, but‰Û_
Can I get you started with some drinks?
No, (waves her away) You were saying, but‰Û_
I‰Ûªd like a drink.
Just say the but thing about Doug and then I‰Ûªll get her back.
Okay, well, you know, it‰Ûªs just me. I‰Ûªm still getting over this break-up with Kurt, and this thing with Doug would be just rebound sex.
Ugh, don‰Ûªt get me started on rebound sex.
It‰Ûªs just, it‰Ûªs my pattern. I break up, then I find some cute guy, and then it‰Ûªs just thirty six meaningless of‰Û_ well, you know.
I‰Ûªm not sure that I do. Um, is that one thirty-six hour experience, or is it thirty six hours spread out over say, one‰Û_ glorious summer.
No, it‰Ûªs usually over a weekend, and trust me, you do not feel good after it.
Well, chafing, right?
Emotionally.
Of course, yeah, emotional chafing. Hey, do you want to see something cool? (Penny nods.) I can make this olive go into this glass without touching it.
How?
Physics. (He places the glass over the olive and spins it until the olive gets caught up on the side).
Wow, centrifugal force!

Actually, it‰Ûªs centripetal force, which is an inward force generated by the glass acting on the olive. (The olive drops.) Excuse me. (Leonard disappears under table.)Now, if you were riding on the olive, you‰Ûªd be in a non-inertial reference frame, and would (he bangs his head on the underside of the table.)
Are you okay?
Yeah, I‰Ûªm okay. Did you spill ketchup?
No.
I‰Ûªm not okay.
The stairwell of the apartment building.
Are you sure you don‰Ûªt want to go to the emergency room?
No, no, I‰Ûªm okay, it‰Ûªs stopped bleeding.
I know, but you did throw up. Isn‰Ûªt that a sign of a concussion?
Yes, but I get car sick too, so‰Û_
Okay.
Sorry about your car, by the way.
Oh, no, it‰Ûªs fine, you got most of it out the window.
The poor guy on the bike. I had a nice time.
Yeah, me too. Um, good night. (Leonard turns across hallway.) Leonard?
Yeah.
Was this supposed to be a date?
This? No. No, of course not, this was just you and me hanging out with a bunch of guys who didn‰Ûªt show up, because of work and a colonoscopy.
Okay, I was just checking.

When I take a girl out on a date, and I do, she knows she‰Ûªs been dated. Capital D. Bold face, underline, like Day-ted. I think I might have a little concussion, I‰Ûªm going to go lay down for a while, good night.
The apartment, Leonard enters.
So, how was your date?
Awesome!
Score one for liquor and poor judgement.
Bill Prady & Steven Molaro
Chuck Lorre
Sheldon and Leonard‰Ûªs apartment.
I‰Ûªve been thinking about time travel again.
Why, did you hit a roadblock with invisibility?

Put it on the back burner. Anyway, it occurs to me, if I ever did perfect a time machine, I‰Ûªd just go into the past and give it to myself, thus eliminating the need for me to invent it in the first place.

Why would I see her again? I already have a dentist. (Exits)
I wonder who‰Ûªs going to tell his parents they‰Ûªre not having grandchildren.
Penny‰Ûªs restaurant. Sheldon is on the piano, singing ‰ÛÏTo Life‰Û from Fiddler on the Roof enthusiastically.
I don‰Ûªt believe it, what‰Ûªs gotten into him?
Oh, maybe a couple of virgin cuba libres that turned out to be kind of slutty.
You didn‰Ûªt?
Hey, you do your experiments, I do mine.
The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Okay, the X10s are online.

Gentlemen, I am now about to send a signal from this laptop through our local ISP, racing down fibre-optic cable at the speed of light to San Francisco, bouncing off a satellite in geosynchronous orbit to Lisbon, Portugal, where the data packets will be handed off to submerged transatlantic cables terminating in Halifax, Nova-Scotia, and transferred across the continent via microwave relays back to our ISP and the X10 receiver attached to this (clicks mouse, lamp switches on) lamp. (The others cheer and clap).
Look at me, look at me, I‰Ûªve got goosebumps.
Are we ready on the stereo?
Go for stereo.
Hey guys.
Hello.
It‰Ûªs a little loud.
No problem, turning it down. (Using mouse again) San Francisco, Lisbon, Halifax (the music gets quieter) et voila.
Okay, thanks.
Hang on, hang on, do you not realise what we just did.
Yeah, you turned your stereo down with your laptop.
No, we turned our stereo down by sending a signal around the world via the internet.
Oh. You know you can just get one of those universal remotes at Radio Shack, they‰Ûªre really cheap.
No, no, no, you don‰Ûªt get it, um, Howard, enable public access.
Public access enabled. (They all stare around for a moment in silence.)
Boy, that‰Ûªs brilliant, but I‰Ûªll see you.
No, hang on, hang on. (The lamp goes off and on again.) See!
No.
Someone in Sezchuan province, China is using his computer to turn our lights on and off.
Huh, well that‰Ûªs handy. Um, here‰Ûªs a question, why?
Because we can. (There is a loud noise)
They found the remote controlled cars.
Well, wait, wait, what‰Ûªs on top of them.
Wireless webcams, wave hello.
The monster truck is out of Austin, Texas, and the blue Viper is being operated from suburban Tel Aviv.
You may want to put on slacks.
What? (Seeing red car is trying to get between her legs) Ew, stop it, no, leave me alone.
Who‰Ûªs running the red Corvette?
That would be me.
The same, clearing up.
You know, in the future, when we‰Ûªre disembodied brains in jars, we‰Ûªre going to look back on this as eight hours well wasted.
I don‰Ûªt want to be in a jar. I want my brain in an android body. Eight feet tall and ripped.
I‰Ûªm with you. I just have to make sure if I‰Ûªm a synthetic human I‰Ûªd still be Jewish. I promised my mother.
I suppose you could have your android penis circumcised. But that‰Ûªs something your Rabbi would have to discuss with the manufacturers.
Not to mention you‰Ûªd have to power down on Saturdays.
Sheldon, why is this letter in the trash?
Well, there‰Ûªs always the possibility that a trash can spontaneously formed around the letter, but Occam‰Ûªs Razor would suggest that someone threw it out.
It‰Ûªs from the Institute for Experimental Physics. They want us to present our paper on the properties of super solids at the topical conference on Bowes-Einstein condensates.
I know. I read it before I threw it out.
Okay‰Û_ if I may drill down to the bedrock of my question, why did you throw it out.

Because I have no interest in standing in the Rose Room of the Pasadena Marriott in front of a group of judgemental strangers, who wouldn‰Ûªt recognise true genius if it were standing in front of them giving a speech. Which, if I were there, it would be.
I don‰Ûªt know, Sheldon, those topical conferences on Bowes-Einstein condensates parties are legendary.
Forget the parties.
Forget the parties? What a nerd.
Are there any other honours I‰Ûªve gotten that I don‰Ûªt know about? Did UPS drop off a Nobel Prize with my name on it?
Leonard, please don‰Ûªt take this the wrong way, but the day you win a Nobel Prize, is the day I begin my research on the drag co-efficient of tassles on flying carpets.
Hoo-hoo-hoo. The only thing missing from that insult was ‰ÛÏyo mamma.‰Û
I‰Ûªve got one, hey Leonard, your mamma‰Ûªs research methodology is so flawed‰Û_.
Shut up, Howard. Sheldon, we have to do this.
No we don‰Ûªt. We have to take in nourishment, expel waste, and inhale enough oxygen to keep ourselves from dying, everything else is optional.
Okay, let me put it this way, I‰Ûªm doing it.
You can‰Ûªt. I‰Ûªm the lead author.
Oh, come on. The only reason you‰Ûªre the lead author is because we went alphabetically.
I let you think we went alphabetically to spare you the humiliation of dealing with the fact that it was my idea. Not to put too fine a point on it, but I was throwing you a bone. You‰Ûªre welcome.
Excuse me, I designed the experiment that proved the hypothesis.
It doesn‰Ûªt need proving.
So the entire scientific community is just supposed to take your word?
They‰Ûªre not supposed to, but they should.
Alright, I don‰Ûªt care what you say, I‰Ûªm going to the conference and I‰Ûªm presenting our findings.
And I forbid it.
You forbid it?
If I‰Ûªm not taking credit for our work then nobody is.
Oh, you admit that it‰Ûªs our work.
No, once again, I‰Ûªm throwing you a bone. And once again, you are welcome.
Ah!
Oh no he dit‰Ûªnt!
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
So, how‰Ûªs it going with Sheldon, are you guys still not talking to each other?

Not only is he still not talking to me, but there‰Ûªs this thing he does where he stares at you and tries to get your brain to explode. You know, like in the classic sci-fi movie Scanners? (Put‰Ûªs fingers to head) You know, bzzz-pchew! Never mind. How about this one. It says, ‰ÛÏI know my physics, but I‰Ûªm still a fun guy!‰Û
Oh, hey, I didn‰Ûªt know they still made corduroy suits!
They don‰Ûªt, that‰Ûªs why I saved this one.
Okay, well, let‰Ûªs just see what else you have. Okay, here, take this, and this, and this, and these.
Is this all stuff you want me to try on?
No, this is stuff I want you to throw out.
Oh.
Seriously, don‰Ûªt even give it to charity, you won‰Ûªt be helping anyone. What‰Ûªs this.
Oh, that‰Ûªs the bottled city of Kandor.
Uh-huh.
You see, Kandor was the capital city of the planet Krypton, it was miniaturised by Brainiac before Krypton exploded and then rescued by Superman.
Oh, nice.
It‰Ûªs a lot cooler when girls aren‰Ûªt looking at it.
Here, why don‰Ûªt you put these on while I find a shirt and sport-coat to match.
Great, be right back.
Well, where you going, just put them on.
Here?
Oh, are you shy?
No, I‰Ûªm not shy.
Don‰Ûªt worry, I won‰Ûªt look.
I know you won‰Ûªt look, why would you look, there‰Ûªs nothing to see, well, not nothing‰Û_.
Sweetie, put the pants on.
Putting them on.
So, you know, isn‰Ûªt there maybe some way you and Sheldon could compromise on this whole presentation thing.
No. No. Scientists do not compromise. Our minds are trained to synthesise facts and come to inarguable conclusions. Not to mention, Sheldon is batcrap crazy.
What is this?
Oh, careful. That‰Ûªs my original series Battlestar Galactica flight suit.
Oh, why didn‰Ûªt you wear it at Halloween?
Because it‰Ûªs not a costume, it‰Ûªs a flight suit.
Okay, alright, moving on, oh, wow, a paisley shirt.
Uh-huh, it goes with my corduroy suit.
If you mean it should end up in the same place then, I agree. Is this your‰Û_ your only tie?
Ah. Technically yes, but, if you‰Ûªll notice, it‰Ûªs reversible. So it works as two.
Oh, sweetie, I don‰Ûªt think it even works as one. Is this all your clothes?
Yeah. Everything since the eighth grade.
The‰Û_ the eighth grade?
My last growth spurt.
Okay, well, I guess we‰Ûªre back to the corduroy suit.
Great.
Yup. (Leonard picks up paisley shirt) I said no, put it down.
The ground floor hallway.
Hey Sheldon!
Hello Penny. åÊ
Get anything good?
Uh, just the latest copy of Applied Particle Physics Quarterly.
Oh, you know, that is so weird that yours came and mine didn‰Ûªt. (Sheldon looks confused). It was a joke. (Sheldon gives a fake laugh.) Yup, tip your waitresses, I‰Ûªm here all week.
Penny, just to save you from further awkwardness know that I‰Ûªm perfectly comfortable with the two of us climbing the stairs in silence.
Oh yeah, me too. Zip it, lock it. (The begin to climb) Put it in your pocket. So you and Leonard‰Û_
Oh dear God!
Little misunderstanding, huh.
A little misunder‰Û_. Galileo and the Pope had a little misunderstanding.
Anyway, I was talking to Leonard this morning and I think he feels really bad about it.
Huh.
Well how do you feel?
I don‰Ûªt understand the question.
Well I‰Ûªm just asking if it‰Ûªs difficult to be fighting with your best friend.
Oh. I hadn‰Ûªt thought about it like that. I wonder if I‰Ûªve been experiencing physiological manifestations of some sort of unconscious emotional turmoil.
Wait‰Û_ what?
I couldn‰Ûªt poop this morning.
You should just talk to him, I‰Ûªm sure you guys can work this out.
It‰Ûªs certainly preferable to my plan.
Which was?
A powerful laxative.

Okay, so you absolutely should talk to him, look, I know Leonard values you as a friend, and he told me himself that without your little idea there‰Ûªs no way he could have come up with this whole experiment thing.
Excuse me, little idea?
Yeah, I mean he tried to explain it to me, I didn‰Ûªt really understand it but‰Û_
Of course you didn‰Ûªt, he said little idea?
Uh, well no, no, not in‰Û_ not in those words.
In what words then, exactly
Um, gee, the exact words aren‰Ûªt written‰Û_ it‰Ûªs more the spirit in which it‰Ûªs
What did he say?
You had a lucky hunch.
Hey, Sheldon, I‰Ûªve been thinking, instead of arguing about this why don‰Ûªt‰Û_.
Don‰Ûªt you ever speak to me again.
What‰Û_ (Sheldon goes into apartment and slams the door).
Uh, he‰Û_ (makes ‰ÛÏhe‰Ûªs screwy‰Û hand movements, turns to go).
The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Okay, I‰Ûªm leaving for the conference.
Have fun presenting my lucky hunch.
Sheldon I didn‰Ûªt mean it like that.
Then why did you say it.
I don‰Ûªt know, I wasn‰Ûªt choosing my‰Û_
Were you trying to impress Penny?
No, no not at all. A little bit.
How‰Ûªd that work out for you?
Leonard, ready to go?
Libido 1, truth zero.
Okay, I‰Ûªm going to ask you one more time, we did the work together, lets present the paper together.
And I‰Ûªm telling you for the last time it‰Ûªs pandering, it‰Ûªs undignified and bite me.
Let‰Ûªs go.
Bye Sheldon.
Goodbye Penny. (Places fingers to head to try to make Leonard‰Ûªs brain explode. Leonard leaves.) Oooh, one of these days, Pkshhhh!
A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard‰Ûªs name tag.
There you go.
You‰Ûªre right, this side does look better.
No, no, I didn‰Ûªt say better, I said less stained.
I just checked the house, there‰Ûªs probably twenty, twenty-five people in there.
You‰Ûªre kidding.
Is that all?
All? In particle physics, twenty five is Woodstock.
Oh, well, then good!
I wasn‰Ûªt expecting such a crowd, I‰Ûªm a little nervous.
It‰Ûªs okay, just open with a joke, you‰Ûªll be fine.

A joke. Okay. How about this, um, okay, uh there‰Ûªs this farmer, and he has these chickens, but they won‰Ûªt lay any eggs. So, he calls a physicist to help. The physicist then does some calculations, and he says, um, I have a solution, but it only works with spherical chickens in a vacuum. (Raj and Howard laugh.) Right?
Oh, sorry, I‰Ûªve just, I‰Ûªve heard it before.
Let‰Ûªs roll. Hey, nice suit.
It‰Ûªs a classic, right?
I really should have brought my own car.
Leonard is presenting.

So, in conclusion, the data show that at temperatures approaching absolute zero, the moment of inertia changes, and the solid becomes a super-solid, which clearly appears to be a previously unknown state of matter. (Applause) Thank you. (Penny is asleep on Howard‰Ûªs shoulder. Howard is taking a photograph with his camera phone.) Are there any questions?
Yeah. What the hell was that?
Any other questions?

character: Sheldon (who previously spoke, now removing his hood and dark glasses)
line: Doctor Sheldon Cooper here, I am the lead author of this particular paper. (No reaction.) Thank you. And you, sir, you have completely skipped over the part where I was walking through the park, and I saw these children on a merry-go-round, which started me thinking about the moment of inertia in gasses like helium at temperatures approaching absolute zero.
I didn‰Ûªt skip it, it‰Ûªs just an anecdote. It‰Ûªs not science.
Oh, I see, was the apple falling on Newton‰Ûªs head, was that just an anecdote?
You are not Isaac Newton.
No, no that‰Ûªs true, gravity would have been apparent to me without the apple.
You cannot possibly be that arrogant.
You continue to underestimate me, my good man.
Look, if you weren‰Ûªt happy with my presentation then maybe you should have given it with me.
As I have explained repeatedly, unlike you, I don‰Ûªt need validation from lesser minds. No offence.
Really, so why did you come?
Because I knew you‰Ûªd screw this up.
I didn‰Ûªt screw it up.
Oh, please. I admit, that spherical chicken joke, that was hilarious. But it was straight downhill from there.

I‰Ûªve had enough of your condescension. Maybe I didn‰Ûªt go to college when I was eleven like you, maybe I got my doctorate at 24 instead of 16, but you are not the only person who is smarter than everyone else in this room. No offense. And I am clearly not the only person who is tormented by insecurity and has an ego in need of constant validation.
So you admit that you‰Ûªre an egotist?
Yes. (To audience) My name is Dr Leonard Hofstadter, and I could never please my parents so I need to get all my self-esteem from strangers like you. But he‰Ûªs worse.
Okay, that is it. (Tries to explode brain again.)
You cannot blow up my head with your mind.
Then I‰Ûªll settle for an aneurysm.
Stop it.
You hit me. You saw him, he hit me.
You were trying to blow up my head.
So it was working.
It wasn‰Ûªt, it was not, you are a nutcase.
Oh we‰Ûªll see about that (tries again), heads up you people in the front row, this is a splash zone.
Stop, stop it, quit it. (The start to fight.)
Is this usually how these physics things go?
More often than you‰Ûªd think.
Vulcan nerve pinch!
The apartment.
You could have offered me a ride home.
You‰Ûªre lucky I didn‰Ûªt run you over.
I really don‰Ûªt understand what you‰Ûªre so unhappy about, you begged me to come, I came, there‰Ûªs just no pleasing you.
You‰Ûªre right, I‰Ûªm the problem, I‰Ûªm the one that needs help.
Well that‰Ûªs not much of an apology, but I‰Ûªll take it.
Excuse me. Is there anything you‰Ûªd like to apologise for?
Yes. I‰Ûªm sorry I tried to blow up your head. It was uncalled for.
You won‰Ûªt believe this.
Somebody got the whole thing on a cell phone and put it on youtube.
What?
Now, who would do that?
That would be me. Hey, check it out, it‰Ûªs a featured video. (The watch).
Oh jeez. Is this suit really look that bad?
Forget your suit, look at my arms waving, I‰Ûªm like a flamingo on Ritalin.
Howard, would you like to explain to me why your facebook page has a picture of me sleeping on your shoulder captioned ‰ÛÏMe and my Girlfriend?‰Û
Uh-oh, here comes ‰ÛÏthe talk.‰Û
Captioned ‰ÛÏSomewhere in China‰Û, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
What losers.
Yeah. Gigantic American geeks. (The lights flicker)
åÊ Who‰Ûªs doing that?
Someone from Pasadena, California named‰Û_ ‰ÛÏWolowizard.‰Û
Awesome!
The downstairs lobby.
See, the liquid metal Terminators were created in the future by Skynet, and Skynet was developed by Miles Dyson, but that future no longer exists, due to Dyson‰Ûªs death in Terminator 2.

Okay, then riddle me this. Assuming all the good Terminators were originally evil Terminators created by Skynet but then reprogrammed by the future John Connor, why would Skynet, an artificial computer intelligence, bother to create a petite hot 17 year-old killer robot?
Skynet is kinky? I don‰Ûªt know.
Artificial intelligences do not have teen fetishes.
Alright, oh wait, they use it to in‰Û_
(Buzzing noise), too late, I win.
Let‰Ûªs go-oh-oh Ou-oooo-ut tonight. I have to go-oh-oh-oh ou-ooooo-ut tonight.
What the hell is that?
I don‰Ûªt know, but if cats could sing, they‰Ûªd hate it too. (The continue up the stairs and disappear from view).
You wanna prowl, be my night owl, (Leonard and Sheldon reappear, running down the stairs) we‰Ûªll take my‰Û_ (appearing) Hey guys, hi! Where you going?
What? Oh we just had to‰Û_ mail some letters and (seeing Sheldon has large bag in hand and bin is nearby) throw away some chicken. (Sheldon very reluctantly does.)
You‰Ûªll never guess what just happened.
Oh, I give up.

I don‰Ûªt guess. As a scientist I reach conclusions based on observation and experimentation, although as I‰Ûªm saying this it occurs to me you may have been employing a rhetorical device rendering my response moot.
What was that?
Believe it or not, personal growth. What happened?
Alright, remember when I auditioned for that workshop production of Rent, but I didn‰Ûªt get it and I couldn‰Ûªt figure out why?
I have a conclusion based on an observation.
No you don‰Ûªt. No he doesn‰Ûªt.
Well, the girl they picked to play Mimi, she dropped out and they asked me to replace her.
Oh, congratulations, what a lucky break.
It‰Ûªs not a big deal, just a one night showcase, but they invite a lot of casting people and agents so, you never know.
I think I know.
No you don‰Ûªt. He doesn‰Ûªt.
It‰Ûªs this Friday at eight, you guys want to come?
No.
Because‰Û_. uh, Friday, we are attending a symposium on molecular positronium.
I think that‰Ûªs a week from Tuesday at six.
No, it‰Ûªs this Friday, at eight.
Oh, too bad, well, I got to get to rehearsal, see you guys.
See you. (Penny exits singing)
You just lied to Penny.
Yes, I did.
And you did it so casually, no rapid breathing, no increase in perspiration.
So?
So, lack of a physiological response while lying is characteristic of a violent sociopath.
Sheldon, are you worried about your safety.
No, I imagine if you were going to kill me you‰Ûªd have done it a long time ago.
That‰Ûªs very true.
Outside Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
(Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard‰Û_
What?
I need to speak to you.
It‰Ûªs two o‰Ûªclock in the morning
It‰Ûªs important.
I highly doubt that. Go away. (Long pause). Are you still out there?
Yes.
What?
You‰Ûªre right, it can wait until morning.
What, what, what, what, what?
Never mind. I clearly woke you up in the middle of a REM cycle, you‰Ûªre in no state to talk.
Sheldon, what is it?
I‰Ûªm uncomfortable having been included in your lie to Penny.
What was I supposed to say.
You could have told her the truth.
That would have hurt her feelings.
Is that a relevant factor?
Yes.
Then I suppose you could have agreed to go.
And what would I have said afterwards?

I would suggest something to the effect of, singing is neither an appropriate vocation nor avocation for you, and if you disagree, I‰Ûªd recommend you have a CAT scan, to look for a tumour pressing on the cognitive processing centre of your brain.
I couldn‰Ûªt say that, I would have to say, you were terrific and I can‰Ûªt wait to hear you sing again.
Why?
It‰Ûªs the social protocol, it‰Ûªs what you do when you have a friend who‰Ûªs proud of something they really suck at.
I was not aware of that.
Well now you are.
Oh, alright. Leonard.
Yes.
When we played chess earlier, you were terrific and I can‰Ûªt wait to play you again. Goodnight.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
(Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock)‰Û_..
Oooaw. This would be so much easier if I were a violent sociopath. (Opening door) What?
I was analysing our lie, and I believe we‰Ûªre in danger of Penny seeing through the ruse.
How?

Simple. If she were to log on to www.socalphysicsgroup.org/activities/other, click on upcoming events, scroll down to seminars, download the pdf schedule, and look for the seminar on molecular positronium, well then, bippidy-boppidy-boo, our pants are metaphorically on fire.
Well, sir, my trousers will not be igniting today.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door.
(Knock, knock, knock, knock) Penny, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Penny, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Penny, (door opens) Good morning.
Do you have any idea what time it is?

Of course I do. My watch is linked to the atomic clock in Boulder, Colorado. It‰Ûªs accurate to one tenth of a second. But as I‰Ûªm saying this it occurs to me that once again your question may have been rhetorical.
What do you want?
Remember how Leonard told you we couldn‰Ûªt come to your performance because we were attending a symposium on molecular positronium?
I remember symposium.
Yes, well, he lied.
Wait, what?
He lied, and I‰Ûªm feeling very uncomfortable about it.
Well imagine how I‰Ûªm feeling.
Hungry? Tired? I‰Ûªm sorry this really isn‰Ûªt my strong suit.
The living room.
You told her I lied, why would you tell her I lied?
To help you.
I‰Ûªm sorry, I‰Ûªm not seeing the help.
She was going to see through your lie eventually, so I told her that you were lying to protect me.
Oh, I‰Ûªm getting a bad feeling.
Hunger? Indigestion, I‰Ûªm sorry I‰Ûªm really not very good at this. Anyway, Penny now believes that on Friday night, we‰Ûªre going to participate in my cousin Leopold‰Ûªs drug intervention.
Your cousin Leopold?
Yea, who most people call Leo, but he also answers to Lee, remember that, it‰Ûªs important.
What‰Ûªs important?
Details, Leonard, the success or failure of our deceitful enterprise turns on details.
Do you have a cousin Leopold.
No, I made him up. I think you‰Ûªd call him Lee.
I don‰Ûªt get it, I already told her a lie, why replace it with a different lie?
Well, first of all, your lie was laughably transparent, where mine is exquisitely convoluted. While you were sleeping I was weaving an un-unravelable web.
Un-unravelable?
Yes, if she googles Leopold Houston she‰Ûªll find a facebook page, an online blog depicting his descent into drug use, and a desperate yet hopeful listing on e-harmony.com.
Okay, why would I go to a drug intervention for your cousing.
Ah, because it‰Ûªs in Long Beach, and I don‰Ûªt drive.
We‰Ûªre going to Long Beach?
No, of course not, there‰Ûªs no cousin Leo, there‰Ûªs no intervention, focus Leonard.
Oh, come on!
We just leave the house on Friday night, and we return in the wee hours emotionally wrung out from the work of convincing Leo to go back into rehab.
So he goes back into rehab?
Yes, but, he can relapse if Penny ever invites us to go hear her sing again.
You still told her I lied.
For a noble purpose, to spare me the social embarrassment of having a drug-addled first cousin, which I‰Ûªm assuming is embarrassing, yes?
I don‰Ûªt know. How am I supposed to remember all of this.

That‰Ûªs the best part, you don‰Ûªt have to, see I told Penny that you would be embarrassed, if you knew that she found out that you had lied, so she‰Ûªs agreed to operate as if the original lie was still in force.
So she‰Ûªs expecting me to lie about going to a symposium in Pasadena, when in actuality we‰Ûªre pretending to go to a drug intervention in Long Beach?
Un-unravelable.
The apartment.
Oh hey Penny, wow, look at you, all ready for your showcase, you look great.
Thanks. I just wanted to come by and wish you guys luck with your symposium.
Oh, well, thankyou.
You know, I got to tell you, a lot of friends would let their friend go alone, but that‰Ûªs not who you are, you are the kind of guy who stands by a friend when‰Û_ when he has a symposium to go to.
I don‰Ûªt know what to say.
It‰Ûªs okay, Leonard (hugs him.)
Oh, okay, alright, good.
Oh boy, group hug.
Uh-huh!
Uh-huh?
Uh-huh!
Okay. So what‰Ûªs up?

Well, uh, Penny is on her way to perform in a one night showcase production of Rent, which we are unable to attend because we are going to a symposium on molecular positronium, given by Dr Emile Farminfarmian.
Wait a minute, Farminfarmian is speaking and you‰Ûªre Bogarding the symposium.
Howard, I‰Ûªm sorry‰Û_ we‰Ûªre‰Û_ we‰Ûªre
No, no, you‰Ûªre quark-blocking us.
I don‰Ûªt know what to say.
Wow.
Howard, listen‰Û_
No, it‰Ûªs okay, it‰Ûªs your Millenium Falcon, you and Chewbacca do whatever you want to do. Me and Princess Leia here will find some other way to spend the evening.
Howard, wait. Sheldon, I think we should tell them.
Okay, sure. I don‰Ûªt see a problem with that.
There‰Ûªs no symposium, Leonard lied to me, isn‰Ûªt that right Leonard.
Well‰Û_ I don‰Ûªt know what to say.
It‰Ûªs okay, I do, look, Leonard is helping Sheldon through a family crisis, he made up the whole story about the symposium with Dr Farmin..farm‰Û_ian
Good for you.

Hah, yeah! Because he didn‰Ûªt want Sheldon to be embarrassed, and there is nothing to be embarrassed okay, every family in America has a relative holed up in a garage somewhere huffing paint thinner.

character: Howard (after Raj whispers in his ear)
line: No, I‰Ûªm lost too, I think she skipped a step.

No, look, Sheldon‰Ûªs cousin Leo escaped rehab, and he‰Ûªs in a Motel 8 at Long Beach, the whole family‰Ûªs going out for an intervention. Leonard is driving Sheldon down there to help him through this because he‰Ûªs such a good man.
Oh, another hug, thank you.
Alright you guys, good luck.
Thanks Penny.
Yeah, uh, break a leg.
Break a leg. (She leaves)
So, road trip to Long Beach.
No, we‰Ûªre not going to Long Beach.
Why not?
Because Sheldon doesn‰Ûªt have a drug addicted cousin Leopold.
Oh, too bad. I‰Ûªve always wanted to go to Long Beach.

It‰Ûªs a very nice community. The Queen Mary is docked there, once the largest ocean liner in the world, it‰Ûªs now a hotel and restaurant where they host a surprisingly gripping murder mystery dinner.
Sounds fun.
I‰Ûªm game.
Shotgun.
No, no, no, Leonard gets nauseous unless he sits in front, and even then it‰Ûªs iffy.
Wait, are we really going to Long Beach?
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
(Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (Knock, knock, knock, knock) Leonard‰Û_
Let it go, Sheldon, the murderer was the first mate whether it makes sense to you or not.
No, that‰Ûªs the least of our worries. I‰Ûªve been doing some research on addiction, both the biochemical and behavioural aspects, and I think there‰Ûªs a problem with the current version of our lie.
What are you talking about, it‰Ûªs fine, she bought it, it‰Ûªs over.
Sadly, it‰Ûªs not. Substance abuse is a lifelong struggle, but beyond that I have realised that the Leo I described would not have agreed to go to rehab.
Why not?
Because Leo is a middle child.
There is no Leo, how can you say that?

You didn‰Ûªt read the bio, did you? He‰Ûªs not just a middle child, he‰Ûªs the quintessential middle child, from a broken home to boot. Psychologically speaking, the attention he gets by rebelling even to the point of self-destruction is more emotionally valuable than the help he would get at rehab.
I‰Ûªve got a solution.
Great, what is it?
Get out.

Fine. (He leaves. A moment later he comes back.) I‰Ûªve hesitated to point this out, but I must now remind you that we are in our current predicament because of your initial and totally inadequate deceit. I‰Ûªm just trying to clean up after your mess. (Leonard throws a glass ornament at him. He just manages to shut the door in time.) We‰Ûªll talk in the morning.
The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Morning.
Who are you?
I am Sheldon‰Ûªs cousin Leo.
Oh, God! Sheldon does not have a cousin Leo.

Au contraire. I‰Ûªm 26 years old, I‰Ûªm originally from (reads off crib notes) Denton, Texas, but I was a Navy brat so I was brought up on a variety of military bases around the world, as a result I‰Ûªve often felt like an outsider, never really fitting in, which is probably the reason for my substance abuse problem.
Excuse me, we just went over this. As the quintessential middle child, your addiction is rooted in your unmet need for attention.
Oh, Sheldon, are we really going to go with pop psychology.
For your information, this is all based on solid research, stick with the character profile I wrote for you.
Sheldon?
I‰Ûªm sorry, Leonard, this is Toby Loobenfeld, he‰Ûªs a research assistant in the particle physics lab, but he also minored in theatre at MIT.
It was more of a double major actually. Theatre and physics. You can guess which one my bourgeois parents pushed me towards.
Yeah, I got it, Sheldon, why?
Well, you see, while Leo would not have gone into rehab, it is completely plausible that we would have talked him into leaving the motel, and coming home with us.
Oh‰Û_!
Sheldon, how about this as my motivation. When I was fourteen years old I was abused in the Philippines by a club footed Navy chaplain.
No. We‰Ûªre going with middle child, and a generic predisposition to inadequate serotonin production.
Swell, how do I play genetic predisposition?
Subtextually, of course. (There is a knock on the door.) Just have fun with it. (Opening door.) Morning Penny.
Hi. How did the intervention go.
Unfortunately, we weren‰Ûªt able to convince him to go to rehab.
Well, based on what you told me, I‰Ûªm not surprised.
But we did convince him to leave the motel. Come say hello. Leo, this is Penny, our friend and neighbour.
Hi Leo, how are you feeling?
Let me ask you something, Penny. Have you ever woken up in a fleabag motel, covered in your own vomit, next to a transsexual prostitute?
No.
Then don‰Ûªt ask me how I‰Ûªm feeling.
Well, that‰Ûªs Leo. Hey, um, why don‰Ûªt you tell me about your showcase last night?
Oh, it was okay I guess, wasn‰Ûªt a big turn out but they both really seemed to like it.
There were only two people there?
By the end. Yeah.
Damn you, Chaplain Horrigan!
I‰Ûªm‰Û_ I‰Ûªm sorry.
