The Philippines. 1992. The Subic Bay Naval Station. A young boy on the cusp of manhood. His only companions mongrel dogs and malarial mosquitos. Desperate and alone he reached out to a man who promised to introduce him to a merciful, loving God, but who instead introduced him to a gin pickled tongue shoved down his adolescent throat. What choice did he have but to drink, shoot and snort his pain away.
Don‰Ûªt forget his genetic predisposition towards addiction.
That‰Ûªs never been proven.
There have been studies.
Not double blind studies.
How could there be a double blind study, who would be the control group.
As you can see, detoxing can get pretty ugly, let‰Ûªs give them some privacy.
Yeah. Hey, do you want to come over to my place, have coffee?
Sounds good.
I have a video of me singing last night, do you want to see it?
Gee, why wouldn‰Ûªt I?
This is even better than you coming to the showcase, because now I get to watch you watch me.
Yeah! Funny how things work out.
And that he loved the companionship and the wisdom that his own father failed to provide.
Your parents made the right decision.
I cannot work like this!
The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
This is amazing. Just sitting on a couch, watching TV with a woman. Not being drunk, or high, or‰Û_ or‰Û_ wondering if you‰Ûªre a dude down there.
Leo, you are a very sweet, really funny guy. You‰Ûªre gonna do okay.
One day at a time, Penny, one day at a time.
How long is he going to stay here.
He‰Ûªs a homeless drug addict, Leonard, where is he going to go? Boy, you have a lot to learn about lying.

The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard‰Ûªs move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Checkmate.
O-o-o-o-h! Again?
Obviously you‰Ûªre not well suited for three-dimensional chess, perhaps three dimensional candyland would be more your speed.
Just reset the board.
It must be humbling to suck on so many different levels.
Hi guys.
Hey!
Did you get my mail.
Yeah, right here. How was Nebraska?
Oh, better than North Dakota! (Pause) I guess that joke‰Ûªs only funny in Nebraska.
From the data at hand you really can‰Ûªt draw that conclusion. All you can say with absolute certainty is that that joke is not funny here.
Boy, it‰Ûªs good to be back.
How was your family?
Ugh, it was the worst trip, everyone got sick over the weekend.
Sick?
Here we go.

character: Sheldon (running to opposite side of the room)
line: What kind of sick?
Oh, the flu I guess.
I don‰Ûªt need you to guess, I need you to know, now when did the symptoms first appear?
Maybe Friday.
Friday, was that morning or afternoon?
I‰Û_ I don‰Ûªt‰Û_
Think woman, who blew their nose and when?
Sheldon, relax, she doesn‰Ûªt have any symptoms, I‰Ûªm sure she‰Ûªs not contagious.

Oh please, if influenza was only contagious after symptoms appear it would have died out thousands of years ago. Somewhere between tool using and cave painting, homo habilus would have figured out to kill the guy with the runny nose.
Penny, you‰Ûªll have to excuse Sheldon, he‰Ûªs a bit of a germophobe.
Oh, it‰Ûªs okay, I understand.
Thanks for your consideration, now please leave.
You‰Ûªd better go before he starts spraying you with Lysol.
Okay, well, thank you for getting my mail.
No problem. Welcome home. (Sees Penny out. Turns to find Sheldon spraying the air with Lysol.)
What?
The kitchen
What the hell are you doing?
I‰Ûªm making petrie dishes to grow throat cultures.
With lime jello?
I need a growth medium, and someone polished off the apricot yoghurt. Here, swab my throat.
I don‰Ûªt think so.
Leonard! If I‰Ûªm going to get ahead of this thing I need to find out what‰Ûªs growing in my throat.
Sheldon, you are not sick. This is, but you are not.
We have no idea what pathogen Typhoid Penny has introduced into our environment. And having never been to Nebraska I‰Ûªm fairly certain that I have no cornhusking antibodies.
Sheldon, don‰Ûªt you think you‰Ûªre overreacting?
When I‰Ûªm lying comatose in a hospital relying on inferior minds to cure me, these jello cultures and my accompanying notes will give them a fighting chance.
I‰Ûªm going back to bed.
Wait. (Handing him a measuring jug) Put this in the bathroom.
What for?
I need to measure my fluid intake and output to make sure my kidneys aren‰Ûªt shutting down.
I mix pancake batter in this!
No, that measuring cup has always been for urine.
You had time to make a label for everything in this apartment, including the label maker, but you didn‰Ûªt have ten seconds to make one that said urine cup?
It‰Ûªs right here on the bottom.
Huh. I guess I owe the Betty Crocker company a letter of apology.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Oh, dear God. (Shouting) Leonard! Leonard, I‰Ûªm sick!
Leonard! Leonard I‰Ûªm sick!
Leonard! Leonard! Leonard. Leonard, my comforter fell down, and my sinuses hurt when I bend over. Leonard? (Bends to get phone) Ow!
Hey.
Leonard, where are you?
I‰Ûªm at work.
At six-thirty in the morning?
Yes.
On Sunday?
Yes.
Why?
They asked me to come in.
Well, I didn‰Ûªt hear the phone ring.
They texted me.
Well, as I predicted, I am sick. My fever has been tracking up exponentially since 2am, and I am producing sputum at an alarming rate.
No kidding?
No. Not only that, it has shifted from clear to milky green.
Alright, well, get some rest and drink plenty of fluids.
What else would I drink? Gasses? Solids? Ionised plasma?
Drink whatever you want.
I want soup.
Then make soup.
We don‰Ûªt have soup.
I‰Ûªm at work, Sheldon. (A woman enters the apartment building with a barking dog.)
Is that a dog?
Yes,
In the lab?
Yes, they‰Ûªre training dogs to operate the centrifuge for when they need dogs to operate the centrifuge for blind scientists, I have to go.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Howard, it‰Ûªs the phone.
I know it‰Ûªs the phone, Ma, I hear the phone.
Well who‰Ûªs calling at this ungodly hour?
I don‰Ûªt know.
Well ask them why they‰Ûªre calling at this ungodly hour.
How can I ask them when I‰Ûªm talking to you! (Into phone) Hello.
Howard, it‰Ûªs Leonard, code Milky Green.
Dear Lord, not Milky Green!
Affirmative, with fever.
Who‰Ûªs on the phone.
It‰Ûªs Leonard.
Why is he calling.
Sheldon‰Ûªs sick.
Were you playing with him?
For God‰Ûªs sake, Ma, I‰Ûªm twenty six years old.
Excuse me Mr Grown-up. Whadda-ya want for breakfast.
Chocolate milk and eggoes please!
Howard, listen to me.
Hang on, call waiting.
No, don‰Ûªt, don‰Ûªt‰Û_.
Hello.
Howard, I‰Ûªm sick.
Howard‰Ûªs sleeping, this is his mother. Why are you calling at this ungodly hour?
I need soup.
Then call your own mother. (To Leonard) It was Sheldon.
I tried to stop you.
It‰Ûªs my own fault, I forgot the protocol we put in place after the great ear infection of ‰Ûª06.
You call Koothrappali, we need to find a place to lay low for the next eighteen to twenty four hours.
Stand by. Ma, can my friends come over?
I just had the carpets steamed.
That‰Ûªs a negatory. But there‰Ûªs a Planet of the Apes marathon at the New Art today.
Five movies, two hours apiece. It‰Ûªs a start.
The Cheesecake Factory.
Homeless crazy guy at table eighteen.
No, just crazy. Sheldon, what are you doing here?
I‰Ûªm sick, thank you very much.
How could you have gotten it from me, I‰Ûªm not sick.
You‰Ûªre a carrier. All these people here are doomed. You‰Ûªre doomed!
Shhh! Sheldon, what do you want.
I want soup.
Why didn‰Ûªt you just‰Û_. (louder throat clearance) Why didn‰Ûªt you just have soup at home.
Penny, I have an IQ of 187, don‰Ûªt you imagine that if there were a way for me to have had soup at home I would have thought of it?
You can have soup delivered.
I did not think of that. Clearly febrile delirium is setting in, please bring me some soup while I still understand what a spoon is for.
Okay, what kind of soup do you want.
Well, my mother used to make me this split pea with little frankfurter slices and these home made croutons.
We have Chicken Tortilla and Potato Leek.
Can I get any of those with little frankfurter slices and home made croutons?
No.
Then surprise me. (Blows nose into handkerchief. Shows it to next table) Would you call that moss green or forest green?
The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Look at this, everyone went chimp.
Well I‰Ûªd like to point out, I voted for orang-utan, but you shouted me down. (Phone rings).
Oh, hi Penny!
Hey, where are you?
I‰Ûªm‰Û_ uh‰Û_ at work.
You sound funny.
I‰Ûªm‰Û_ uh‰Û_ in a‰Û_ I‰Ûªm in a radiation suit. What‰Ûªs up?
Yeah, well I‰Ûªm at work too, and you‰Ûªll never guess who‰Ûªs here infecting my entire station.
Sheldon‰Ûªs at the Cheesecake Factory. (Into phone) Just tell him to go home.
He won‰Ûªt leave, he says he‰Ûªs afraid he‰Ûªll pass out on the bus and someone will harvest his organs.
He‰Ûªs paranoid, and he‰Ûªs established a nest.
Can you please come get him?

Uh, yeah, I‰Ûªd be‰Û_ I‰Ûªd be happy to Penny. (Holds phone up, Howard makes warning siren noises) Oh my God there‰Ûªs a breech in the radiation unit (Raj joins in) The whole city is in jeopardy, oh my God, Professor Googenfeil is melting, gotta go, bye! (To Howard and Raj) I feel really guilty.
You did what you had to do. (Steals some of Howard‰Ûªs popcorn)
Take your stinking paws off my popcorn you damn dirty ape.
The stairwell.
Thanks for bringing me home.
Oh, it‰Ûªs okay, I didn‰Ûªt really need to work today, it‰Ûªs not like I have rent or car payments or anything.
Good. Good.
Okay, well, you feel better.
Wait, where are you going?
Um, home, to write some bad cheques.
You‰Ûªre going to leave me?
Sheldon, you are a grown man, haven‰Ûªt you ever been sick before?
Well, of course, but, not by myself.
Really, never?
Well, once. When I was fifteen, and spending the summer at the Heidelberg Institute in Germany.
Studying abroad?

No, visiting professor. Anyway, the local cuisine was a little more sausage-based than I‰Ûªm used to, and the result was an internal blitzkrieg with my lower intestine playing the part of Czechoslovakia.
And there was no-one there to take care of you?
No. No, my mum had to fly back to Texas to help my dad because the house had slipped off the cinderblocks again.
Again?

It was tornado season. And it was an aluminium house. Anyway, the housekeeper in the faculty residence didn‰Ûªt speak any English, when I finally managed to convince her I was sick, she said ‰ÛÏMÌ¦chtest Du eine DarmspÌ_lung?‰Û
What does that mean?
Based on what happened next, I assume it means ‰ÛÏwould you like an enema?‰Û
Okay, sweetie, I‰Ûªll take care of you, what do you need?
Well, my mom used to give me sponge baths.
Okay, ground rules, no sponge baths, and definitely no enemas.
Agreed.
The cinema.
Here we go, ten and a half hours of apey goodness.
Oh dammit, my glasses. Okay, I‰Ûªm blind here guys, can you help me find them?
Sorry. (Crunching sound) Found ‰Û÷em.
Oh great.
Sorry, don‰Ûªt you have a spare.
Yeah, at home.
Well if you leave now, you can be back before the gorillas rip the crap out of Charlton Heston.
Unless Sheldon‰Ûªs there, in which case you‰Ûªll be trapped forever in his whiny hyper neurotic snot-web.

Hi, Penny. I was wondering, is Sheldon still at the restaurant? Okay, that was very nice of you. Okay, gotta go, got kind of a full blown Chernobyl thing here, gotta go, bye. (To Howard) He‰Ûªs home, I‰Ûªm screwed. Ten and a half hours of apey blurriness.
How about Lasic?
You want me to get eye surgery?
Would you rather go back to the apartment and deal with Sheldon, or have a stranger carve out your corneas with a laser beam?
Well?
I‰Ûªm thinking!
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Okay, nice and cosy, okay, I‰Ûªll see you later.
Wait. Will you please rub this on my chest.
Oh, Sheldon, can‰Ûªt you do that yourself?
Vaporub makes my hands smell funny.
But Sheldon‰Û_.
Please, please, please, please, please, please, please.
I can‰Ûªt believe I‰Ûªm doing this.
No, no, counter-clockwise or my chest hair mats.
Sorry.
Can you sing ‰ÛÏSoft Kitty‰Û.
What?
My mom used to sing it to me when I was sick.
I‰Ûªm sorry, honey, I don‰Ûªt know it.
I‰Ûªll teach you. ‰ÛÏSoft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur, happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr purr purr.‰Û Now you.
Soft kitty, warm kitty‰Û_
Little ball of fur. Keep rubbing.
Little ball of fur.
The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
What do you see, what do you see.
The living room appears to be empty.
Okay, he must be in his bedroom. My spare glasses are in my bedroom, on my dresser, next to my Bat-signal.
I‰Ûªm not going in there.
Raj?
No way, Jose.
Well I can‰Ûªt do it, I can‰Ûªt see anything.
It‰Ûªs all right, wireless mini-cam and Bluetooth headset. We‰Ûªll be your eyes.
Fine.

One more thing. This is a subsonic impact sensor. If Sheldon gets out of bed and starts to walk, this device will register it and send a signal to the laptop. At that point, based on the geography of the apartment and the ambulatory speed of a sick Sheldon, you‰Ûªll have seven seconds to get out, glasses or no glasses.
Won‰Ûªt my footsteps set it off?
No, you‰Ûªll be on your hands and knees. Now you‰Ûªll need to get the sensor as close as you can to Sheldon‰Ûªs room.
Well, how do I carry it if I‰Ûªm on my hands and knees?
Stay low. Bear left. Now keep true.
What?
It means go straight.
Then just say go straight.
You don‰Ûªt stay go straight when you‰Ûªre giving bearings, you say keep true.
Alright (Bangs head on a trunk.) I just hit my head.
Because you didn‰Ûªt keep true. (Time shift, Leonard is now outside bedrooms) Okay, turn right.
The‰Û_ the picture‰Ûªs breaking up.

Angle your head to the right. A little more. A little more. (Leonard now has his head at right angles to his body) That‰Ûªs it, now just keep true. Alright, you‰Ûªre close enough to Sheldon‰Ûªs room, deploy the sensor. Now turn it on.
It wasn‰Ûªt on?
No.
Then why did I have to crawl?
Oh, I guess you didn‰Ûªt.
Okay, it‰Ûªs on.
Good. From this point forward you will have to crawl.
I know.
Hang on, the sensor‰Ûªs picking up something, turn your head back. (Camera angle shows a pair of female legs.)
You rat bastard.
Told you the sensor would work.
Hi!
You deliberately stuck me with Sheldon.
Well, I had to, you see what he‰Ûªs like.
Penny! Penny, I‰Ûªm hungry.
Uh, it‰Ûªs okay, sweetie, good news, Leonard‰Ûªs home!
No!
Here you go, good luck, bye.
W-wait!
Leonard, I‰Ûªm hungry!
Wait! Penny! Take me with you! (Runs after her and bumps into pillar. Falls semi-conscious to the floor. åÊSheldon appears in his comforter.)
I want grilled cheese.
Do you think Penny will come here and take care of us?
I don‰Ûªt think Penny‰Ûªs ever coming here again.
I‰Ûªm very congested.
Yeah, so?
Can you go to the kitchen, and get me the turkey baster labelled mucus.
If I stand, I‰Ûªll vomit.
Under the sink, yellow Tupperware bowl.
The University cafeteria.
Here‰Ûªs the problem with teleportation.
Lay it on me.

Assuming the device could be invented which would identify the quantum state of matter of an individual in one location, and transmit that pattern to a distant location for reassembly, you would not have actually transported the individual. You would have destroyed him in one location, and recreated him in another.
How about that.
Personally, I would never use a transporter. Because the original Sheldon would have to be disintegrated in order to create a new Sheldon.
Would the new Sheldon be in any way an improvement on the old Sheldon?
No, he would be exactly the same.
That is a problem.
So, you see it too.
Dr Hofstadter, Dr Cooper.
Dr Gablehouser.
Gentlemen, I‰Ûªd like you to meet Dennis Kim. Dennis is a highly sought after Doctorial candidate and we‰Ûªre hoping to have him do his graduate work here.
Graduate work, very impressive.
And he‰Ûªs only fifteen years old.
Not bad, I myself started graduate school at fourteen.
Well, I lost a year while my family was tunnelling out of North Korea.
Advantage Kim.
I thought maybe you boys could show Dennis around, let him see why we‰Ûªre the best physics research facility in the country.
I already know you‰Ûªre not. You don‰Ûªt have an open science grid computer, or a free electron laser, and the string theory research being done here is nothing but a dead end.
Excuse me, that is my research, and it is by no means a dead end.
Well, obviously you don‰Ûªt see it yet, but trust me, you will.

Dennis, we discussed this, we‰Ûªre in the process of updating our equipment, and we welcome your input on our research goals, and we‰Ûªve agreed to look the other way if you want to use up to 20% of the grant money you attract to smuggle your grandfather out of Pyongyang. We want him here boys, make it happen.
Yes sir.
You can count on us, we‰Ûªre on it. What the hell do you mean, dead end.
I mean, the whole landscape of false vacuums in string theory could be as large as ten to the five-hundredth power. In addition‰Û_ ooh, look, chocolate milk.
I sense a disturbance in the force.
A bad feeling I have about this, mmm-hmmm.
A corridor.
So, Dennis, how long have you been in America.
A year and a half.
No kidding, you speak English really well.
So do you. Except for your tendency to end sentences with prepositions.
What are you talking about?
That.
He‰Ûªs not wrong. Alright, and this is my office.
Is this part of the tour?
Nope. Goodbye.
Come on, Sheldon, we‰Ûªve hardly shown him anything.
Oh, alright, this is my desk, these are my books, this is my door, please close it behind you. Goodbye.
Looks like you‰Ûªre doing work in quantum loop corrections.
Keen observation, goodbye.
You see where you went wrong, don‰Ûªt you?
Leonard.
Huh, yeah?
Get him out.
Come on, Dennis, I‰Ûªll show you the rec centre, they‰Ûªve got nautilus equipment.
Do I look like I lift weights.
Not heavy ones.
It‰Ûªs startling to me you haven‰Ûªt considered a Lorentz invariant field theory approach.
You think I haven‰Ûªt considered it? You really think I haven‰Ûªt considered it?
Have you considered it?
Get him out Leonard.
Come on, Dennis, I‰Ûªll show you the radiation lab.
Wow, you won the Stephenson award.
Yes, in fact I am the youngest person ever to win it.
Really, how old?
Fourteen and a half.
You were the youngest person ever to win it.
It‰Ûªs like looking into an obnoxious little mirror, isn‰Ûªt it?
The living room of the apartment.
Mmm, this is really delicious, isn‰Ûªt it? (Raj looks uncomfortable, then nods.) Still can‰Ûªt talk to me unless you‰Ûªre drunk, huh? (Shakes head) Oh, sweetie, you are so damaged.
Hey, I‰Ûªm damaged too. How about a hug for Howie?
Sure. Raj, hug Howard.
Uh-uh-uh.
Something you‰Ûªd like to share? A tale of woe perhaps.
Fifteen years old. Dennis Kim is fifteen years old, and he‰Ûªs already correcting my work. Today I went from being Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to‰Û_ you know, that other guy.
Antonio Salieri?
Oh, God, now even you‰Ûªre smarter than me.
You know, Sheldon, you don‰Ûªt have so many friends that you can afford to start insulting them.
Just eat, Sheldon, you‰Ûªll feel better.
Why waste food. In Texas when a cow goes dry they don‰Ûªt keep feeding it, they just take her out and shoot her between the eyes.
I‰Ûªm confused, did Sheldon stop giving milk?
You can‰Ûªt let this kid get to you. You always knew that someday someone would come along who was younger and smarter.
Yes, but I assumed I would have been dead hundreds of years, and that there would be an asterisk by his name because he would be a cyborg.
So, you‰Ûªve got a bit of competition, I really don‰Ûªt see what the big deal is.
Well of course you don‰Ûªt, you‰Ûªve never excelled at anything.
I don‰Ûªt understand, exactly how did he get any friends in the first place?
We liked Leonard.
Well, what are you going to do, Sheldon, give up?

Yes. That‰Ûªs what a rational person does when his entire life‰Ûªs work is invalidated by a post-pubescent Asian wunderkind. He ceases his fruitless efforts, he donates his body to scientific research, and he waits to die.
You know, I‰Ûªm confused again, is he waiting, or do we get to shoot him between the eyes?
The same, later that night
Hey.
Hey.
I‰Ûªve decided you‰Ûªre right. My career is not over.
Great.
But, since the arrival of Dennis Kim has rendered my research pointless, I just have to find something else to focus on.
Great.
So I‰Ûªve decided, I‰Ûªm going to collaborate with you.
Great.
What exactly is it you do? I know you chatter on about it all the time, but I‰Ûªve never really paid attention.
Okay, well, right now I‰Ûªm designing an experiment to study the soft component of cosmic radiation at sea-level, but I really don‰Ûªt need any help.
Oh, sure you do. Now, see, what‰Ûªs this here in the schematic, is that a laser array?
Yes.
No. Hmmm. What happens if you use argon lasers instead of helium neon?
It would blow up.
Are you sure?
Pretty sure.
Pretty sure‰Ûªs not very scientific, is this how you normally work, just hunches and guesses and stuff?

Okay, Sheldon, I understand that you‰Ûªre going through a bit of a career crisis, you‰Ûªre searching for some other area where you can feel valuable and productive but I need to tell you something and I want you to listen carefully.
Alright.
Go away.
If you‰Ûªre concerned about sharing credit with me, you‰Ûªre name can go first‰Û_ I‰Ûªm going.
Howard‰Ûªs lab.
It‰Ûªs a small brown paper bag, Ma, I‰Ûªm looking at it right now. (Pause.) Why would I make that up, there‰Ûªs no ding-dong in it. (Pause.) How are two ding-dongs tomorrow going to help me today?
So, this is engineering, huh?
I‰Ûªll talk to you later.
Engineering. Where the noble semi-skilled labourers execute the vision of those who think and dream. Hello, oompah-loompahs of science.
Sheldon, what are you doing here?
I just came by to say hello.
I‰Ûªve been at this lab for three years, you‰Ûªve never came by to say hello.
Well, up until now I‰Ûªve had better things to do. So, what are we making today?
A small payload support structure for a European science experimental package that‰Ûªs going up on the next space shuttle.
Really, how does it work?
When this is done, it will be attached to the payload bay, and the sensor apparatus will rest on it.
Uh, huh. So it‰Ûªs a shelf?
No, you don‰Ûªt understand, during acceleration it needs to stay perfectly level and provide‰Û_ yeah, okay, it‰Ûªs a shelf.
Now, I notice you‰Ûªre using titanium, did you give any consideration to carbon nanotubes, they‰Ûªre lighter, cheaper and half twice the tensile strength.
Sheldon, there‰Ûªs a diploma in my office that says I have a masters in engineering.
And you also have a note from your mother that says I love you, bubbula. But neither of those is a cogent argument for titanium over nanotubes.
Sheldon.
Yes.
Go away.
Did Leonard tell you to say that?
No, I thought of it all by myself.
Huh. It can‰Ûªt be a coincidence. There must be some causal link I‰Ûªm missing.
Raj is exiting his office.
Go away. (Sheldon exits)
Curiouser and curiouser.
The apartment.
Is he here?
If he were, I wouldn‰Ûªt be.
Do you know what he did. He watched me work for ten minutes, and then started to design a simple piece of software that could replace me.
Is that even possible?
As it turns out, yes.
Something‰Ûªs got to be done about him, Leonard.
Like what? He‰Ûªll never be able to cope with the fact that some fifteen year-old kid is smarter and more accomplished than he is.
Well, what if something were to happen to this boy so he was no longer a threat to Sheldon?
Then our problem would be solved.
Hang on, are we talking about murdering Dennis Kim? I‰Ûªm not saying no.
We don‰Ûªt have to go that far, there are other means available.
We can‰Ûªt send him back to North Korea. He knows how to get out.
The only thing we need to do is make this Kim kid lose his focus.
That won‰Ûªt happen, he‰Ûªs not interested in anything but physics.
What about biology?
What?
You know, biology? The one thing that can completely derail a world class mind.
Howard, he‰Ûªs fifteen.
Yeah, so, when I was fifteen I met Denise Polmerry and my grade point average fell from a 5.0 to a 1.8.
She was sleeping with you?
No, I just wasted a lot of time thinking about what it would be like if she did.

Oh, good, you‰Ûªre all here. Look, I‰Ûªve decided that if the three of you drop whatever it is you‰Ûªre working on and join me, we could lick cold fusion in less than a decade, twelve years tops. (They stare at him.) Go away? (They nod) Hmm. Could it be me?
Outside Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
Oh, hey guys, what‰Ûªs up?
We need a hot fifteen year-old Asian girl with a thing for smart guys.
What?
Howard, that‰Ûªs racist, any fifteen year-old girl will do the trick. (Penny slams door.)
It‰Ûªs possible she may have misunderstood us.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Dr Cooper? Oh, are we interrupting?
No, no, please, come in. Yeah, I think you‰Ûªll appreciate this, very exciting.
Oh, what are you working on?

Something remarkable. Since my prospects for the Nobel Prize in physics have disappeared, thank you very much, I‰Ûªve decided to refocus my efforts and use my people skills to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Look, I‰Ûªm going to solve the Middle-East Crisis by building an exact replica of Jerusalem in the middle of the Mexican desert.
To what end?
You know, it‰Ûªs like the baseball movie, build it and they will come.
Who will come?
The Jewish people.
What if they don‰Ûªt come.
We‰Ûªll make it nice, put out a spread.
Okay, well, um, speaking of spreads, we‰Ûªre having a small welcoming party this afternoon for Mr Kim, who‰Ûªs agreed to join us here at the University.
Of course he has, the oracle told us little Neo was the one. You can see the Matrix, can‰Ûªt you.
Okay, well, uh, obviously you‰Ûªre very busy with your‰Û_ uh, um, come Dennis. You‰Ûªll have to excuse Dr Cooper, he‰Ûªs been under a lot of‰Û_ um‰Û_ he‰Ûªs nuts.

character: Sheldon (voice off, sings to a Mexican tune)
line: Ah, la-la-la, Hava Nagila. They‰Ûªll come, they‰Ûªll settle and I‰Ûªll win the prize‰Û_
The welcoming party
I really don‰Ûªt understand your objections, Professor Goldfarb, why wouldn‰Ûªt the Senoran Desert make a perfectly good promised land?
Go away.
We could call it Nuevo Cherusalem.
Please go away.
Said Pharoah to Moses.
Why are all these young women here?
It‰Ûªs take your daughter to work day.
Really, I was not aware of that.
Oh, yes. There was a very official email that was sent to everyone whose insurance files indicated they had daughters between the ages of 14 and 16.
Hm?
Smooth.
Thank you.
There‰Ûªs the man of the hour.
Okay, so we now have a socially awkward genius in a room full of attractive age-appropriate women.
All he has to do now is hook up with one of them. (The look at Dennis, who is picking his ear.)
Does anyone else see the flaw in this plan?
We need a social catalyst.
Like what? We can‰Ûªt get fifteen year-old girls drunk. åÊ
Or can we?
No, we can‰Ûªt.
I don‰Ûªt think you mean we can‰Ûªt. I think you mean we shouldn‰Ûªt.

Hey, Howard. You‰Ûªre a Jew. If there was another wailing wall, exactly like the one in Jerusalem, but close to taco stands and cheap prescription drugs, would you still be able to wail at it? Okay, it‰Ûªs definitely me.
Okay, we cannot leave this to chance, lets pick a girl, and figure out how to get her together with Dennis.
Okay. How about that one.

Uh-uh. I know the type, cheerleader, student council, goes out with jocks, won‰Ûªt even look at anybody in the gifted programme. And if, after two years of begging, she does agree to go out with you, it turns out to be a set-up and you‰Ûªre in the back seat of your mom‰Ûªs car with your pants off while the whole football team laughs at you.
Are you crying?
No, I have allergies.
Okay, uh, how about her?

Sure. If he wants to spend a couple of years doing her homework while she drinks herself into a stupor with non-fat White Russians, while you‰Ûªre the one holding her head out of the toilet while she‰Ûªs puking and telling you she wishes more guys were like you, and they she gets into Cornell because you wrote her essay for her, and you drive up to visit her one weekend and she acts like she doesn‰Ûªt even know you.
Okay, so not her either. How about her?
Interesting, kind of pretty, a little chubby so probably low self-esteem.
I think that‰Ûªs our girl. One of us should go talk to her.
I can‰Ûªt talk to her, you do it.
I can‰Ûªt just go up and talk to her. Howard, you talk to her.
Oh no, she‰Ûªll never go for the kid once she gets a peek at this.
You know, if we were in India this would be simpler. Five minutes with her dad, twenty goats and a laptop and we‰Ûªd be done.
Well, we‰Ûªre not in India.
Alright, why don‰Ûªt we do it your way then? We‰Ûªll arrange for this girl to move in across the hall from Dennis so he can pathetically moon over her for months on end.
Okay, that was uncalled for.
You started it, dude.

Could I have everyone‰Ûªs attention please. What a wonderful occasion this is. And how fortunate that it should happen to fall on take your daughter to work day. We‰Ûªre here to welcome Mr Dennis Kim to our little family.
Welcome Dennis Kim.
Mr Kim was not only the valedictorian at Stamford University, he is also the youngest recipient of the prestigious Stephenson Award.
Youngest till the cyborgs rise up!
And now, without any further ado, let me introduce the man of the hour, Mr Dennis Kim. Dennis! Dennis!
What?
Would you like to tell us a little bit about your upcoming research.
Um, no thanks. I‰Ûªm going to the mall with Emma.
Well, uh, well, uh‰Û_.
The kid got a girl.
Unbelievable.
Did anyone see how he did it?

Don‰Ûªt worry, I‰Ûªve got this. Ladies and Gentlemen, honoured daughters. While Mr Kim, by virtue of his youth and naivety, has fallen prey to the inexplicable need for human contact, let me step in and assure you that my research will go on uninterrupted, and that social relationships will continue to baffle and repulse me. Thank you.
He‰Ûªs back.
Yeah, mission accomplished.
Forget the mission, how did that little yutz get a girl on his own?
I guess times have changed since we were young. Smart is the new sexy.
Well, why do we go home alone every night, we‰Ûªre still smart.
Maybe we‰Ûªre too smart. So smart it‰Ûªs offputting.
Yeah, let‰Ûªs go with that.
The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Unbelievable. Components I built are on the International Space Station, and I get a ticket for launching a model rocket in the park.
I don‰Ûªt know if the ticket was so much for the launch as it was for you telling the policewoman ‰ÛÏyou have to frisk me, I have a rocket in my pants.‰Û

Hey, look at that. (There is a group of youngsters on the grass, laying about. One is playing a guitar. Dennis Kim is among them. He is drinking something from a bottle in a brown paper bag.) It‰Ûªs Dennis Kim.
Wow, I almost didn‰Ûªt recognise him.
You know, I kind of feel bad about what we did to him. (Dennis is now snogging the face off Emma)
Yeah, we really ruined his life.
Screw him, he was weak.
The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Ooh, more details about the new Star Trek film. There‰Ûªs going to be a scene depicting Spock‰Ûªs birth.
I‰Ûªd be more interested in a scene depicting Spock‰Ûªs conception.
Oh, please. For Vulcans, mating, or, if you will, Pon Farr, it‰Ûªs an extremely private matter.
Still, I‰Ûªd like to know the details. His mother was human, his father was Vulcan, they couldn‰Ûªt just conceive.
Maybe they had to go to a clinic. Imagine Spock‰Ûªs dad in a little room with a copy of pointy ears and shapely rears.
How come on Star Trek everybody‰Ûªs private parts are the same. No alien lady ever told Captain Kirk, hey, get your thing out of my nose.
Hi, can you help me, I was writing an email and the A key got stuck. Now it‰Ûªs just going ‰ÛÏaaaaaaa‰Û.
What did you spill on it?
Nothing. Diet coke. And yoghurt. A little nail polish.
I‰Ûªll take a look at it.
Gentlemen, switching to local nerd news. Fishman, Chen, Chowdry, McNair aren‰Ûªt fielding a team in the university physics bowl this year.
You‰Ûªre kidding, why not?
They formed a barbershop quartet, and got a gig playing Knotsbury Farm.
Wow, so in your world, you‰Ûªre like, the cool guys.
Recognise.
This is our year! With those guys out, the entire physics bowl will kneel before Zod.
Zod?
Kryptonian villain. Long story.
Good story. (Clasps hands to mouth in shock.)
Well count me out.
What? Why?
You want me to use my intelligence in a tawdry competition? Would you ask Picasso to play Pictionary? Would you ask Noah Webster to play Boggle? Would you ask Jacques Cousteau to play Go Fish?
Come on, you need a four person team, we‰Ûªre four people.
By that reasoning we should also play bridge, hold up a chuppah and enter the Olympic bobsled competition.
I want tickets to that please.
Sheldon, what, do I need to quote Spock‰Ûªs dying words to you.
No, don‰Ûªt.
The needs of the many.
Outweigh the needs of the few.
Or the one. Dammit, I‰Ûªll do it.
The cafeteria.
Okay. First order of physics bowl business. We need a truly kick-ass team name. Suggestions.
How about the perpetual motion squad? It‰Ûªs beyond the laws of physics, plus a little heads up for the ladies.
The ladies?
Perpetual motion squad, we can go all night.
I like it.
I don‰Ûªt. Teams are traditionally named after fierce creatures, thus intimidating ones opponent.
Then we can be the Bengal Tigers.
Poor choice. Gram for gram, no animal exceeds the relative fighting strength of the army ant.
Maybe so. But you can‰Ûªt incinerate a Bengal Tiger with a magnifying glass.
Let‰Ûªs put it to a vote. All those in favour‰Û_.
Point of order. I move that any vote on team names should be unanimous. No man should be forced to emblazon his chest with the bengal tiger, when common sense dictates it should be an army ant.
Will the gentleman from the great state of denial yield for a question?
I will yield.
After we go through the exercise of an annoying series of votes, all of which the gentleman will lose, does he then intend to threaten to quit if he does not get his way?
He does.
I move we are the Army Ants, all those in favour?
The apartment.

Good afternoon, and welcome to today‰Ûªs physics bowl practice round. I‰Ûªm Penny, and I‰Ûªll be your host, because apparently I didn‰Ûªt have anything else to do on a Saturday afternoon, and isn‰Ûªt that just a little sad? Gentlemen, are you ready?
Yes.
Of course.
Fire away. (Raj puts his thumb up.)
You know, it‰Ûªs none of my business, but isn‰Ûªt a guy who can‰Ûªt speak in front of women going to hold you back a little?
Oh, uh, he‰Ûªll be okay once the women are mixed into the crowd. He only has a problem when they‰Ûªre one on one and smell nice.
Oh, thanks Raj, it‰Ûªs vanilla oil.
I was actually the one who noticed, okay, let‰Ûªs just start.
Okay, the first question is on the topic of optics. What is the shortest light pulse ever produced? Dr Cooper.
And of course, the answer is 130 adoseconds.
That is correct.
I knew that too.
Good for you, sweetie. Okay, next question. What is the quantum mechanical effect used to encode data on hard disk drives? Howard.
And of course, the answer is giant magneto resistance.
Right.
Hey, I buzzed in.
But I answered, it‰Ûªs called teamwork.
Don‰Ûªt you think I should answer the engineering questions? I am an engineer.
By that logic I should answer all the anthropology questions because I‰Ûªm a mammal.åÊ
Just ask another one.
Okay. What artificial satellite has seen glimpses of Einsteins predicted frame dragging? (Raj buzzes.)
And of course it‰Ûªs Gravity Probe B.
Sheldon, you have to let somebody else answer.
Why?
Because it‰Ûªs polite.
What do manners have to do with it? This is war. Were the Romans polite when they salted the ground of Carthage to make sure nothing would ever grow again?
Leonard, you said I only had to ask questions.
The objective of the competition is to give correct answers, if I know them, why shouldn‰Ûªt I give them?
Some of us might have the correct answers too.
Oh please, you don‰Ûªt even have a PhD.
Alright, that‰Ûªs it.
Howard, sit down.
Okay.
maybe we should take a little break.
Good idea, I need my wrist brace, all this button pushing is aggravating my old Nintendo injury.

character: Howard (after Raj whispers in his ear)
line: I agree.
What did he say?
He compared Sheldon to a disposable feminine cleansing product one might use on a summer‰Ûªs eve.
Yeah, and the bag it came in.
The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Leonard, excellent, I want to show you something.
Can it wait, I need to talk to you.
Just look. I‰Ûªve designed the perfect uniforms for our team. The colours are based on Star Trek, the original series. The three of you will wear support red, and I will wear command gold.
Why do they say AA?
Army Ants.
Isn‰Ûªt that confusing? AA might mean something else to certain people.
Why would a physics bowl team be called anodised aluminium?
No, I meant‰Û_. never mind. Hey, check it out. I got you a Batman cookie jar!
Oh neat, what‰Ûªs the occasion?
Well, you‰Ûªre a friend, and you like Batman, and cookies, and you‰Ûªre off the team.
What?
Howard, Raj and I just had a team meeting.
No you didn‰Ûªt.
Yes we did, I just came from it.
Okay, I don‰Ûªt know where you just came from, but it couldn‰Ûªt have been a team meeting because I‰Ûªm on the team and I wasn‰Ûªt there, ergo the team did not meet.
Okay, let me try it this way, uh, I was at a coffee klatch with a couple of friends and one thing led to another and it turns out you‰Ûªre off the team.
Why?
Because you‰Ûªre taking all the fun out of it.
Well, I‰Ûªm sorry, is the winner of the physics bowl the team that has the most fun?
Okay, let me try it this way, you‰Ûªre annoying and no-one wants to play with you any more.

I see. Well. At this point I should inform you that I intend to form my own team and destroy the molecular bonds that bind your very matter together, and reduce the resulting particulate chaos to tears.
Thanks for the heads up.
You‰Ûªre welcome. One more thing.
Yes.
It‰Ûªs on, bitch.
The cafeteria.
So who‰Ûªd he get to be on his team.
He won‰Ûªt say. He just smiles, and eats macaroons out of his bat jar.

He‰Ûªs using psychological warfare. We must reply in kind. I say we wait until he looks at us, then laugh like, yes, you are a smart and strong competitor, but we are also smart and strong and we have a reasonable chance of defeating you.
How exactly would that laugh go?
Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee!
That sounds more like, we are a tall thin woman who wants to make a coat out of your Dalmatians.
Guys, let‰Ûªs remember that Sheldon is still our friend and my room mate.
So?
So nothing, let‰Ûªs destroy him.
Gentlemen.
Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee!
Okay, we‰Ûªre going to need a strong fourth for our team.
You know who‰Ûªs apparently very smart, is the girl who played TV‰Ûªs Blossom. She got a PhD in neuroscience or something.
Raj, we‰Ûªre not getting TV‰Ûªs Blossom to join our physics bowl team.
How about the girl from the Wonder Years?
Gentlemen, I believe I‰Ûªve found the solution to all our problems.
We can‰Ûªt ask Leslie Winkle.
Why? Because you slept together and when she was done with you she discarded you like last night‰Ûªs chutney?
Yes.
Sometimes you‰Ûªve got to take one for the team.
Yeah. Sack up, dude.
Fine. Here I go, taking one for the team. In the sack. Hey Leslie.
Hi guys.
Leslie, I have a question for you, and it might be a little awkward, you know, given that I‰Û_
Hit that thang.
Leonard, there‰Ûªs no reason to feel uncomfortable just because we‰Ûªve seen each other‰Ûªs faces and naked bodies contorted in the sweet agony of coitus.
There‰Ûªs not? Gee, cos it sure sounds like there should be.
Rest assured that any aspects of our sexual relationship regarding your preferences, your idiosyncrasies, your performance, are still protected by the inherent confidentiality of the bedroom.
That‰Ûªs all very comforting, but if it‰Ûªs okay, I‰Ûªd like to get on with my question now.
Proceed.
We are entering the physics bowl and we need a fourth for our team.
No thanks, I‰Ûªm really busy with my like sign dilepton super symmetry search.
Dilepton, schmilepton, we need you.
Sorry.
Well, we tried. Just have to face Sheldon mano-e-mano-e-mano. A-mano.
Wait, you‰Ûªre going up against Sheldon Cooper?
Yes.
That arrogant, misogynistic East-Texas doorknob that told me I should abandon my work with high energy particles for laundry and child bearing?
She‰Ûªs in.
The Physics Bowl.
So, how do you feel? Nice and loose? Come to play? Got your game face on? (The guys look confused.) Are you ready?
Oh, yeah. You know you don‰Ûªt have to stay for the whole thing.
Oh, no, no, I want to. It sounds really interesting.

character: Sheldon (entering in his Star Trek themed shirt)
line: Gentlemen.
Sheldon.
Sheldon.
Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee hee.
Sheldon. I‰Ûªm just going to sit down.
So, is that your team.

Actually, I don‰Ûªt need a team, I could easily defeat you single-handedly. But the rules require four, so may I introduce, the third floor janitor, he lady from the lunchroom, and, my Spanish is not good, either her son or her butcher. And what about your team? What rat have you recruited to the SS Sinking Ship?
Hello, Sheldon.
Leslie Winkle?
Yeah, Leslie Winkle. The answer to the question, who made Sheldon Cooper cry like a little girl?

Yes, well, I‰Ûªm polymerised tree sap and you‰Ûªre non-organic adhesive so, whatever verbal projectile you launch in my direction is reflected off of me, returns on its original trajectory, and adheres to you.
Oh, ouch.
Okay, if everyone could please take your seats.
Here‰Ûªs your tee-shirt. (Hands her a tee-shirt with PMS on it. Takes jacket off to reveal similar.)
PMS? It‰Ûªs a couple of days early, but‰Û_
No, it stands for Perpetual Motion Squad.
Oh, right, of course, what was I thinking?
Good afternoon everyone, and welcome to this year‰Ûªs physics bowl. Today‰Ûªs preliminary match features two great teams‰Û_ AA versus PMS.
All night long, y‰Ûªall! (Stands and turns round to reveal the back of the tee-shirt which reads ‰ÛÏWe Can Go All Night‰Û.)
Okay, well let‰Ûªs jump right in, first question, for ten points. What is the isospan singlet partner of the Pi Zero Meson? (Buzz) PMS?
The Eta Meson.
Correct.
Formal protest.
On what grounds?
The Velcro on my wrist brace caught on my shirt.
Denied. Alright, for ten points, what is the lightest element on earth with no stable isotope. (Buzz) AA?
And of course, the answer is Technetium.
Terrific. Next question, what is the force between two uncharged plates due to quantum vacuum fluctuation. (Buzz) PMS?
Sheldon can suck on, the Casimir Effect.
Correct.
How does a quantum computer factor large numbers. (Buzz) PMS?
Shor‰Ûªs Algorithm.
Correct.
4.1855 times ten to the seventh ergs per calorie.
Prevost‰Ûªs theory of exchanges.
Lamda equals one over Pi R squared N
760 degrees celsius, the approximate temperature of the young lady in the front row.
Mr Wolowitz, this is your second warning.
A sigma particle.
Yes, assuming the hypothetical planet has a mass greater than the earth.

Correct. Ladies and gentlemen, I hold in my hand the final question. The score now stands AA 1150, PMS 1175. So, for one hundred points, and the match, please turn your attention to the formula on the screens. Solve the equation.
Holy crap.
What the hell is that.
It looks like something they found on the ship at Roswell.
Come on, think, Leslie.
Leonard, it‰Ûªs not going to work if you rush me, you have to let me get there.
You‰Ûªre never going to let that go, are you?
Ten seconds. (Buzz) PMS.
Sorry, I panicked.
Then guess.
Um, eight. (Gablehouser stares at him.) Point four.
I‰Ûªm sorry, that‰Ûªs incorrect. AA, if you can answer correctly, the match is yours.
He doesn‰Ûªt have it. He‰Ûªs got squat.
AA, I need your answer. (Buzz)
The answer is minus eight by alpha.
Hang on, hang on a second, that‰Ûªs not our answer. What are you doing?
Answering question. Winning physics bowl.
How do you know anything about physics?
Here I am janitor, in former Soviet Union I am physicist. Leningrad Politechnica. Go Polar Bears.
Well that‰Ûªs a delightful little story, but our arrangement was that you sit here and not say anything, I answer the questions.
You didn‰Ûªt answer question.
Hey look, now maybe you have democracy now in your beloved Russia, but on this physics bowl team I rule with an iron fist. (Makes fist in the air). Ow!
AA, I need your official answer.
Well it‰Ûªs not what he said.
Then what is it?
I want a different question.
You can‰Ûªt have a different question.
Formal protest.
Denied.
Informal protest.
Denied. I need your official answer.
No. I decline to provide one.
Well, that‰Ûªs too bad, because the answer your teammate gave was correct.
That‰Ûªs your opinion.
Alright, the winner of the match is‰Û_
Hang on. Sheldon, is proving that you are single-handedly smarter than everyone else so important that you would rather lose by yourself than win as part of a team.
I don‰Ûªt understand the question.
Go ahead.
The winner is PMS!
The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Sorry, somebody‰Ûªs sitting there.
Who?
My Physics Bowl Trophy!
That trophy is meaningless, I forfeited, therefore you did not win.
I know someone who would disagree.
Who?
My Physics Bowl Trophy! (In weird voice) ‰ÛÏLeonard is so smart, Sheldon who?‰Û
Alright that is very immature.
You‰Ûªre right, I‰Ûªm sorry. (In voice, waving trophy in Sheldon‰Ûªs face) I‰Ûªm not!
Okay, new contest.
What are you doing?
I‰Ûªm settling once and for all who is the smartest around here. Okay, are you ready?
Absolutely.
Bring it on.
Okay. Marsha, Jan and Cindy were the three daughters of what TV family? (They stare at her.) The Brady Bunch. Okay, Sammy Hagar replaced David Lee Roth as the lead singer in what group?

character: Sheldon (after they look at each other in confusion)
line: The Brady Bunch?
Van Halen. Alright, Madonna was married to this Ridgemont High alum. (Pause) Oh my God, Sean Penn!
How do you know these things?
I go outside and I talk to people. Alright, here, what actor holds the record for being named people magazine‰Ûªs sexiest man alive?
William Shatner.
Wait, I don‰Ûªt think it‰Ûªs Shatner.
Then it‰Ûªs got to be Patrick Stewart.
No.
Formal protest.
Alright, singer who sang ‰ÛÏOops I Did It Again.‰Û (Sheldon starts involuntarily twitching again.) Okay, Tweetie Bird, taught he taw a what?

character: Sheldon (after they pass a smug look between each other)
line: Romulan.
Yes. He taught he taw a Romulan.
The apartment.
Well, this sandwich is an unmitigated disaster. I asked for turkey and roast beef with lettuce and swiss on wholewheat.
What did they give you?

Turkey and roast beef with swiss and lettuce on wholewheat. It‰Ûªs the right ingredients but in the wrong order. In a proper sandwich the cheese is adjacent to the bread to create a moisture barrier against the lettuce. They might as well have dragged this thing through a car wash.
I don‰Ûªt believe it.
I know, it‰Ûªs basic culinary science.
Some guy is auctioning off a miniature time machine prop from the original film and no-one is bidding on it.
A time machine from the movie The Time Machine?
No, a time machine from Sophie‰Ûªs Choice.
Boy, Sophie could have used a time machine in that movie. Did you see it, it‰Ûªs rough.
Oh, that‰Ûªs cool.
Uh-huh.
It‰Ûªs only $800?
Yeah. And that‰Ûªs my bid.
You bid $800.
It was a spur of the moment thing, I figured it would go for thousands and I just wanted to be a part of it.
There‰Ûªs only 30 seconds left in the auction.
Do you have $800?
Not to blow on a miniature time machine.
Don‰Ûªt worry, the way these things work there‰Ûªs people waiting ‰Û÷til the last second to bid, and then they swoop in and get it, it‰Ûªs called sniping.
Fifteen seconds.
Come on, snipers.
Ten, nine, eight‰Û_
Where are your snipers?
Five.
Snipe.
Four.
Snipe.
Three.
Snipe!
Two.
SNIPE!
One.
Aaaa-aw!
Congratulations, you are the proud owner of a miniature time machine.
You lucky duck.
I wonder why no-one else bid, this is a classic piece of sci-fi movie memorabilia.
Yeah, I know, I still can‰Ûªt afford it.
Why don‰Ûªt we share it? We‰Ûªll each put in two hundred bucks and we‰Ûªll take turns having it in our homes.
A time share time machine? I‰Ûªm in. Sheldon?
Need you ask? But I still don‰Ûªt understand why no-one else bid.
The lobby. The guys stand around a full sized time machine.
I understand why no-one else bid.
The same
Did the listing actually say miniature?
I just assumed. Who sells a full sized time machine for $800?
In a venn diagram, that would be an individual located within the intersection of the sets ‰ÛÏno longer want my time machine‰Û and ‰ÛÏneed $800‰Û.
It‰Ûªs actually a tremendous bargain, even with shipping it works out to less than four dollars a pound.
Cocktain shrimp are $12.50.
How are we going to get it upstairs?
If we take the dish off it might fit in the elevator.
Yes but the elevator‰Ûªs been broken for two years.
I‰Ûªve been meaning to ask you, do you think we should make a call about that?

Not necessary, I have a masters in engineering, I remotely repair satellites on a regular basis. I troubleshoot space shuttle payloads. When the Mars rover started pulling to the left I performed a front end alignment from 62 million miles away. (Presses lift button. Nothing happens.) No, that baby‰Ûªs broken.
The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Come on, guys, push.
If I push any harder I‰Ûªm going to give birth to my colon.
I can‰Ûªt feel my fingers, hurry up.
It‰Ûªs the same amount of work no matter how fast you go, basic physics.
Sheldon?
Yeah.
If my fingers ever work again, I‰Ûªve got a job for the middle one.
Oh, hey guys.

character: Leonard (letting go of time machine, as does Sheldon)
line: Uh, hi Penny. (Raj and Howard are heard to scream as the time machine slides back down the stairs.) Take a break, guys!
What are you doing?
Oh, just, you know, moving‰Û_ something upstairs.
What is it?
It‰Ûªs‰Û_ you know, time machine.
Yeah, okay, neat, but I really got to get to work, so‰Û_.
Uh, just give us a few minutes.
I don‰Ûªt have a few minutes, I‰Ûªm running really late.
Then I have a simple solution, go up to the roof, hop over to the next building, there‰Ûªs a small gap, don‰Ûªt look down if you‰Ûªre subject to vertigo, and use their stairwell.
You‰Ûªre joking, right?
Oh, I never joke when it comes to vertigo.
Damn, okay, I‰Ûªll just take the roof.
Hey, if you wait for us to set up the time machine, I can drop you off at work yesterday. Time travel joke, it‰Ûªs not‰Û_ never mind.
For what it‰Ûªs worth, I thought it was humorous.
Let‰Ûªs just do this. Guys, ready to push?
In a minute. Howard stepped outside to throw up.
The living room. The time machine is set up.
I don‰Ûªt know what you were worried about. I think it really works in the room.
Yeah. It is by far the coolest thing I have ever owned.

The exact time machine that carried actor Rod Taylor from Victorian England into the post-apocalyptic future, which society had splintered into two factions, the sub-terranean Morlocks, who survived by feasting on the flesh of the gentle surface dwelling Eloy.
Talk about your chick magnets.

Oh yeah. The guy who lives next to me is always like, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony. But wait until I tell him, I‰Ûªve got a time machine on my balcony. Stuff that in your speedos, Jacuzzi Bob!
Gentlemen, I know we said we‰Ûªd take turns, but I think you‰Ûªd agree that practicality dictates it remain here.
You can‰Ûªt just keep it here, what if I meet a girl and say, ‰ÛÏyou wanna come up and see my time machine, it‰Ûªs at my friends house,‰Û how lame is that?
He‰Ûªs got a point.

Alright, I think we‰Ûªre going to need some ground rules, in addition to the expected no shoes in the time machine and no eating in the time machine, I propose that we add pants must be worn at all times in the time machine.
Seconded.
I was going to put down a towel.
I still want it on my balcony. I say we move it on a bi-monthly basis.
That sounds fair.
Hold on. Bi-monthly is an ambiguous term, do you mean move it every other month, or twice a month?
Twice a month.
Then no.
Okay, every other month.
No.

Sheldon, you can‰Ûªt be selfish, we all paid for it, so it belongs to all of us. Now out of the way so I can sit in my time machine. (Sits and turns it on. The three lights on the front illuminate. All let out an ‰ÛÏoh‰Û.) Okay, I am setting the dials for March 10th, 1876.
Good choice, Alexander Graham Bell invents the telephone and calls out for Dr Watson.
Wait a minute, I‰Ûªd want to see that too.
So, when it‰Ûªs your turn you can.
But if we all go back to the same point in time, Bell‰Ûªs lab is going to get very crowded, he‰Ûªll know something‰Ûªs up.
Also, since the time machine doesn‰Ûªt move in space, you‰Ûªll end up in 1876 Pasadena.
And even if you can make it to Boston, what are you going to do, knock on the door and say to Mrs Bell, ‰ÛÏhey Mrs Bell, big fan of your husband, can I come in and watch him invent the telephone?‰Û
Mrs Bell was deaf, she‰Ûªs not even going to hear you knock.
Oh, I have a solution, first go into the future and obtain a cloaking device.
Ooh, how far into the future?
If I remember correctly, Captain Kirk will steal a cloaking device from the Romulans on Stardate 5027.3, which will be January 10th 2328 by pre-federation reckoning.

Okay, I am setting the dials for January 10th, 2328. Here we go into the future. (Pulls lever, the disk begins to spin. The other guys all run around the flat as if moving in fast motion.) That was fun.
My turn.
Okay, first of all, what you call a gap was nearly three feet wide, I slipped and skinned my knee.
Are you okay?

Zzz-zz-zz-zz! Second of all, the door to the stairwell of the other building was locked, so I had to go down the fire escape which ends on the third floor, forcing me to crawl through the window of a lovely Armenian family, who insisted I stay for lunch.
That doesn‰Ûªt sound too bad.
It was eight courses of lamb, and they tried to fix me up with their son.
Sorry.
Not done. By the time I finally got to work, they‰Ûªd given my shift away. Yeah, that‰Ûªs right, I‰Ûªve lost an entire day‰Ûªs pay thanks to this‰Û_ this‰Û_
Time machine.
The lights flash and the dish spins, you wanna try it?
No! I don‰Ûªt want to try it, my God, you are grown men, how could you waste your lives with these stupid toys and costumes and comic books and‰Û_ and now that‰Û_ that‰Û_
Again, time machine.
Oh please, it‰Ûªs not a time machine, if anything it looks like something Elton John would drive through the Everglades.
It only moves in time. It would be worse than useless in a swamp.
Pathetic. All of you, completely pathetic. (Storms out. A beat, and then‰Û_)
My turn!
Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Leonard, it‰Ûªs two in the morning.
So?
So it‰Ûªs my turn. Why did you set it for the day before yesterday?
Because I want to go back and keep myself from getting a time machine.

You can‰Ûªt. If you were to prevent yourself from buying it in the past, you would not have it available in the present to travel back and stop yourself from buying it, ergo you would still have it. This is a classic rookie time travel mistake.
Can I go back and prevent you from explaining that to me?
Same paradox. If you were to travel back in time and, say, knock me unconscious, you would not then have the conversation that irritated you, motivating you to go back and knock me unconscious.
What if I knocked you unconscious right now?
It won‰Ûªt change the past.
But it would make the present so much nicer.
Are you upset about something?
What was your first clue?
Well, it was a number of things. First the late hour, then your demeanour seems very low energy, plus your irritability‰Û_
Yes I‰Ûªm upset.
Oh! I don‰Ûªt usually pick up on those things. Good for me.
Yeah, good for you.
Oh, wait. Did you want to talk about what‰Ûªs bothering you?
I don‰Ûªt know. Maybe.
Wow, I‰Ûªm on fire tonight.
Uh, here‰Ûªs the thing. Girls like Penny never end up with guys who own time machines.
I disagree. Your inability to successfully woo Penny long predates your acquisition of the time machine. That failure clearly stands on its own.
Thanks for pointing it out.

In addition, your premise is flawed. In the original film, Rod Taylor got Yvette Mimeaux with that very time machine. In Back to the Future, Marty McFly got the opportunity to hook up with his extremely attractive young mother.
Those are movies.
Well of course they‰Ûªre movies. Were you expecting me to come up with an example involving a real life time machine? That‰Ûªs absurd.
The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Come on, guys, push.
If I push any harder I‰Ûªm going to give birth to my colon.
Oh, hey guys.

character: Leonard (letting go of time machine, as does Sheldon)
line: Uh, hi Penny. (Raj and Howard are heard to scream as the time machine slides back down the stairs.) Take a break, guys!
What are you doing?
Oh, just, you know, moving a‰Û_ time machine.
Yeah, okay, neat, but I really got to get to work, so‰Û_.
No problem. (Removes glasses, pulls down out of order tape from lift doors, and forces them open.) Hang on. (Takes Penny in his arms as he holds onto the lift cable.)
But, what about your time machine.
Some things are more important than toys. (She puts her arms around his neck as he dangles from the cable.)
Oh, I‰Ûªm scared.
Don‰Ûªt worry baby, I‰Ûªve got you.
Oh, Leonard. (Kisses him as they descend from view. Leonard wakes up still sitting in the time machine.)
It‰Ûªs still my turn.
The living room.
What are you doing?
I‰Ûªm packing up all my collectibles and taking them down to the comic book store to sell.
Well is that really necessary. If you need money you can always sell blood. And semen.
It‰Ûªs not about money.
We brought food.
Lox and bagels, the breakfast of time travellers.
Terrific, does anyone want to buy my share of the time machine?
Why?
Because I don‰Ûªt want it any more.
Why?
Just‰Û_ personal reasons.
My spidey-sense tells me this has something to do with Penny.
Look, do you want to buy me out or not?
I‰Ûªll give you a hundred dollars, which will make me half owner, and we‰Ûªll put it on my balcony.
Screw his balcony, I‰Ûªll give you a hundred and twenty and we‰Ûªll put it in my garage.
I paid two hundred dollars for my share.
Dude, everyone knows a time machine loses half its value the minute you drive it off the lot.
I‰Ûªll go for two hundred, that time machine stays right where it is.
Three hundred, and I‰Ûªll throw in my original 1979 Mattel Millenium Falcon with real light speed sound effects.
No, no more toys or action figures or props or replicas or costumes or robots or Darth Vader voice changers, I‰Ûªm getting rid of all of it.
You can‰Ûªt do that, look what you‰Ûªve created here, it‰Ûªs like nerdvana.
More importantly, you‰Ûªve a Darth Vader voice changer?
Not for long.
Oh, I call dibs on the Golden Age Flash.
Hang on, I need that to complete my Justice Society of America collection.
Too bad, I called dibs.
Well you can‰Ûªt just call dibs.
I can and I did, look up dibs on Wikipedia.
Dibs doesn‰Ûªt apply in a bidding war.
It‰Ûªs not a bidding war, I‰Ûªm selling it all to Larry down at the comic book store.
Why Larry? Did Larry call dibs?
Will you forget dibs!
He offered me a fair price for the whole collection.
What‰Ûªs the number, I‰Ûªll match it.
I‰Ûªll match it, plus a thousand rupees.
What‰Ûªs the exchange rate.
None of your business. Take it or leave it.
Mom, my bar-mizvah bonds, how much do I got? Thanks. I can go twenty six hundred dollars and two trees in Israel.
Forget it guys, if I sell to one of you, the other two are going to be really mad at me.
Who cares, as long as you pick me.
Okay, Leonard, put down the box, let‰Ûªs talk.
Sorry Raj, my mind is made up.
No. I can‰Ûªt let you do this.
Sheldon, get out of my way.

character: Sheldon (brandishing toy sword from Leonard‰Ûªs box)
line: None shall pass.
Okay man, be cool, we‰Ûªre all friends here.
What the hell‰Ûªs going on?
You hypocrite!
What?

Little Miss ‰ÛÏgrown ups don‰Ûªt play with toys‰Û. If I were to go into that apartment right now, would I find Beanie Babies? Are you not an accumulator of Care Bears and My Little Ponies? And who is that Japanese feline I see frolicking on your shorts? Hello,Hello Kitty!
Okay, okay look, if this is about yesterday, Leonard, I am really sorry about what I said, I was just a bit upset.
No, I needed to hear it.
No you didn‰Ûªt. Look, you are a great guy, and it is things you love that make you who you are.
I guess that makes me large breasts.
Still, I think it‰Ûªs time for me to get rid of this stuff and‰Û_ you know‰Û_ move on with my life.
Really?
Yeah.
Oh. Wow. Good for you. (Kisses his cheek.)
Thanks. Hey, do you want to, I don‰Ûªt know, later‰Û_

character: Good looking man coming up stairs
line: Excuse me. Hey, Penny!
Hi Mike.
Are you ready to go.
Yeah, I just have to change.
I‰Ûªll give you a hand.
Oh, stop it! Bye guys.
My turn on the time machine.
A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.

It worked. It really worked. They said I was mad, but it worked. (Large hairy creatures with glowing eyes emerge from the forest and walk towards him menacingly.) Oh no, not Morlocks! Not flesh-eating Morlocks! He-e-e-e-e-e-e-elp! (With a yelp, he wakes up in the time machine in the living room.)
Sheldon, are you okay?
We have to get rid of the time machine.
It is a little big for the living room, isn‰Ûªt it?
Yeah, that‰Ûªs the problem, it‰Ûªs too big.
I‰Ûªm glad you agree. I hired some guys to help us move it, come on in fellas. (A pair of Morlocks come through the door.)
Oh no, Morlocks? Eat him, eat him. Aaaaargh. (Sheldon wakes up in his own bed.) Leonard!!!!!!!!
A corridor at the University.
On the other hand, some physicists are concerned that if the super collider actually works, it will create a black hole and swallow up the Earth ending life as we know it.
Psh, what a bunch of crybabies. No guts, no glory man.

character: Leonard (looking at an orange notice on the noticeboard)
line: Hey, check it out, the school of pharmacology is looking for volunteers.
We are testing a new medication for social anxiety, panic attacks, agoraphobia and obsessive compulsive disorder. Why would they be looking for test subjects here?
I don‰Ûªt know, Raj. Maybe the comic book store doesn‰Ûªt have a bulletin board. (Sees crowds in the corridor) What‰Ûªs going on?
Shhh! Hot girl in Sheldon‰Ûªs office.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office? Is she lost?
Don‰Ûªt think so. I followed her here from the parking lot.
Maybe she‰Ûªs his lawyer.
Well she‰Ûªs free to examine my briefs.
Howard‰Û_
I know, I‰Ûªm disgusting, I should be punished. By her, oh look, I did it again.
Well, that should do it.
Thank you for coming by. (He rises from his desk. Everyone rushes to look nonchalant.) Hello.
Oh, hey buddy.
Buddy.
Sorry I‰Ûªm late, I‰Ûªm working on a project that may take me up on the next space shuttle.
How can you be late, I wasn‰Ûªt expecting you at all.
Nobody ever expects me, sometimes you just look and‰Û_ BAM! (shakes girl‰Ûªs hand) Howard Wolowitz.
Sheldon, are you going to introduce us?
Oh, alright, this is Missy, Missy this is Leonard and Rajesh and you‰Ûªve already met Howard.
It‰Ûªs nice to meet you.
You too, swell, also.
Yeah.
So, how do you two know each other.
Oh, he once spent nine months with my legs wrapped around his head.
Excuse me?
She‰Ûªs my twin sister, she thinks she‰Ûªs funny but frankly I‰Ûªve never been able to see it.
It‰Ûªs because you have no measurable sense of humour, Shelly.
How exactly would one measure a sense of humour? A humourmometer?
Well, I think you‰Ûªre delightfully droll. Or as the French say, Tres Drole.

Okay, so let me see if I got this. Leonard, Howard and‰Û_ I‰Ûªm sorry what was your name again. (Raj looks uncomfortable, turns and walks away, disappears round corner. He then reappears, takes the orange paper from the noticeboard and leaves again.)
Rajesh.
The same.
So Missy, what brings you all the way from Texas?
Was it perhaps destiny, I think it was destiny.
My friend‰Ûªs getting married in Disneyland tomorrow night.
Destiny, thy name is Anaheim.
And I had to drop off some papers for Shelly to sign for my dad‰Ûªs estate.
The papers could have been mailed, Mom just sent you here to spy on me, didn‰Ûªt she.
I guess that‰Ûªs why they call you a genius.
They call me a genius because I‰Ûªm a genius. Tell Mom that I currently weigh 165 pounds, and that I‰Ûªm having regular bowel movements. Enjoy the wedding, goodbye.
Woah, woah.
If the wedding‰Ûªs not until tomorrow, why don‰Ûªt you stay with us tonight?
Oh, I don‰Ûªt think so. Shelly doesn‰Ûªt like company. Even as a little boy he‰Ûªd send his imaginary friends home at the end of the day.
They were not friends, they were imaginary colleagues.
Look, you‰Ûªre here, we have plenty of room.
No we don‰Ûªt.
Come on, Shelly, she‰Ûªs family.
So what? I don‰Ûªt issue invitations to your mother.
Well it would be nice not to have to drive out to Anaheim in rush hour.
And don‰Ûªt ever call me Shelly.
So it‰Ûªs settled. You‰Ûªll stay with us.
I‰Ûªll walk you to your car. You‰Ûªre in structure 3 level C, right?
What just happened?
The apartment.
So anyway, we‰Ûªre eight years old, and Sheldon converts my easy-bake oven to some kind of high-powered furnace.
Hee-hee, just classic.
I needed a place to fire ceramic semi-conductor substrates for home-made integrated circuits.
He was trying to build some kind of armed robot to keep me out of his room.
Made necessary by her insistence on going into my room.
Anyway, I go to make those little corn muffins they give you, there‰Ûªs a big flash, next thing you know my eyebrows are gone.
Ha-ha, not your eyebrows?
Yep. I had to go through the entire second grade with crooked eyebrows my Mom drew on.
Is that what that was? I just assumed that the second grade curriculum had rendered you quizzical.

character: Penny (knocking and entering, holding up a pair of superman undershorts.)
line: Hey, Leonard, you left your underwear in the dryer downstairs.
Those are not mine.
Really, they have your little name label in them.

Yeah, no, I do, I use those‰Û_ uh‰Û_ just to polish up my‰Û_ spear-fishing equipment. I spear fish. When I‰Ûªm not crossbow hunting, I spear fish. Uh, Penny, this is Sheldon‰Ûªs twin sister, Missy. Missy, this is our neighbour Penny.
Hi.
Wow, you don‰Ûªt look that much alike.
Can I get a hallelujah.
Fraternal twins come from two separate eggs, they are no more alike than any other siblings.
Hallelujah.
Hey, guess what. I‰Ûªve been accepted as a test subject for a new miracle drug to overcome pathological shyness.
Hey, good for you, Raj.
Yes, I‰Ûªm very hopeful. Hello Missy. (He waves his hand. It keeps waving.) They mentioned there may be side effects.
The same, later.
So, Missy. Have you ever met a man from the exotic subcontinent of India?
Well, there‰Ûªs Dr Patel at our church.
Ah yes, Dr Patel, good man.
Do you like motorcycles, ‰Û÷cos I ride a hog.
A hog? You have a two cylinder scooter with a basket on the front.
You still have to wear a helmet.
Have you ever heard of the Kama Sutra?
The sex book?
The Indian sex book. In other words if you wonder wonder who wrote the book of love, it was us.
Hey, Sheldon‰Ûªs sister‰Ûªs pretty cute, I w‰Û_.
I wasn‰Ûªt staring!
I didn‰Ûªt say you were, I just said she was cute.
Oh. Huh, um, maybe, if you like women who are tall‰Û_ and perfect.
Sheldon, why are you ignoring your sister?
I‰Ûªm not ignoring my sister. I‰Ûªm ignoring all of you.
I brought snacks.
Oh my! Gherkins and‰Û_.
Onion dip, it‰Ûªs onion dip.
Oh.
We don‰Ûªt entertain much.
Missy, do you enjoy pajamas?
I guess.
We Indians invented them. You‰Ûªre welcome.
Yeah, well my people invented circumcision. You‰Ûªre welcome!
Missy, I‰Ûªm going to go get my nails done. Do you want to come?
God yes. Thanks.
You‰Ûªre welcome.
Bye guys.
Bye Missy.
Bye Missy, see you.
Goodbye Leonard!
Uh, yeah, no, uh, bye Penny.
Okay, you two have to back off.
Why should I back off, you back off dude.
Excuse me, this is my apartment and she‰Ûªs my roommate‰Ûªs sister.
So what, you‰Ûªve already got Penny.
How do I have Penny? In what universe do I have Penny?
So I can have Penny?
Hell, no!
Excuse me, can I interject something. I‰Ûªm ordering pizza online, is everyone okay with pepperoni?
Sheldon, can I talk to you in private?
I guess. Don‰Ûªt worry, I was going to order you cheeseless.
Thank you.
That‰Ûªs okay. Lactose intolerance is nothing to be embarrassed about.
I‰Ûªm a fancy Indian man, we invented pajamas!
Hey, look at me, I don‰Ûªt have a foreskin.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Sheldon, are you aware that your sister is an incredibly attractive woman?

Hmmm? She certainly has the symmetry and low body fat that western culture deems desirable. It‰Ûªs noteworth that at other points in history, heavier women were the standard for beauty because their girth suggested affluence.
That‰Ûªs fascinating, but I‰Û_
I didn‰Ûªt say it was fascinating, I said it was noteworthy.
Alright, noted. But my point is that Koothrappali and Wolowitz‰Û_ they‰Ûªre hitting on your sister.
Oh. Okay. You know, I don‰Ûªt want to criticise your rhetorical style but, we‰Ûªd be a lot further along in this conversation if you‰Ûªd begun with that thought.
That‰Ûªs great, but I‰Û_.
What I‰Ûªm saying is that we took quite an unnecessary detour from what I now understand to be your thesis.
Whatever. You have to do something about it.
Why?
Because she‰Ûªs your sister.
I don‰Ûªt understand. Yes, we shared a uterus for nine months, but since then we‰Ûªve pretty much gone our own separate ways.
Okay, uh‰Û_. oh, consider this. With your father gone, it is your responsibility to make sure that Missy chooses a suitable mate.
I hadn‰Ûªt considered that. We do share DNA.
Uh-huh.
So there is the possibility, however remote, that resting in her loins is the potential for another individual as remarkable as myself.
Exactly. And, you owe it to yourself and to posterity to protect the genetic integrity of your sister‰Ûªs future offspring.
You‰Ûªre right. If someone wants to get at Missy‰Ûªs fallopian tubes, they‰Ûªll have to go through me.
The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
I am Shiva the destroyer, I will have the woman!
I‰Ûªm warning you, I was judo champion at math camp.
Alright, that‰Ûªs enough juvenile squabbling, stop it, stop it I say. I‰Ûªm going to settle this right now. Neither of you are good enough for my sister.
Who are you to decide that?
He‰Ûªs the man of his family, you have to respect his wishes.
You‰Ûªre out too, by the way.
Say what?
It‰Ûªs nothing personal, I‰Ûªd just prefer if my future niece or nephew didn‰Ûªt become flatulent every time they eat an Eskimo pie.
What are you so happy about?
I‰Ûªm not happy, it‰Ûªs the medication, I can‰Ûªt stop smiling. (Waves hand at mouth. It keeps waving.)
Now that Leonard‰Ûªs made me aware of how high the genetic stakes are, we have to face the fact that none of you are suitable mates for my sister.
Wait a minute. Leonard made you aware of that?
We all make mistakes, let‰Ûªs move on.
Excuse me, but I think you‰Ûªre missing a big opportunity here.
How so?
Everybody knows genetic diversity produces the strongest offspring. Why not put a little mocha in the family latte.
In principle you have a point, but as a practical matter, need I remind you that it takes experimental pharmaceuticals to simply enable you to speak to the opposite sex.
I think you‰Ûªre focussing entirely too much on the drugs. (Finger keeps waving. Leonard has to reach out and stop it.)
Is it ‰Û÷cause I‰Ûªm Jewish, ‰Û÷cause I‰Ûªd kill my Rabbi with a porkchop to be with your sister.
This has nothing to do with religion. This has to do with the fact that you‰Ûªre a tiny, tiny man who still lives with his mother.
Sheldon, you are really being unreasonable.
Am I? Here. Eat this cheese without farting and you can sleep with my sister.
Oh really?
Oops.
Shelly, can I speak to you for a minute? Alone?
Why does everyone suddenly want to talk to me alone? Usually nobody wants to be alone with me. åÊåÊ

character: Leonard (to Penny who is standing next to him grinning)
line: We all make mistakes, let‰Ûªs move on.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Okay. I‰Ûªm not even going to ask why you‰Ûªre pimping me out for cheese. But since when do you care at all about who I sleep with?
Truthfully, I‰Ûªve never given it any thought, but it has been pointed out to me that you carry DNA of great potential.
What on earth are you talking about?
Let me explain. You see, I‰Ûªm a superior genetic mutation, an improvement on the existing mediocre stock.
And what do you mean, mediocre stock?
That would be you. But residing within you is the potential for another me. Perhaps even taller, smarter and less prone to freckling, a Sheldon 2.0 if you will.
Sheldon 2.0?
Exactly. Now, I am not saying that I should be the sole decider of who you mate with. If you‰Ûªre not attracted to the suitor then the likelihood of conception would be reduced.
You have got to be kidding me!
Not at all. Frequent coitus dramatically increases the odds of fertiliziation.
Okay Shelly, sit down. Now I‰Ûªve lived my whole life dealing with the fact that my twin brother is, as Mom puts it, one of God‰Ûªs special little people.

I always thought I was more like a cuckoo bird. You know, a superior creature whose egg is placed in the nest of ordinary birds. Of course the newly hatched cuckoo eats all the food, leaving the ordinary siblings to starve to death. Luckily for you, that‰Ûªs where the metaphor ended.

I thought it ended at cuckoo. Now you listen to me, if you want to start acting like a brother who cares about me, then terrific. Bring it on. But you try one time to tell me who I should be sleeping with, and you and I are going to go round and round the way we did when we were little. Remember? (Sheldon hurriedly crosses his legs.)
I have an alternate proposal.
Go on.
You donate eggs. We will place them in cryogenic storage. I will find an appropriate sperm donor for your eggs, have them fertilized and implanted in you, that way everybody wins.
The living room. Sheldon enters limping, holding his groin area.
Correction. Missy can date whoever she wants.
The same, later.
Look, we have to settle this.
I agree. Sheldon‰Ûªs sister is hiding at Penny‰Ûªs because we‰Ûªve all been hitting on her at the same time.
She‰Ûªs not hiding. She needed privacy to call her grandmother who‰Ûªs apparently very sick. Oh, and then I believe she has to wash her hair.
Oh, you poor, deluded bastard.
Don‰Ûªt start with me dude.
You want to go again? Let‰Ûªs go.
Sit down.
Okay.
If we‰Ûªre going to fight over Missy, let‰Ûªs do it the right way. The honourable way.
And he‰Ûªs down!
Come on, come on, get up.
Stay down, bitch. Yeah, ha ha, natural selection at work.
I weep for humanity.
Excuse me while I go tell Missy the good news. (Leaves and knocks on Penny‰Ûªs door.)
Ah, hey Leonard.
Hi Penny, how‰Ûªs it going. Listen, that guy Mike that you were dating, is that still going on?
Uh, pretty much, why?
Nothing, just catching up. By the way, may I speak to Missy please?
Of course.
Hi, Leonard, what‰Ûªs up?
Well, since you‰Ûªre leaving tomorrow I was wondering if you‰Ûªd like to go out to dinner with me?
That‰Ûªs so sweet. But no thanks.
Oh. You have other plans, or‰Û_?
No.
Oh. Alright uh‰Û_ enjoy the rest of your evening.
Thanks. See you.
Um, here‰Ûªs something we didn‰Ûªt anticipate.
What do you want, Howard?
I‰Ûªm fine, thanks for asking. I‰Ûªve come to call on Missy.
Missy?
Hi Howard.
The amazing Howard. Do you like magic?
Not really. No.

Then you are in for a treat. Behold, an ordinary cane. (Taps against doorpost. While humming he tries to perform a trick, but the cane falls in half with a yellow handkerchief flying out. Howard has to retrieve the pieces.) Da-dah! (Emerges with the handkerchief, on which are written the words ‰ÛÏwill you go out with me?‰Û)
No.
Okay. (Does something with hands, from which another yellow handkerchief emerges. This one reads ‰ÛÏare you sure?‰Û Missy closes the door.)
Missy?
Thank you. I apprec‰Û_. (looks panicked) apprec‰Û_. appreeee‰Û_. oh-oh.
Oh, honey, is your medication wearing off?åÊ (Raj nods.)
Oh, hi, cutie pie. I was hoping you‰Ûªd show up.
We had a dog who made a noise like that. Had to put him down.
The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Any news you want me to pass along to Mom?
Well, she might be interested to know that I have refocused my research from bosonic string theory to heteronic string theory.
Yeah, I‰Ûªll just tell her you said hey.
Okay, well, it was pleasant seeing you, other than that business with my testicles. (Holds out hand to shake.)
Come on, Shelly. (Hugs him. He looks uncomfortable, then hugs back half heartedly.) I want you to know I‰Ûªm very proud of you.
Really?
Yup, I‰Ûªm always bragging to my friends about my brother the rocket scientist.
You tell people I‰Ûªm a rocket scientist?
Well yeah.
I‰Ûªm a theoretical physicist.
What‰Ûªs the difference?
What‰Ûªs the difference?
Goodbye Shelly.
My God! Why don‰Ûªt you just tell them I‰Ûªm a toll taker at the Golden Gate Bridge? Rocket scientist, how humiliating.
The Cheesecake Factory. Raj and Sheldon are arm wrestling while playing tetris. There is a cacophony of cries such as ‰ÛÏtake him down‰Û and ‰ÛÏhe‰Ûªs got you, Sheldon.‰Û
Hey, guys, guys, some of the other waitresses wanted me to ask you something.
Oh, it‰Ûªs called trestling.
It combines the physical strength of arm wrestling with the mental agility of tetris into the ultimate sport.

Yeah, that‰Ûªs terrific, but what they wanted me to ask you was to cut it the hell out. (To someone off) Right come on guys, come on. (Singing while approaching another table) Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you‰Û_
We might as well stop, it‰Ûªs a stalemate. You‰Ûªre beating me in tetris, but you‰Ûªve got the upper body strength of a Keebler Elf.
Keebler Elf? I‰Ûªve got your Keebler Elf right here. (Strains to push Sheldon‰Ûªs arm down. Tries using both hands, still with no effect.) Okay, it‰Ûªs a stalemate.
So Leonard, will we be seeing you on Saturday for your free birthday cheesecake?
He can‰Ûªt eat cheesecake, he‰Ûªs lactose intolerant.
Okay, he can have carrot cake.
What about the cream cheese frosting.
he can scrape it off.
Forget about the cake, how did you know that my birthday is Saturday?
I did your horoscope, remember, I was going to do everybody‰Ûªs until Sheldon went on one of his typical psychotic rants.

For the record, that psychotic rant was a concise summation of the research of Bertram Forer, who in 1948 proved conclusively through meticulously designed experiments, that astrology is nothing but pseudo scientific hokum.
Blah blah blah, a typical Taurus. So, seriously, are we going to see you Saturday?
Oh, I don‰Ûªt think so.
Why not?
I don‰Ûªt celebrate my birthday.
Shuddup, yeah you do.
No, it‰Ûªs no big deal, it‰Ûªs just the way I was raised. My parents focussed on celebrating achievements, and being expelled from a birth canal was not considered one of them.
Uh, that‰Ûªs so silly.
It‰Ûªs actually based on very sound theories, his mother published a paper on it.
What was it called, ‰ÛÏI hate my son and that‰Ûªs why he can‰Ûªt have cake?‰Û
