What right do you have to pick who I can have children with?
Look, Rajesh, I understand, you‰Ûªre in America, you want to try the local cuisine. But trust me, you don‰Ûªt want it for a steady diet.
Now you listen to me, I am no longer a child, and I will not be spoken to like one. Now if you‰Ûªd excuse me, I have to go throw up.
What‰Ûªs wrong with him?

I don‰Ûªt know, maybe it‰Ûªs the local cuisine. Okay, well, it‰Ûªs nice to meet you, just gonna set you on down over here, and I‰Ûªm going to leave so, Namaste. (Leaves, then almost immediately returns) And FYI, you‰Ûªd be lucky to have me as a daughter-in-law.
She‰Ûªs feisty. I like that.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. She is in her bathrobe. A note slides under the door.

character: Penny (opening door to find Raj outside)
line: Raj, what are you doing. (He hands her the note). No. No notes. If you have something to say to me, say it.

character: Raj (tries several times. Finally, in a high pitched squeak)
line: Sorry.

Oh, sweetie, it‰Ûªs okay. (She hugs him. As she does, Leonard exits his apartment to see Penny, in bathrobe, hugging Raj who is apparently about to leave. As she goes back inside, Raj turns, smiles, and puts both thumbs up. Leonard turns, with an upset look, to Sheldon who is standing behind him. Sheldon gives him his exaggerated smile.)
The apartment. Leonard enters, drops his keys in the bowl by the door, then collapses onto the settee. Sheldon enters from the bedroom area.
Good morning, Leonard.
Uh-huh.

Yeah, we‰Ûªre going to have to stop by Pottery Barn on the way to work, I bought these Star Wars sheets but they turned out to be much too stimulating to be compatible with a good night‰Ûªs sleep. I don‰Ûªt like the way Darth Vader stares at me.
I‰Ûªm not going to work.
Oh, just because your career‰Ûªs been stagnant for a few years, that‰Ûªs no reason to give up.
Sheldon, I was up all night using the new free-electron laser for my X-ray diffraction experiment.
Did the laser accidentally burn out your retinas?
No.
Then you can drive. Let‰Ûªs go.
Didn‰Ûªt I tell you I‰Ûªd be working nights, and that you‰Ûªd have to make other arrangements.
You did.
And?
I didn‰Ûªt. Let‰Ûªs go.
Goodnight, Sheldon.
But how am I going to get to work?
Take the bus.
I can‰Ûªt take the bus any more. They don‰Ûªt have seatbelts. And they won‰Ûªt let you lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords.
You tried to lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords?
I didn‰Ûªt try, I succeeded. For some reason it alarmed the other passengers and I was asked to de-bus.
Oh, you‰Ûªre a big boy, you‰Ûªll figure it out.
Don‰Ûªt talk to me like I‰Ûªm a child. Now, take me to return my star wars sheets!
Outside Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny‰Û_
Sheldon, what is it?
Leonard‰Ûªs asleep.
Thanks for the update (begins to close door.)
No, wait. You have to drive me to work.
Yeah, uh, I really don‰Ûªt think I do.
But I don‰Ûªt drive, and I can‰Ûªt take the bus.
Yeah, honey, you‰Ûªll be fine as long as you don‰Ûªt do that bungee cord thing, okay?
Penny. Didn‰Ûªt you recently state that you and I are friends?
Yes, Sheldon, we are friends.
Then I hereby invoke what I‰Ûªm given to understand is an integral part of the implied covenant of friendship. The favour.
Oh, dear God.
I‰Ûªm sorry, I didn‰Ûªt realize I was interrupting your morning prayers. When you‰Ûªre done, we‰Ûªll go.
Inside Penny‰Ûªs car.
Thank you for driving me to work.
You know this is my day off, Sheldon.
Oh, good. I‰Ûªm not keeping you from anything. Your check engine light is on.
Mm-hmm.
Typically that‰Ûªs an indicator. To, you know, check your engine.
It‰Ûªs fine, it‰Ûªs been on for, like, a month.
Well, actually, that would be all the more reason to, you know, check your engine.
Sheldon, it‰Ûªs fine.
If it were fine, the light wouldn‰Ûªt be on. That‰Ûªs why the manufacturer installed that light, to let you know it‰Ûªs not fine.
Uh, maybe the light‰Ûªs broken.
Is there a ‰ÛÏcheck the check engine light light‰Û? (Penny takes a drink of coffee) O-o-o-oh!
What?
Studies have shown that performing tasks such as eating, talking on a cell phone or drinking coffee while driving reduces one‰Ûªs reaction time by the same factor as an ounce of alcohol.
Do you have any alcohol?
Of course not.
Too bad.
You‰Ûªre going up Euclid Avenue?
Mm-hmm.
Leonard takes Los Robles Avenue.
Well, good for Leonard.

Euclid Avenue is shorter as the crow flies, but it has speed bumps, which appreciably increase point-to-point drive time, making it the less efficient choice. But you have the conn. Of course, if you‰Ûªre not going to slow down for the speed bumps, I withdraw my previous objection. Here‰Ûªs a fun question. Do you know what the most common street name is?
No.

The answer‰Ûªs tricky. It‰Ûªs Second Street. You see, you‰Ûªd think it would be First Street, but in most towns, First Street eventually gets renamed to something else, you know, like Main Street, Broad Street, Michigan Avenue. Leonard and I often use our commute time to exercise our mindsåÊ with brain-teasers like that. We also play games. Would you like to play one?
No.

Oh, come on, it‰Ûªs fun. Ooh! Another bump. Okay. I‰Ûªll say an element, and uh, you say an element whose name starts with the last letter of the one I said, okay? I‰Ûªll start. Helium. Now, you could say Mercury. That would give me a Y. Ooh. åÊVery clever, that‰Ûªs a tough one. So I go Ytterbium, which gets you back to M. So you go Molybdenum, and I say Magnesium, you say Manganese, andåÊ I say Europium, and, and you‰Ûªre left with Mendelevium, and åÊthere are no more M‰Ûªs because I believe that Meitnerium should still be called Ekairidium, so congratulations, you win. Do you wanna go again?
How about we just have a little quiet time now?
All right. Hmm, huh, I‰Ûªm sorry, I‰Ûªm finding your reckless nonchalance regarding the check-engine light to be very troubling.
Get out.
Well, I have to tell you that while I do have a theoretical understanding of the workings of an internal combustion engine, I‰Ûªm not sure I‰Ûªm capable of performing diagnostics.
I said, get out.
Okay. I‰Ûªll give it a shot. (Gets out. Penny drives away.)
The university cafeteria. Sheldon enters.
Oh, Leonard, there you are, I‰Ûªm ready to go home.
I just got here.
Good, perfect timing.
Sheldon, I told you, I only have access to the free-electron laser at night. I can‰Ûªt drive you for the next few weeks.
No, you said you couldn‰Ûªt drive me to work, this is from work.
Howard, help me out here.
No, just for the fun of it, I‰Ûªm gonna take his side.
Now, how do you propose I get home?
How did you get here in the first place?
Penny. But I sense that‰Ûªs no longer an option.
Look, I need to get to the laser lab, you‰Ûªre just going to have to find someone else to take you home.
Oh damn, I picked the wrong side.
Howard‰Ûªs motor scooter. Howard is driving, Sheldon is on the back clutching him for dear life and screaming.
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa! Oh God, not Euclid Avenue! Aaaaaaaaaaaaaa!
Raj‰Ûªs car.
Why did Howard leave you in the middle of the road anyway?
We had a difference of opinion.
Over what?
Whether or not he was trying to kill me. For the record, I maintain he was. Where are you going?
I‰Ûªm taking you home.

Oh, but I‰Ûªm not going home. It‰Ûªs Wednesday, Wednesday is new comic book day, we have to go to the comic book store. And then we have to stop at Soup Plantation, it‰Ûªs creamy tomato soup day, and Radio Shack, there‰Ûªs a sale on triple-a batteries. Plus, we have to go to Pottery Barn and return my Star Wars sheets.
I have a better idea.
You want to go to pottery barn first?
Penny‰Ûªs apartment, she opens the door, Sheldon is stood outside with his Star Wars sheets.
Can you drive me to Pottery Barn? (She closes the door) Maybe if I turn off the night-light, I can keep the sheets.
The apartment. Sheldon enters from the bedroom area. Everyone else is present.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Sheldon, sit down.
She‰Ûªs in my spot. Don‰Ûªt look at me like that, everybody knows that my spot.
Sheldon, you knowåÊ that we care about you.
And it‰Ûªs because we care about you that we‰Ûªve decided we have to speak up.
You‰Ûªre hurting the people around you, sweetie.
So we made you an appointment, and we want you to keep it.
Department of motor vehicles new driver handbook? But I don‰Ûªt have a problem.
Sheldon, you need to learn how to drive.
This madness has to stop.
Penny‰Ûªs taking you to the DMV, I‰Ûªm going to bed.
Why Penny?
Because rock breaks scissors, goodnight.
All right, come on Sheldon.
Hold on, I have one condition.
What?
We have to stop at Pottery Barn.
Okay.
And Radio Shack.
Fine.
And the comic book store.
All right! (They leave.)
Ooh, I want to go to the comic book store. (He leaves.)
I like comic books.
The DMV.
I just don‰Ûªt see why I need a driver‰Ûªs license, Albert Einstein never had a driver‰Ûªs license.
Yeah, but Albert Einstein didn‰Ûªt make me wet myself at 40 miles an hour.
Yeah, and I never wanted to kick Albert Einstein in the nuts. You know, I gotta ask, why didn‰Ûªt you just get a license at 16 like everybody else?
I was otherwise engaged.
Doing what?
Examining perturbative amplitudes in n=4 supersymmetric theories leading to a re-examination of the ultraviolet properties of multi-loop n=8 supergravity using modern twistor theory.
Well, how ‰Ûªbout when you were 17?

character: DMV Lady (to the person ahead of Sheldon in the queue)
line: Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next! (Sheldon moves forward) Application?
I‰Ûªm actually more of a theorist.
The application in your hand, give it to her.
Oh.
Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next!
Excuse me, but I have some concerns about these questions.
Look at that sign up there.
Yes?
Does it say I give a damn?
No.
That‰Ûªs because I don‰Ûªt.

Just, look, see, this first question makes no sense, how many car lengths should you leave in front of you when driving? There‰Ûªs no possible way to answer that, a car length is not a standardized unit of measure.
Look at the sign.
Sheldon, it‰Ûªs C, just put down C.
I don‰Ûªt need your help, Penny.
Listen to that little girl, honey, put C. Next!
No, no, wait, no, hang on, look at this next question.
Sheldon, why are you arguing with the DMV?

How else are they going to learn? Look, question 2, when are roadways most slippery? Now, okay, there are three answers, none of which are correct. The correct answer is, when covered by a film of liquid sufficient to reduce the coefficient of static friction between the tire and the road to essentially zero, but not so deep as to introduce a new source of friction.
Here‰Ûªs your learner‰Ûªs permit. Go away.
But I‰Ûªm not done. I have many additional concerns about these questions.
Don‰Ûªt make me climb over this counter.
Come on, let‰Ûªs go.
Next!
Aced it.
The apartment. Howard is setting up a large kit of high tech equipment.
Okay, that‰Ûªs it, let‰Ûªs boot it up.
Booting.
This is a state-of-the-art simulator. I adapted it from something a friend of mine designed for the army.
Is that why I appear to be in downtown Fallujah, behind the wheel of an up-armored Humvee?
I haven‰Ûªt configured it yet. Let‰Ûªs see‰Û_ Bradley tank‰Û_ transport truck‰Û_åÊ Batmobile‰Û_
Ooh!
No.
Here we go, red 2006 Ford Taurus on the streets of Pasadena.
Hmmmm?
What?
Statistically, red cars are stopped by police far more often than any other colour. I don‰Ûªt want any hassles with the fuzz.
Fine, what colour do you want?
You know the pale blue of Luke Skywalker‰Ûªs lightsaber, before it was digitally remastered?
Black it is.
Okay, now, what you want to do first is turn on the ignition and shift into drive.
I haven‰Ûªt fastened my seat belt yet.
Okay, fasten your seat belt.
Click. Now, are there air bags?
You don‰Ûªt need air bags.
What if a simulated van rear-ends me?
I‰Ûªll hit you in the face with a pillow.
Okay, now shift into drive, pull out slowly into traffic.
Oh.
Oh.
Oh.
Watch out.
Oh God!
Watch, watch out, watch out for pedestrians!
Oh God, wait, slow, hit the brakes, hit the brakes!
Thank you.
The same, only Sheldon and Leonard are present. Sheldon is practicing. There are sounds of squealing tyres and brakes and general panic and mayhem.
Sorry‰Û_ excuse me‰Û_ my bad‰Û_ student driver‰Û_
How did you manage to get on the second floor of the Glendale galleria?
I don‰Ûªt know. I was on the Pasadena freeway, I missed my exit, flew off the overpass, and one thing led to another.
Maybe you want to give it a rest and try again tomorrow.
No. I quit. (Stands up. There is more sound of crashing and panic, then animal noises.)
Aw, the pet store?
Remind me to compliment Wolowitz on the software, it‰Ûªs amazingly detailed.
So wait,you‰Ûªre just gonna give up?
No, I‰Ûªm not giving up, I never give up.
So what is it you‰Ûªre doing?
I‰Ûªm transcending the situation. I‰Ûªm clearly too evolved for driving.
What does that mean?
Leonard, have you ever wondered why my little toes and lateral incisors are significantly smaller than the average for someone of my size?
I wonder a lot of things about you, Sheldon, but not‰Û_ not that.
Well, those are indicators that I‰Ûªm farther along the evolutionary scale than the average human.
No kidding.

Well, no, no, I‰Ûªm not going to go so far as to say that I represent a distinct new stage in humankind, you know, a Homo Novus, if you will, no, that‰Ûªs for anthropologists to decide. But I am convinced that the reason I cannot master the plebeian task of driving is because I‰Ûªm not meant to.
Yes, you are, you‰Ûªre meant to learn how to drive. Please learn how to drive!
No, no. Leonard, I‰Ûªm meant for greater things, like unraveling the mysteries of the universe, not determining when it‰Ûªs safe to pass a stopped school bus on a country road.
It‰Ûªs never safe.
Yeah, well, I know that now.
Fine. Assuming that everything you say is true, how does the biologically superior Homo Novus get to work tomorrow morning?
Homo Novus doesn‰Ûªt know.
Well, hang in there, maybe you‰Ûªll evolve into something with wings.
A corridor in the university. Sheldon emerges from his office in a shower cap and bathrobe. The others are turning the corner.
Good morning, gentlemen.
Hey.
Good morning. Is there some new kind of casual Friday I don‰Ûªt know about?
No, he lives here now.
Really? Why?
Well, since he won‰Ûªt take the bus and he‰Ûªs too evolved to drive, he decided it would be easier to just sleep in his office and shower in the radiation lab until I‰Ûªm finished with my experiment.
But you finished your experiment a week ago.
Yep
The cafeteria, late at night. Two cleaning ladies enter and find a plate with toast crusts.
Oh my God, again?
It must be rats.
Rats don‰Ûªt make toast and cut off the crust.
You saw nothing! (Sweeps hood around himself and vanishes through cafeteria door.)
A lecture room at the university.

So, if any of you are considering going into experimental physics, my door is always open. Once again, I‰Ûªm sorry that the demonstration didn‰Ûªt quite work out, but now we know what happens when you accidentally spill peach Snapple into a helium neon laser. Short answer is‰Û_ don‰Ûªt. And now to tell you about the theoretical physics department is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Dr. Cooper?
Forget it.
Excuse me. Sheldon, we both agreed to do this.
It‰Ûªs a waste of time. I might as well explain the laws of thermodynamics to a bunch of labradoodles.
If you don‰Ûªt do this, I won‰Ûªt take you to the comic book store.

Hello. Nice work with the laser, by the way. Looking out at your fresh young faces, I remember when I too was deciding my academic future as a lowly graduate student. Of course, I was 14, and I‰Ûªd already achieved more than most of you could ever hope to, despite my 9 o‰Ûªclock bedtime. Now, there may be one or two of you in this room who has what it takes to succeed in theoretical physics, although, it‰Ûªs more likely that you‰Ûªll spend your scientific careers teaching fifth graders how to make paper mache volcanoes with baking soda lava.
Oh, good God.

In short, anyone who told you that you would someday be able to make any significant contribution to physics played a cruel trick on you, a cruel trick indeed. Any questions? Of course not. I weep for the future of science. Now if you‰Ûªll excuse me, the latest issue of Batman is out. Come, Leonard.
Laser demonstration‰Ûªs looking pretty good now, huh?
The university cafeteria.
I love this time of the year. The leaves are turning, there‰Ûªs a bracing chill in the air.
Plus there‰Ûªs a whole new crop of female grad students about to put on just enough winter weight to make them needy and vulnerable. That‰Ûªs right, honey, have another calzone, Daddy can wait.
Isn‰Ûªt there a university policy against dating graduate students?
No, if you can talk to them, you can ask them out.
Damn, there‰Ûªs always a catch.
Hey, guys.
Hey, Leslie.
So, dumbass, I heard you made a grad student throw up last night.
The truth can indeed be a finger down the throat of those unprepared to hear it. But why should I cater to second-rate minds?
Because first-rate minds call you ‰ÛÏdumbass‰Û?
Oh, yeah? Well‰Û_ you‰Ûªre a mean person.
Excuse me, Dr. Cooper, I‰Ûªm Ramona Nowitzki, I was at your talk last night. I think you‰Ûªre just brilliant.
That is the prevailing opinion.
Oh, now I‰Ûªm gonna throw up.
Howard Wolowitz, department of engineering, co-designer of the International Space Station‰Ûªs Liquid Waste Disposal System.

Ew. Dr. Cooper, I‰Ûªve read everything you‰Ûªve published. I especially liked your paper on grand unification using string-network condensates and was wondering how you determined that three-dimensional string-nets provided a unified picture of fermions and gauge bosons?
Amazing, an intelligent labradoodle.
Woof.
The fact is I‰Ûªm quite close to a breakthrough in showing how neutrinos emerge from a string-net condensate.
Oh, my God, that would change the way we view the entire physical universe.
It‰Ûªs what I do.
You know, the Pishkin-Wolowitz Liquid Waste Disposal System is turning a few heads as well.
Again, ew. You know, I‰Ûªd love to hear more about how you intend to add neutrinos. Could we get a cup of coffee sometime?
I don‰Ûªt drink coffee.
I do. I love me a cup of joe.
Well, it doesn‰Ûªt have to be coffee. How about dinner?
I do eat dinner.
Great. I know a terrific little Italian place.
I never eat in strange restaurants. One runs the risk of non-standard cutlery.
Excuse me?
Sheldon lives in fear of the three-tined fork.
Three tines is not a fork, three tines is a trident. Forks are for eating, tridents are for ruling the seven seas.
What if I brought food to your place?
That would be acceptable. On Mondays, I eat Thai food. Mee krob and chicken sate with extra peanut sauce from Siam Palace.
You got it. I already have your address.
What a nice girl.
Sheldon, do you have any idea what just happened?
Yes. Apparently I‰Ûªm getting a free dinner.
The apartment building lobby. Ramona is waiting by the lift. Penny enters.
Oh, yeah, no, this thing‰Ûªs majorly out of order. (Picking up out of order sign) See? Sorry.
That‰Ûªs okay. Guess I‰Ûªm taking the stairs.
Where you going?
Oh, are you here to see Leonard?
No, Dr. Cooper.
Dr. Sheldon Cooper?
We‰Ûªre having dinner.
Sheldon Cooper? Tall, thin, looks a little like a giant praying mantis?
He is cute, isn‰Ûªt he?
Sheldon Cooper?
The apartment. Leonard opens the door, Ramona and Penny are outside.
Hi, Leonard.
Hey, Ramona. Come on in.
Thanks. Where should I put this?
Uh, the kitchen‰Ûªs fine. (To Penny) Hey, what are you doing?
I need to see this.
Uh-huh. The viewing area‰Ûªs right over there. Sheldon, your girl‰Û_ date‰Û_ person‰Û_ Ramona‰Ûªs here.
Oh, hello.
Oh, sorry I‰Ûªm late. I just got so caught up reading the draft of your latest paper.
Did you enjoy the humorous footnote where I illustrate mirror-symmetry by likening it to the Flash playing tennis with himself?
So funny. But the idea that you might be able to incorporate gravity, I have to tell you, I found it physically exhilarating.
My hypotheses tend to have that effect.
I‰Ûªm sorry I didn‰Ûªt bring enough for your friends. I assumed we were going to be alone.
Oh, yeah. No, we were just going.
To watch, right?
No, come on, now, we‰Ûªre going out.
Oh, come on, we‰Ûªll be quiet.
Let‰Ûªs go. Okay, you two, just, have a nice‰Û_ whatever this is.
Okay, you guys, look, I know this is none of my business, but I just, I have to ask, what‰Ûªs Sheldon‰Ûªs deal?
What do you mean ‰ÛÏdeal‰Û?
You know, like what‰Ûªs his deal? Is it girls? Guys? Sock puppets?
Honestly, we‰Ûªve been operating under the assumption that he has no deal.
Come on, everybody has a deal.
Not Sheldon. Over the years, we‰Ûªve formulated many theories about how he might reproduce. I‰Ûªm an advocate of mytosis.
I‰Ûªm sorry?
I believe one day Sheldon will eat an enormous amount of Thai food and split into two Sheldons.
On the other hand, I think Sheldon might be the larval form of his species, and someday he‰Ûªll spin a cocoon and emerge two months later with moth wings and an exoskeleton.
Okay, well, thanks for the nightmares.
Hey, do you want to hang out with us?
What are you guys gonna do?
Uh‰Û_
My mom‰Ûªs making a brisket tonight.
The one with the little onions? Mmm.
Yeah, I‰Ûªm busy, so, goodnight.
Her loss. Let‰Ûªs go.
Brisket party! B-to-the-R-to-the-I-S-K‰Û_ To-the-E-to-the-T‰Û_ Ooh‰Û_
Don‰Ûªt.
The cafeteria.
Hey, aren‰Ûªt you having breakfast?
Yes.
Are you experimenting with nutritional suppositories again?
Not in these pants.
So, how‰Ûªd it go with Ramona last night?
Oh, great. She‰Ûªs smart, insightful and she has a very unique way of, you know, revering me.
Here‰Ûªs your spinach mushroom omelette .
Thank you. Did anyone touch it?
Gloves were worn by everyone involved. I was vigilant.
Ramona pointed out that I‰Ûªve been wasting 20 minutes a day standing on cafeteria lines.
Time which would be better spent tackling the great physics problems of our day.
You don‰Ûªt tackle the big issues, Ramona. You fence with them. En garde. Riposte.
Touche.
Morning.
Ah, hey Leslie.
So, Sheldon, I see you‰Ûªre organizing your papers for the Smithsonian Museum of Dumbassery.
There won‰Ûªt be any room until they get rid of the permanent Leslie Winkle exhibit.
Oh, good one.
I see you got a grad student to fight your battles for you. I‰Ûªll let you keep your lunch money today.
Okay, Dr. Cooper is on the verge of a breakthrough. If you‰Ûªre going to stay, you‰Ûªll have to be respectful and quiet. (Leslie leaves. Ramona looks pointedly at Leonard)
Wait for me.
So have you worked out the neutrino issue?
Well, to paraphrase Mozart, all the subatomic particles are there, I just have to put them in the right order.
You‰Ûªre so witty.
Aren‰Ûªt I?
The apartment. There is a knock on the door which then opens and Penny enters.
Hey, guys, this package came for y‰Û_
Dr. Cooper is working.
Yes, I‰Ûªm close to a breakthrough. Ooh, it tickles
Sorry. (Puts package down and leaves. In hallway, shudders)  Holy crap on a cracker.
Hey, Penny.
Hi. You know, you probably don‰Ûªt want to go in there.
Why? What are they doing?
You know, the only way I could explain it would be in a therapist‰Ûªs office with dolls.
Hoo-boy.
Dr. Cooper‰Ûªs working.
Yeah, I can see that. Sheldon, Halo night, Koothrappali‰Ûªs. You coming?
Oh, yes, it‰Ûªs Halo night. Let me just dry my tootsies.
You‰Ûªre not going to Halo night.
Yes, I am. It‰Ûªs Wednesday. Wednesday‰Ûªs Halo night.
Didn‰Ûªt a great man once say, ‰ÛÏScience demands nothing less than the fervent and
He did.
And who was that great man?
Me. Sorry, Leonard.
Seriously? You‰Ûªre not coming?
You heard her. How can I argue with me?
Okay, well, once again, you guys have a good‰Û_ whatever this is.
Dr. Cooper, I have to tell you, your friends are holding you back.
I prefer to think of it as I‰Ûªm pulling them forward.
Halo night? A man with your intellectual gifts doesn‰Ûªt waste an evening playing video games.
He does on Wednesdays.
Not if he wants a Nobel Prize.
He does want that. Does a man with my intellectual gifts play paintball on weekends?
What do you think?
Drat.
Now shall we get back to work?
I suppose. Battlestar Galactica comes on tonight. (Pause) I guess I can wait for the DVD. (Pause) And then never ever watch it.

To the sound of ‰ÛÏYou Can Be My Yoko Ono‰Û by Barenaked LadiesåÊ we see 1. the guys set off for paintball while Sheldon, dressed in paintball gear, sadly waves them goodbye, 2. Ramona catch Sheldon hiding behind the shower curtain playing on a Nintendo DS, 3. Ramona remove a book Sheldon is reading to reveal a Batman comic underneath, 4. Sheldon escape the apartment in his paintball gear only to be chased back inside by Ramona returning with groceries, she finds him sitting in his underpants with his paintball helmet still on.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs apartment.

character: Sheldon (Knock, knock, knock, in a low voice)
line: Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny

You could try calling Triple-A, but based on NASA‰Ûªs latest timetable, they won‰Ûªt get there for 35 years.
Plus I understand you have to be standing next to the vehicle with your card when they arrive.
Oh, snap.
Snap what?
OK, I guess we have to turn to Plan B.
What‰Ûªs Plan B?
Erase all the hard drives, scrap the surveillance tapes, wipe our fingerprints off every surface and run.
Why wasn‰Ûªt that Plan A?
The apartment.
Thank God for Plan B.
Howard, didn‰Ûªt you say you worked on the Mars Rover?
No, you‰Ûªre mistaken.
Yeah, when we first met, you said that if I went out with you, I could drive a car on Mars.
I don‰Ûªt know what you‰Ûªre talking about.
Psst! Psst!
Will you all excuse me? Leonard is subtly signalling that he‰Ûªd like to talk to me in private.
No. Yeah, I remember specifically. You started by asking if I was from Mars because my ass was out of this world.
Well, that does sound like me, but no.
Is there some problem?
Yeah. Listen, I have to kinda sneak out for a while.
All right, goodbye.
No, wait! If anyone asks you where I went, you don‰Ûªt know.
Where are you going?
I can‰Ûªt tell you that.
Who would ask me?
I can‰Ûªt tell you that, either.
So you brought me in here to inform me that you can‰Ûªt tell me where you‰Ûªre going and you can‰Ûªt tell me who might ask?
Yeah, I really didn‰Ûªt think this through.
Leonard, a moment.
What?
If someone, and of course, we don‰Ûªt know who this would be, does ask where you‰Ûªve gone, what should I say?
I don‰Ûªt know. Just tell them I went to the office.
Are you going to the office?
No.
Then how can I say it convincingly?
Just say, Leonard went to the office.
All right. Leonard went to (exaggerated) the office.
What is? No, not like that! Just, Leonard went to the office.
This would have worked out a lot better if you‰Ûªd just told me you were going the office.
I‰Ûªm going to the office.
See? Why don‰Ûªt I believe you?
I‰Ûªm going out for a while.
Okay.
Doesn‰Ûªt anyone want to know where he‰Ûªs going?
Okay, where is he going?
Leonard is going to (exaggerated) the office.
The girl‰Ûªs apartment.
So how was work today?
Busy. I removed an appendix, a gall bladder and about a foot and a half of bowel.
I‰Ûªm hoping that‰Ûªs three different guys.
No, just the one. He didn‰Ûªt make it. So, how was your day?
Oh, you know, I‰Ûªm a physicist, so, I thought about stuff.
That‰Ûªs it?
Well, I wrote some of it down.
Are you done eating?
Uh, yeah.
Oh, good. (Kisses him)
If I knew you were waiting, I would‰Ûªve swallowed that lasagna whole.
You‰Ûªve reached Dr. Stephanie Barnett. Leave a message. Beep.
Hey, Steph, it‰Ûªs me again, Howard. Listen, if you‰Ûªre free Friday, maybe we could have a little something to eat at my place. My mom cooks a hell of a brisket. Let me know. It‰Ûªs Howard.
I‰Ûªve had her brisket. Melts in your mouth.
Maybe we should think about going to the bedroom.
That‰Ûªs a good idea. There‰Ûªs a bed in there, and I‰Ûªm very, very, very pro-bed.
You‰Ûªve reached Dr. Stephanie Barnett. Leave a message. Beep.

Hey, it‰Ûªs me again. Just want to let you know the head count for dinner Friday has gone up. My Aunt Betty and Uncle Elliot are coming in from Palm Springs. Oh, and if anybody should ask, you‰Ûªre half-Jewish on your mother‰Ûªs side. Okay, call me. It‰Ûªs Howard.
Don‰Ûªt you think we should tell him you‰Ûªre not interested?
Do you want me to stop and call him back right now?
Dear God, no!
Oh, Leonard‰Û_
You‰Ûªve reached Dr. Stephanie Barnett. Leave a message. Beep.
Hey, it‰Ûªs me again. Howard. Listen, my cousins from Fort Lauderdale are flying in to meet you so that means we‰Ûªre gonna have to move the dinner to a restaurant.
Tell her we‰Ûªre going to the Olive Garden! I have a coupon from the paper.
We‰Ûªre not going to the Olive Garden, Mom!
Oh, Mr. Bigshot with his Red Lobster.
I‰Ûªll call you back when we firm up the details. It‰Ûªs Howard.
The laundry room
Oh, hey.
Hey.
New shirts?
Yeah, a couple.
Nice.
åÊThank you.
So, who‰Ûªs the girl?
I‰Ûªm sorry?
Well, last time you bought a new shirt was when we were dating.
So, uh, what we did was in fact dating?
Well, yeah, we did have a date.
Exactly. Thank you. Do me a favour, tell Koothrappali that next time you see him.
So, who is she?
Oh, she‰Ûªs a doctor.
Oh, nice. A doctor doctor, or a you kind of doctor?

Doctor doctor. Surgical resident. Smart, pretty. Let me ask you something. If your friend thinks he‰Ûªs dating someone, but he‰Ûªs not because, in fact, you‰Ûªre dating her, does that make you a bad person?
Well, that depends.
On what?
Is that friend Wolowitz?
Yeah.
Screw him. You‰Ûªre fine.
Are you sure?
Well, have you slept with her yet? You dog! Good for you.
Does that change things?
No.
So why‰Ûªd you ask?
I‰Ûªm nosy. See ya.
Outside Howard‰Ûªs front door.
Howard, get the door!
Really? Is that what you do when someone knocks? Thank you. I had no idea! (opening door) Hey, buddy. What brings you to my little slice of hell?
Who is it?!
It‰Ûªs Leonard!
You‰Ûªre gonna have to play outside! I‰Ûªm not dressed to receive!
No one cares, Ma! So, what‰Ûªs up?
Listen, I need to talk to you about something.

Momentito. Yello. Oh, Stephanie, thanks for calling me back. I was worried‰Û_ Oh‰Û_ Uh-huh‰Û_ Uh-huh‰Û_ Uh-huh‰Û_ No, I understand‰Û_ Sure, we can be friends. Absolutely. Thanks for calling. Yeah, you have a nice day, too. (To Leonard) You are dead to me.
The apartment
Okay, who gets the extra dumpling?
Rock-paper-scissors- lizard-Spock.
Okay, one of us is going to have to stop putting up Spock.
How do we decide that?
Rock-paper-scissors-lizard-Spock. Oh!
Oh, hey, guys.
Hello.
Hey.
Hi, Howard. Howard?
Sheldon.

Howard is employing a schoolyard paradigm in which you are, for all intents and purposes, deceased. He intends to act on this by not speaking to you, feigning an inability to hear you when you speak and otherwise refusing to acknowledge your existence.
That‰Ûªs just ridiculous. Why are you cooperating with him?
I don‰Ûªt make the rules, Leonard.
Howard, come on, I didn‰Ûªt plan on this. These things just happen. Usually not to me, but they do happen.
Did someone just feel a cold breeze?
I believe this is an extension of the death metaphor. The cold breeze is the so-called ectoplasmic issue of a disembodied soul passing by.
You know, screw it, I‰Ûªm just gonna eat the dumpling.
Oh, hi, Steph, come on in.
åÊIs this a bad time?
Yeah, but I don‰Ûªt see a better one on the horizon, so‰Û_
Oh, if it isn‰Ûªt Mrs. Dead to Me.
Hello, Howard.
Sheldon?
Look I‰Ûªm sorry, you violated the terms of your metaphor by acknowledging her existence. I‰Ûªm out.
He just won‰Ûªt listen to me.
Okay, I guess it‰Ûªll just be the three of us then.
Hmm. Lisa‰Ûªs gonna be disappointed.
Yeah.
Lisa?
Yeah, my roommate. She just went through a really bad breakup and I thought she might like to meet somebody fun like you.
Leonard, Stephanie, you‰Ûªre alive, it‰Ûªs a miracle!
The apartment kitchen. Howard is on the phone.

So, anyway, Lisa, I just wanted to tell you again how much I enjoyed the other night, and again, I‰Ûªm sorry for how it ended. But again, if you could let me know about Friday. My mother needs a head count so she can know how big a brisket to get.
Howard, Howard, look at this.
Anyway, call me. It‰Ûªs Howard.

The possibility of life on Mars has long fascinated scientists and laypersons alike. It‰Ûªs unclear how the Mars Rover got into the crevice, but one thing‰Ûªs certain, the data which it has sent back contain the first clear indications that there may have been life on Mars. It‰Ûªs a scientific discovery that has staggering implications for all mankind. Unfortunately, we‰Ûªll never know who‰Ûªs responsible.
Son of a bitch.
The lobby.
Penny, hello.
Hey, Sheldon.
What is shaking?
I‰Ûªm sorry?
It‰Ûªs colloquial, a conversation opener. So, do you find the weather satisfying? Are you currently sharing in the triumph of some local sports team?
What‰Ûªs wrong with you? you‰Ûªre freaking me out.
I‰Ûªm striking up a casual conversation with you. S‰Ûªu‰Ûªup?
Please don‰Ûªt do that.
All right, But I‰Ûªm given to understand that when you have something awkward to discuss with someone, it‰Ûªs more palatable to preface it with banal chit chat.
So, this wasn‰Ûªt the awkward part?
No.
Oh, all right. S‰Ûªu‰Ûªup?
Oh, good, I used that right. Anyway, you‰Ûªre aware that Leonard has entered into a new romantic relationship which includes a sexual component?
Okay, feeling the awkward now.
Her name is Dr. Stephanie Barnett and she is a highly distinguished surgical resident at Freemont Memorial.
Yeah, Leonard told me.
Good. What he may have left out is how important this relationship is to me.
To you?
Yes, see, of the handful of women Leonard‰Ûªs been involved with, she‰Ûªs the only one I have ever found tolerable.
Well, what about me?
The statement stands for itself.
Well, aren‰Ûªt you sweet?
Anyway, should you have any interaction with her, it would be most helpful that she not see you as a sexual rival.
Yeah, I think she‰Ûªs pretty safe.

You say that now, but consider the following scenario, you‰Ûªre sitting in your apartment, it‰Ûªs late, you‰Ûªre alone, your hypothalamus is swimming in a soup of estrogen and progesterone and suddenly even Leonard seems like a viable sexual candidate, or a, uh, hookup as it‰Ûªs referred to by today‰Ûªs urban youth.
Really?
Yes. Now, should that happen, I would ask you to find some way to suppress your libido.
I could think about you.
Fine, whatever works.
Always nice talking to you, Sheldon.
Uh, peace out!
The apartment.
Well, this is very pleasant.
I‰Ûªm glad you‰Ûªre enjoying yourself.
And you said there‰Ûªd never be enough pasta for the three of us.
I stand corrected.
You know, Italian housewives have a rule of thumb. A handful of dry pasta about an inch in diameter is sufficient for each person as it doubles in volume when cooked.
That‰Ûªs very interesting.
Thank you.
She doesn‰Ûªt mean it. She‰Ûªs just being nice.
Well, Stephanie, since Leonard seems to be dropping the conversational ball, I guess I‰Ûªll just have to pick it up. Have you ever witnessed a violent crime?
No.
Good. What‰Ûªs your favourite fruit?
Ih-uh, strawberries.
Hmm, technically not a fruit, but all right. Where did you do your medical internship?
Uh, Lawrence Memorial in Galveston, Texas.
Really? That‰Ûªs where I was born!
You‰Ûªre kidding!
I spent so much of my childhood at that hospital. When I was 12, I got to ride there in a helicopter.
Why, what-what-what happened?
Radiation burns. A little mishap while I was building my own cat scanner.
I‰Ûªm sorry, you tried to build your own cat scanner?

No, I didn‰Ûªt try, I succeeded. In fact, I was briefly able to see the inside of my sister‰Ûªs guinea pig, Snowball, before he caught fire. It led to an interesting expression in our house, not a snowball‰Ûªs chance in a cat scanner.
Uh, Sheldon?

Excuse me. When I come back, just for fun, the subject will be alternative history. Specifically, how would the civil war have gone differently if Lincoln had been a robot sent from the future? (To Leonard) Look at that, there‰Ûªs even pasta left over.
Do you understand that this was supposed to be a date?
I do. Do you? Because frankly, you‰Ûªve been in a foul mood since I sat down.
Okay, here‰Ûªs my question, why did you sit down?
To help. Look, if you fail at this relationship, and history suggests you will, then we risk losing the medical officer that our landing party has always needed.
What landing party?
You‰Ûªre Kirk, I‰Ûªm Spock, Wolowitz is Scotty, Koothrappali is the guy who always gets killed, and now we‰Ûªve got McCoy.
A cinema.
So, we‰Ûªre all standing around looking at the post-op x ray and there it is, clear as day, right in the guy‰Ûªs chest cavity, one of my earrings.
Oh, my god, what did you do?
What do you think I did? I discreetly slipped off the other earring, put it in my pocket and then got the hell out of there!
I have a bone to pick with you, sir.
Oo-oo-oh!
Hi, Sheldon.
Hi, Stephanie. I‰Ûªm sorry I‰Ûªm late, but your companion left the most indecipherable invitation.
What invitation?
We‰Ûªre going to the movies. What movie? What theatre? What time? If you were trying to make it impossible to locate you, you couldn‰Ûªt have done a better job.
Oh, clearly I could have.
It took me nearly 20 minutes to go through the browser history on your computer to see what movie times you looked up. Wait here, I‰Ûªll find us seats.
No, no, we have seats.
Not the right seats. (Sheldon moves around the theatre sitting in various seats and shouting ‰ÛÏHa!‰Û)
What is he doing?
He‰Ûªs finding the acoustic sweet spot.
Does he always do this?
Sometimes he brings a toy xylophone. I am really sorry about this.
No, it‰Ûªs fine. you know, he‰Ûªs sweet.
My apologies, you‰Ûªve been sitting in it all along. Leonard, you want to slide over one?
No, just sit here.
Oh, yeah, this is it.
Outside Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Leonard (knock, knock, knock)  Leonard (knock, knock, knock)  Leonard.
What, Sheldon? What, Sheldon? What, Sheldon?
Tell me what you see here.
The blunt instrument that will be the focus of my murder trial?
This is Stephanie‰Ûªs facebook page. Now, where it should say in a relationship, what does it say?
Stephanie Barnett is single.
Yeah, furthermore, earlier this evening, she threw a digital sheep at some guy named Mike. Who‰Ûªs Mike? Why does he get a digital sheep and not you?
It‰Ûªs just her facebook page and we‰Ûªve only been going out a couple of weeks.
You don‰Ûªt see it, do you? We‰Ûªre losing her.
Okay, I‰Ûªm going to make this very simple for you. You are not in this relationship, I am. Ergo, you have no say in anything that happens between me and Stephanie.
I‰Ûªm afraid I can‰Ûªt allow that. Pursuant to Starfleet General Order 104 Section A, you are deemed unfit and I hereby relieve you of your command.
General Order 104, Section A does not apply in this situation.
Give me one good reason why not.
Because this is not Star Trek
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door.
Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny.
What?
This is banana bread.
This is a door knob.
It‰Ûªs my understanding that an unsolicited gift of food can be a precursor to an impromptu invitation to come in and chat.
Sheldon, would you like to come in?
I suppose I could spare a few minutes. Were you robbed?
No.
How can you be sure?
Sheldon, what do you want?
I‰Ûªm certain this will come as no surprise to you, but Leonard is failing in yet another relationship.
He‰Ûªs having problems with Stephanie?

She‰Ûªs sending virtual livestock to random men on the internet. If I have any hope of keeping them together, I need data. Specifically, I need to know exactly what Leonard did that caused you to pop an emotional cap in his buttocks.
What?

Again, urban slang. In which, I believe I‰Ûªm gaining remarkable fluency. So, what is the down and the low? And don‰Ûªt worry, this is all entirely confidential, so, you feel free to include any and all shortcomings in the bedroom.
We never got to the bedroom.
Because?
Oh, okay, all right, you know what? I‰Ûªll tell you what happened. We were young, we were very much in love, but we could only communicate through a time-traveling mailbox at my lake house.
It‰Ûªs not enough that you made me watch that movie, but now you mock me with it?
The university cafeteria.
Gentlemen, I have a question about dating and relationships.
You told me you were going to have the talk with him.
I‰Ûªve been waiting for someone to have the talk with me.
More to the point, it‰Ûªs about finding a way to keep Leonard and Stephanie together.
Oh, I don‰Ûªt think you can.
Well, why not?
Look at Leonard‰Ûªs record. 27 days with Joyce Kim.
During which she defected to North Korea.
Two booty calls with Leslie Winkle.
For which she awarded him the nickname ‰ÛÏspeed of light Leonard.‰Û
And a three hour dinner with Penny.
Which would have been two and a half if they ordered the souffle when they sat down.
Based on the geometric progression, his relationship with Stephanie should have ended after 20 minutes.
Yes, I‰Ûªm aware of the math, Y equals 27 days over 12 to the nth, the issue remains, how do we circumvent his inevitable rejection?
Well, if you want to guarantee his appeal to Stephanie, your best bet would be to kill all the other men on the planet.

I‰Ûªll tell you what you shouldn‰Ûªt do. Don‰Ûªt spritz him with that body spray from the commercial where the women undress when they smell it, that doesn‰Ûªt work at all, no matter how much you put on.
So, that‰Ûªs all you‰Ûªve got? Apocalyptic genocide and go easy on the cologne?
Yes.
Yeah.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door.
Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny.
What?
Penny. Zucchini bread.
Oh, thank you.
May I come in?
No.
I see. Apparently my earlier inquiry regarding you and Leonard crossed some sort of line. I apologize.
Well, thank you.
So, have you and I returned to a social equilibrium?
Yes.
Great. New topic. Where are you in your menstrual cycle?
What?

I‰Ûªve been doing some research online, and apparently female primates, you know, uh, apes, chimpanzees, you, they find their mate more desirable when he‰Ûªs being courted by another female. Now, this effect is intensified when the rival female is secreting the pheromones associated with ovulation. Which brings me back to my question, where are you in (Penny slams door). Clearly, I‰Ûªm 14 days too early.
The apartment.
All I‰Ûªm saying is if they can cure yellow fever and malaria, why can‰Ûªt they do something about lactose intolerance?
Leonard, you‰Ûªre going to have to let this go. You had a little cheese dip, you farted, I thought it was cute.
Oh, hi Stephanie.
Hi.
Want some more wine?
Yeah, I assume I‰Ûªm not driving anywhere tonight. (Sheldon lets out a loud noise).
What are you doing?
I have a craving for white asparagus that apparently is destined to go unsatisfied.
Excuse me. What the hell is wrong with you?
I‰Ûªm helping you with Stephanie.
By making constipated moose sounds?

When I fail to open this jar and you succeed it will establish you as the alpha male. You see, when a female witnesses an exhibition of physical domination she produces the hormone oxytocin. If the two of you then engage in intercourse this will create the biochemical reaction in the brain which lay people naively interpret as falling in love.
Huh? Would it work if I just punched you in the face?
Yes, actually it would, but let‰Ûªs see how the lid goes. I‰Ûªm not strong enough, Leonard, you‰Ûªll have to do it.
Oh, for god‰Ûªs sakes.
Go ahead, it‰Ûªs pre-loosened.
Do you want some help with that?
No, no, no, I got it.

No, yeah, yeah, he‰Ûªs got it, and that‰Ûªs not surprising. This is something I long ago came to peace with in my role as the beta male. Open it. (Leonard tries again. Then taps jar on counter. Jar breaks.)
Oh my god, are you okay?
No, I‰Ûªm not. I‰Ûªm bleeding.
Like a gladiator!
Oh, honey, you‰Ûªre going to need stitches.
Stitches? With a needle?
Well, yeah, I mean, just a few.
Oh, okay, yeah, hang on a sec. (Throws up in sink)
FYI, I was defrosting a steak in there.
The hospital.

What a beautiful job Stephanie did. I might have gone with a mattress suture instead of a blanket stitch, but you can‰Ûªt argue with her results. It‰Ûªs a shame it won‰Ûªt scar, the war wound is a time-honoured badge of masculinity.
I can‰Ûªt remember a time when you weren‰Ûªt talking.
Just for the record, my efforts to establish you as the alpha male were not aided by you bursting into tears.
I did not burst into tears, my eyes just got a little watery.
Watery?
She stuck a needle into my hand!
Hey, how‰Ûªs my big cry baby?
I didn‰Ûªt cry.
Okay, I‰Ûªm just teasing you. But, yeah, you did. Alright, it‰Ûªs all good. what do you say we get you home and put you to bed?
Oh, are you still going to spend the night?
Uh, no, I think that you probably need to rest.
She‰Ûªs right, as long as you‰Ûªre vomiting, coitus is contra-indicated.
Thank you, Dr. Cooper.
You‰Ûªre welcome, Dr. Hofstadter.
Okay, I‰Ûªm going to go get your discharge papers.
What?
Well, you seem like a perfectly pleasant person. I just can‰Ûªt understand why women have such a hard time loving you.
The Apartment.
Hey, can you open this for me?
Can I see your stitches?
Sure. (Holds out hand. Howard starts to retch).
Answering the question once and for all why Wolowitz bailed out of medical school.
Leonard, congratulations.
What for?
Your facebook status update. Leonard Hofstadter is in a relationship.
What? no. no, that‰Ûªs not right.
Oh, man, did you switch your status before she did? Speaking as an expert, way to look needy.
Seriously? You went first, after only two weeks? That‰Ûªs bold.
It‰Ûªs not bold, it‰Ûªs a mistake. I didn‰Ûªt change my status.
Well, then who did?
I had no choice, he cried in front of her.
You hacked my facebook account?
Oh, it‰Ûªs hardly hacking when you use the same password for everything, Kal-el.

Are you insane? Now she‰Ûªs going to think I‰Ûªm desperate. You‰Ûªve destroyed this relationship! And you want to know what the worst part is? You don‰Ûªt even understand what you did wrong because you can‰Ûªt conceive of something that you are not an expert in!
In which I am not an expert.
Don‰Ûªt even! I don‰Ûªt want to hear another word out of you.

character: Penny (after Raj lets out a noise)
line: What‰Ûªs wrong, Lassie? Timmy fall down the well? (He points) Oh, wow. She just updated her facebook status.
Stephanie Barnett is in a relationship with Leonard Hofstadter.‰Û
Really? Oh, look at that, I have a girlfriend.
If I am permitted to speak again, Dr. Sheldon Cooper for the win.
The apartment.
I don‰Ûªt see anything at all, Sheldon.
Well, you‰Ûªre the doctor, but I am constantly hearing this annoying sound.
Me, too.
Is it a high-frequency whistle?
No, it‰Ûªs more of a relentless, narcissistic drone.
Yup, there‰Ûªs no inflammation at all, Sheldon.
Then it must be a tumour.
I Seriously doubt it.
Maybe it‰Ûªs a lingering bacterial infection from all those childhood toilet swirlies.
Is that possible? I used to get those all the time. Even in church.
Well, you know, if it is from a swirly, there‰Ûªs something I can do. Okay, circle, circle, dot, dot, now you have a cootie shot! I‰Ûªm going to bed
Okay, I‰Ûªll be right in.
It‰Ûªs not enough that she mocks me, but that isn‰Ûªt even the correct procedure for a cootie shot.
Do you understand that Stephanie‰Ûªs not here to treat your imaginary ailments?
How is it imaginary that I keep hearing an octave above Middle C? Is that imaginary? I don‰Ûªt think so.
Good night.
Leonard, there‰Ûªs one more thing. Under Article One, Section Three of our Roommate Agreement, I‰Ûªm calling an emergency meeting.
No, you‰Ûªre not.
Leonard moves the meeting not occur. Is there a second? None heard, the motion fails. I‰Ûªd like to begin the meeting by congratulating you on the progress in your relationship with Dr. Stephanie.
Thank you.
That being said, we have to discuss the implementation of the agreed upon ‰ÛÏcohabitation‰Û rider which has been activated now that the two of you are living together.
We‰Ûªre not living together.
That‰Ûªs absurd.
You initialed it. See? L.H., L.H., L.H.
Wait, I only initialed it because I never thought it would happen! I initialed another clause naming you my sidekick in case I get superpowers.

Hmm, yes, you did. Now, to review the following provisions are hereby activated. In the refrigerator, as opposed to us having two separate shelves and one communal shelf, the three of us now get individual shelves and the door becomes communal. Next, apartment vacuuming shall be increased from two to three times a week to accommodate the increased accumulation of dead skin cells. Third,the bathroom schedule. Now, I‰Ûªm given to understand women have different needs, so, we‰Ûªll have to discuss that.
I‰Ûªm going to bed.

At least take this with you. Look, and have Stephanie initial here, here, here, here and here. This states that she does not now nor does she intend to play a percussive or brass instrument. Sure it sounds like a tumor pressing on the auditory nerve.
The kitchen.
No, absolutely not.
It‰Ûªs not a big deal. We have latex gloves.
I don‰Ûªt care what the symptoms are, my girlfriend is not going to give you a prostate exam.
Hi, Sheldon.
Good morning, Dr. Stephanie. I trust Leonard satisfied you sexually last night.
Oh come on! Sheldon, we don‰Ûªt ask questions like that.
I heard you ask it over and over. How is it inappropriate for me to ask it once?
He did very nicely.
See? She‰Ûªs not offended. And now you finally have an answer.
Out of coffee. Need coffee.
Uh, hello.
Hi! Stephanie, right?
Uh-huh. And, and, and you are?
I‰Ûªm Penny, I live across the hall. I‰Ûªve heard a lot about you.
Really?
Mm-hmm.
I haven‰Ûªt heard a thing about you. Leonard? Why haven‰Ûªt I heard a thing about this woman who lives across the hall and comes into your apartment in the morning in her underwear?
She‰Ûªs heard about you because we‰Ûªre, you know, involved and you haven‰Ûªt heard about her because‰Û_ I never slept with her, I swear!
In Leonard‰Ûªs defence, it wasn‰Ûªt for lack of trying.

In the pre-Christian era, as the winter solstice approached and the plants died, pagans brought evergreen boughs into their homes as an act of sympathetic magic, intended to guard the life essences of the plants until spring. This custom was later appropriated by Northern Europeans and eventually it becomes the so-called Christmas tree.

What did I ever do to Jimmy Mullins in the third grade? He still punched me in the face with my own fists. Sorry, you little nerd, you were just in the wrong boys‰Ûª room at the wrong time.
Gentlemen, goggles.
Yeah, this is an auspicious moment. Yeah, like Robert Oppenheimer or Neil Armstrong, we need the appropriate words to mark this historic scientific event.
How about ‰ÛÏDie, toaster, die‰Û?
That‰Ûªll do it.

character: Raj (after watching complete destruction of toaster oven)
line: All right, what‰Ûªs next?
The stairwell.
No, I think I‰Ûªm just going to stay in tonight and do laundry. (Monte bursts through boys door. Penny screams and runs down the stairs.)
Outside in stairwell
Oh yeah, they still got the full Monte.
Leonard?
Uh-huh?
What the hell?
Killer robot. We built it.
Yeah, well, it almost killed me.
If it wanted to kill you, you‰Ûªd be dead.
So, who exactly does it want to kill?
I‰Ûªm sorry, are you unaware of the upcoming Southern California Robot Fighting League Round Robin Invitational?
You know, since I moved last year, not all my mail has been forwarded.
It‰Ûªs a big deal. There‰Ûªs an awards banquet and a dance afterward. Perhaps you‰Ûªd like to come with me. I know the other fellas would be really excited to see a girl there.
How is it supposed to be a dance if I‰Ûªm the only girl?
Well, that may be a slight exaggeration. You‰Ûªd be the only doable girl.
You‰Ûªre a pig, Howard.
How is doable anything but a compliment?
Howard, why don‰Ûªt we just work on the robot?
Please, Leonard, not now. Once again, Penny and I have begun our little tango.
Our tango?
The carnal repartee, the erotic to and fro. But as delicious as the appetizer might be, at some point we will have to succumb and eat the entree while it‰Ûªs still‰Û_ hot.
I‰Ûªm begging you, stop talking.
Look, normally I can just ignore you. I mean, I get it, you‰Ûªre a little peculiar. You know, like Sheldon.
Yeah, excuse me, Penny, but in this room, you‰Ûªre the one who‰Ûªs peculiar.
Yeah, you might be right. But back to you. I know you think you‰Ûªre some sort of smooth-talking ladies‰Ûª man, but the truth is, you are just pathetic and creepy.
Um, so what are you saying?

I am saying it is not a compliment to call me doable. It‰Ûªs not sexy to stare at my ass and say, ‰ÛÏOoh, it must be jelly ‰Ûªcause jam don‰Ûªt shake like that.‰Û And most important, we are not dancing a tango, we‰Ûªre not to‰Ûªing and fro‰Ûªing. Nothing is ever going to happen between us. Ever.
Wait a minute. This isn‰Ûªt flirting, you‰Ûªre serious.
Flirting? You think I‰Ûªm flirting with you? I am not flirting with you, no woman is ever gonna flirt with you, you‰Ûªre just gonna grow old and die alone.
Thanks for the heads up.
Howard, where you going?
I‰Ûªm going home to live my creepy, pathetic life.
Wow.
Well, someone had to say it. (Raj whispers in Leonard‰Ûªs ear) What?
He said maybe we should enter you in the killer robot competition.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Howard, the phone is ringing!
Here‰Ûªs a crazy idea, Ma, answer it!
Hello? All right, hold on. It‰Ûªs your friend, Leonard! He wants to know why you‰Ûªre not at school today!
I don‰Ûªt go to school, Ma. I work at a university.
That‰Ûªs a school! Now pick up the phone!
I don‰Ûªt want to talk to anybody.
Should I ask Leonard to bring over your homework?!
I don‰Ûªt have homework. I‰Ûªm a grown man with a master‰Ûªs degree in engineering!
Excuse me, Mr. Fancy-Pants. Want me to get you a Popsicle?
Cherry, please!
I ate the cherry. All that‰Ûªs left is green.
You make me want to kill myself.
The university cafeteria. Other end of the phone call.
What‰Ûªs going on?
I don‰Ûªt know, now they‰Ûªre just yelling about Popsicles. Sounds like Penny really got to him.

I‰Ûªm not surprised. Despite his hard and crusty shell, Howard is a very sensitive man. Do you know he writes poetry? Mostly about men from Nantucket and hermits named Dave, but he does it with real sensitivity.
Hey, Hofstadter. Word around the pwasma wab is you built a wobot?
Yes, we did, Kripke.
His name is Monte.

Well, if you have any dewusions about entewing him against my wobot, the Kwipke Kwippler in the Southern California Wobot Fighting League Wound Wobin Invitational, aka the S.C.aw.F.L.aw.aw.I., his name is gonna be Swrap Metal.
Come on, is that really necessary?

Leonard, I believe it is. This is trash talk, and trash talk is a traditional component in all sporting events. Kripke, your robot is inferior and it will be defeated by ours because ours exceeds yours in both design and execution. Also, I‰Ûªm given to understand that your mother is overweight.
Oh, snap.
Now, of course, if that is the result of a glandular condition and not sloth and gluttony, I withdraw that comment.
What difference does it make? Fat is fat.
There are boundaries.
Tell you what, forget the S.C.aw.F.L.aw.aw.I., let‰Ûªs settle this woboto a woboto.
What do you mean?
There‰Ûªs no guawantee we‰Ûªve gotta go against each other in the Wound Wobin, so let‰Ûªs thwow down. You know, unless you‰Ûªre afwaid.
We accept your challenge. Name a time and place.
Tomowow, thwee o‰Ûªclock, the kinetics wab.
Make it so.
No, don‰Ûªt make it so. Barry, we can‰Ûªt fight you tomorrow, our engineer is incapacitated.
What‰Ûªs wrong with him?
He‰Ûªs depressed because he‰Ûªs pathetic and creepy and he can‰Ûªt get girls.
We‰Ûªre all pathetic and cweepy and can‰Ûªt get girls, that‰Ûªs why we fight wobots. If you‰Ûªre not there, you‰Ûªll be exposed to widicule.
I‰Ûªm curious, what part of America is that accent from?
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door.
Hey.
Hey, you got a minute?
Yeah, come on in. What‰Ûªs up?
I need you to apologize to How‰Û_
Get out.
Come on. Wolowitz won‰Ûªt come out of his house and we need him for a robot battle.
Well, then have the robot go and get him.
The robot didn‰Ûªt hurt his feelings.
His feelings needed to be hurt.
He‰Ûªs been in bed for two days.
Yeah, probably with a blow-up doll.
He‰Ûªs not with a‰Û_ does it really matter who or what he‰Ûªs with? The guy is devastated.
Oh, please, how could I possibly devastate Howard?
Okay, don‰Ûªt take this as a criticism, but you kind of have that overexposed-to-gamma-rays thing going on.
What does that mean?
You know, like, most of the time, you‰Ûªre the easygoing Bruce Banner, but then, when you get angry, you kind of turn into, like, you know, grrrrr!
I turn into a bear?
Seriously? Gamma rays? Bruce Banner? You didn‰Ûªt get The Incredible Hulk from that? Never mind, just, please go talk to him.
And say what? That I didn‰Ûªt mean it, because I meant it.
Well, maybe you can go at it from a different angle, like, um, you see a glimmer of goodness in him and you only said what you said because you want to nurture it and make it shine.
Oh, pthththth.

Okay, let‰Ûªs try it this way. Remember the day that we first met and you asked me to go to your boyfriend‰Ûªs apartment to get your TV back and he was nine feet tall and he took my pants off and you said‰Û_ what was that? What did you say? Oh, yes, you said you owed me one.
Okay, come on, that‰Ûªs not fair.
I came home with no pants.
Fine, I‰Ûªll go over there tomorrow.
Thank you. I should probably give you a heads up about his mother.
What about her?
She‰Ûªs a delightful woman. You‰Ûªll love her.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Howard, there‰Ûªs a blonde girl, Patsy, here to see you!
Who?
Okay, now she‰Ûªs saying it‰Ûªs Penny.
I don‰Ûªt want to talk to her.
Hey.
Ma!
She ran past me. Was I supposed to tackle her?
So, I just came by to see how you were doing.
I‰Ûªm fine.
Good. Your mom seems nice.
People move away from her on the bus. What do you want?
Okay, look. Howard, I just want to apologize for some things that I have said. About you. I‰Ûªve been informed that you have feelings. And apparently, I have hurt them. So, I‰Ûªm sorry. Howard.
Fine, you‰Ûªre sorry. Good-bye.
So, you‰Ûªre okay?
Hey, I‰Ûªm a big boy. I‰Ûªm not traumatized by some random comment from some random woman. I mean, get over yourself.
Okay. Well, bye. (Penny leaves room. Sound of Howard crying through door.) So close (goes back in.)
The apartment. The guys are watching footage on a laptop screen.
Oh, my God. That‰Ûªs Kripke‰Ûªs robot?
As you can see, the Kwippler is weducing the Chevy Cavawier to wubble.
I can‰Ûªt watch anymore.
Sheldon, we have to call it off.
We don‰Ûªt have that option, we‰Ûªve accepted the challenge. We can‰Ûªt run away from a fight.
Oh, please, we‰Ûªve spent our whole lives running away from fights. Personally, I can squeeze through a hole in a fence half my size.
Impressive as that may be, Monte is not us. Monte has no fear.
Sheldon, did we all not just watch the same video? Kripke‰Ûªs robot just had angry sex with a mid-sized automobile.
You are overlooking the fact that we now know what we‰Ûªre up against and we can modify Monte so that he‰Ûªs prepared.
You want to prepare him? Install a bladder and a pair of shorts so he can wet himself.
Excuse me, but how are we going to make any modifications without Wolowitz? Have you heard from Penny yet?
Not yet.
Have faith, gentlemen. We don‰Ûªt need Wolowitz, engineering is merely the slow younger brother of physics. Watch and learn. Do either of you know how to open the toolbox?
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.

And then, when I was 14, I met Marcy Grossman. She was so beautiful. She just got her braces off but they left a little of the overbite. It was so hot, like a sexy little chipmunk. I didn‰Ûªt have the courage to ask her out, but I dedicated a song to her at the ninth grade talent show.
Aw, that sounds sweet.
Marcy Grossman is sunshine, on a cloudy day, when it‰Ûªs cold outside, Marcy Grossman is the month of May‰Û_
Oh, it‰Ûªs cute.
I guess you‰Ûªd say, what can make me feel this way, Marcy Grossman, Marcy Grossman, Marcy Grossman, Talkin‰Ûª ‰Ûªbout Marcy‰Û_
That‰Ûªs great.
Grossman.
Oh, it‰Ûªs fun.
And then she came up with that sexy little chipmunk mouth and spit in my hair. Which brings us to tenth grade.
Howard, do you think maybe sometimes you try too hard?
Look at me. What chance do I have if I don‰Ûªt try too hard?
Well, you‰Ûªd have a terrific chance. I mean, you‰Ûªre smart, you‰Ûªre funny, you have a cool job. You build stuff that goes into outer space.
I guess.
Look, I‰Ûªm telling you, I‰Ûªve known you for, like, a year and a half and this is the first time I feel like I‰Ûªm talking to a real person. And you know what? I like him, he‰Ûªs a nice guy.
You really think so?
Yes.
I don‰Ûªt know.
I do. (Howard tries to kiss her. She punches him.)
The lab.
Nice little bot you‰Ûªve got here.
I‰Ûªm aware.
What‰Ûªs this do, spin?
Yep. At 3400 RPM. It can cut through steel like it was wubber.
Neat. Good work. Sheldon, we‰Ûªve got to call this off.
No, Leonard. For years, merciless thugs like Kripke have made my life a series of painful noogies and humiliating wedgies and the insensitively named Indian burns. That stops now.
But, Sheldon, we don‰Ûªt have a chance. The only improvement you were able to make on the robot was to put fresh batteries in the remote.
What you fail to realize is Kripke suffers from a fatal flaw, overconfidence from his robot‰Ûªs massive size and its overwhelming power.
That‰Ûªs not overconfidence, that‰Ûªs observation.
Trust me, Kripke will fall easy prey to my psychological warfare. Observe. Kripke! I would ask if your robot is prepared to meet its maker, but as you are its maker, clearly the two of you have met.
What is his pwoblem?
Way to bust out the Jedi mind tricks, dude.
I just want to make sure that we‰Ûªre all clear, standard robotic fighting league rules apply.
Are you cwazy? This is a stweet fight, the stweet has no rules.
He‰Ûªs right, Leonard. The paradigm is to the death.
I will, however, give you the opportunity to concede my supewiowity now and offer me your wobot as the spoils of war.
Never. I‰Ûªd rather see Monte dead than in your hands.
That could be easily awanged. Weady, set, go?
Do it.
Alwight then. Weady. Set. Go.
Come on, Sheldon, you got this.
Indeed. We are prepared for anything he can throw at us. (A flame begins to jet out of Kripke‰Ûªs robot.) That‰Ûªs new.
Run, Monte, run!
Go, Monte! Go Monte!
Go, go, go, go!
Don‰Ûªt hurt us, don‰Ûªt hurt us,
The apartment. Monte is in pieces on the table.
Well, so much for making up for the emotional wounds of childhood.
I did this. Monte was killed by my hubris and my pride. No matter what anybody says, this is my fault.
No one‰Ûªs arguing with you, dude.
I got your text. How bad is‰Û_ Oy.
Forget the robot. What happened to you?
He slipped and fell.
Yes, I slipped and fell. In the bathroom. Bounced right off the tub.
Yes, now he knows what bathtubs are capable of doing when you don‰Ûªt treat them with respect.
Yeah. They sucker punch you when your eyes are closed.
So what do you think, Howard? It‰Ûªs not that bad, right?
Oh, no. A little electrical tape, some solder. Are you insane? I‰Ûªve seen space probes that crashed into the desert that were in better shape than this.
You‰Ûªre right. Monte‰Ûªs gone. We‰Ûªll bury him in the morning. A simple ceremony. I‰Ûªll speak. Leonard, you‰Ûªll play your cello.
Sheldon, honey, aren‰Ûªt you getting a little carried away? I mean, it‰Ûªs just a toy robot.
Just a toy robot?
Penny.
I know, I got it. Sheldon, I‰Ûªm sorry.
Well, don‰Ûªt get the wrong idea. The way I see it, I‰Ûªm halfway to pity sex.
The university cafeteria
Mmm, gentlemen, I put it to you, the worst tapioca pudding is better than the best pudding of any other flavour.

First off, that is axiomatically wrong, because the best pudding is chocolate. Secondly, the organic structure of tapioca makes it a jiggling bowl of potential death. It is extracted from the plant‰Û_
Hey, I‰Ûªm thinking of growing a mustache.
Ah, no kidding! A Fu Man Chu? A handlebar pencil?
It is extracted from the plant‰Û_
I‰Ûªm not sure yet. You know, George Clooney has one now!
Really? I once saw him shopping at Ralph‰Ûªs. He was buying tequila.
Oh, you‰Ûªd think a guy like that would have some kind of booze lackey.
Alright this is cruel, we better let him finish before his head explodes.
Alright Sheldon, why is tapioca‰Û_
Tapioca is extracted from the root of the plant Manihot Esculenta. Due to a high concentration of cyanide it is poisonous in its raw form and lethal if prepared improperly.
Feel better now?
It is also indigenous to Brazil, as is the Cocoa Bean, from which we get chocolate, the best pudding. And you promised you wouldn‰Ûªt do that anymore!
Hey Hofstadter!
Hey Kripke.
Heard about your watest pwoton decay expewiment, twenty thousand data wuns and no statistically significant wesults. Vewy impwessive!
What a jerk.
Don‰Ûªt feel bad Leonard, negative results are still results.
Even twenty thousand of ‰Ûªem.
Alright, please don‰Ûªt cheer me up anymore.
C‰Ûªmon, don‰Ûªt let him get to you. It‰Ûªs Kripke.
Yeah, he‰Ûªs a ginormous knob.
That‰Ûªs why he eats by himself, instead of sitting here at the cool table.
Fo‰Ûª shizzle.

Hey it‰Ûªs true, Kripke lacks the basic social skills that we take for granted, but he also controls the new open science grid computer that I need to use to run some simulations of structure formation in the early universe.
Good luck getting time on it. The only people he lets use it are his friends.
Well then, the solution is simple. I shall befriend him. Kripke!
Yeah?
What‰Ûªd you say of the idea of you and I becoming friends?
I would say, I have no intewest in becoming your fwiend.
Really? That seems rather short sighted, coming from someone who is generally considered altogether unlikable. Why don‰Ûªt you take some time to reconsider?
Yeah, I‰Ûªll do that.
Well I think we‰Ûªre off to a terrific start.
The apartment.
There you go. Now any e-mail from Wolowitz will go right into your spam folder.
Thanks! I mean the e-mail doesn‰Ûªt bother me as much as the vacation pictures of him in a bathing suit.
Yeah, I got the same one. And that‰Ûªs not a bathing suit, it‰Ûªs a tan line.

Hello. This is Sheldon Cooper. I‰Ûªm leaving a message for Barry Kripke. Barry, It was pleasant seeing you today in the cafeteria. I saw that you purchased the chef‰Ûªs salad. Apparently, you did not know that the chef‰Ûªs salad is kitchen trickery, to utilize scrap meat. Nevertheless, I hope you enjoyed it. I‰Ûªm following up on our pending friendship, and I look forward to hearing from you regarding its status. Sheldon Cooper.
What‰Ûªs up with Ichabod?
Oh he‰Ûªs trying to make a new friend.
Oh really? Well, good for him.
Well, unless he‰Ûªs makes one out of wood like Gepetto, I don‰Ûªt think it‰Ûªs gonna happen.
Well, how did you guys become friends?
There was a flier on the bulletin board at the university. Roommate wanted. Whistlers need not apply.
And you moved in anyway?
I assumed he was joking. You‰Ûªd be surprised how many particle physicists have a whimsical side.
Well, what about Howard and Raj, I mean how did you become friends with them?
I don‰Ûªt know, how do carbon atoms form a benzene ring? Proximity and valence electrons.
Well yeah, sure. When you put it that way. But it all worked out, right?
I suppose. I do miss whistling though.
Oh come on, really? (Leonard whistles)
First warning.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door.
Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny.This is for you.
Hello Sheldon.
Hi.
What is this?
It‰Ûªs a questionnaire I devised. I‰Ûªm having some difficulty bonding with a colleague at work, so I‰Ûªm doing a little research to better understand why my current friends like me.
Yes. Well, that is a good question. But is this really the best way to figure it out?
Yeah, I agree, the social sciences are largely hokum. But, short of putting electrodes in your brain and monitoring your response to my companionship, this is the best I can do.
Okay, question 1. Rank the following aspects of Sheldon Cooper in order of appeal. Intelligence. Ruthless attention to hygiene. Playfulness. Java applet writing?

I know, I may have started off with a fairly obvious one. You did an aspect of my most appealing trait, playfulness. Why don‰Ûªt you just go ahead and write that number 1. I‰Ûªm afraid you‰Ûªre on your own for the rest. It should take you no more than 3 hours.
Wait! How many questions are on this thing?
Only 211. Don‰Ûªt worry, in deference to you, I‰Ûªve kept them on a high school graduate reading level.
Thanks pal.
You got it, buddy.
Sheldon honey, did you ever consider making friends by being, I don‰Ûªt know, pleasant?
Well that‰Ûªs certainly a thought-provoking hypothesis. May I suggest it as the topic for your essay.
The apartment. Sheldon is reading one of the questionnaires. He tuts.
Your questionnaire, very disappointing.
I answered every question Sheldon.
You answered the multiple choice questions in a pattern. A B B A C. A B B A C.
Aw, you picked up on that huh?
How could I not?
Come on! There‰Ûªs over 200 questions. And look at some of these things. Sheldon is to camaraderie, as the space shuttle is to blank?
Hold on. I put some real work into that!
Yes, well it‰Ûªs better than what Wolowitz did. He drew a raccoon with what appears to be, a distended scrotum.
It‰Ûªs kinda cute, until you get to the scrotum.
What hope do I have for establishing new relationships given that my current friends apparently cannot take a few hours out of their lives to help me?
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm not going to defend a big-balled raccoon.
I don‰Ûªt see how you could.
What I‰Ûªm trying to say is that, maybe you can‰Ûªt approach this as a purely intellectual exercise.
What do you mean!?
Well, remember when you tried to learn how to swim using the internet?
I did learn how to swim.
On the floor.
The skills are transferrable. I just have no interest in going in the water.
Then why learn how to swim?

The ice caps are melting Leonard. In the future, swimming isn‰Ûªt going to be optional. But you do bring up an interesting point. I don‰Ûªt have to break new ground here, I‰Ûªm sure much of the research already exists.
No! no, my point is, if you want to learn how to make friends, then just go out to a coffee shop or a museum. Meet people. Talk to them. Take an interest in their lives.
That‰Ûªs insane on the face of it. Come on.
Where are we going?
You‰Ûªre driving me to the mall. I‰Ûªm going to acquire a book that summarizes the current theories in the field of friendmaking.
Why don‰Ûªt you just lie down on the floor and swim there?
A bookshop.
Coping with the death of a loved one. My condolences.
Thank you.
Family or friend?
Family.
Too bad. If it‰Ûªd been a friend, I‰Ûªm available to fill the void. (Woman moves away) It‰Ûªs just as well, she smelled like moth balls.
Okay, if you‰Ûªre gonna start sniffing people, I‰Ûªm gonna go get a hot pretzel.
Excuse me. Do you have any books about making friends?
Um, yeah but they‰Ûªre all for little kids.
I assume the skills can be extrapolated and transferred.
Uh, I guess. They‰Ûªre right over there by the wooden train set.
Oh! I love trains!
I bet you do.

Oh my! That‰Ûªs awfully sticky. Alright, let‰Ûªs see. Bernie Bunny has Two Daddies Now. It‰Ûªs probably about homosexual rabbits. Jerry the Gerbil and the Bullies on the Bus. Read it, not helpful. Oh! Here we go. Stu the Cockatoo is New at the Zoo. Author Sarah Carpenter lives in Fort Wayne, Indiana, with her husband and best friend Mark, and their cockatoos too. Hardly makes her an expert in making friends, wouldn‰Ûªt you agree?
I don‰Ûªt like birds, they scare me.
Me too! Most people don‰Ûªt see it. What are you reading?
Curious George.
Oh I do like monkeys!
Curious George is a monkey.
Somewhat anthropomorphized but yes. Say, maybe sometime you and I can go see monkeys together. Would you like that?
Okay.
Sheldon, what are you doing?
I‰Ûªm making friends with this little girl. What‰Ûªs your name?
Rebecca.
Hi Rebecca, I‰Ûªm your new friend, Sheldon.
No you‰Ûªre not, let‰Ûªs go.
We were really hitting it off.
Don‰Ûªt look up, there‰Ûªs cameras.
The stairwell.
I‰Ûªm curious. In the ‰ÛÏHow Well Do You Know Sheldon‰Û section, what do you put for his favourite amino acid?
Lysine.
Damn it. I had Lysine and changed it.
Oh good! You‰Ûªre just in time. I believe I‰Ûªve isolated the algorithm for making friends.
Sheldon, there is no algorithm for making friends!
Hear him out. If he‰Ûªs really on to something, we can open a booth at Comic-Con, make a fortune.
See, my initial approach to Kripke, had the same deficiencies as those that plagued Stu the Cockatoo, when he was new at the zoo.
Stu the cockatoo?
Yes, he‰Ûªs new at the zoo.
It‰Ûªs a terrific book. I‰Ûªve distilled its essence into a simple flowchart that would guide me through the process.
Have you thought about putting him in a crate while you‰Ûªre out of the apartment?

Hello, Kripke. Yes, Sheldon Cooper here. It occurred to me you hadn‰Ûªt returned any of my calls because I hadn‰Ûªt offered any concrete suggestions for pursuing our friendship. Perhaps the two of us might share a meal together‰Û_ I see. Well then perhaps you‰Ûªd have time for a hot beverage. Popular choices include tea, coffee, cocoa‰Û_ I see. No, no, no, wait. Don‰Ûªt hang up yet. What about a recreational activity? I bet we share some common interests. Tell me an interest of yours. Really? On actual horses? Tell me another interest of yours. Oh no, I‰Ûªm sorry, I have no desire to get in the water until I absolutely have to. Tell me another interest of yours.
Uh-oh, he‰Ûªs stuck in an infinite loop.
I can fix it.

Mmhmm. Mmhmm. It‰Ûªs interesting. But isn‰Ûªt ventriloquism, by definition, a solo activity? Yeah? Tell me another interest of yours. Hmmm. Is there any chance you like monkeys? What is wrong with you? Everybody likes monkeys. Hang on, Kripke. (Checking changes Howard has made to his flowchart) A loop counter? And an escape to the least objectionable activity! Howard, that‰Ûªs brilliant! I‰Ûªm surprised you saw that.
Gee. Why can‰Ûªt Sheldon make friends?

Alright Kripke, that last interest strikes me as the least objectionable and I would like to propose that we do that together. Tomorrow. Yes, I‰Ûªll pay. Alright, goodbye. Alright! Time to learn rock climbing.
Rock climbing centre. Sheldon and Kripke are watching someone descend the practice wall.
You know, I am a fan of ventriloquism. Maybe you, me and your dummy could go get a hot beverage. He could talk while you drink.
Nope, I wanna climb some wocks.
This appears significantly more monolithic than it did on my laptop. No, one expects to see Hominids learning to use bones as weapeons.
You afwaid of heights, Cooper?
Hardly. Fear of heights is illogical. Fear of falling, on the other hand, is prudent and evolutionary. What would you say is the minimum altitude I need to achieve to cement our new-found friendship?
Come on, they have birthday parties here. Wittle kids climb this.
Little kid Hominids, perhaps. (To man who attaches him to ropes) Is this your entire job? Your parents must be so proud.
Let‰Ûªs go, Cooper.
Coming, Kripke. Okay. Harness seems to be secure. Small amount of incontinence just now, but the website said that‰Ûªs to be expected. Hey, this isn‰Ûªt so bad. A bit like vertical swimming.
Hey, look at you, Cooper. You‰Ûªre almost halfway to the top.
I am? I was wrong. It IS a fear of heights.
