That‰Ûªs over the wheelbase. Are you completely unfamiliar with the suspension characteristics of a pre-1980 Pullman-built Superliner Deluxe passenger coach?
Sheldon, we‰Ûªve been on this train 90 seconds, and you‰Ûªve already said a thousand words. Just tell us where to sit and shut up.
Here. I‰Ûªm hoping once you reap the endorphic rewards of the steady clickety-clack of steel wheels on polished rails, your sour disposition will abate.
Yeah, maybe. Meanwhile back in the 21st century, people are raising their tray tables and putting their seat-backs in an upright position ‰Ûªcause it‰Ûªs time to land in San Francisco.
It‰Ûªs not so bad, really. At least these trains have modern plumbing. In India, you squat over a hole in the train and expose your naked buttocks to the chilly air of Rajasthan.
He is referring, of course, to third class on Indian Railways‰Ûª magnificent Ranakpur Express and its twelve hundred kilometer journey from Maharashtra to the Bikaner Junction.
Oh, look, now he‰Ûªs boring on an international scale.
Holy crap! Look!
Is that who I think it is?
It can‰Ûªt be. What would Summer Glau be doing riding the train?
Maybe John Connor‰Ûªs aboard and she‰Ûªs protecting him from an evil Terminator.
Unlikely. That‰Ûªs a television show, Leonard.
Thank you.

Of course, if SkyNet actually did exist in the future, a perfect way to infiltrate and destroy mankind would be to send Terminators back posing as actors who have played Terminators in popular films and television series, lulling us into a false sense of security, i.e., that‰Ûªs Summer Glau from The Sarah Connor Chronicles. No, Summer, don‰Ûªt kill me! I‰Ûªm pro-robot! Ahh!
At least he‰Ûªs off the train crap.
Whee!
Sheldon, I owe you an apology. Taking the train was a stroke of brilliance! I‰Ûªve actually got a shot at a Terminator.
Oh, please.When it comes to Terminators, you‰Ûªve got a better shot of scoring with Arnold Schwarzenegger.

You‰Ûªre overlooking something. I have 11 hours with her in a confined space. Unless she‰Ûªs willing to jump off a moving train, tuck and roll down the side of a hill, she will eventually succumb to the acquired taste that is Howard Wolowitz.
My money‰Ûªs on tuck and roll.
I‰Ûªm confused. I thought you were involved in some sort of socially intimate pairing with Leslie Winkle.
Sheldon, let me explain to you how this works.
All right.
That‰Ûªs Summer Glau.
Yes.
That‰Ûªs it.
Hang on a sec. Why do you get first crack at her?
Um, well, let‰Ûªs see, couple reasons. One, I saw her first.
No, you didn‰Ûªt. I did.
Fair enough. But then let me move on to number two, unlike you, I can actually talk to women when I‰Ûªm sober.
You fail to take into account that even mute, I am foreign and exotic, while you, on the other hand, are frail and pasty.
Well, you know the old saying, pasty and frail never fail.
Excuse me, but what about me? Why don‰Ûªt I get a shot?
Fine, go ahead. Take a shot.
You know, I‰Ûªve already got a gorgeous blonde back home at I can‰Ûªt score with. I think I‰Ûªll let you two take this one.
Sheldon, is there a place on this train to get alcohol?
Interesting that you ask. The Coast Starlight recently added the refurbished Pacific Parlour Car. Built in 1956 and originally known as the Santa Fe Lounge Car, the lower level is a theatre‰Û_
Yeah-yeah, which way?
and the upper level is a bar that offers wine tastings if you‰Ûªre going as far as Portland.
So aren‰Ûªt you going to go talk to her?
I will, I‰Ûªm just working on my opening line.
She‰Ûªs probably heard every possible line, Howard. Why don‰Ûªt you just try hello?
No, no, no, that always creeps girls out. I need to come up with something that‰Ûªs funny, smart and delicately suggests that my sexual endowment is disproportionate to my physical stature.
You‰Ûªre going to need more than 11 hours.
Oh, no.
What‰Ûªs the matter?
I forgot my flash drive.
So?
So we have to go back.
Okay, Sheldon, I‰Ûªm going to say why and your answer cannot be because I forgot my flash drive.
You don‰Ûªt understand. My flash drive has my paper on astrophysical probes of M-theory effects in the early universe that I was going to give to George Smoot at the conference.
Why do you have to give your paper to George Smoot?
It‰Ûªs brilliant. He needs to read it.
So you‰Ûªll send him an e-mail when we get back.
Then I won‰Ûªt get to see his face light up as he reads it.
Right. Of course.
Oh, this is an unmitigated disaster.
Well, there‰Ûªs nothing you can do about it, so relax, sit back, enjoy the clickety-clack of the steel wheels on the polished rails.
You forgot your flash drive, You forgot your flash drive (repeated over and over in time to the sound of the train)
Only ten hours, 55 minutes to go.

character: Howard (steeling himself to talk to Summer Glau, to himself)
line: It‰Ûªs hot in here. Must be Summer. (Walks towards her, then walks straight past. Returns, makes to talk to her, then turns to two nuns over the other side of the corridor) So, where you gals headed?
I‰Ûªve got a better idea.
Are you going to be sarcastic?
Boy, you take all the fun out of it for me.åÊ But look, Penny‰Ûªs home. Why don‰Ûªt we just call her, have her go in the apartment, get your flash drive and e-mail you the paper?
But the flash drive is in a locked drawer in my desk.
So?
The key is hidden in my room.
So?
Penny would have to go into my room.
So?
People don‰Ûªt go in my room!
I see. Well, it seems once again, you‰Ûªre caught between a rock and a crazy place.
Oh, I hate when that happens.
It‰Ûªs hot in here. It must be Summer. It‰Ûªs hot in here. Must be Summer. It‰Ûªs hot in here. Must be Summer.

character: Raj (walking past and straight up to Summer Glau)
line: It‰Ûªs hot in here. Must be Summer.
That‰Ûªs cute.
Really? I just made it up. Have you seen Slumdog Millionaire?
Oh, yeah, I loved it.
It‰Ûªs loosely based on my life.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. Penny is on the phone.

Yeah, we‰Ûªre putting the play on for one night in this little 99-seat theatre. Can you come? Oh, great. Do you know 98 other people that might want to come? Oh, hang on. (Switches to another line) Hello?
Listen carefully. I‰Ûªm about to give you a set of instructions, which you must follow to the letter.

Just a sec. (Switches back to first line) The theatre is above a bowling alley, so it‰Ûªs a little noisy, but it might be the only chance I‰Ûªll ever get to play Anne Frank. And the director is brilliant. He uses the bowling sounds as, like, Nazi artillery. Okay, great, I‰Ûªll see you then. (Switches line again) Hello?
Okay, step four. Do you see that small plastic case on my dresser?
Your dresser? Who is this?
It‰Ûªs Sheldon.
Oh, hey, Sheldon! How is San Francisco?
I‰Ûªm not in San Francisco. I‰Ûªm on a train. Were you even listening to me?
Uh, no, I was talking to my friend, but what‰Ûªs up?
What‰Ûªs up? I‰Ûªll tell you what‰Ûªs up. I‰Ûªm in a crisis situation, and I need you to marshal your powers of concentration, limited as they may be‰Û_
Give me the phone. Hi, Penny. It‰Ûªs Leonard.
Hey, Leonard. What‰Ûªs going on with Dr. Wackadoodle?
He‰Ûªs calling to ask you a favour. You might be confused because he didn‰Ûªt use the words, Penny, Sheldon, please or favour.
Okay. Enough chitchat. Okay, step one, locate your emergency key to our apartment. Step two, enter our apartment. Step three, enter my bedroom.
Oh, hang on, Sheldon, getting another call.
No! Leonard, let me tell you something. Personal robots cannot get here soon enough.
And that bright little star peeking her head out early today, that‰Ûªs Venus.
That is so cool. You really know a lot about space.
Come on. When you were on TV in Firefly, you were actually in space.
You‰Ûªre not one of those guys who really believe that, are you?
You mean one of the hopeless geeks? No. Those are crazy people. Howard, be a dear and get me another one of these. Now, him, he‰Ûªs one of those geeks.
All right, now, before you enter my bedroom unescorted, I need you to understand that this onetime grant of access does not create a permanent easement. Easement. It‰Ûªs a legal right
Do you believe him? Normally around women, he has the personality of a boiled potato. Put one beer in him, and he‰Ûªs M. Night Charmalarmalon.
Is that what he‰Ûªs drinking? It‰Ûªs not even real beer.
What?
Look at it. Non-alcoholic beer.
What‰Ûªs going on?
I don‰Ûªt know. Some sort of placebo effect, I guess.
Placebo, you say. Interesting.

Yes, I‰Ûªm still here. Where am I going? I‰Ûªm on a train. Now, what you‰Ûªll be looking for is a small wooden box located between a Hoberman‰Ûªs sphere and a sample of quartz flecked with pyrite. Hoberman‰Ûªs Sphere. It‰Ûªs a collapsible icosidodecahedron. No, the thing with the time on it is my alarm clock.
Actually, in India, the names of constellations are different. Where you have the Big Dipper, we have the Big Curry Pot.
You‰Ûªre making that up.
You got me. Now what are you going to do with me?
Raj.
Yes?
Look.
What am I looking at?
You tell me.
Non-alcoholic bee-ee-eeuh (Runs off)
Hi, I‰Ûªm the small package good things come in.
Okay, I got a box, but there‰Ûªs no key in here. Just letters.
That‰Ûªs the wrong box. Put it back.
Oh, Sheldon, are these letters from your grandmother?
Don‰Ûªt read those letters!
Oh, look, she calls you Moon Pie. That is so cute.
Put down the letters!
Hey, Penny. It‰Ûªs Leonard.
Hey, Leonard. How‰Ûªs the train ride?
Delightful. Listen, I don‰Ûªt know what you‰Ûªre doing right now, but there are little bubbles forming on the corners of Sheldon‰Ûªs mouth.
Okay, yeah, I kind of crossed a line. Put him back on.
Thank you.
I‰Ûªm back.
What up, Moon Pie?
Nobody calls me Moon Pie but Meemaw!
Hey, Penny. Leonard again.

So anyway, in the dream, you and I were ice skating, just the two of us. And then, I picked you up by your ankles and twirled you round and round until your legs tore off. I tried to stick them back on, but before I could, you turned into a giant loaf of pumpernickel bread. What do you think that means?
I really don‰Ûªt know.
I‰Ûªll give you a little clue. My favourite sandwich? Salami on pumpernickel.
Is that so?
And did you know the word ‰ÛÏpumpernickel‰Û comes from the German words pumper and nickel, which loosely translates to fart goblin?
No. I didn‰Ûªt.
Okay, I found the box. Now what?

You‰Ûªre holding a Japanese puzzle box, which takes ten precise moves to open. First, locate the panel with the diamond pattern and slide the centre portion one millimetre to the left. Then, on the opposite end of the box, slide the entire panel down two millimetres. You‰Ûªll hear a slight click.
Hang on. Sheldon, do you have any emotional attachment to this box?
No, it‰Ûªs a novelty I ordered off the Internet. Now, did you hear the click?
Not yet. (Puts box on ground and stomps on it)There it is.
Okay, here‰Ûªs another one. If you married the famous rock guitarist Johnny Winter, you‰Ûªd be Summer Winter.
Uh-huh.
Okay, I‰Ûªm going to just go for broke here and say I like you.
Yeah?
So here‰Ûªs my question, do you realistically see any conversational path that would take me from where we are right now to a place where I could ask you out and you‰Ûªd say yes?
No.
Fair enough. I‰Ûªll leave you in peace.
Thank you.
But before I go, would you mind if I just take one picture of us together for my Facebook page?
Sure.
Okay. Great. Now, can I take one where it looks like we‰Ûªre making out?

Okay, now you‰Ûªre going to insert the flash drive into the USB port. She calls me Moon Pie because I‰Ûªm nummy-nummy and she could just eat me up, now, please put the flash drive in the USB port. The one that looks like a little duck‰Ûªs mouth.
Hey, how‰Ûªd it go?
Terminator broke my phone.

Excuse me. (Goes down to Summer) Okay, I‰Ûªll be honest with you. I‰Ûªve just spent the last two hours imagining various scenarios in my head, trying to come up with some clever line to say to you. But then I finally realized you‰Ûªre a human being; I‰Ûªm a human being. I could just say to you‰Û_
I‰Ûªm sorry. This is me.
Hi, my name‰Ûªs Leonard.
The conference.

So, I‰Ûªm thinking, you won the Nobel Prize what, three years ago? So you must deal with a whole lot of what has Smoot done lately? My thought is we continue my research as a team, you know, Cooper-Smoot, alphabetical, and when we win the Nobel Prize, you‰Ûªll be back on top.
With all due respect, Dr. Cooper, are you on crack?
Fine! Smoot-Cooper. Wow, what a diva.
The apartment.
Knight to queen‰Ûªs bishop-five.
Oh, very nice. What‰Ûªs Leonard going to do? Does he give up the pawn or does he give up the position?
Let‰Ûªs find out. Leonard, ready?
Ready.
Go. (Leonard sprays an aerosol which lights up laser beams. He tries to negotiate the beams as Howard and Raj sing dramatic music. Eventually he touches one of the beams and a buzzer sounds.)
Damn it. I slipped.
Too bad. You know the rules of Secret Agent Laser Obstacle Chess. Uh, Leonard died again, Sheldon. You‰Ûªre up.
Despite my deep love of chess, lasers and aerosol disinfectant, I must forfeit.
Why?
‰ÛÒ Because it‰Ûªs almost eleven o‰Ûªclock.
So?
So, Penny has a don‰Ûªt knock on my door before eleven o‰ÛªclockåÊ or I punch you in the throat rule.
Ah.
Hey, you know what‰Ûªd be a great idea? We get some girls over here and play Laser Obstacle Strip Chess.
Believe me, Howard, any girl who would be willing to play that, you don‰Ûªt want to see naked.
You underestimate me.
Outside Penny‰Ûªs door. Sheldon stands looking at his watch with his hand poised to knock. At the right moment he starts knocking.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny.
Hey, Sheldon.
It‰Ûªs eleven am.
I know. You‰Ûªre safe.
This package came while you were at work.
Oh, great, my rhinestones. Thank you.
Excuse me.
What?
You have to sign this.
What is it?

When I signed for the package, I was deputized by the United Parcel Service and entrusted with its final delivery. I now need you to acknowledge receipt of the package so that I‰Ûªm fully indemnified and no longer liable.
Sheldon, it‰Ûªs just a box of rhinestones.
Well, the contents are irrelevant. A legal bailment has been created. Does that mean nothing to you?
It means nothing to anybody. Come here, let me show you what I‰Ûªm doing.
Bailment describes a relationship in common law where a physical possession of personal property, or chattels, is transferred from one person, the bailor, to another person, the bailee.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Look, look, look! I started a business.
Obviously, not a cleaning business.

No, I‰Ûªm making flower barrettes. See? I call them Penny Blossoms. I made one for myself, then all the girls at work wanted one. Then I showed some to this lady who runs a shop in Old Town. She sells cards and homemade jewellery. She said she wanted to sell them. I said okay, and in one week, I made a $156.
Good for you. Sign here.
Sheldon, don‰Ûªt you get it? If this takes off, I won‰Ûªt have to be a waitress anymore.
But then who will bring me my cheeseburger on Tuesday nights?
Another waitress.
What‰Ûªs her name?
I don‰Ûªt know.
And you‰Ûªre going to let her handle my food?
Nancy. Her name is Nancy.
I think you‰Ûªre just making that up.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm sorry about your hamburger, okay? I just don‰Ûªt want to be a waitress for the rest of my life.
Cheeseburger. I get a cheeseburger.
Fine, cheeseburger.
Maybe I‰Ûªd be better off with Nancy.
So, what do you think? I mean, this could be a business, right?
How many of these can you make a day?
About twenty.
And how much profit do you make per Penny Blossom?
I don‰Ûªt know, like, 50 cents. I‰Ûªm not sure.
No, Of course you‰Ûªre not. All right, ten dollars a day times five days a week times 52 weeks a year is two thousand six hundred dollars.
That‰Ûªs all?
Before taxes.
Well, I don‰Ûªt have to pay taxes on this stuff.

I believe the Internal Revenue Service would strongly disagree. But, if you took advantage of modern marketing techniques, and you optimized your manufacturing process, you might be able to make this a viable business.
And you know about that stuff?
Penny, I‰Ûªm a physicist. I have a working knowledge of the entire universe and everything it contains.
Who‰Ûªs Radiohead?
I have a working knowledge of the important things in the universe. Good luck.
Sheldon, hold on. Could you maybe show me how to make more money with this?
Of course I could.
Sheldon, wait! Will you?
Just to be clear here, you‰Ûªre asking for my assistance.
Yes.
And you understand that will involve me telling you what to do?
I understand.
And you‰Ûªre not allowed to be sarcastic or snide to me while I‰Ûªm doing so.
Okay.
Good. Let‰Ûªs begin with the premise that everything you‰Ûªve done up to this point is wrong.
Oh, imagine that.
Sarcasm. Good-bye.
No, sorry. Wait! Please come back!
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. Penny is making a barette. Sheldon is timing her.
There. Done.
All right. 12 minutes and 17 seconds.
Pretty good, right?
That‰Ûªs 4.9 Penny Blossoms per hour. Based on your cost of materials and your wholesale selling price, you‰Ûªll effectively be paying yourself‰Û_ $5.19 a day.
A day?
There are children in a sneaker factory in Indonesia who outearn you.
That just can‰Ûªt be right.
You‰Ûªre questioning my math?
No, sorry.
Want me to show my work?
Oh, God, no, no. Just please tell me what to do about it.
All right, are you familiar with the development that resulted from HonorÌ© Blanc‰Ûªs 1778 use of interchangeable parts? The assembly line, of course.
Okay, you know what, if I‰Ûªm not allowed to be snide, you‰Ûªre not allowed to be condescending.
That wasn‰Ûªt a part of our original agreement, and I do not agree to it now.
All right, fine. How are we supposed to set up machines and conveyor belts in my apartment?

You‰Ûªre thinking of the moving assembly line, an understandable but not excusable mistake. No. The moving assembly line, that was introduced by Henry Ford in 1908. That innovation is what made possible our modern consumer culture by enabling a low-unit cost for manufactured goods. I guess that isn‰Ûªt one of the topics discussed on your Radiohead.
The apartment
Let‰Ûªs go. We‰Ûªre going to miss the coming attractions.
What‰Ûªs the matter?
I think I bruised a testicle capturing that last pawn.
Hello?
Hello. (They resume singing and working)
W-W-Wait, what‰Ûªs going on?
I assume you‰Ûªre referring to the sea shanty. It‰Ûªs a rhythmic work song designed to increase productivity.
Yeah, it‰Ûªs crazy, but it totally works. Look, we made this Penny Blossom in under three minutes.
Terrific, but that kind of raises more questions than it answers.
Penny‰Ûªs making hair accessories. I‰Ûªm helping her optimize her manufacturing process. All right, break‰Ûªs over. (They start singing again.)
Hold on. What are you using as a bonding agent?
Hot glue.
You‰Ûªre kidding. Any of the cyanoacrylates would do a better job.
It won‰Ûªt work, the flower‰Ûªs too porous.
What if we infused the bottom layer with silicone-RTV to provide a better mounting surface?
Intriguing.
Good question, what are you marketing and distribution channels?
Well, there are the waitresses at my work, and this cute, little shop in Old Town.
Hush, hush, hush, hush, hush, virtually non-existent. I‰Ûªm thinking that we set her up with a hosted turnkey e-commerce system to start.
Why not eliminate the middle man? We could install a small server farm with a static IP in her bedroom.
She‰Ûªd need some kind of industrial cooling system.

Of course, but before we set up a marketing and distribution infrastructure, we should finish optimizing the manufacturing process. To start with, she has a terrible problem with moisture-induced glitter clump.
Yeah, it‰Ûªs a bitch.
Uh, I‰Ûªve seen this before.
Where?
It‰Ûªs a common stripper problem. They dance, they sweat, they clump.
Ew.
Are you thinking about adding a desiccant like calcium sulphate?
Actually, I‰Ûªm thinking about this one stripper named Vega. But sure, calcium sulphate could work.
Let‰Ûªs think out of the box for a moment. How about a molecular sieve?
Oh!
I‰Ûªve got a spaghetti strainer in the kitchen.
Wow.
Hey, we could liberate some micro-porous charcoal from the chem lab.

Oh, great. Raj, why don‰Ûªt you and Howard go get the charcoal? Leonard, why don‰Ûªt you start working on some preliminary Web site designs. I‰Ûªll make some space in our apartment so we can move the manufacturing process.
Well, what‰Ûªs wrong with my apartment?
It‰Ûªs not my apartment.
Wait, wait, what am I going to do?
Uh, hey, it‰Ûªs your business. Do whatever you want.
Oh, okay, cool. I‰Ûªm going to take a nap.
The apartment.
I‰Ûªm still tweaking things a little bit, but this will give you the general idea of the Web site. So, what do you guys think?
Uh, pretty much any way I say that is going to hurt his feelings.
Okay, what‰Ûªs wrong with it?
‰ÛÒ What‰Ûªs wrong with it?
Not you. I wasn‰Ûªt asking you. Penny?
Uh, well, it‰Ûªs a little juvenile. I mean, it kind of looks like the MySpace page of a 13-year-old girl.
No, it doesn‰Ûªt.
Please. Dateline could use it to attract predators.
Penny, this is your enterprise, so it‰Ûªs ultimately your decision, but based on the quality of his work, I‰Ûªd strongly recommend that we let Leonard go.
You want to fire me?
What I want is irrelevant. This is Penny‰Ûªs decision. Penny?
Excuse me, but if I did such a bad job then why do we already have orders?
We do?
Uh-huh. Look. Mrs. Fiona Fondell from Huntsville, Alabama has ordered two.
No kidding. Two?
Uh-huh. Look at the comments.
Thank you, Penny Blossoms. These will be perfect to cover my bald spot. Aww, that is so sweet.
Camouflaging bald spots. That‰Ûªs primarily a male concern. Perhaps we could expand our market.
How are flower barrettes going to appeal to men?
We add Bluetooth!
Brilliant. Men love Bluetooth.
Wait a minute, wait a minute, you want to make a hair barrette with Bluetooth?
Penny, everything is better with Bluetooth.
Holy crap. Someone just ordered a thousand Penny Blossoms.
Get out! Who needs a thousand sparkly flower barrettes with rhinestones?
The Fifth Annual East Rutherford, New Jersey, Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Alliance Luau.
Oh, another market to expand into, balding gay men.
And I‰Ûªll bet lesbians love Bluetooth.
We should get to work.
Wait, wait, wait, why does it say one-day rush? Since when do we offer a one-day rush?
Amazon offers one-day rush.
Yeah, but they don‰Ûªt have to glue the books together. How the hell are we going to make a thousand Penny Blossoms in one day?
Don‰Ûªt yell at me. I‰Ûªm not manufacturing. I‰Ûªm just Web design.
Okay, well, I‰Ûªm gonna have to call them and cancel the order.
Excuse me, but was this not your goal? Financial independence through entrepreneurial brilliance and innovation? My brilliance and innovation, of course, but still.
I just don‰Ûªt see how see can pull this off.
Okay, that, right there, that equivocation and self-doubt, that is not the American spirit. Did Davy Crockett quit at the Alamo? Did Jim Bowie?
They didn‰Ûªt quit. They were massacred by, like, a gazillion angry Mexicans.
Alright, let me put it this way. Your gross receipts on this one order will be over $3,000 for one night‰Ûªs work.
You guys get started.
What are you doing?
Going online to buy shoes!
The same, later. Sheldon and Penny are making barettes, singing ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªll be coming round the mountain.‰Û
You know, if I wanted to spend my Saturday nights doing this, I could have stayed in India.
Oh, stop with the fake third world crap. Your father‰Ûªs a gynaecologist, and you had a house full of servants.
We only had four servants. And two of them were children.
How are we doing?
We have 128 assorted Penny Blossoms ready to ship.
Oh, God, we‰Ûªre never gonna finish in time. Who made Sheldon the boss anyway?
I believe I‰Ûªm hearing some negativity on the factory floor.
So?
Penny, the labour force is a living organism that must be carefully nurtured. Any counterproductive grumbling must be skilfully headed off by management. Observe. Hey! Less talk, more work!
Nicely done.
Thank you. You hear any union talk, you let me know.
Someone‰Ûªs in the kitchen with Dinah‰Û_
Someone‰Ûªs in the kitchen I know-ow-ow-ow
Someone‰Ûªs in the kitchen with Dinah‰Û_ Sheldon? Sheldon! (nudges him)
‰Û÷Cause I sold my soul to the company store.
Honey, do you want some coffee?
No, I don‰Ûªt drink coffee.
Come on, but if you don‰Ûªt stay awake we‰Ûªll never finish in time.
I‰Ûªm sorry, coffee‰Ûªs out of the question. When I moved to California, I promised my mother that I wouldn‰Ûªt start doing drugs.
Leonard, help.
Sheldon, we still have 380 of these things to make.
I have complete faith that you will make them. Good night.
Leonard?
Yeah, no. But, Sheldon, without your insight and leadership this entire enterprise will surely fail.
You‰Ûªre right, of course.
Here, this will help.
Very well, but if this leads to opiates or hallucinogenics, you‰Ûªre going to have to answer to my mother.

Look at Planck‰Ûªs Constant. People say it‰Ûªs arbitrary. It could not be less arbitrary. If it varied even slightly, life as we know it would not exist. Bam! Now, now, let‰Ûªs reconsider the entire argument, but with entropy reversed and effect preceding cause, so you are thinking of a universe that‰Ûªs not expanding from the centre, no, it is retreating from a, from a possibility space. Bam! This is a space where we are all essentially Alice through the looking glass, standing in front the Red Queen, and we‰Ûªre being offered a cracker to quench our thirst. Bam! Of course, in another universe, let‰Ûªs call it universe prime, there‰Ûªs another Sheldon, let‰Ûªs call him Sheldon prime‰Û_
We should have let him go to bed.
Bam.

It‰Ûªs a‰Û_ (gives up)

Easily calculable, we begin by identifying the set of married couples with unisex names. We then eliminate those unqualified for restaurant work, the aged, the imprisoned and the limbless, for example. Next we look at‰Û_

Well, thank you. How thoughtful. Would you like a chocolate

They‰Ûªre called tattoo sleeves. Look. I bought them online, Raj got a set, too. Fantastic, right? Put them on, have hot sex with some freaky girl with her business pierced, take them off, and I can still be buried in a Jewish cemetery.

They‰Ûªre gonna get beaten up at Walgreens. Oh, sorry, Sheldon, I almost sat in your spot.

Anime. You know, I knew a girl in high school named Anna May. Anna May Fletcher. She was born with one nostril. Then she had this bad nose job and basically wound up with three.

Yes please. (Her phone rings) Oh. Hey, Kim. Yeah, I‰Û_ (sees Sheldon looking disapprovingly) You know what, hold on, let me take this in the hall. (Sheldon silently offers her another chocolate. She takes it.) You‰Ûªll never guess who they got to replace you at work‰Û_

character: Sheldon (Squirting him with a water spray)
line: Bad Leonard.
The goth club.

Oy vay.
That sounds really cool.

Dark and fun.

well, my new bed got delivered, if you come over and put it together, you can stay at my place.

A few moments later.

I believe it means that the U.S. Government is going to expel him from the country. He could then either return to his native India, emigrate to another country that‰Ûªs willing to accept him, or wander the high seas as a stateless pirate. Personally, I‰Ûªd choose pirate.

Okay, she‰Ûªs gone.

So, my visa‰Ûªs only good as long as I‰Ûªm employed at the university, and when they find out I‰Ûªve got squat, they‰Ûªre going to cut me off. By the way, when I say squat, I mean diddly-squat. I wish I had squat.

You know, checking e-mail, updating my facebook status, messing up wikipedia entries. Hey, did you know Netflix lets you stream movies on your computer now?
And you‰Ûªve continued to take the university‰Ûªs money under false pretences? Highly unethical for an astrophysicist. Although practically mandatory for a pirate.
I don‰Ûªt want to go back to India. It‰Ûªs hot and loud, and there‰Ûªs so many people. You have no idea, they‰Ûªre everywhere.
Okay, guys, think, how do we keep Raj in the country?
Why doesn‰Ûªt he just get another job?

Oh, beef, I‰Ûªm going to miss you so much. Do you know, at the Mumbai McDonald‰Ûªs, you can‰Ûªt get a Big Mac? All you can get is a Chicken Maharaja Mac. And the special sauce, curry, which, in India,
Don‰Ûªt worry, you‰Ûªll find another job.
Yeah let me start practicing for it. Do you want fries with that Maharaja Mac?‰Û
Hi, Leonard. Hello, Raj.
Hello Sheldon.
Forgive me, as you know, I‰Ûªm no adept at reading facial cues, but I‰Ûªm going to take a stab here, you‰Ûªre either sad or nauseated.
I‰Ûªm sad.
I was going to say sad. I don‰Ûªt know why I hedged.

Elbow macaroni with ground hamburger and tomato sauce.
Oh, beefaroni. I think I‰Ûªll miss you most of all.
I‰Ûªve always been a little confused about this. Why don‰Ûªt Hindus eat beef?

Do not tell me about my own culture, Sheldon! In the mood I‰Ûªm in, I‰Ûªll take you out, I swear to cow!
I‰Ûªm sorry.
Me, too. I‰Ûªm just, I‰Ûªm a little on edge.

Hey, Raj, guess what. Professor Laughlin is looking for someone to join the stellar evolution research team.

Professor Laughlin‰Ûªs office.

No, no, it‰Ûªs a very promising area. In a perfect world I‰Ûªd spend several more years on it. But I just couldn‰Ûªt pass up the opportunity to work with you on your tremendously exciting and not yet conclusively disproved hypothesis.
Splendid. Uh, please sit down. Can I offer you a sherry?

Not on Proxima Centauri.
That‰Ûªs very good. Jolly amusing, but if you don‰Ûªt mind, I‰Ûªll hold off until sunset on titan.

It‰Ûªs nice to meet you, Dr. Koothrappali. I read your paper on Kuiper belt object size distribution. I really enjoyed it. How did you correct for the selection bias? (During this, Raj surreptitiously wanders over to where Prof Laughlin‰Ûªs drinks are, pours himself a large sherry and knocks it back in one.)

That‰Ûªs okay. A complaint has been filed. So, that‰Ûªs it. That was my last hope. I‰Ûªm going to be deported, sent home in disgrace, exposed to the sardonic barbs of my cousin Sanjay. Or, as you may know him, Dave from AT&T customer service.

Halfway is 600 miles off the coast of Japan.

Gentlemen.
Hey.

I assumed as much. But never fear. Like the subordinate male protagonist in countless action movies who disappears half way through the second reel, I have returned to save the day. Odd, usually, he‰Ûªs met by cheers. Anyway, I was thinking about exploring the string theory implications of gamma rays from dark matter annihilations, and it occurred to me that I could benefit‰Û_
Excuse me, Sheldon, how many reels before the subordinate male protagonist gets to his point?
I‰Ûªm sorry, if you didn‰Ûªt cheer at my entrance, it‰Ûªs too late to buy into the premise. Anyway, I got some extra money from the head of the department, and raj can come work for me.
You want me to work with you?
For me. You‰Ûªre going to have to listen more carefully when you‰Ûªre on the job.

Okay, uh, please don‰Ûªt take this the wrong way, but I‰Ûªd rather swim buck-naked across the Ganges with a paper cut on my nipple and die a slow, agonizing death from a viral infection than work with you.
For me.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.

Yes, for you. I do, however, have a few conditions. First, at all times, I am to be treated as a colleague and an equal. Second, my contributions shall be noted in all published material. And third, you are never allowed to lecture me on Hinduism or my Indian culture.

I‰Ûªm sorry, I believe you‰Ûªve misunderstood. I‰Ûªm not giving you the job. I‰Ûªm simply affording you the opportunity to apply for it. Have a seat, we‰Ûªll get started with the interview.
Wha‰Û_ You‰Ûªre kidding!
Please.
All right.
So, that‰Ûªs what you wear to an interview?
Come on, dude, we‰Ûªve been friends for years.

Sheldon, for God‰Ûªs sakes, don‰Ûªt make me beg.
Bazinga! You‰Ûªve fallen victim to another one of my classic practical jokes. I‰Ûªm your boss now. You may want to laugh at that.
The apartment.
Ah, it‰Ûªs nice having the place to ourselves, isn‰Ûªt it?
Uh-huh. Now that Raj is working for Sheldon, I don‰Ûªt have to chauffeur him around anymore. Plus, yeah, with them working late so much, we get some privacy.
Mm-hmm. Hey, want to get a little crazy?
What are you thinking?
Let‰Ûªs slide over to Sheldon‰Ûªs spot a make out.
You are a dirty girl.

character: Penny (as the making out is interrupted by a knock on the door)
line: Oh, God, how did he know?
Hello.
Hi, Howard.
Am I interrupting?
Little bit, yeah.
Guess I should have called.
Yeah, maybe.
Tonight‰Ûªs the night I usually go line dancing with Raj at the palomino.
Uh-huh.
But he‰Ûªs working with Sheldon.
Yes, we know.
Want me to leave?
You know, whatever.
Okay, I guess I can hang for a little while. So what are we watching? Sex and the city.
Hey, I happen to love this movie.
Fine, let‰Ûªs watch it. Maybe all our periods will synchronize.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.
All right, we‰Ûªre going to be designing an experiment to look for the annihilation spectrum resulting from dark matter collisions in space.
Ooh, dark matter. We better bring a flashlight. I was making a joke.
I‰Ûªm the boss. I make the jokes.
Sorry, go ahead and make your joke.
This is not the time for joking. We‰Ûªre doing serious research, which requires complete and utter focus.
All right, let‰Ûªs buckle down and work.
Sheldon.
What?
I need an aspirin.
Top desk drawer.
Thank you.
Alright?
Yes.
Good.
Penny and Leonard exiting Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
That was fun. Thank you.
Leonard, honey, you don‰Ûªt have to say thank you every time we have sex.
Oh. Okay. Tomorrow you‰Ûªre going to get a card in the mail. Just throw it away.
Top o‰Ûª the mornin‰Ûªo ya!
What are you doing here?

Well, usually, on Sundays, I go with Raj to scam on hippie chicks at the farmers market, but he‰Ûªs still working with Sheldon, so I thought I‰Ûªd come over here and make you guys scrambled eggs and salami. It‰Ûªs the perfect meal for apres l‰Ûªamour.
Oh, kill me.
By the way, I couldn‰Ûªt help overhearing your big finish. Bravo, Leonard.
See, if you had killed me when I said kill me, I wouldn‰Ûªt have had to hear that.
What do you guys think? Want to take in a matinee, maybe go rollerblading, catch a step class?
Do something.
Yeah, okay. Um, Howard, we need to talk.
Sure. ‰Û÷sup, homes?
Uh, please understand that it‰Ûªs not that we don‰Ûªt want you around, but Penny and I occasionally need some alone time.
Oh. I get it, I‰Ûªm the third wheel. Sorry, I should have seen that. I‰Ûªll get out of your way. Uh, you‰Ûªre gonna want to eat those eggs while they‰Ûªre still hot.
Thank you. There‰Ûªs lox and cream cheese in the fridge, the bagels are in the oven, I was warming them up.
That‰Ûªs great.
Ill just hang out with my mom. That‰Ûªs always fun.
Good.
Are we terrible people?
I don‰Ûªt know. What do you want me to do?
Get him, bring him back.
Are you sure?
Yeah.
Okay. Howard come back.
Oh, you guys had me scared for a minute.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office. Sheldon is writing on the whiteboard.
No, no, no, no! That rate is much too low for what we‰Ûªd expect from this collision. Do you understand that we‰Ûªre talking about dark matter colliding in outer space?
Of course I understand. And who are you to tell me about outer space?
I‰Ûªm the astrophysicist. Astro means space.
Astro means star.
Okay, well, let me just tell you, if we were having this argument in my native language, I‰Ûªd be kicking your butt.
English is your native language.
Okay, you got me there, but you‰Ûªre wrong about this!
There is a fine line between wrong and visionary. Unfortunately you have to be a visionary to see it.
My god, you think that every thought that comes out of your head is pure gold. Well, let me tell you something. Some of those thoughts are pure caca.
Caca?
It means doo-doo.
All right! First of all, Dr. Koothrappali, when I first proposed that you work with me‰Û_
Aha! So I am working with you.
In this context, with me means for me.
Ah, well, in this context‰Û_ (blows raspberry)
Oh! If I‰Ûªm wrong, prove it.
Okay. Here‰Ûªs where we derive the mass of the dark matter particle.
No, no, no, you‰Ûªve misstated the atomic weight of the target.
Let me finish.
You‰Ûªre defacing my work.
I‰Ûªm not defacing it, I‰Ûªm fixing it.
Give me the eraser.
No.
I said give it to me.
Come and get it.
Fine. (Uses hand as an eraser. Then realises his hand is dirty) Oh, lord. Dr. Koothrappali, as your superior, I forbid you from writing on my board!
You are not my superior.
I am in every way.
Oh, yeah? Can you do this? (PerformsåÊ complex finger trick*) Nice working with you. I‰Ûªm sorry, for you. (Exits. Sheldon stares a moment, then tries to perform the trick. Fails.)
Outside Raj‰Ûªs flat.
(Knock, knock, knock) Raj. (Knock, knock, knock) Raj. (Knock, knock, knock) Raj.
I‰Ûªm busy.
Doing what? (Performs finger trick again) All right, you‰Ûªve made your point.
What do you want, Sheldon?
I looked over the board and it turns out you were right.
So you were wrong.
I didn‰Ûªt say that.
That‰Ûªs the only logical inference.
Nevertheless, I didn‰Ûªt say it. Anyway, I would like you to come back and work for me.
For you or with you?
In this context for me could mean with me.
All right, but I have some conditions.
I reject them all.
I‰Ûªll take the job. See you Monday.
Wait, you have to drive me home.
How did you get here?
I walked.
So walk home.
I can‰Ûªt. There‰Ûªs a big dog outside. On the way home, we can start thinking about methods of optimizing the detector for 500 GEV particles.
All right. (As they walk down the corridor, Eye of the Tiger starts playing again.)
The apartment.
All right, Raj has played his phantom warlord card, and I am going to back him up with my strangling vines. Choke on that, sucka.
Okay, well, then I‰Ûªll just cut your vines with my ruby sword. That‰Ûªs right, I did it. I cut ‰Ûªem.
Um, I have a question.
Warlord beats troll, troll beats elf, elf beats water sprite, and basically everything beats enchanted bunny.
Unless you have the carrot power.
Okay, I‰Ûªve got another question. When does this get fun?
Are we going to talk or are we going to play Mystic Warlords of Ka-ah?
Just play a potion card.
Which one?
It doesn‰Ûªt matter. You can‰Ûªt possibly win.
Sheldon, don‰Ûªt ruin the game.
How could he ruin the game?

Given the cards that have already been played, Penny can only be holding necromancer potions, which are only effective against wraiths and day-walkers, and there are no more of either left to be drawn. The cards remaining in the undrawn stack are four fire weapons, a troll, two ogres and the jewel of Osiris.
See? Ruined.
Sheldon, that is incredible.
From your vantage point, it certainly must seem so.
Sheldon has kind of a photographic memory.
Photographic is a misnomer. I have an eidetic memory, as I‰Ûªve told you many times. Most recently last year during lunch on the afternoon of may seventh. You had turkey and complained it was dry.
Well, I guess game‰Ûªs over.
Really? Oh, great. I mean, aw. Okay, I gotta go.
Why?
Because the last me I didn‰Ûªt go, I ended up playing Mystic Warlords of Ka.
Not Ka. Ka-ah.
Ba-eye.
See ya. Still can‰Ûªt believe she‰Ûªs going out with me.
Nobody can.
That reminds me, I have a bone to pick with you.
What?
You and I made a pact that if either of us ever got a hot girlfriend, that person would have his girlfriend hook the other guy up with one of her girlfriends.
Yeah, I don‰Ûªt remember that.
June 30th, 2004. Opening day of Spider-man 2 at the AMC Pasadena. They only had red icees, no blue.
Oh, yeah.
So you‰Ûªve been with Penny for like a month and a half now. Where‰Ûªs my shorty, Morty?
Howard, you can‰Ûªt hold me to that.
Why not?
Because when I made that agreement, I didn‰Ûªt think I‰Ûªd ever have a hot girlfriend. And I was positive you never would.
Hey, how come I wasn‰Ûªt part of this deal?
You had left the refreshment stand in order to indulge in your customary preemptive pre-show urination.
Oh, so that‰Ûªs how it works? I have a teeny bladder and now I don‰Ûªt get a hot girlfriend?
Yeah, Raj, that‰Ûªs how it works.
Damn.
The university cafeteria.
Oh, damn it. Can I have a napkin?
I‰Ûªm sorry, no.
But you have a whole bunch of ‰Ûªem.

Yes, I‰Ûªve moved to a four-napkin system. Lap, hands, face and personal emergencies. If you like, starting tomorrow, I‰Ûªll add a guest napkin, but I‰Ûªm afraid there‰Ûªs nothing I can do for you today. (Leonard steals a napkin) Good luck. That‰Ûªs the face napkin.
So, have you talked to Penny yet?
No, I haven‰Ûªt.
Why not?
Because I‰Ûªve been busy, because I haven‰Ûªt figured out a way to bring it up, and mostly, and I can‰Ûªt stress how key this is, because I don‰Ûªt want to.
Leonard, a pact is a pact. You have to get Penny to fix me up.
It‰Ûªs not that simple. What am I supposed to say? Penny, do you have any friends you‰Ûªd like to never hear from again?
Come on, I‰Ûªm smart, I have good job and I have only three percent body fat.
It‰Ûªs true. I‰Ûªve seen him at the beach, he‰Ûªs like a human chicken wing.
Leonard, come on.
Fine. I‰Ûªll ask if she has a friend for you.
A hot friend.
Right.
And tall. I want our kids to be able to ride space mountain before they‰Ûªre 20.
I‰Ûªll see what I can do.
Hey, Sheldon, guess what I heard today?

I‰Ûªd imagine you heard any number of things today. When you arrived at work you undoubtedly heard, hello, Raj, how are you, Raj? Given that you‰Ûªre wearing a new sweater-vest, you may have heard new sweater-vest? And possibly, though far less likely, nice sweater-vest.
Why don‰Ûªt I just tell you what I heard today.
That would probably save us some time.
Saturday night at the comic book store, they‰Ûªre having a Mystic Warlords of Ka-ah tournament. First prize is five hundred dollars. If we team up, we‰Ûªd be unstoppable.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Raj, but I have no interest in playing a game in which I find no challenge.
What about the money?
I have money.
But this is other money.
How does it different from the money I have?
Half of it will be mine.
Do you need it to buy a less disturbing sweater-vest?
Leonard, help.
Are you kidding? I couldn‰Ûªt even talk him into giving me one of his freakin‰Ûª napkins.
Leonard and Penny are in bed.
Wow, you really are a genius.
Not really. I googled how to do that. So, listen, have you ever made a pact with someone?
You mean, like a pinky swear?
Okay, fine, like a pinky swear.
Well, in the first grade, my friend Rosie and I made a pact to marry Bert and Ernie. You know, from Sesame Street?
Yeah, I‰Ûªm familiar with Bert and Ernie.
Then we found out we both wanted Ernie. We didn‰Ûªt speak again until middle school.
Over puppets?
The heart wants what the heart wants, Leonard.
Okay. Speaking of what the heart wants, um, a long time ago, I made a pact with Wolowitz that kind of involves you.
Okay, I don‰Ûªt know where you‰Ûªre going with this, but tread carefully because it may be the last conversation we ever have.
No, no, nothing like that. The deal was that if either of us ever got a girlfriend, we‰Ûªd have her fix the other one up with one of her friends.
And you thought a good time to bring this up be right after sex.
Well, I sure as hell wasn‰Ûªt going to bring it up before sex, and during, I was trying to remember what I read on google, so‰Û_
I‰Ûªm not hooking Wolowitz up with one of my friends.
Come on, it doesn‰Ûªt have to be a good friend. And you know that deep down inside, Howard‰Ûªs a really nice guy.
The problem isn‰Ûªt what‰Ûªs on the inside. It‰Ûªs the creepy candy coating.
Will you at least think about it? Just as a favour to me?
Oh, great thing about Ernie, was he never asked me for anything. He just gave.
The comic book store.
Got it. Got it. Got it. Got it. Got it. Got it. Betty and Veronica? Ugh.
Hey, Sheldon, the new Green Lantern figurine‰Ûªs coming in tomorrow. Want me to set one aside for you?
Thank you. You just robbed me of the opportunity to stumble upon the figurine and make the oh-so-satisfying journey from discovery to desire to possession.
All right, I won‰Ûªt set one aside for you.
But I must have it.
Okay, I‰Ûªll set one aside for you.
Thank you. You know, I can buy all these things online. I come here for the personal service.
Hey, Stuart, is the Wil Wheaton signed up for the mystic warlords tournament THE Wil Wheaton from Star Trek?
Yeah, he lives around here. Big gamer.
Oh, I‰Ûªm sorry, did I rob you of the opportunity to stumble onto that for yourself?
You don‰Ûªt understand. Growing up, I idolized Wil Wheaton? Wesley Crusher had an eidetic memory just like me.
Oh, what a coincidence. Maybe you can discuss that with him while you‰Ûªre playing in the tournament. Sign here.

I was such a fan that in 1995, I travelled ten hours by bus to a sci-fi convention in Jackson, Mississippi, wearing my Star Fleet Academy cadet uniform in order to meet Wil Wheaton and get him to autograph my mint in-package Wesley Crusher action figure.
Ooh, it‰Ûªll be like a reunion then. Sign here.
My arduous journey, however, was for naught. Although advertised to appear, he did not show up. It was at that moment, I vowed eternal hatred for Wil Wheaton.
Okay, great, you can tell him you hate him. Sign here.

It might also interest you to know that Wil Wheaton currently ranks sixth on my all-time enemies list, right between director Joel Schumacher, who nearly destroyed the Batman movie franchise, and Billy Sparks, who lived down the street from me and put dog poop on the handles of my bicycle.
Okay, I get it, he‰Ûªs a bad guy. Sign here.
In the words of Khan Noonien Singh in the immortal wrath of Khan, he tasks me, he tasks me and I shall have him.
No doubt, sign here.
From hell‰Ûªs heart, I stab at thee.
All right, Raj, looks like you‰Ûªre teamed up with die, Wil Wheaton, die.
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
So, tell me more about the future mother of my children.
She‰Ûªs adorable, Howard. I think you‰Ûªll like her.
Great. So what did you tell her about me? Did you mention the body fat?
No, I thought that would be a nice surprise for her.
Good, good.
I just told her you‰Ûªre an aerospace engineer, you speak five languages‰Û_
Six if you count Klingon.
Girls don‰Ûªt count Klingon, Howard. Right?
Right. Oh, and I told her you have an unhealthy attachment to your mother.
What?
I‰Ûªm kidding.
Another delightful surprise for her.
The comic book store.
Sheldon, it‰Ûªs your play. Sheldon.
My enchanted troll bludgeons your screaming harpy with a cursed mace. Game.
Sorry, boys. Say hi to your mother when she picks you up. Or I could just tell her later tonight! We pwned them, dude! Up top!
Look at him. Wil Wheaton, my old friend, I have chased you round the moons of Nibia and round the Antares maelstrom and round perdition‰Ûªs flames!
You know you keep quoting Wrath of Khan, but he was in next generation. It‰Ûªs a totally different set of characters.
Silence! How much longer must I wait for my revenge?
Well, if Wil Wheaton and Stuart win their match and we beat lonely Larry and Captain Sweatpants in the next round, we‰Ûªll face off for the championship.
So, my path to satisfaction is blocked by lonely Larry and Captain Sweatpants. Very well. They must be destroyed.
Dude, you have to stop talking like that. It‰Ûªs really lame.
Silence!
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
So, Penny tells me you‰Ûªre working as a waitress to put yourself through grad school. That‰Ûªs pretty great, what are you studying?
Microbiology.
Oh, cool. So you could study me.
I don‰Ûªt understand.
Microbiology is the study of tiny living things.
I know, I‰Ûªm studying it.
And I said you could study me ‰Ûªcause I‰Ûªm a tiny living thing. It‰Ûªs a joke.
Are you sure?
Do you like science-fiction?
No.
Role-playing games?
Like in the bedroom or like Dungeons and Dragons?
Either.
No.
Gonna be a long night.
Yeah, well, it‰Ûªs your fault.
I had to ask. You didn‰Ûªt have to say yes.
You like magic?
Not really.
Okay.
Long, long night.
The comic book store.

I play my endless serpent. Raj will play ecstatic frenzy, which means Larry will have to play chaos overlord, then Captain Sweatpants, molten river. I play nightshade dryad, game, set and match. Now fetch me Wil Wheaton! bortaS bIr jablu‰ÛªDI‰Ûª reH QaQqu‰Ûª nay‰Ûª
Did that guy just say revenge is a dish best served cold in Klingon?
I believe so.
What is wrong with him?
Everyone has a different theory.
A restaurant.
How about computers? Do you like computers?
I use them. I don‰Ûªt like them.
Okay‰Û_ Puppies? Where do you stand on puppies?
A puppy once bit my face.
Of course it did.
How about that? Einstein was wrong.
What?
Approaching the speed of light doesn‰Ûªt slow down time. Approaching them does.
Excuse me. Oh, damn. It‰Ûªs my mother.
Are you going to answer it?
I‰Ûªm torn. She might be dying, and, you know, I wouldn‰Ûªt want to miss that. On the other hand, if I let it go to voicemail, I could play it over and over.
I know how you feel. My mother makes me crazy.
Not as crazy as my mother makes me.
Oh, yeah? Does your mother call you every day at work to see if you‰Ûªve had a healthy lunch?
My mother calls me at work to see if I had a healthy bowel movement.
Okay, well, does she lay out your clothes for you in the morning like you‰Ûªre nine years old?
You live with your mother?
No. That‰Ûªs the sad part.
Ooh, rough. Okay, check this out. My mother made me wear rubber gloves to kindergarten so I wouldn‰Ûªt pick up a disease from the other children.
That‰Ûªs nothing. I couldn‰Ûªt ride a bicycle ‰Ûªcause my mother was afraid I‰Ûªd hit a bump and lose my virginity.
Oh, wow. You didn‰Ûªt, did you?
Not on a bicycle. In a Camry.
Corolla!
Oh!
More wine?
I‰Ûªd love some.
Listen, you have to come to shabbat dinner at my house sometime.
Why?
A catholic girl like you wearing a big cross like that might just give my mother the big brain aneurysm I‰Ûªve been hoping for.
Okay, but only if you come to Sunday dinner at my house wearing a yarmulke.
It‰Ûªs a date.
Am I a matchmaker or what?
The comic book store.
Lava serpent.
Nest of snakes.
Underworld guardian.
Underworld guardian. We skirmish to the death.
Invisibility spell.
Luminescence spell.
Water nymph.
Fire demon.
Two-headed tiger.
Three-headed lion.
Sulphur.
Brimstone.
Problem, Wil Wheaton?
Hang on.

You‰Ûªre holding two moderate spell cards, a small rock and a potion of Zancor, which will be about as much help as an air conditioner on the ice planet Hoth. Your only move is to play the potion, lose the skirmish, and two moves later, the game.
I think he‰Ûªs got me.

The year was 1995, the place, Jackson, Mississippi. Having spent ten hours on a bus, during which I had to twice violate my personal rule against relieving myself on board a moving vehicle, I finally arrived at the fourth annual Dixie-Trek convention only to find that my idol Wil Wheaton decided he had better things to do than to show up and sign my action figure.
What?
You betrayed me, Wil Wheaton. Now I have my revenge.
You went to the ‰Ûª95 Dixie-Trek? Oh, dude, my grandmother had just died, and I had to go to her funeral.
Your mee-maw died? That‰Ûªs terrible.
Yeah, it was. But I‰Ûªm really sorry that I disappointed you.
No, no, I understand. Anything happened to my mee-maw, I‰Ûªd be one inconsolable moon pie. I should clarify that statement by explaining that she calls me moon pie.
It‰Ûªs special relationship, isn‰Ûªt it, between a boy and his grandmother?
Oh, yes.
Okay, great, everybody loves their grandmas! Now, come on, Sheldon, finish him off!
It‰Ûªs okay, Sheldon. I let you down. I deserve it. Potion of Zancor.
What are you waiting for? Kill Wil Wheaton! From hell‰Ûªs heart, stab at him!
I can‰Ûªt.
Sure you can. Do it! Do it!
No. I came here to defeat Wil Wheaton, the man who destroyed my dreams. But I can‰Ûªt defeat Wil Wheaton, the man who loved his mee-maw. Enchanted bunny.
No! Not enchanted bunny!
I call my mee-maw nana. And she‰Ûªs going be very happy to hear that my small rock kills your enchanted bunny. Game over, moon pie.
I‰Û_ I‰Û_ I don‰Ûªt understand. Your grandmother‰Ûªs alive?
Oh, you catch on quick. Come on, Stewie, let‰Ûªs get our prize money.
That was fun.

character: Sheldon (while camera zooms out from Sheldon to above planet in a pastiche of the famous Wrath of Khan scene)
line: Wheaton! Wheaton! Wheaton!
The stairwell. The guys are carrying kites.
Kites, ho!
Kites ho!
Kites ho!
Kites, ho!
Excuse me. You‰Ûªre misusing the word ho. It‰Ûªs an interjection used to call attention to a destination, not an object, as in, uh, Land, ho! Or, uh, Westward, ho!
Kites, ho!
Hey, guys. What you doing? Going out to discover electricity?

If you‰Ûªre referring to the work of Benjamin Franklin, he did not discover electricity, he merely used a kite to determine that lightning consists of electricity. He also invented the Franklin stove, bifocals and the flexible urinary catheter. Kites, ho.
We‰Ûªre heading out for some kite fighting.
Kite fighting?
Oh, yeah. It‰Ûªs an extremely competitive, cutthroat sport.
Well, actually, the risk of throat cutting is very low. On the other hand, severe string burn is a real and ever-Present danger.
You want to come watch?
Oh, gee, sounds amazing, but, um, I‰Ûªve got some friends coming over. Not a big thing, we‰Ûªre just gonna watch the Nebraska game.
Oh. Football, sure.
Good guess.
I would‰Ûªve invited you, but I know you‰Ûªre not a football fan.
No, no, I‰Ûªm not, so, great. You‰Ûªve got plans doing something you like, I‰Ûªve got plans doing something I like, so it‰Ûªs good.
Well, maybe we‰Ûªll hang out later, you know, after everybody‰Ûªs gone.
Yeah, great.
See ya.
Well, this sucks.
I‰Ûªm sorry, I got bored and drifted off. Where exactly in the interaction did the sucking lie?
Leonard just realized that Penny‰Ûªs been hiding him from her friends because he‰Ûªs a tiny, little man who flies kites.
Oh, that certainly would suck.
The park.
Wolowitz is trying to outflank us. Let out some string, add altitude and I‰Ûªll go under and cut his line.
Why wouldn‰Ûªt Penny want her friends to meet me?
Focus, Leonard, focus! The heat of battle is upon us, the dogs of war are unleashed.
Maybe Koothrappali‰Ûªs right, maybe I embarrass her.
You‰Ûªre embarrassing me right now, a grown man worrying about such nonsense when in the middle of flying kites.
Sorry.
Sorry won‰Ûªt bring their kites down. Ow! String burn! String burn!
Oh, they think we‰Ûªre flanking, they‰Ûªre playing right into our hands. On the count of three, we execute the flying scissor. One, two‰Û_
Whoa! Did you see that?
See what?
That chick, she smiled at me.
No, she didn‰Ûªt.
Yes, she did.
Come on, scissors, scissors!
Hold my line.
Wait, what are you doing? I can‰Ûªt scissors by myself! Howard! Come back!
Victory!
Son of a bitch.
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
You‰Ûªre a sucky friend, you know that? A sucky, sucky friend.
What was I supposed to do? She gave me that come-hither look.
If she gave you any look at l. It was a you suck look.
I would‰Ûªve caught up to her if I hadn‰Ûªt pulled a hammy.
Oh, please, you weigh 80 pounds. You don‰Ûªt have a hammy.
So, Penny doesn‰Ûªt want me around her friends, I embarrass her. What else could it be?
Well, her actions could be out of concern for your feelings. Perhaps she‰Ûªs excluded you from these gatherings because she‰Ûªs scouting for a new mate and doesn‰Ûªt want to do it in front of you.
Oh, how kind of her.
Agreed. Most primates don‰Ûªt show that sort of discretion. A female bonobo will copulate with a new male in front of the old one without so much as a how do you do?
You always do this, you know? You ditch me for a woman you don‰Ûªt have a shot with.
I totally had a shot.

With a woman you were chasing through a park? That‰Ûªs not a shot, that‰Ûªs a felony. What‰Ûªs worse, it cost me my prized Patang fighting kite. Sheldon, I don‰Ûªt suppose there‰Ûªs any chance you could give me my kite back?

I‰Ûªm sorry, Raj, but the rules of aerial warfare dictate at the fallen kite go to the victor. And without rules, the competition has no meaning. And without meaning, the following would be an empty gesture. (Sings) I have your kite. I have your kite.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
Hey.
Hi.
How was your football party?
It was pretty good. We won.
Oh, that‰Ûªs excellent. It‰Ûªs a weird figure of speech, isn‰Ûªt it, we won when you weren‰Ûªt
I‰Ûªm glad to hear it.
Oh, hey, on a related subject, are you embarrassed to have me around your friends?
Oh, my god, no. Why would you ask that?
Well, you know, I just noticed I haven‰Ûªt really met any of them.
Sure you have.
Well, yeah, no, I met the huge ex-boyfriend and the smaller yet still larger than me ex-boyfriend. Were they here today?
Of course not.
Of course not. Why would they be? Why would I ask? Why am I rambling? Why don‰Ûªt you stop me?
Leonard, look, if you want to meet my friends, that would be great. I just, you know, I didn‰Ûªt want you to be bored.
I wouldn‰Ûªt be bored. Why would I be bored?
Well, ‰Ûªcause they‰Ûªre not genius scientists.

This will only take a second. You asked me to think about where our relationship was going, and I did. Bernadette? Will you marry me?
Is this more comedy that I don‰Ûªt understand?
No. I‰Ûªm serious. I‰Ûªm never going to find another girl like you who likes me and is, you know, real.
So, this isn‰Ûªt a joke?
No.
Then you‰Ûªre insane.
I prefer to think of myself as quirky.
Howard, we‰Ûªve only been on three dates. We haven‰Ûªt even had sex yet.
Fair enough. When‰Ûªs your break?
Wow. (Walks away)
Don‰Ûªt you just hate when this happens?
Wow.
The apartment kitchen.
All right, how‰Ûªs this for revenge? A solution of hydrogen peroxide, and one of saturated potassium iodide.
What‰Ûªs this?
Mountain Dew. Ah, refreshing. Now, we‰Ûªre going to combine these chemicals with ordinary dish soap, creating a little exothermic release of oxygen.
Foamy vengeance.
Yes, exactly.
This is brilliant, Sheldon. How are we going to deploy it in Kripke‰Ûªs office?

Already taken care of. Observe. This is a live shot of Kripke‰Ûªs lab via a mini webcam I was able to install, thanks to a dollar bill discreetly placed in the night janitor‰Ûªs shirt pocket. At the same time, I also secured large quantities of these chemicals above the tiles in the drop ceiling.
Oh, Sheldon, you remind me of a young Lex Luthor.
You flatter me, sir.
Let me guess, motion sensors?
The reaction will be triggered when Kripke reaches the center of the room. Mwah, ha, ha.
I gotta say, I am really impressed. This is truly the Sheldon Cooper way to get even. (Sits down. There is a flatulent noise)
It may be low-tech, but I still maintain the whoopee cushion has comic validity.
Here comes Kripke!
Who is that with him?
I believe that‰Ûªs the president of the university.
And the board of directors. Abort! Abort!
There is no abort.
Well, how could you not put in an abort?
I made a boo-boo, all right?
I think the board will weally appweciate how well we‰Ûªre using that NSA gwant, Pwesident Seibert. Wight here we have a micwo-contwolled pwasma‰Û_ (foam falls from the ceiling soaking everyone)
Wow. Looks like the Ganges on laundry day.
At least they don‰Ûªt know it was you.

character: Sheldon (on Kripke‰Ûªs computer in the lab)
line: Hello, Kripke. This classic prank comes to you from the malevolent mind of Sheldon Cooper. If you‰Ûªd like to see the look on your stupid face, this video is being instantly uploaded to YouTube. Oh, and a hat tip to Leonard Hofstadter and Raj Koothrappali for their support and encouragement in this enterprise.
Well, I‰Ûªm going back to India. What‰Ûªs your plan?
The Cheesecake Factory.
Hey, here‰Ûªs your tip from table seven.
Oh, thanks.
Mm-hmm.

character: Howard (on the stage, into a microphone)
line: Testing. Check. Check two.
Oh, now what?
You want me to throw him out?
No, that‰Ûªs okay.
Are you sure? He‰Ûªs small. I bet I can get a nice, tight spiral on him.

I want to dedicate this number to a great gal who I‰Ûªve done wrong. (To the tune of the Four Tops song Bernadette)  Bernadette, I am so sorry for trying to propose to you, Bernadette, you found it creepy but that‰Ûªs just the kind of thing I do. I know now it was too soon to talk of love. It was just a crazy idea that came to me in my tub. But, Bernadette, give me one more chance, sweet Bernadette, I‰Ûªll get the hang of this thing they call romance, sweet Bernadette, I dream to once again kiss your lips, sweet Bernadette. Sincerely yours, Howard Wolowitz, Bernadette‰Û_
Oh, I am so sorry.
Are you kidding? That‰Ûªs the most romantic thing anyone‰Ûªs ever done for me.
‰Û_Bernadette! Thank you, Cheesecake Factory!
The apartment
Hey, Leonard, check this out. (Throws some food in the air and catches it in her mouth)
Leonard, she‰Ûªs doing it again.
I think it upsets Sheldon when you play with the food.
No. It upsets Sheldon when she willy-nilly takes it from the containers without regard for its equitable distribution. This is essentially why you have famine in India.
You want me to put it back?
Leonard.
It upsets Sheldon when you play with the Sheldon.
What‰Ûªs up, my nerdizzles? Raj, Sheldon, I want you to meet my girlfriend Bernadette.
Hello.
Leonard, Penny, you know my girlfriend Bernadette.
Yeah. Hey.
Bernadette, say fo‰Ûªshizzle to my nerdizzles.
I don‰Ûªt think I can. I don‰Ûªt have Howard‰Ûªs street cred.
I hope it‰Ûªs all right, I told my girlfriend Bernadette she could join us for dinner.
Sure. The more, the merrier.
Wait, no, that‰Ûªs a false equivalency. More does not equal merry. If there were 2,000 people in this apartment right now, would we be celebrating? No, we‰Ûªd be suffocating.
Sheldon‰Û_
Don‰Ûªt Sheldon me. We ordered for five people, not six.
Oh, come on, it‰Ûªs fine. We‰Ûªll just put it all on the table, you know, family style.
Oh, sure. And while we‰Ûªre at it, why don‰Ûªt we put our hands behind our backs, have an old-fashioned eating contest?
Relax, it‰Ûªll be fine, sit down, you guys.
NO!
What?
Oh, yeah, you can‰Ûªt sit there.
Why not?
That‰Ûªs where Sheldon sits.
He can‰Ûªt sit somewhere else?

Oh no, no, you see, in the winter, that seat is close enough to the radiator so that he‰Ûªs warm, yet not so close that he sweats. In the summer, it‰Ûªs directly in the path of a cross-breeze created by opening windows there and there. It faces the television at an angle that isn‰Ûªt direct, so he can still talk to everybody, yet not so wide that the picture looks distorted.
Perhaps there‰Ûªs hope for you after all.
A few moments later.
Ooh, I love your shoes.
Oh, thanks. They are cute, aren‰Ûªt they?
Where‰Ûªd you get them?
Shoes for Less.
I‰Ûªve been meaning to go over there.
Oh, great selection, great prices.
My mother was right. Hell is real.
Come on, Sheldon. let the womenfolk chat.
Womenfolk?
Gals? Chicks? Utero-Americans?
Just eat your dinner.
Don‰Ûªt take him too seriously, a lot of what he says is intended as humour.
Yeah, well, I don‰Ûªt think it‰Ûªs very funny.
Me neither, but he just lights up when I laugh.
Howard, never let her go.
So, Leonard, Howard says you‰Ûªre working on fundamental tests of quantum mechanics.
I am. Are you interested in physics?
Oh, I find it fascinating. If I hadn‰Ûªt gone into microbiology, I probably would have gone into physics. Or ice dancing.
Actually, my tests of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum interference effect have reached an interesting point. Right now, we‰Ûªre testing the phase shift due to an electric potential.
That‰Ûªs amazing.

Yes. Leonard‰Ûªs work is nearly as amazing as third graders growing lima beans in wet paper towels. (Raj whispers to him) While I appreciate the oh, snap, I‰Ûªm uncomfortable having your moist breath in my ear.
Are you going to try to set up the voltages using tunnel junctions?
Yes, I am. You want to see a simulation on my laptop?
Oh, yeah, show me. In microbiology, the most exciting thing I get to work with is yeast.
Howard?
Yeah?
Your shoes are delightful. Where did you get them?
What?
Bazinga. I don‰Ûªt care.
The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
Ha! Eat my dust, racially stereotypical plumber.
That‰Ûªs not fair. I got stuck behind a tree.
And a cow and a penguin. Face it dude, whether it‰Ûªs a real car or a virtual cartoon car, you can‰Ûªt drive.
Just need a little more practice.
What you need is cheat codes, motor skills and a magic genie who grants wishes to little boys who suck at Mario Kart.
Hey, Sheldon, can I talk to you for a second?
It‰Ûªs not about shoes, is it? I don‰Ûªt think I could go through that again.
It‰Ûªs not about shoes.
Then speak.
Um, actually, can we do it in private?
All right. (To Raj) Go away. I agree, it‰Ûªs rude, but she asked for privacy.
Thanks, Raj. Okay, so here‰Ûªs the thing, I was wondering if you could maybe teach me a little physics?
A little physics? There‰Ûªs no such thing. Physics encompasses the entire universe, from quantum particles to supernovas, from spinning electrons to spinning galaxies.
Yeah, okay, cool. I don‰Ûªt need the PBS special, I just want to know enough so I can talk to Leonard about his job. You know, like Bernadette does.
Why can‰Ûªt Leonard teach you?
‰Û÷Cause I want to surprise him.
Can‰Ûªt you surprise him in some other way? For example, I‰Ûªm sure he‰Ûªd be delightfully taken aback if you cleaned your apartment.
Come on, Sheldon, this is important to me.
Penny, this would be a massive undertaking, and my time is both limited and valuable.
You‰Ûªre sitting here playing video games all day.
Okay, point. What sort of foundation do you have? Did you take any science classes in school?
Sure. I did the one with the frogs.
The one with the frogs.
Yeah, actually, it was pretty cool. A lot of the girls threw up, but I gutted that thing like a deer.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Penny, I don‰Ûªt think so.
Oh, come on! A smart guy like you, it‰Ûªll be a challenge. You can make it like an experiment.
Interesting. I suppose if someone could teach sign language to KoKo the gorilla, I could teach you some rudimentary physics.
Great! It‰Ûªs a little insulting, but great. I‰Ûªll be KoKo.
Not likely. KoKo learned to understand over 2,000 words, not one of which had anything to do with shoes.
The university cafeteria.
Hey, fellas. This is my girlfriend Bernadette. My girlfriend Bernadette.
Who are all those people?
Have no idea. Hey, Leonard.
Hi.
Hey, look, it‰Ûªs Howard and his girlfriend Bernadette.
Thought I‰Ûªd give the little woman a tour of the old salt mines.
He doesn‰Ûªt mean salt mines. He means where he works.
Yeah, no, I got it.
So, how‰Ûªs your experiment going?
Ah, terrific. We‰Ûªre getting the electron accelerator set up. We should be ready to go day after tomorrow.
Boy, I‰Ûªd love to see that.
You‰Ûªre welcome to come.
Really? Oh, that‰Ûªd be great. How exciting is that?
Like Hanukkah in July.
Do they have that?
No.
Oh. You got me again. This isn‰Ûªt non-fat yogurt, this is fatty fat fat. Excuse me.
Could you grab me another napkin, sweetie?
Sure.
Thanks, honey. (She goes) All right, what is your deal?
Excuse me?
Inviting my girlfriend to come see your electron accelerator?
Yeah? So?
Wow! You really are a piece of work. It‰Ûªs not enough you get the prom queen, you have to get the head of the decorating committee, too?
What are you talking about?
Don‰Ûªt play innocent with me. I practically invented using fancy lab equipment to seduce women.
Has it ever worked?
Not so far, but that‰Ûªs not the point!
Howard, relax, I‰Ûªm not interested in your girlfriend.
I hope not, because you don‰Ûªt want to mess with me. I‰Ûªm crazy.
I believe you.
The apartment.
Research journal, entry one. I‰Ûªm about to embark on one of the great challenges of my scientific career, teaching Penny physics. I‰Ûªm calling it Project Gorilla.
Hey, Sheldon.
Come in. Take a seat. Subject has arrived. I‰Ûªve extended a friendly casual greeting.
Ready to get started?
One moment. Subject appears well-rested and enthusiastic. Apparently, ignorance is bliss. All right, let us begin. Where‰Ûªs your notebook?
Um, I don‰Ûªt have one.
How are you going to take notes without a notebook?
I have to take notes?
How else are you gonna study for the tests?
There‰Ûªs gonna be a test?
Tests. Here. It‰Ûªs college-ruled. I hope that‰Ûªs not too intimidating.
Thank you.

You‰Ûªre welcome. Now, Introduction to Physics. What is physics? Physics comes from the ancient Greek word physika. It‰Ûªs at this point that you‰Ûªll want to start taking notes. Physika means the science of natural things. And it is there, in ancient Greece, that our story begins.
Ancient Greece?

Hush. If you have questions, raise your hand. It‰Ûªs a warm summer evening, circa 600 BC, you‰Ûªve finished your shopping at the local market, or agora, and you look up at the night sky. There you notice some of the stars seem to move, so you name them planetes, or wanderer. Yes, Penny?
Um, does this have anything to do with Leonard‰Ûªs work?

This is the beginning of a twenty six hundred year journey we‰Ûªre going to take together from the ancient Greeks through Isaac Newton to Niels Bohr to Erwin Schrodinger to the Dutch researchers that Leonard is currently ripping off.
Twenty six hundred years?
Yeah, give or take. As I was saying, it‰Ûªs a warm summer evening in ancient Greece‰Û_ Yes, Penny?
I have to go to the bathroom.
Can‰Ûªt you hold it?
Not for twenty six hundred years.
Project Gorilla, entry two. I am exhausted.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Howard?
Huh?
It unhooks in the front.
Oh, that explains a lot.
Howard, I‰Ûªm home!
Of course.
Senior fitness was cancelled. It turns out you can forget how to ride a bike. I‰Ûªm fine, but, oy, did Sam Harpootian eat gravel.
That‰Ûªs great, Ma!
What‰Ûªs great about an 80-year-old Armenian man with half his chin scraped off?
I guess I should go.
No, no, don‰Ûªt move. Hey, Ma, can I have lamb stew for dinner?
Lamb stew? I‰Ûªd have to go to the supermarket.
Please? I got a real hankering.
Oh, I can‰Ûªt say no to my little tushy face. I‰Ûªll be back soon.
Thanks, Ma.
Do you want the regular peas or the Le Seur?
Always Le Seur peas with lamb stew!
You‰Ûªre right! When you‰Ûªre right, you‰Ûªre right! What if they‰Ûªre out of the Le Seur?
Then get the regular!
All right! You don‰Ûªt have to yell!
Sorry about that.
Let me just put that on vibrate.
I‰Ûªm already on vibrate.
You know, that one I got. Howard, did you say something to Leonard about me?
Uh, what do you mean?
He says if I go see his experiment tomorrow it might weird you out.
Really? He said that?
You‰Ûªre not jealous of Leonard, are you?
Me? No. I may have mentioned that it‰Ûªs a little inappropriate to be asking another man‰Ûªs girlfriend to his experiment without first discussing it with said man.
Are you saying I need to ask your permission to hang out with Leonard?
I didn‰Ûªt say anything like that. I said Leonard has to ask my permission. (Bernadette storms out) Come on, I don‰Ûªt want to eat lamb stew with my mother. Damn, I was this close on the bra.
The apartment.

Now, remember, Newton realized that Aristotle was wrong and force was not necessary to maintain motion. So let‰Ûªs plug in our 9.8 meters per second squared as A and we get force, Earth gravity, equals mass times 9.8 meters per second per second. So we can see that MA equals MG and what do we know from this?
Uh, we know that‰Û_ Newton was a really smart cookie. Oh! Is that where Fig Newtons come from?
No, Fig Newtons are named after a small town in Massachusetts. Don‰Ûªt write that down!
Sorry.
Now, if MA equals MG what does that imply?
I don‰Ûªt know.
How can you not know? I just told you. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?
Hey! You don‰Ûªt have to be so mean!
I‰Ûªm sorry. (Smiling) Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?
No, you just suck at teaching.
Really? Of those two explanations, which one seems the most likely?
Oh, God, Sheldon, look I‰Ûªm trying to understand, but you‰Ûªre going too fast. Can you just back up a little bit?
All right. It‰Ûªs a warm summer evening in ancient Greece‰Û_
Not that far back!
Okay! At what point did you begin to feel lost?
I don‰Ûªt know. Where were we looking up at the night sky?
Greece.
Damn it!
There‰Ûªs no need to get frustrated, people learn at different rates. Unlike objects falling in a vacuum, which‰Û_? MA equals MG?
Squared?
No.
Aristotle?
No.
Five?
Oh!
Then I don‰Ûªt know.
Why are you crying?
Because I‰Ûªm stupid!
That‰Ûªs no reason to cry. One cries because one is sad. For example, I cry because others are stupid and it makes me sad.
Okay, look, can we just please forget about all this extra stuff and can you just tell me what Leonard does?
All right. Leonard is attempting to learn why sub-atomic particles move the way they do.
Really? That‰Ûªs it? Well, that doesn‰Ûªt sound so complicated.
It‰Ûªs not. That‰Ûªs why Leonard does it.
Okay, I just have one question. What exactly are sub-atomic particles?
A good question.
Thank you.
And to answer it, we first must ask ourselves, what is physics?
Oh, balls.
It‰Ûªs a warm summer evening in ancient Greece‰Û_
Leonard‰Ûªs lab.
Okay, I got a bone to pick with you.
What did I do now?
I was in bed with Bernadette, and you text-blocked me.
What?
We were completely naked, about to devour each other when, you text her that I have a problem with her hanging out with you.
You do have a problem with her hanging out with me.
Yeah, but that‰Ûªs not what you tell her.
What was I supposed to tell her?
I don‰Ûªt know, something that doesn‰Ûªt make me come off as a petty, jealous douche.
And what would that be?
Come on, do I have to think of everything?
Hey, Leonard. Am I too late to see the experiment? Oh, hi.
Hi.
What are you doing here?
Same thing you‰Ûªre doing here. I came to see Leonard‰Ûªs experiment.
No, you didn‰Ûªt. You said Leonard‰Ûªs experiment was stupid.
You told her my experiment was stupid?
I was just repeating what Sheldon said. Let‰Ûªs not get off topic, Bernadette, I need to apologize. I was wrong to tell you who you should be friends with.
Should I, um, leave you two alone?
No, Leonard, you should hear this.
Okay, good, ‰Ûªcause I wasn‰Ûªt really gonna go.
Look, I know I come off as confident and worldly, but the truth is I‰Ûªm not.
We‰Ûªre shocked.
Which is why I tend to feel threatened by other guys.
Or loud noises, clowns and nuns.
But I now realize how foolish that is.
He had a panic attack once when he got his head stuck in a sweater.
It was a full turtleneck. Why aren‰Ûªt you helping me?
I don‰Ûªt know. Maybe because I‰Ûªm crazy?
Bernadette, please, I‰Ûªm asking you to give me another chance.
What do you think, Leonard? Should I give him another chance?
It‰Ûªs up to you. He didn‰Ûªt call your experiment stupid.
Come here, tushy face.
Tushy face, that is going on Twitter right now.
The apartment.
Raj, you should‰Ûªve seen Leonard‰Ûªs experiment. The interference pattern was so cool when the electron beam was on.
I‰Ûªm glad you enjoyed it. Most people aren‰Ûªt that interested in what I do.

Actually, that‰Ûªs not true, Leonard. In fact, recently I‰Ûªve been thinking that given the parameters of your experiment, the transport of electrons through the aperture the nano-fabricated metal rings is qualitatively no different than the experiment already conducted in the Netherlands. Their observed phase shift in the diffusing electrons inside the metal ring already conclusively demonstrated the electric analogue of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum-interference effect. That‰Ûªs it. That‰Ûªs all I know. Oh, wait! Fig Newtons were named after a town in Massachusetts, not the scientist.
The apartment.
Oh, I always tear up when the Grinch‰Ûªs heart grows three sizes.
Tears seem appropriate. Enlargement of the heart muscle, or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, is a serious disease which could lead to congestive heart failure.
Fa-la-la, la-la-la, la-la-la.
You really didn‰Ûªt like it, Sheldon?

No, on the contrary. I found the Grinch to be a relatable, engaging character, and I was really with him right up to the point that he succumbed to social convention and returned the presents and saved Christmas. What a buzz kill that was.
When we watch Frosty the Snowman, he roots for the sun.
Excuse me, but the sun is essential for all life on Earth. Frosty is merely a bit of frozen supernatural ephemera in a stolen hat. A crime, by the way, for which he is never brought to account.
Fa-la-la-la-la, la-la-la-la.
The apartment.
I just love decorating the Christmas tree. It makes me feel like a little girl again.
We didn‰Ûªt have a tree when I was growing up.
Really? Why not?
Mmm, in my family, holidays weren‰Ûªt so much celebrated as studied for their anthropological and psychological implications on human society.
Oh, sounds festive. Did you at least give presents?
Mmm, in a way. We presented papers, and then broke off into focus groups and critiqued each other.
Sheldon, what about you? Did you have a Christmas tree?

Oh, yes. We had a tree, we had a manger, we had an inflatable Santa Claus with plastic reindeer on the front lawn. And to make things even more jolly, there were so many blinking lights on the house they induced neighbourhood-wide seizures.
So I take it you don‰Ûªt want to help us trim the tree.
I do not. But if you insist on decorating a spider-infested fire hazard in my home I would request that you add this.
What is it?
You‰Ûªre kidding, right? It‰Ûªs a bust of Sir Isaac Newton.
Oh, sure, sure, yeah. Very Christmassy.
Wait, excuse me, but it‰Ûªs much more Christmassy than anything you‰Ûªve put on the tree.
Here we go.

December 25, 1642, Julian calendar, Sir Isaac Newton is born. Jesus, on the other hand, was actually born in the summer. His birthday was moved to coincide with a traditional pagan holiday that celebrated the winter solstice with lit fires and slaughtered goats. Which, frankly, sounds like more fun than 12 hours of church with my mother followed by a fruitcake.
Merry Newton-mas, everyone.
I sense that‰Ûªs not sincere, although I have no idea why.
No, it‰Ûªs fine. Look, Sir Isaac can go right next to this little candy cane.
No. Isaac goes at the top of the tree.
No, he doesn‰Ûªt.
I understand. You dispute Newton‰Ûªs claim that he invented calculus and you want to put Gottfried Leibniz on the top.
Yeah, you got me. I‰Ûªm a Leibniz man.
Well, perhaps when your mother gets here, she‰Ûªll talk some sense into you.
What? Your‰Û_ your mother‰Ûªs coming? When?
Tomorrow.
When were you going to tell me?
Um, tomorrow?
Why were you keeping this a secret?
Well, I just, I thought‰Û_
If I can interject here, obviously Leonard is concerned that his mother won‰Ûªt approve of you as his mate.
Why wouldn‰Ûªt she approve of me? I‰Ûªm adorable.
You are, it‰Ûªs just‰Û_

If I can interject again. Leonard comes from a remarkably high-achieving family, who have all chosen high-achieving partners. He probably feels that it‰Ûªs doubtful that his mother will be overly impressed with his dating a woman whose most significant achievement is memorizing the Cheesecake Factory menu.
Hey, it‰Ûªs a big menu. There‰Ûªs two pages just for desserts.
I know. And those specials, they change every day.
Okay, you know what? It‰Ûªs lame when I say it, it‰Ûªs just ridiculous when you pile on.
Okay, sorry.
So what did she say when you told her we were going out?
Um‰Û_
You didn‰Ûªt tell her we were going out, did you?
Um‰Û_
Why not?
Um‰Û_
Leonard, I‰Ûªm no expert on meditation, but if you‰Ûªre trying to calm yourself down, I believe the word is Om.
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
It was so nice of you to come all the way down to the airport to pick me up.
No trouble at all.
I drove, Mother. I‰Ûªm driving now.
Yes, dear. Mommy‰Ûªs proud. I‰Ûªve been meaning to thank you for your notes on my paper disproving quantum brain dynamic theory.
My pleasure. For a non-physicist, you have a remarkable grasp of how electric dipoles in the brain‰Ûªs water molecules could not possibly form a Bose condensate.
Wait, wait, wait. When did you send my mom notes on a paper?
August 16th. Right after her carpal tunnel surgery.
Oh, did I thank you for the flowers?
You did.
I don‰Ûªt really like flowers.
Neither do I, but it‰Ûªs the social convention.
It is, isn‰Ûªt it?
Wait, wait, wait. You had surgery?
Yes, and Sheldon sent me flowers.
No, I heard that.
