Then what was all that wait, wait, wait about?
I just don‰Ûªt understand why he knows more about your life than I do.
Well, I would assume it‰Ûªs because Sheldon and I stay in touch due to mutual interest and respect, while you avoid me, due to unresolved childhood issues.
It‰Ûªs what we think caused your narcissistic personality disorder. We discussed it at length during our last video chat. Although how we got onto the subject of you is baffling.
Yes, but we are on the subject, so I‰Ûªm obliged to ask, Leonard, how are you?
Fine, Mom. How are you?
Mmm, menopausal.
Now I‰Ûªm less fine.
Have you heard your brother has gotten engaged?
No. Sheldon, why didn‰Ûªt you tell me?
My bad. I did send a gift from both of us.
She‰Ûªs a remarkable girl. The youngest appeals court judge in New Jersey and a two-time Olympic bronze medallist.
You must be very happy.
Why? I‰Ûªm not marrying her. So, how about you? Are you seeing anyone interesting?
Well, I‰Ûªm not sure about interesting, but‰Û_
Not the time, Sheldon.
Very well. Shall we switch topics to Isaac Newton v. Gottfried Leibniz?

It‰Ûªs all right, Sheldon. I will just pretend that Leonard‰Ûªs not withholding information. Although, I will point out, Leonard, that I am a trained psychiatrist and you are exhibiting the same secretive behavioural tics that accompanied your learning to masturbate.
Isn‰Ûªt she brilliant, Leonard? How I envy you.
The apartment.
So, Howard, have you and Rajesh finally summoned the courage to express your latent homosexual feelings toward one another?
What? No.
Why not?
Because we don‰Ûªt have latent homosexual feelings toward one another.
I see.
No, really. I have a girlfriend now.
And where is she this evening?
She had to go out of town. Her grandmother died.
I see. Her grandmother died.
Honest to God. Leonard, tell her I have a girlfriend.
I don‰Ûªt know what you‰Ûªre talking about.
What do you mean you don‰Ûªt know what I‰Ûªm talking about? Tell her I have a girlfriend!
All right. He ‰ÛÏhas‰Û a ‰ÛÏgirlfriend.‰Û
Her name is Bernadette, she‰Ûªs working as a waitress, but she‰Ûªs going to school to be a microbiologist.
Howard, keep in mind that the more passionately you stick to this construct, the more you‰Ûªre hurting your partner.

character: Howard (to Raj who has whispered to him)
line: Do you really think your lips in my ear is helping?
Hi. Sorry I‰Ûªm late.
Oh, glad you‰Ûªre here, uh, sit down, I‰Ûªll get you a plate. Mom, you remember Penny.
Oh, yes, the waitress slash actress with the unresolved father issues. Has he finally come to terms with his little slugger growing breasts?
Well, he sent me a football and a catcher‰Ûªs mitt for Christmas, so I‰Ûªm going to say no.
If it helps, we‰Ûªre all good with your breasts.
Classic overcompensation. Oh, speaking of fathers, Leonard, that reminds me, I‰Ûªm divorcing yours.
What?
Yes. He was cheating on me.
No!
Yes, with some waitress from the university cafeteria. Can you believe it? A waitress? Oh, no offense, dear.
No, it sounded like a compliment.
When did this happen?
Mmm, well, let‰Ûªs see. Sheldon, when did I leave Leonard‰Ûªs father?
September 22nd.
Oh, yes, that‰Ûªs right. The weekend after Leonard‰Ûªs dog died.
Mitzy‰Ûªs dead?
She was old and blind, Leonard. What choice did we have?
I don‰Ûªt believe this. Why am I the last to know?
Excuse me, Leonard, I am the one who‰Ûªs getting a divorce, Mitzy is the one who is dead. Why are you the one making a fuss?
You‰Ûªre right. I‰Ûªm-I‰Ûªm-I‰Ûªm-I‰Ûªm sorry, I‰Ûªm way out of line!
So, Penny, what‰Ûªs new in your life?
Nothing. Not a damn thing.
Penny‰Ûªs car.
Thank you for driving me back to my hotel.
Oh, it‰Ûªs not a problem.
I was going to ask Leonard to do it, but he seemed a bit emotionally unstable and you don‰Ûªt want someone like that operating heavy machinery.
No, you do not.
Your check engine light is on.
Yeah, I gotta put a sticker over that. So, uh, you must be devastated about your divorce.
Oh, not at all. But I am a bit distressed to be in a vehicle that‰Ûªs not subjected to regular maintenance.
Come on, I mean, you‰Ûªre not upset that your marriage is over?
Well, initially I felt something akin to grief and perhaps anger, but that‰Ûªs the natural reaction of the limbic system to being betrayed by a loathsome son of a bitch.
Sure, sure.
Thankfully, my shock was somewhat mitigated by the fact that I haven‰Ûªt had intercourse with him in eight years.
Eight years?
Oh, that‰Ûªs nothing. I‰Ûªve been responsible for my own orgasms since 1982.
Yikes. What‰Ûªs so funny?
That‰Ûªs exactly what I say during orgasms. Yikes.
You know what? I could use a drink. Do you want to stop for a drink?
Oh, I don‰Ûªt drink.
I do, I‰Ûªll teach you.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard?
I don‰Ûªt want tea.
I didn‰Ûªt make tea for you. This is my tea.
Then why are you telling me?
It‰Ûªs a conversation starter.
That‰Ûªs a lousy conversation starter.
Oh, is it? We‰Ûªre conversing. Checkmate.
What do you want, Sheldon?
What I want is to be departing the Starship Enterprise in a one-man shuttle craft headed to the planetoid I rule known as Sheldon Alpha Five.
I want that too. Why are you here?

To comfort you, of course. No, that‰Ûªs not going to work at all, I‰Ûªll comfort you from over here. Leonard, what you‰Ûªre experiencing is a classic Jungian crisis in which the aging individual mourns the loss of the never-to-be realized ideal family unit.
Thank you, that‰Ûªs very comforting.
That‰Ûªs not the comforting part.
It‰Ûªs not?

No, no. The comforting part is that the Germans have a term for what you‰Ûªre feeling. Weltschmerz. It means the depression that arises from comparing the world as it is to a hypothetical, idealized world.
You‰Ûªre right, I do feel better.
Well, the Germans have always been a comforting people. Just remember, Leonard, where your biological family has failed you, you always have me, your surrogate family.
You‰Ûªre my surrogate family?
If it‰Ûªs any consolation, I‰Ûªm not happy about it either. Good night.
A bar.
Okay, now this time try drinking it all at once.
Yikes.
I‰Ûªve been responsible for my own buzz since 2003. Another round for me and my homegirl.
I feel a spreading warmth through my extremities.
As long as you don‰Ûªt feel it running down your pants, you‰Ûªre fine.

Oh, that is fascinating. I‰Ûªm noticing an immediate lowering of my inhibitions. For example, I‰Ûªm seriously considering asking that busboy to ravish me in the alleyway while I eat cheesecake. What do you think?
Well, we are known for our cheesecake. Hit us again.
Yes. If a little is good, more must be better.
Hey, Bev, guess what?
What?
I‰Ûªm sleeping with your son.
Really? Which one?
The one from whom I live across the hall from.
Well, that‰Ûªs convenient. How did his penis turn out?
Oh, Beverly, I can‰Ûªt talk to my boyfriend‰Ûªs mother about his penis.
Oh, fair enough. What can you tell me, if anything, about that busboy‰Ûªs penis?
Actually, I‰Ûªve only had the cheesecake. One more time. You know, Leonard did not want to tell you we were dating.
Really? Well, that means he‰Ûªs either embarrassed about the relationship or he doesn‰Ûªt care enough about his mother to tell her he‰Ûªs in one. Either way, one of us should be insulted.
Well, let‰Ûªs go find out who.
You go get a taxi. I‰Ûªm gonna slip my business card into that busboy‰Ûªs back pocket, cupping his firm, right buttock as I do so.
The apartment.
Leonard?
Sonny boy!
Get out here! Your mommy wants to talk to you!
What the hell is going on?
You‰Ûªre in trouble.
Why didn‰Ûªt you tell me you were tapping my homegirl? Did I say that right?
Yeah, not bad, not bad.
Are you guys drunk?
Well, I hope so. Otherwise, why would we have stopped at Del Taco? Now, how could you not tell me you were in a relationship with this lovely, charming young woman?
Oh, thank you.
You‰Ûªre welcome. Is it because she‰Ûªs uneducated, trapped in a menial service position?
What the hell happened to lovely and charming?
How come you didn‰Ûªt tell me that you and Father were getting a divorce? How come you didn‰Ûªt tell me you had surgery? How come you didn‰Ûªt tell me my dog died?
Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. What I hear you saying is that you want a more intimate mother-son relationship.
I do.
There. It‰Ûªs late. Now, go to bed. I‰Ûªm getting a warm feeling spreading through my heart.
That‰Ûªs the Del Taco.
Why is Leonard softly banging his head against his bedroom door?
Speaking of warm feelings, come here. (She grabs Sheldon and kisses him) No, I‰Ûªd rather have the busboy.
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
Thank you for taking me to the airport.
You‰Ûªre very welcome.
Once again, I‰Ûªm driving. I‰Ûªm right here.
Please, I am very hungover and in no mood to satisfy your need for approval. Sheldon, I do hope you‰Ûªll forgive me for my inappropriate behaviour last night.
I don‰Ûªt blame you. You were intoxicated.
Thank you.
I blame Penny.
I blame Penny, too. Bad Penny.
Wait a minute, what are you talking about? What inappropriate behaviour?
I think it‰Ûªs best that you not know.
Agreed.
Agreed.
What the hell, agreed.
And I want you to take very good care of this young woman.
Oh, thank you, Beverly.
You‰Ûªre welcome. She doesn‰Ûªt have much in the way of career prospects, don‰Ûªt make her responsible for her own orgasms as well.
Mother, remember when I was complaining that you don‰Ûªt communicate with me enough?
Yes, dear.
I‰Ûªm over it.
Fa-la-la-la-la, la-la la-la.
The apartment.
Look at us. Getting ready for a double date with actual women who publicly acknowledge they‰Ûªre our girlfriends.
Yes, actual women are the best.
I don‰Ûªt understand. What other kind of women are there?
Howard, artificial women are your department. You want to take this?
No, it would just freak him out. Listen, before we leave, I should warn you, I‰Ûªm a passionate man and I tend towards public displays of affection.
What are you trying to tell me, Howard?
There might be some making out in the car or the restaurant, and I don‰Ûªt want Bernadette to feel uncomfortable, so it would help if you and Penny made out, too.
Don‰Ûªt worry. We‰Ûªre planning to have sex right on the salad bar.
Namaste, white people. Good news! I rented us the four-hour edition of Watchmen.
Got it.
Seen it.
Detailed analysis posted online.
Well, then what are we going to do tonight?
Uh, sorry, Raj. Howard and I are going out to dinner with Penny and Bernadette.
Yeah, no more carefree bachelor nights for me and Leonard. These broncos have been saddled.
How did we get actual women?
Great. They get girlfriends, and they just abandon us?
It is great, isn‰Ûªt it? We have a wonderful evening ahead of us.
We do?

Oh, yes. I just discovered I don‰Ûªt have enough room on my hard drive for a Linux partition, so you and I are going to perform a full backup, reinitialize and then reinstall all my operating systems.
I don‰Ûªt want to do that.
All right. Well, I‰Ûªm going to perform full backup, reinitialize and then reinstall all my operating systems.
What about me?
Well, I understand there are several types of artificial women. Maybe you should look into that.
A little later.

Dude, there‰Ûªs so many cool things we could be doing tonight. Look. At the Glendale Galleria, put on your best zoot suit, it‰Ûªs a salute to Swing music in the center court near Macy‰Ûªs. 5pm to 9pm, huh, huh? A salute to zoot. Sounds like a hoot.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Raj, I have no desire to salute any article of clothing tonight. Much less one that‰Ûªs linked to race riots in the 1940s.
Race riots?
The zoot suit riots.
Oh. I always thought that was some sort of after-Christmas sale. Well, then why don‰Ûªt we just go to the galleria and walk around?
I don‰Ûªt need anything at the Galleria. Do you need anything at the Galleria?
No. We would just walk around and see what‰Ûªs what.
That‰Ûªs a semantically null sentence.

Okay, well, how about this? From the university Web site, 7pm to 10pm, Norton Hall Multipurpose Room, mixer for grad students and faculty of the science and humanities departments. Whether you split atoms or infinitives, this is the place to be.
Well, that‰Ûªs certainly amusing, but I have no interest.
Come on, Sheldon, the world is filled with people doing things outside. Let‰Ûªs go outside. Outside is good.
If outside is so good, why has mankind spent thousands of years trying to perfect inside?
I don‰Ûªt know, it‰Ûªs a marketing scheme. Please, Sheldon, I‰Ûªm a young, virile visitor from a foreign land and I need to strut my stuff.
Let me offer you a compromise. Sometimes when I feel stifled and want a change of scenery, I use my imagination.
Oh, boy.
One of my favourite places to visit is the two-dimensional world described in Edwin Abbott‰Ûªs mathematical fantasy, Flatland.
I don‰Ûªt want to go to Flatland.
You‰Ûªre only saying that because you haven‰Ûªt been there. I am now a hexagon in two-dimensional space and can only perceive the edges of other objects.
Oy.
Is that you, Raj? I don‰Ûªt recognize your edge.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm begging you. I want to go to this mixer, and I don‰Ûªt want to go alone.
Well, you‰Ûªre in luck, there‰Ûªs a mixer here in Flatland. Oh, look, there‰Ûªs a sexually attractive line segment, you should chat her up.
What?
Tell her you‰Ûªre a circle, Flatland gals are all hot for circles.
Leonard‰Ûªs car.
I hope you‰Ûªre hungry, Bernadette, we‰Ûªre going to a terrific restaurant.
Oh, yeah, I‰Ûªm starved. When you spend all day in a bio-lab, watching flesh-eating bacteria skeletonize small rodents it really works up an appetite.
Flesh-eating bacteria. And yet, I still want to kiss this woman, what does that tell you?
That you‰Ûªd be willing to die a horrible death on the off-chance you‰Ûªd get to second base?
Oh, we‰Ûªre way past second base. Right, Howard?
Well, we kind of disagree about what the bases are.
How‰Ûªs your work going, Penny? Any acting jobs?
Well, the last big thing I did was this production of Diary of Anne Frank above a bowling alley. But I think things might be turning around pretty soon.
Great. How come?
Well, promise you won‰Ûªt make fun of me.
Of course, I would never make fun of you.
Okay. Well, I went to this psychic who told me that if I cut my hair, I‰Ûªm going to get a national commercial.
Seriously? You‰Ûªre getting career advice from a psychic?
Good job not making fun of her.
She‰Ûªs not one of those phonies, okay. She wrote a book and has her own Web site.
Oh, gee, why didn‰Ûªt you say so? They don‰Ûªt let just anyone have a Web site.
Why are you being such a jerk?
You‰Ûªre surprised? Your psychic didn‰Ûªt tell you I was going to be a jerk?
Ha-ha, bite me.
Come on, Penny.
Why don‰Ûªt you kids go ahead and chat? We‰Ûªre gonna make out back here.
I‰Ûªm sliding into third.
The university mixer.
Thanks for coming with me.
Thanks for giving me your limited edition Green Lantern lantern.
Did you really have to bring it in with you?
What if evil strikes and my power ring runs low?
Come on, let‰Ûªs get a drink.
I don‰Ûªt drink.
Yeah, well I do. And when my wingman is carrying a Green Lantern lantern, I drink a lot. I‰Ûªll have a screwdriver, please. Don‰Ûªt be chintzy with the screw.
I would like a root beer float.
Sheldon, they don‰Ûªt have ice cream.
They don‰Ûªt? Well, apparently, these people and I differ greatly on the definition of party.
He‰Ûªll have a Shirley Temple.
And don‰Ûªt be chintzy with the Shirley.
Okay, let‰Ûªs check out the females.
All right. There‰Ûªs a female.
That‰Ûªs Professor Wilkinson‰Ûªs wife, she‰Ûªs like 80 years old.
But she‰Ûªs female. Isn‰Ûªt that the game?
No. I‰Ûªm looking for a hookup.
Oh, yes. So, the point of this exercise is for you to find someone to copulate with?
Not so loud, but ideally, yes. Thanks.
Thank you. And what is my function as wingman?
You help me run my game.
Okay. What is your game?
When I lie through my teeth to a woman, you nod and agree.
Hey, that‰Ûªs pretty cool. What is it?
It‰Ûªs a limited edition Green Lantern lantern. My friend is looking for someone to copulate with.
You‰Ûªre very funny. I‰Ûªm Abby.
I‰Ûªm Sheldon. How do you do?
How do you do? Rajesh Ramayan Koothrappali. Call me Raj.
Hi, Raj. Where are you from?
The mysterious subcontinent of India.
Ooh, India.
You know India?
I saw Slumdog Millionaire.
Well, I‰Ûªm a slumdog astrophysicist.
I thought your father was a gynaecologist. I‰Ûªm sorry. (Smiles and nods)
Martha, come here. Meet Raj and Sheldon. This is my friend, Martha.
Hi.
Hello.
Hello.
Is that the limited edition Green Lantern lantern?
In brightest day, in darkest night, no evil shall escape my sight.
Oh, that is so awesome.
Thank you. Have you chosen one to copulate with?
A restaurant.
So, what should we talk about?
Well, we could always learn more about why people who believe in psychics are idiots. Leonard?
Oh, we don‰Ûªt need to talk about that anymore. Leonard covered it pretty well in the car.
I‰Ûªm sorry, but facts are facts.
Right, and if you can‰Ûªt understand it, it‰Ûªs not a fact.
No, if it‰Ûªs not a fact, it‰Ûªs not a fact.
Oh, got it. Thank you for educating me.
You‰Ûªre welcome. How‰Ûªs your fish?
Amazing. Would you like to try some?
Yeah, sure.
Well, the fact is, you can‰Ûªt.
Come on, Howard, Bernadette, you‰Ûªre both scientists. Help me out here.
What do you think? Want to jump right into the middle of another couple‰Ûªs argument?
No, thank you.
Sorry.
Maybe we should just stop talking about this.
Maybe some of us should stop talking altogether.
How is everything tonight?
Really uncomfortable.
The stairwell.

You know, the best thing about being in a committed, monogamous, mutually supportive relationship is that even if you have different ideas, you can have a spirited debate, yet still care for, even make love with‰Û_ (she shuts the door in his face) Want your fish? (Opens door, takes fish, closes it again) I knew you were going to do that. Doesn‰Ûªt make me psychic! Attaboy, Leonard, make it worse. (Opens his own apartment door to find Sheldon, Raj and the two girls playing Rock Band and performing American Woman)
What‰Ûªs going on?
We scored. I‰Ûªm the wingman.
Leonard‰Ûªs lab.
Hey.
Laser.
Had a great night last night. I don‰Ûªt like to kiss and tell, but somebody made it to eighth base.
What the hell is eighth base?
Seventh base with shirt off. Well, my shirt. How‰Ûªd things go with Penny?
Oh, couldn‰Ûªt be better.
Are we taking our relationship frustrations out on innocent Cylons?
It‰Ûªs not just Cylons. Superman‰Ûªs next.
All right, I was going to try to squeeze in a little more mocking before lunch, but I can come back later when you don‰Ûªt have a high-powered weapon.
How can I go out with a woman who believes in psychics?
Hey, I once dated a girl who believed she was abducted by aliens.
And that didn‰Ûªt bother you?
Au contraire. It meant she was gullible and open to a little probing.
What am I supposed to do, pretend I believe something I don‰Ûªt whenever I‰Ûªm with Penny?
Hey, I‰Ûªm sure Penny fakes all kinds of things when she‰Ûªs with you.
Do me a favour, lean over, put your head right here.

Let me show you another way to look at this. Here we have the universe of all women. These are the ones you want to sleep with. These are the women who believe exactly what you believe. These are the women who would be willing to sleep with you. And right there in the

What‰Ûªs your point? In order to keep having a sexual relationship with Penny, I have to give up everything I believe in, my intellectual integrity, the very nature of who I am? I can‰Ûªt do that, Howard.
I respect that. (Takes Leonard‰Ûªs hand, draws a dot on it.)
What is that?
Your new girlfriend. Have fun tonight.
The apartment. Sheldon is learning Finnish.
The dog‰Û_ koira. The roof‰Û_ katto. Grapes‰Û_ ryp leet. (There is a knock on the door) One minute. SisåÊ n.
What was that?
It means come in. It‰Ûªs taking forever to load the new operating system on my computer. I disinfected the kitchen and the bathroom, and now I thought I‰Ûªd learn Finnish.

ˆ_Ïˆ´Ü ˆ__ˆ´Û ˆ__ˆ´ˆ_¨ˆ´ˆ__ˆ__ˆ_¡ˆ´à ˆ_¬ˆ__ˆ_µ ˆ_¨ˆ_âˆ_Ñˆ__ˆ_ö. That‰Ûªs Hindi for whatever floats your boat. Uh, listen, I got a text from that girl Abby, and she and her friend Martha want to hang out with us again. What do you say?
I don‰Ûªt say anything. I merely offer you a facial expression that suggests you‰Ûªve gone insane.
I don‰Ûªt get it. You had a great time.
Yes, exactly, I had a great time. That‰Ûªs done, I‰Ûªve moved on to other things. For example, after I learn Finnish, I‰Ûªm not going to learn Finnish again.
Please, Sheldon, I‰Ûªm a lost Indian boy far from home, and I want a girlfriend and I want her to be Abby, and she‰Ûªll only come over if she can bring Martha.

Raj, I highly doubt there is any argument you can make, threat you might levy, rhetorical strategy, plea, invocation, supplication, or‰Û_ vetoomus that you can employ that would convince me to reconsider.
My Incredible Hulk hands signed by Stan Lee.
Oh, my. I‰Ûªve admired these for years.
So does that mean we can go with the girls again?
Hulk agree to second date with puny humans!
You can‰Ûªt wear the hands on the date.
Hulk sad.
The laundry room.

Hey. Cleaning out the old dryer lint, huh? Not only is it courteous, it‰Ûªs safety smart. Every year, 15,000 fires are caused by accidental dryer lint ignition. Now you‰Ûªre supposed to say, wow, what an interesting fact. Come here, you crazy, nerdy guy. I could never be mad at you.
Wow, that‰Ûªs all you got after you were the most obnoxious person on a double date that included Howard Wolowitz?
No, I‰Ûªm sorry. I really am. It‰Ûªs not right to mock what a person believes in.
Thank you. Would you be willing to go to my psychic and see what it‰Ûªs all about?
Would you be willing to read a book that concisely explains how all psychics are frauds?
I would not.
Okay, let‰Ûªs go see your psychic.
Really?
Well, yeah, one of us has to keep an open mind.
You saying I don‰Ûªt have an open mind?
No, not at all. Let me help you with this stuff.
You know, I believe in ghosts, too.
Great.
And astrology.
I know, and pyramid power and healing crystals.
Oh, no, no, no, crystals don‰Ûªt work.
Really, that‰Ûªs the line? Psychics are real, but crystals are voodoo?
Oh, voodoo‰Ûªs real. You don‰Ûªt want to mess with voodoo.
The apartment.
Flatland is more than just a mathematical essay. It is also a treatise on Victorian social mores.
You know, I had never considered that. Wow, that‰Ûªs going to completely change my visits there. Well, it‰Ûªs late.
Uh-huh.
Time for bed.
Okay.
Good night, puny human! (He gets up and leaves).
Outside Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Sheldon?
Yes?
Listen, they‰Ûªre kind of getting busy in the living room, and I was wondering if I could hang out in here for a while.
Well, I suppose. Come in. I‰Ûªll sleep in Leonard‰Ûªs room. Good night.
A Chinese restaurant.
Boy, seems like forever since the four of us have been out to eat, you know? Just the guys.
Oh, God! Yes, we get it. You have a girlfriend now.
A little jealous, are we?
No, I‰Ûªm not jealous. All right, I‰Ûªd kill a hobo if it‰Ûªll get me laid. Now, can we order?
Oh, dear Lord, they re-did the menu.
So what? It‰Ûªs the same food.
Oh, is it? Look at this. General Tso‰Ûªs Chicken is no longer listed under specialties. It‰Ûªs now under chicken.
So?
Yes, General Tso.
Not Tso the chicken, so the question. So?
So, why is it no longer a specialty? Did the chef lose confidence in the dish or himself? And look over here, shrimp in mobster sauce. What is mobster sauce?
It‰Ûªs obviously a typo.
Perhaps. Perhaps this restaurant‰Ûªs now a front for organized crime. For all we know, the mobster sauce contains actual chunks of deceased mobsters.
No, no, no, no, I think it just means it‰Ûªs the kind of sauce that mobsters like.
It doesn‰Ûªt mean any of that! It‰Ûªs a typo.
You know what? Let‰Ûªs just get a pizza.
Good idea. We‰Ûªll go to Corleone‰Ûªs.
Sure, no mobsters there.
The stairwell.
You know, the more I think about it, the mobster sauce couldn‰Ûªt possibly contain chunks of mobster.
And why is that?
It was listed under seafood.
What if they were mobsters who slept with the fishes?
Leonard, are we having a serious conversation or not?

character: Leonard (noticing their door has been broken open)
line: What the‰Û_?
The TV is gone.
So are our laptops.
Oh God, oh God, oh, God! It‰Ûªs all right. They didn‰Ûªt take my comic books.
The apartment.
They took our TV, two laptops, four external hard-drives, our PS2, our PS3, our X-Box, our X-Box 360, our classic Nintendo, our Super Nintendo, our Nintendo 64 and our Wii.
We like games.
Assorted video games.
When does the CSI team get here?
What?

In anticipation of their arrival, I‰Ûªve bagged some evidence. One of the thieves had the audacity to quench his thirst while ransacking our home. You should be able to pull some good prints off this. And now, here are my prints so you can rule me out as a suspect.
What about me?
I‰Ûªm sorry, Leonard. It‰Ûªs too early to discount the possibility of this being an inside job.
Would I be completely out of line to ask you to shoot him?
I‰Ûªd be happy to put him under a 72-hour psychiatric hold.
I‰Ûªm not crazy. My mother had me tested.
We‰Ûªre done here. Call this number, and we‰Ûªll fax you a copy of the report so you can submit it to your insurance company.
I‰Ûªm sorry, that‰Ûªs the end of your inquiry?
Do you have any more information that might be relevant?
Oh, my goodness. Where do I begin? For instance, my laptop contained four out of the five gedanken experiments necessary for a cogent restatement of the quantum measurement problem.
How is that going to help them?
Well, they could monitor scientific publications and see if anyone posts such a cogent restatement in the next couple of months. If so, the authors are most likely in possession of my stolen laptop.
Good night, fellas. Come on, Bochco.
What are we supposed to do now?
The only thing we can do. Watch TV on our phones until the criminals return and bludgeon us to death in our sleep.
Does that mean you‰Ûªve ruled me out as a suspect?
Oh, how I wish I could.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom. Sheldon is restless. He gets up and checks the door is locked. He then moves his chest of drawers in front of the door. Goes back to bed.
I do not have to urinate. I am the master of my own bladder. Drat.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
I can‰Ûªt believe it. If I hadn‰Ûªt been working the dinner shift, I would‰Ûªve run
Hey, there‰Ûªs no reason for you to be scared.
I‰Ûªm not scared. I would‰Ûªve gone all Nebraska on their asses.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
Hand me the bat.
We just had a major crime in the building, and you open the door without asking who it is?
It won‰Ûªt happen again, what‰Ûªs up?
Nothing. Just wanted to see if you were both okay.
We‰Ûªre fine, Sheldon.
All right, then. Good night.
Good night. That was weird, even for him.
Mm-hmm.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
Who is it?
Sheldon. Sheldon Cooper.
Yes?
May I come in?
Yeah.
I see you‰Ûªre drinking wine.
Yes, we are. And we‰Ûªre about to go to bed.
Uh-huh.
Sheldon, do you want to sleep here tonight?
Oh, as small as Leonard is, I don‰Ûªt think the two of you‰Ûªd be comfortable on the couch.
What do you want?
It‰Ûªs not what I want, it‰Ûªs what evolution wants. Human beings are primates. Primates have evolved to live in groups, both for protection and support.
But you don‰Ûªt like other people.
I do tonight. It‰Ûªs scary over there.
It‰Ûªs getting scary here, too.
The apartment. Sheldon is drawing picture clues on his whiteboard.
Um‰Û_ three little kittens? Three little pigs? God, I don‰Ûªt know. Star Wars?
Did we win? Can we go to bed?

Good Lord, I could not have made this easier. Hydrogen atom, H, plus pigs minus pea, Higgs. Bow, General Zod trapped in the Phantom Zone. Bow-zone. Pear. Tickle. Pear-tickle. Higgs Boson Particle. How could you not get that?
He‰Ûªs right, Penny. It‰Ûªs all there.
Look, Sheldon, sweetie, I know you‰Ûªre feeling insecure, but we‰Ûªve really got to go to sleep.
All right. I‰Ûªll take the first watch and wake you at 0400.
Great. Good night.
Wait, wait, what‰Ûªs 0400?
4am.
That‰Ûªs, like, in 45 minutes.
Just keep walking. (Sheldon checks door then puts TV on his phone)
It‰Ûªs quiet out there.
Maybe a little too quiet.
Where are you going?
Just gonna take a look around outside.
Bad idea.
No, Jim, don‰Ûªt open the door!
Listen to her, Jim.
Don‰Ûªt worry, there‰Ûªs no one out here. (Sound of woman screaming. Sheldon nods, and turns off TV. Walks down to Leonard‰Ûªs room.)
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny!
Who is it?
Outside the apartment.
All right, we‰Ûªve got a titanium dead bolt and a reinforced jamb controlled by a state-of-the-art electronic access system.
What if they cut the power?
There‰Ûªs a 200-watt uninterruptible backup power supply.
What if someone steals my keys?
There are independent voice and fingerprint scanners.
What if someone kidnaps me, forces me to record my voice, and then cuts off my thumb?
I‰Ûªll send them a basket of muffins.
Now, inside, we‰Ûªve got motion detectors, infrared sensors, and cameras connected to a server running state-of-the-art facial recognition software.
Where did you get all this stuff?
I got a buddy over at the Department of Defence.
He just gave it to you?
I‰Ûªm sure he would have if I had asked. Ironically, their security isn‰Ûªt all that good.
Raj, your car is blocking me‰Û_ (A wire net falls on her, while a computer voice repeats the words ‰ÛÏIntruder Alert‰Û) What the hell?
Sorry, let me help you.
Wonderful security system if we‰Ûªre attacked by a school of tuna.
Don‰Ûªt worry, the net‰Ûªs going to be electrified. Picture her on the floor, spasming uncontrollably.
Better.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.

Sheldon‰Ûªs journal. Security system in place. However, sleep continues to elude me. I‰Ûªve seen the underbelly of Pasadena, this so-called City of Roses, and it haunts me. Ah, the injustice, I lie here awake, tormented, while out there evil lurks, probably playing Donkey Kong on my classic Nintendo. (Hears a noise. Goes to check, then panics and climbs out window onto ledge.) Oh, dear. I am the master of my own bladder. (Crawls along to Leonard‰Ûªs window, where Leonard and Penny are inside being intimate. Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
Oh, my‰Û_
God, Sheldon. What the hell are you doing out there?
I heard a noise.
It was us. We knocked over a lamp.
Why would you knock over a lamp?
We were going to have‰Û_
He doesn‰Ûªt need to know what we were doing, Leonard.
Oh! No, she‰Ûªs right, I don‰Ûªt need to know what you were doing. Carry on. (Starts to climb back out of window)
What are you doing? Use the door.
Good thinking. Perhaps I‰Ûªll check the perimeter and make some warm milk.
Great, you do that.
Would you like me to bring you some warm milk?
I‰Ûªm lactose intolerant.
And you don‰Ûªt wish to alarm me with any more loud noises, very thoughtful. Warm milk, Penny?
No, thanks.
Fine. Good night to you, sir. Miss.
Sorry about that.

Ugh, what can you do? Here. (From outside there is the sound of the net falling and computer voice saying ‰ÛÏIntruder alert.‰Û Then Sheldon screaming. They run out to find Sheldon convulsing under the net.)
Looks like Wolowitz got the net electrified.
Sheldon, are you okay?
I‰Ûªm fine. Although I‰Ûªm no longer the master of my own bladder.
The apartment.
My new computer came with Windows 7. Windows 7 is much more user-friendly than Windows Vista. I don‰Ûªt like that.
Don‰Ûªt you think looking for a new city to live in is a bit of an overreaction?
Our apartment was broken into, our security system tried to kill me, and as a result, I‰Ûªm leaving Pasadena forever. Tell me how that‰Ûªs overreacting.
Come on, Sheldon, you can‰Ûªt move. Don‰Ûªt you need to stay in one place so the mother ship can find you when it returns?

Oh, if that were only true. Unfortunately, as I‰Ûªm earthbound for the foreseeable future, I need to find a location that‰Ûªs more hospitable than the mean streets of Pasadena. Like Enid, Oklahoma. Low crime rate and high-speed Internet connectivity, but no model train shops. Sorry, Enid.
Is he quitting his job at the university?
Oh, no, he‰Ûªs going to telecommute. Everybody‰Ûªs really excited about it.

All right. Boone, North Carolina. Every summer since 1952, Boone has hosted an outdoor amphitheater portrayal of the life and times of its namesake, Dan‰Ûªl Boone. Sounds like something that would attract the wrong crowd. Penny, you‰Ûªre from Nebraska, correct?
Born and raised. (Sheldon crosses Nebraska off his map)
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom. Sheldon is packing.

It will take me a few days to get settled. After I do, I will e-mail you detailed PDFs containing diagrams and instructions that will guide you through packing and shipping the rest of my possessions to Bozeman, Montana. In the meantime, please forward my mail.
Any place specific or just the Bozeman, Montana Loony Bin?
I sense you‰Ûªre making a joke, but Bozeman does have a comedy club called The Loony Bin, so do not forward my mail there.

Oh, come on. So you were the victim of a crime. That‰Ûªs part of life. When my great-grandfather first came to this country, he put all his hopes and dreams into this little butcher shop he ran on the Lower East Side of New York. You know what happened? Every customer who walked into that butcher shop and asked for a pound of liver, got ripped off. But, those people moved on, and so should you.
I am moving on. I‰Ûªm going to be a Bozite.
They call themselves Bozites?
They should. It‰Ûªs one of the first things I plan to bring up upon arrival.
Sheldon, I can‰Ûªt believe I‰Ûªm saying this, but I‰Ûªm going to miss you.
Please, Penny, as you know, I‰Ûªm not comfortable with prolonged good-byes and maudlin displays of emotion, so I prepared a short video.

Greetings. As you know, I‰Ûªm not comfortable with prolonged good-byes and maudlin displays of emotion, so I prepared this short video. The four of you are three of my closest friends and one treasured acquaintance. Though I cannot state categorically that my life will be diminished by not having you in it, I am comfortable if you choose to believe that. Since you intend to remain in this lawless metropolitan area, statistics suggest that you will succumb to tragic and gruesome ends before we meet again. Live long and prosper.
Sheldon, that‰Ûªs so‰Û_ (Turns to find he has gone.)
You might want to lock the door behind me. This isn‰Ûªt Bozeman.
How the hell do I know who‰Ûªs the friend and who‰Ûªs the acquaintance?
Bozeman, Montana bus depot.
That is a bracing cold, an invigorating cold. Lord, is it cold!
Help you with your bags, sir?

Thank you, fellow Bozite. And may I say, you are the living embodiment of all the promises made by our lovely town‰Ûªs Chamber of Commerce. (Man picks up bags and starts running.) Wait! Wait! Excuse me! (At ticket desk) One ticket to Pasadena, California, please.
The apartment. Sheldon enters.
Hey, look who‰Ûªs back!
Interesting. The acquaintance is the first to greet me.
The apartment. Sheldon is stood in the middle of the room. His whiteboard is behind him. Every few moments he turns round suddently.
Whatcha doing?
I‰Ûªm attempting to view my work as a fleeting peripheral image so as to engage the superior colliculus of my brain.
Interesting. I usually just have coffee. You‰Ûªve been up all night?
Is it morning?
Yes.
Then I‰Ûªve been up all night.
And you‰Ûªre stuck?
Why else would a person try to engage their superior colliculus?
Oh, sorry, sweetie, I can‰Ûªt help you till I‰Ûªve had my coffee.
Penny, I told you if you don‰Ûªt put him in his crate at night he just runs around the apartment.
What is he doing now?
Mmm, he‰Ûªs either isolating the terms of his formula and examining them individually, or looking for the alligator that swallowed his hand after Peter Pan cut it off.
Captain Hook‰Ûªs hand was eaten by a crocodile, not an alligator. If you‰Ûªre going to mock me, at least get your facts straight.
Aye, aye, Captain.
I can‰Ûªt see it! It just won‰Ûªt coalesce.
Maybe you need a fresh start.
You‰Ûªre right. (Takes whiteboard to window and throws it out. Picks up a new one) It‰Ûªs a great idea, Leonard. Thank you.
The cafeteria.
Electrons move through graphene, act as if they have no mass‰Û_
How long has he been stuck?
Intellectually about 30 hours. Emotionally about 29 years.
Unit cell contains two carbon atoms. Interior angle of a hexagon is 120 degrees.
Have you tried rebooting him?
No, I think it‰Ûªs a firmware problem.
Hey, it‰Ûªs Disco Night at the Moonlight Roller Rink in Glendale tonight. Who‰Ûªs up for getting down?
Oh, that‰Ûªs perfect. Bernadette‰Ûªs been hocking me to take her roller skating.
I think Penny likes to skate. The four of us could double.
What could be better? We‰Ûªre in.
Great. It‰Ûªs not like I brought it up because I wanted to go.
You can come with us.
No, it‰Ûªs okay. I don‰Ûªt have to go. I‰Ûªm happy just to guide you and your ladies to suitable entertainment choices. I‰Ûªm a walking brown Yelp.com.
Structure, constant structure. One atom‰Û_
Boy, he‰Ûªs really gone, isn‰Ûªt he?
Yeah, this morning he used a stick of butter as deodorant.
I thought I smelled popcorn.
Pattern is the same as fermions, travels on the pathways, hexagonal, it‰Ûªs always hexagonal‰Û_
I haven‰Ûªt seen him this stuck since he tried to figure out the third Matrix movie.

character: Raj (as Sheldon reaches out and grabs from his plate)
line: Hey, those are my lima beans!
Not lima beans, carbon atoms.
But if I don‰Ûªt eat my lima beans, I can‰Ûªt have my cookie.
Here, you want my peas?
Peas! Perfect, they can be electrons.
Want my corn?
Don‰Ûªt be ridiculous. What would I do with corn?
So roller skating, should we all grab a bite to eat first?
Good. P.F. Chang‰Ûªs? My mom has coupons.
Great. Your mom‰Ûªs not coming, right?
Not this time, I promise.
Okay, just to be clear, roller skating was my idea, and I‰Ûªm very unhappy that you turned it into a double date, and I hope you both fall on your asses and break your coccyxes.
The plural of coccyx is coccyges.
Screw you. Give me back my lima beans.
The stairwell.
Oh, my God, have you ever been so embarrassed?
Not recently.
I don‰Ûªt know which was lamer, their roller-skating or their disco dancing.
For me, the worst part was when people saw us leave with them.
You had some nice moves out there, Howard.
Thanks. You, too.
Yeah. Did you notice all the people looking at us?
Not really. I was in my boogie zone.
When Howard tried to do the splits‰Û_
Shh.
Sorry. I‰Ûªm moving a little slow. I think I bruised my coccyx.
Oh, poor baby.
Don‰Ûªt tell Koothrappali. After you.
Oh, what a gentleman. Hey, Sheldon. (Steps on marbles which are all over the floor, screams and falls)
Oh, my God! Are you‰Û_ (falls as well)
Good Lord! You‰Ûªre ruining everything!
Oh, damn.
Are you okay?
Do I look okay?
Don‰Ûªt bark at me. I fell, too.
Oh, you‰Ûªve been falling all night. You‰Ûªre used to it.
Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
The same thing I‰Ûªve been doing for three days. Trying to figure out why electrons behave as if they have no mass when travelling through a graphene sheet.
With marbles?
Well, I needed something bigger than peas, now, didn‰Ûªt I?
Sheldon, when was the last time you got any sleep?
I don‰Ûªt know, two, three days. Not important. I don‰Ûªt need sleep, I need answers. I need to determine where in this swamp of unbalanced formulas squatteth the toad of truth.
Toad of truth? Is that a physics thing?
No, that‰Ûªs a crazy thing.
Okay, Sheldon. What happens to our neuroreceptors when we don‰Ûªt get enough REM sleep?
They lose their sensitivity to serotonin and norepinephrine.
Which leads to‰Û_?
Impaired cognitive function.
Right, so march in there, brush your teeth and go to bed.
But I don‰Ûªt want to go to bed.
I‰Ûªm going to count to three. One‰Û_
Oh, all right.
That was amazing how you handled him.
I know how to deal with stubborn children. My mother used to run an illegal day care centre in our basement.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Leonard, you‰Ûªre‰Û_ you‰Ûªre giggling in your sleep.
It‰Ûªs not me, it‰Ûªs my new ringtone. The Joker from Batman.
Well, it creeps me out.
Me, too, but I paid three bucks for it.
Just answer the phone.
Hello. Yeah, I‰Ûªm Leonard Hofstadter. Yeah, yeah, he‰Ûªs my roommate. Oh, God, is he okay? Yeah, alright, alright, I‰Ûªll be right there.
What happened?
Sheldon‰Ûªs escaped and is terrorizing the village.
Okay. Have fun.
A children‰Ûªs play area.
Hi. I‰Ûªm Dr. Hofstadter. Where is he?
Ball pit.
Thanks for not calling the cops.
Oh, hey, it‰Ûªs no big deal. My sister‰Ûªs got a kid who‰Ûªs special.
Yeah, well, he‰Ûªs extra special. Hey, Shelly. What you doing?
Size ratio was all wrong. Couldn‰Ûªt visualize it. Needed bigger carbon atoms.
Sure, sure. How did you get into this place?
Back door has a five-pin tumbler system, single-circuit alarm. Child‰Ûªs play. You can start sorting protons and neutrons while I build carbon atoms.
No, I don‰Ûªt think so. We need to go home now.
But I‰Ûªm still working.
If you don‰Ûªt come out of there, I‰Ûªm going to have to drag you out.
You can try, but you‰Ûªll never catch me. (He disappears under the balls)
For God‰Ûªs sakes. Sheldon, come here!
Bazinga. (Disappears, pops up in another place) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom. Sheldon is standing over their bed. He knocks on the wall.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
What! What, what, what?
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
What?
I have good news.
And you had to barge in here and wake us up in the middle of the night?
Your cell phone was off.
Because we didn‰Ûªt want to be disturbed.
And that didn‰Ûªt work out, did it?
Sheldon, what do you want?
I came to tell you I‰Ûªve got the answer.
Really? You figured out the graphene problem?
No, no, I‰Ûªm still hopelessly stuck on that, but I figured out how to figure it out.
Hey, you know what, Leonard, I know I said I could handle your roommate, but I was wrong. We‰Ûªre going to have to break up.
What are you talking about?

character: Penny (as Sheldon sits on the bed)
line: Oh.
Einstein.
Yeah, I‰Ûªm going to need a little more.
Albert Einstein.
Keep going.
When Albert Einstein came up with special relativity, he was working at the patent office.
So, you‰Ûªre going to go work at the patent office?

Don‰Ûªt be absurd. That‰Ûªs in Washington. You know I could never live in a city whose streets are laid out in a wheel-and-spoke pattern. No. I‰Ûªm going to find a similarly menial job where my basal ganglia are occupied with a routine task, freeing my prefrontal cortex to work quietly in the background on my problem.
Sounds like a great plan.
Of course it is. Even talking to you is sufficiently menial that I can feel the proverbial juices starting to flow.
Okay, well, thanks for sharing with us. Good night.
You‰Ûªre welcome. Good night to you, too. Oh, by the way, I was watching you sleep for a moment, and I noticed that your snoring seems to be worse when you‰Ûªre on your back.
Leonard doesn‰Ûªt snore.
No, I wasn‰Ûªt talking to Leonard.
Told you.
An employment office
So, Mr. Cooper, you‰Ûªre looking for a job.
A menial job. Like yours.
Why, thank you for noticing. I‰Ûªm Menial Employee of the Month. Do you have a particular field in mind?

I do. For thousands of years, the lowest classes of the human race have spent their lives labouring to erect monuments under the lash of their betters, until finally they dropped down and became one with the dust through which they trudged. Do you have anything like that?
No.
Shouldn‰Ûªt you check your database?

character: Assistant (clicks her keyboard a few times)
line: No.
You didn‰Ûªt really type.
I didn‰Ûªt really have to. So, how about construction?
Oh, that would be good! Sawing, hammering, eating out of a lunch pail as my working-class fellows and I sit perched precariously on a girder high above the metropolis.
No, no. This is putting up sheetrock at a housing project in Rosemead.
I could do that.
Good.
One question.
Yes?
What‰Ûªs sheetrock?
Moving on. How about doing deliveries for a florist?
That seems acceptable.
Do you have your own car?
I don‰Ûªt drive.
Of course you don‰Ûªt. Mr. Cooper, let me just ask you a question. What was your last job?
Senior theoretical particle physicist at CalTech, focusing on M theory, or, in layman‰Ûªs terms, string theory.
I see. Just give me a second. Security!
The Cheesecake Factory.
Okay, I‰Ûªll get those drinks started for you.

character: Sheldon (appearing in an apron and carrying a tray)
line: Behind you.
Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
I‰Ûªm trying to get these tables cleared. We‰Ûªre slammed.
No, wait, wait, no, wait. Wh.. what are you doing here?

A reasonable question. I asked myself, what is the most mind-numbing, pedestrian job conceivable, and three answers came to mind, uh, toll booth attendant, an Apple Store genius, and what Penny does. Now, since I don‰Ûªt like touching other people‰Ûªs coins, and I refuse to contribute to the devaluation of the word genius, here I am.
You just, you just walked in and they hired you, just like that?
Oh, heavens, no. Since I don‰Ûªt need to be paid, I didn‰Ûªt need to be hired. I simply came in, picked up a tray, and started working for the man. Let me get that plate out of your way.
Sheldon, this is ridiculous.
Is it? Just a moment ago I had a minor epiphany regarding the polymer degradation phenomenon while scraping congealed nachos off a plate. Bernadette, table 10 wants their check.
Thanks, Sheldon.
Sheldon, wait, this isn‰Ûªt even what I do. I‰Ûªm a waitress, not a busboy.
You‰Ûªre right. That is more menial. Hello, I‰Ûªm Sheldon. I‰Ûªll be your server today. I don‰Ûªt recommend the salmon. I saw it in the kitchen.
The same, later.

All right, one bacon cheeseburger, breaking two Jewish dietary restrictions simultaneously, kudos. Beer-battered fish and chips. Now, here‰Ûªs your tartar sauce. I also brought you salsa. It‰Ûªs a little unconventional, but I think you‰Ûªll like it. It‰Ûªs zingy. And for you, Factory Burrito Grande, no cheese, no sour cream, no ugly consequences from your lactose intolerance. Bon appÌ©tit.
Hang on. Black beans, not pinto beans?
Yes.
Double guacamole?
Of course.
No cilantro?
Nope.
Lettuce shredded, not chopped?
Yep.
You understand why I‰Ûªm doing this to you?
I do.
That‰Ûªll be all. That was fun.
How long can he keep this up?
I heard about this professor at MIT who melted down, bought a van, and spent the rest of his life as a mobile dog groomer.
He never went back to the university?
Only to shampoo Professor Chambourg‰Ûªs shih tzu.
Sheesh.
I bet if we all chipped in, we could buy Sheldon a van.
But he‰Ûªs afraid of dogs.
Yeah, that‰Ûªs the only thing wrong with that plan.
Hey, guys, sorry you had to wait, but we are swamped. What‰Ûªs this?
Sheldon took our order.
Sheldon doesn‰Ûªt work here.
Well, honey, not to complain, but we were starting to think you didn‰Ûªt either.

character: Sheldon (drops tray. A nearby table claps)
line: Is that really necessary? Good Lord. The interference pattern in the fracture. The motion of the wave through the molecular structure. I‰Ûªve been looking at it all wrong. I can‰Ûªt consider the electrons as particles. They move through the graphene as a wave. It‰Ûªs a wave! The moment to applaud would be now. Troglodytes.
Sheldon, where are you going? Aren‰Ûªt you going to clean this up?
I‰Ûªm sorry. I don‰Ûªt work here.
The roller disco.
Happy now?
I‰Ûªm on a cloud. Swing me. (Howard swings Raj several times.)
The ball pit, presumably earlier.
Sheldon, come here.
The university cafeteria.
Yeah, I miss you, too, sweetie. Listen, I got to go, but I‰Ûªll see you tonight? Okay. Bye-bye. Yeah, bye-bye. No, you hang up first. Hello?
Dude, I‰Ûªm glad you finally got a girlfriend, but do you have to do all that lovey-dovey stuff in front of those of us who don‰Ûªt?

Actually, he might have to. There‰Ûªs an economic concept known as a positional good in which an object is only valued by the possessor because it‰Ûªs not possessed by others. The term was coined in 1976 by economist Fred Hirsch to replace the more colloquial, but less precise neener-neener.
That‰Ûªs not true. My happiness is not dependent on my best friend being miserable and alone.
Thank you.
Although, I‰Ûªd be lying if I said it wasn‰Ûªt a little bit of a perk.
Who‰Ûªs miserable and alone?
Me.
Oh. I used to be like that. Then I got a girlfriend.
In pre-1976 terms, neener-neener.
Hey, what are you and Bernadette doing for your first Valentine‰Ûªs Day?
Yeah, I am pulling out all the stops. There‰Ûªs a $39.95 lover‰Ûªs special at P.F. Chang‰Ûªs. Egg rolls, dumplings, bottomless wok, and you get your picture taken on the big marble horse out front.

Given that Saint Valentine was a third century Roman priest who was stoned and beheaded, wouldn‰Ûªt a more appropriate celebration of the evening be taking one‰Ûªs steady gal to witness a brutal murder?
I understand your point, but given a choice, Jews always go with Chinese food.

Well, if anyone‰Ûªs interested, I‰Ûªll be spending this Valentine‰Ûªs Day the same way I spend every Valentine‰Ûªs Day. Buying a rotisserie chicken from the supermarket, taking it home, standing over the sink and eating it out of the package with my bare hands like an animal.
Fine, tell us you‰Ûªre going to have sex with Penny.
That‰Ûªs not what I was going to tell you.
It‰Ûªs okay. I don‰Ûªt mind hearing about your sex life. It‰Ûªs his that bugs me.
Guess who the university is sending to Switzerland to attend a conference and see the CERN supercollider on February 14?
Professor Norton, although, God knows why. He hasn‰Ûªt published anything of note since he won that Nobel Prize.
Actually, Professor Norton can‰Ûªt make it. He threw his back out rock climbing.
I heard he threw his back out climbing on his new girlfriend.
The big-boobed weather girl on Channel 2?
That‰Ûªs the one.
In any case, they‰Ûªre asking me to fill in for him.
In Switzerland or with the big-boobed weather girl?
Switzerland. And I get to bring a guest!
Oh, man!
No way, dude!
This is incredible! I‰Ûªm so happy, I‰Ûªm not even going to question their judgment in picking you. I‰Ûªm just going to run home and start packing.
Why wouldn‰Ûªt you take Penny?
I am taking Penny.
Oh. Well, then I anticipate an awkward situation when you get home.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Sheldon, you got a minute?
Of course, my good friend. Come in. Help me out, which ski hat says aprÌ¬s supercollider?
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm not taking you to Switzerland.
Well, of course you are. Who else would you take?
Penny.
What? That‰Ûªs absurd. Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.
Yes, but it‰Ûªll be Valentine‰Ûªs Day. We can go sightseeing and skiing and make love in front of a roaring fire in the shadow of the snowcapped Alps.
But Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Sheldon.
Sorry? I‰Ûªve been dreaming about going to the Large Hadron Collider since I was nine years old.
Yeah, well, I‰Ûªve been dreaming about spending Valentine‰Ûªs Day with a girl since I was six.
Shame on you! That‰Ûªs no dream for a scientist!
The apartment.
Okay, what‰Ûªs the big surprise?
Just a minute. This tray contains clues as to what you and I are going to be doing on Valentine‰Ûªs Day.

Oh. Wow. Okay. Let‰Ûªs see. We‰Ûªve got, uh, milk chocolate, Swiss cheese, fondue. My lactose-intolerant boyfriend is going to eat all this, then I‰Ûªm going to climb on his back and rocket to the moon?
No. But it does involve air travel. Okay, um, let me slice this Swiss cheese with my Swiss army knife, and then you can wash it down with a cup of Swiss Miss instant cocoa.
Okay, I‰Ûªm starting to think Swiss is key here.
Uh-huh.
We‰Ûªre going to Disneyland and ride the Matterhorn?
How does that involve air travel?
We‰Ûªre going to Disney World and ride the Matterhorn?
No.
Okay, sweetie, this started out fun, but I‰Ûªm over it.
We‰Ûªre going to Switzerland to see the CERN supercollider! And ski. We‰Ûªll also go skiing.
We‰Ûªre going skiing in Switzerland?!
Well, you‰Ûªll ski, I‰Ûªll fall, but, yeah, we will be in Switzerland for Valentine‰Ûªs Day.
Oh, my God, Leonard! That‰Ûªs incredible!
Not so fast. You might want to hold off on lighting your rabeliechtli, Penny.
My Rabe-what-ly?

Rabeliechtli. It means turnip light and refers to a traditional lantern hand-carved from a root vegetable and used to celebrate certain Swiss festivals. Which you will not be celebrating because, A, these festivals occur in the fall, and B, you will not be going to Switzerland.
Sheldon, we‰Ûªve been through this. I‰Ûªm taking Penny.
Afraid not. Do you recognize this?
Not the roommate agreement.

Indeed, the roommate agreement. I call your attention to the Friendship Rider in Appendix C, Future Commitments. Number 37, in the event one friend is ever invited to visit the Large Hadron Collider, now under construction in Switzerland, he shall invite the other friend to accompany him.
Oh, for God‰Ûªs sakes.
You actually put that in an agreement?
Yeah. We also put in what happens if one of us wins a MacArthur Grant, or if one of us gets superpowers, or if one of us is bitten by a zombie.
He can‰Ûªt kill me, even if I turn.
Is there anything in there about if one of you gets a girlfriend?
No, that seemed a little farfetched.
Sheldon, do you really expect to enforce this?

I‰Ûªve lived up to all my commitments under the agreement. At least once a day I ask how you are, even though I simply don‰Ûªt care. I no longer stage spontaneous biohazard drills after 10 pm And I abandoned my goal to master Tuvan throat singing.
Okay, I know I shouldn‰Ûªt ask, but what is‰Û_?
No.
I‰Ûªd be much further along if I‰Ûªd been allowed to practice.
Look, Sheldon, I know it‰Ûªs in the agreement, and if you turn into a zombie, I promise I will not kill you. In fact, I‰Ûªll even let you eat my brains. But I am taking Penny to Switzerland.
Is that your final decision?
It is.
Very well.
It‰Ûªs not over, is it?
What do you think? (The sound of Tuvan throat singing comes from Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.)
Leonard‰Ûªs car.

Got a bit of traffic this morning, huh? Think it‰Ûªs gonna rain? Instead of underpants, I covered my crotch with potato salad this morning. Thoughts? Okay, I know what‰Ûªll cheer you up, let‰Ûªs play one of your driving games.
All right. This game is called Traitors. I will name three historical figures, you put them in order of the heinousness of their betrayal. Benedict Arnold, Judas, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.
You really think I belong with Benedict Arnold and Judas?
You‰Ûªre right. Judas had the decency to hang himself after what he did.
Come on, Sheldon. Can‰Ûªt you at least try to understand how much this means to me?
Round two, Leonard Hofstadter, Darth Vader, Rupert Murdoch.
Rupert Murdoch?
He owns Fox, and they cancelled Firefly. Hint, he and Darth Vader are tied for number 2.
The university cafeteria.
I‰Ûªm sorry I couldn‰Ûªt hang with you last night. I had a date with Bernadette.
I know. I saw the Tweet.
So, what did you end up doing?
Not much. Nuked a burrito. Prayed to the Hindu god Urvashi that your bowels would loosen and your penis would droop like a willow tree.
You seen Sheldon?
No. Is he still mad about the supercollider?
Yeah. He thinks I betrayed him. I mean, come on, what would you guys do if you were me?
I‰Ûªd take Sheldon to Switzerland.
Seriously?
Absolutely. And I‰Ûªd leave him there. (Sheldon enters, puts a tray in front of Leonard, and exits.)
What the hell is that?
Uh, let‰Ûªs see. Yup, 30 pieces of silverware.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Morning, old chum.
What‰Ûªs going on?
I‰Ûªve made you breakfast. Juice, coffee, and pancakes in the shape of some of your favorite fictional characters. See, here‰Ûªs Frodo.
You made Frodo pancakes?

Yeah, I used coconut shavings to do the hair on his feet. If you need to void your bladder before eating, I can keep them warm with this beret that I thoroughly laundered and pressed into service as a pancake cosy.
Why are you doing this?

It‰Ûªs by way of an apology for my recent behaviour. I‰Ûªve had some time to reflect and I‰Ûªve come to realize that friendship is not an aggregation of written agreements. It‰Ûªs a result of two people respecting and caring for each other. Butterscotch scone?
Thanks. It‰Ûªs good.

What you‰Ûªre tasting is respect and affection. And about a pound of Crisco. After you‰Ûªve finished breakfast, I thought we could spend the day watching the final season of Babylon 5 with director commentary.
You hate Babylon 5.
I do. It fails as drama, science fiction, and it‰Ûªs hopelessly derivative. But you like it, and you‰Ûªre my friend.
Okay, great. Still not taking you to Switzerland.
Drat. No Frodo for you.
The laundry room.
Hello.
Hello.
Alright, let‰Ûªs dispense with the friendly banter, I believe you know why I‰Ûªm here.
Well, I always figured it was to study us, discover our weaknesses, and report back to your alien overlords.
Yes, amusing. Extraordinary intelligence might well appear extraterrestrial to you, but let me be more specific. I believe you know why I‰Ûªm here in the laundry room.
Better acoustics for your throat singing?

It‰Ûªs actually not bad. But my true purpose in being here will be revealed in this brief PowerPoint presentation. Lights. Why Sheldon Cooper, PhD, should go to Switzerland to see the CERN supercollider. A PowerPoint presentation by Sheldon Cooper, PhD.
Oh, for God‰Ûªs sakes.

Here we have a highly gifted researcher in the field of particle physics whose work has brought him to the precipice of forever changing mankind‰Ûªs understanding of the universe. AKA me. And here we have a waitress brushing her teeth with her finger. AKA you.
I‰Ûªm sorry. Is this supposed to be buttering me up?

Please hold all questions to the end of the presentation. This is the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Switzerland, the product of decades of planning and construction. It is a Mecca for physicists the world over. This is Bath and Body Works on Colorado Boulevard. They sell scented soaps and lotions, some of which contain glitter. Now, let‰Ûªs see if we can match the individual to the appropriate destination.
Okay, show‰Ûªs over.
No, it‰Ûªs not. I‰Ûªve got five more slides.
Sheldon, this is Leonard‰Ûªs decision. He invited me to Switzerland, and I intend to go.

Very well. Enjoy yourself. You‰Ûªre going to be in the presence of something that I‰Ûªve dreamed of seeing for decades. I just hope you‰Ûªll be able to appreciate the magnitude of where you are and what it represents.
I‰Ûªll talk to Leonard.
You will?
Yes. If it means that much to you, you should go.
Oh, Penny, thank you!
You‰Ûªre welcome.
Since I rarely hug, I‰Ûªm relying on your expertise regarding duration.
I think we‰Ûªre there.
Oh, good. Bye-bye.
The apartment.
You know what? Even though I don‰Ûªt have a girlfriend, I can still have a good time on Valentine‰Ûªs Day.
Trust me, you can‰Ûªt. I‰Ûªve tried.
No, no, no, I‰Ûªm going to have a me day. First I‰Ûªm going to go to one of those spas in Koreatown, take a steam and get a massage. Then I‰Ûªm going to stop at a pet store and get licked by puppies.
Sheldon, I need to talk to you.
All right, my friend. Would you like some cholermus?
Some what?
Cholermus. It‰Ûªs a traditional Swiss breakfast dish. I‰Ûªm preparing my gastrointestinal system for the exotic cuisine of Switzerland.
You‰Ûªre not going to Switzerland!
Oh, but I am. Didn‰Ûªt Penny tell you the good news?
She told me that you went behind my back to guilt her into letting you go instead of her.
Yes, that good news.
Well, forget it. I was the one who was invited, I get to decide who goes with me, and it‰Ûªs Penny, not you!
Howard, could you lower the lights? I have a short PowerPoint presentation.
I don‰Ûªt need to see your presentation. This discussion is over!
That‰Ûªs a somewhat ambiguous response. Am I going or not?
Sheldon, at this point, I would go by myself before I would take you.
Really?
Yeah, really.
Well then, you leave me no alternative. From this moment forward, we can be roommates, but we will no longer be friends.
I‰Ûªm sorry you feel that way.
I don‰Ûªt think you‰Ûªre fully aware of the ramifications here, Leonard.
Why don‰Ûªt you enlighten me?
With the friendship clause of our roommate agreement nullified you are no longer entitled to accompany me to go swimming at Bill Gates‰Ûª house should I be invited.
Ooh, that‰Ûªs gotta sting.
Penny‰Ûªs bedroom.
Just think, this time tomorrow we‰Ûªll be in Geneva, Switzerland for our first Valentine‰Ûªs Day.
I know! I went shopping today and bought special undies for the occasion.
Thermal? ‰Û÷Cause it‰Ûªs gonna be cold.
Think it through, Leonard.
Oh!
Oh!
Gesundheit. Or as they say in Switzerland, gesundheit. You getting a cold?
No, no, it‰Ûªs probably just allergies.
Do you want an allergy pill? ‰Û÷Cause I have ‰Ûªem all. Prescription, nonprescription, foreign, domestic, experimental.
Do any of them work?

Penny? You okay?
Did that sound okay to you? Do not come in here!
What‰Ûªs going on?

Well, our plane leaves at 9 a.m. Do you think you‰Ûªll feel better by then?
Yep. ‰Û÷Cause I‰Ûªm gonna be dead.
Outside Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.

Hey, Sheldon? Listen, Penny is pretty sick and she‰Ûªs not going to be able to go to Switzerland. So if you‰Ûªre still interested, you‰Ûªre welcome to come. (Sound of Sheldon vomiting in the bathroom)
Great. I‰Ûªll start packing. In a minute. (Vomits again) Oh, look, it‰Ûªs the cholermus.
The apartment.
Here‰Ûªs your soup.
Chicken?
Yes.
With the little stars?
Yes.
Heated to 180 degrees?
Why don‰Ûªt I pour it in your lap, and you can tell me.
You don‰Ûªt have to be mean. I‰Ûªm sick.
Yeah, well, I‰Ûªm sick, too.
Not my problem. I just don‰Ûªt understand how this happened to me. I‰Ûªm scrupulous about my hygiene. I regularly disinfect my hands, and I avoid contact with other people on general principle.
I don‰Ûªt know what to tell you, Sheldon.
It‰Ûªs you! I touched you!
Happy Valentine‰Ûªs Day.
A Swiss hotel room.
Oh, my goodness, look at this room! Champagne! Roses! Oh, and little chocolates! This is going to be the best Valentine‰Ûªs Day ever.
Yeah, I forgot about all this.
But I never will.
The comic book store. Raj enters carrying an iPod with a speaker on his tee shirt. As he enters the shop he starts the iPod and the Darth Vader theme from Star Wars emerges from the speaker.
Will you please turn your shirt off?
What? I‰Ûªm giving myself dramatic entrance music. People will know I‰Ûªm awesome and to be feared.
Yeah, right, there‰Ûªs nothing more awesome and frightening than a man who‰Ûªs got music blasting from between his nipples.
Hey, Stuart, what‰Ûªs going on?
Well, you might want to mark your Google calendars. Stan Lee is coming to do a signing on Thursday.
Did he finally write a sequel to his autobiography? I‰Ûªm sure ages 79 through 87 were just action-packed.
No, just a regular comic signing. My uncle is his dermatologist and Stan‰Ûªs doing him a favour.

Oh, I don‰Ûªt want to know that! How can I possibly discuss with Stan Lee the scientific foundations for interstellar flight on a silver surfboard when part of my brain will be scanning his face for signs of contagious skin disease?
Stan Lee does not have a contagious skin disease.
Well, look who thinks he‰Ûªs Stuart‰Ûªs uncle now.
Can‰Ûªt believe it. We‰Ûªre going to meet Stan Lee! (Presses play on his iPod. His shirt starts to play ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm So Excited‰Û by the Pointer Sisters. He dances.)
I‰Ûªm sad to say I taught him those moves.
The apartment.

I can‰Ûªt decide whether I want Stan Lee to autograph my Journey into Mystery 83, first appearance of Thor or my Fantastic Four number five, first appearance of Dr. Doom. (Raj presses his iPod. The theme from Jeopardy plays.) Alex, I‰Ûªm going to go with what is‰Û_ you‰Ûªre a dumbass? (Presses again, his shirt blows a raspberry.)
I‰Ûªve decided I‰Ûªm going to have Mr. Lee sign my copy of this month‰Ûªs Batman.
That‰Ûªs crazy. Stan Lee had nothing to do with Batman.
Yes, which is why no one else will ask him to sign one, and I will be the possessor of a unique, albeit confusing, artifact, which will set me apart from the hoi polloi of comic book fandom.
That‰Ûªs a great idea, I‰Ûªm going to get him to sign a Batman as well.
What is it about the word unique you don‰Ûªt understand?
Ow! Damn, paper cut. Nothing worse than a paper cut.
Well, obviously you don‰Ûªt remember your circumcision.
There‰Ûªs Neosporin and Band-Aids in my top desk drawer.
Why don‰Ûªt you keep that stuff in the bathroom?
He does. And in the kitchen. And in the car. And in his pocket.
Yeah, but the ones in my pocket are mine.
Hi!
Hey. Guess who‰Ûªs going to be at the comic bookstore on Thursday?
Um, can you give me a hint?
Stan Lee.
Um, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley Tucci?
No, no, Stan Lee.
Oh, oh, Stan Lee! Cool!
You have no idea who he is, do you?
Of course I do. You‰Ûªre an important part of my life and I pay attention to the things you are interested in.
Good, good, so, who‰Ûªs Stan Lee?
Um, he was on Star Trek.
Nope.
Star Wars?
No.
Um, uh, Stan Lee, oh, he was in those goofy kung fu movies you love so much?
That‰Ûªs Bruce Lee.
Oh. So, is this Bruce Lee‰Ûªs nerdy brother, Stan?
Sheldon, why do you have all these unopened paychecks in your desk?
Because most of the things I‰Ûªm planning to buy haven‰Ûªt been invented yet.
But there must be thousands of dollars here. Why don‰Ûªt you put it in the bank?
I don‰Ûªt trust banks. I believe that when the robots rise up, ATMs will lead the charge.
You‰Ûªve also got something from the Pasadena Municipal Court.

Undoubtedly yet another snide response to my repeated letters complaining that the flags in front of the courthouse are flying in the wrong order. From left to right, it‰Ûªs supposed to be federal, state, and then city of Pasadena.
I‰Ûªm sorry. You sent more than one letter about that?
It bothers me.
Sheldon, this is a summons.
A summons for what?
November 16? Penny, that‰Ûªs the evening you fell in your bathtub and I had to drive you to the emergency room.
No, it isn‰Ûªt.
Yes, it is.
No, it isn‰Ûªt.
Penny, I have an eidetic memory. Also, that‰Ûªs a picture of you in the passenger seat holding your dislocated shoulder.
Mmm, no, it isn‰Ûªt.
Okay, then why is a summons for a traffic violation committed in your car, bearing your license plates, coming to me?
Okay, look, they sent me the ticket. I told them I wasn‰Ûªt driving and they were all, if it wasn‰Ûªt you, who was it?
So you betrayed me?
No! It wasn‰Ûªt a betrayal. It was more of a can‰Ûªt afford any more points on my license. I already have to buy my insurance from this place in the Cayman Islands.
But the only reason I was driving your car was because you were in distress and I was rescuing you.
Yes, yes, look, and now you have a photo to remember that heroic day.
It‰Ûªs not that big a deal. You just go down to the court on Thursday and you pay the fine.
I‰Ûªm not going to pay a fine. That would imply I‰Ûªm guilty.
You are guilty. (Raj‰Ûªs shirt plays the gavel sound from Law & Order) That one I liked.
I am not guilty. I only have a learner‰Ûªs permit, Penny was the teacher. When the light turned yellow she said go, go, go, so I went, went, went.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm sorry. I‰Ûªll be happy to reimburse you for the fine. You know, as soon as I get a part in a movie or my own TV series.
You don‰Ûªt need to reimburse me because I‰Ûªm not paying. On Thursday, I will have my day in court and justice will be done. In fact, I‰Ûªm going to begin preparing my defence right now.
Okay, he‰Ûªs going to jail.
Oh, that‰Ûªs right. Thursday is Stan Lee Day.
Now you see what you‰Ûªve done? Because of you, we‰Ûªre all going to miss Stan Lee.
Whoa! What do you mean all?

Well, you‰Ûªre my friends. You‰Ûªll be standing by my side, supporting me, feeding me legal precedents, and if you had the upper body strength, carrying me out on your shoulders when I‰Ûªm victorious.
Yeah, okay. No.
Are you saying that you will not stand beside me as I plead my case?
That‰Ûªs what I‰Ûªm saying.
Howard?
Wow. Uh, Stan Lee, or you in court? Uh, if this was Sophie‰Ûªs Choice it would‰Ûªve been a much shorter movie. No.
Raj? You‰Ûªll be there, won‰Ûªt you? (Shirt plays ‰ÛÏincorrect‰Û quiz sound) All right, then, my so-called friends have forsaken me. So, I guess it‰Ûªll just be me and my eyewitness.
Oh, balls.
Please try to wear something appropriate. It won‰Ûªt help my case if the judge is busy trying to read the word Juicy scrawled across your buttocks.
Penny‰Ûªs door.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
That‰Ûªs just wrong.
All right, let‰Ûªs go.
Wait, hold on. Before we get to the courthouse, I‰Ûªd like to call on your skills as an actress.
What is this?

I‰Ûªve taken the liberty of scripting your appearance on the witness stand because, let‰Ûªs face it, you‰Ûªre somewhat of a loose cannon. Now, don‰Ûªt worry, it‰Ûªs written in your vernacular. So shall we rehearse?
Do I have a choice?

Well, of course you have a choice. Although we live in a deterministic universe, each individual has free will. Now, sit down. I call your attention to the events of November 16. Do you remember that date?
Darn tootin‰Ûª, I do, if the court will excuse my homespun, corn-fed Nebraskan turn of phrase.
Excellent. Go on.
The reason that date is, like, so totally fixed in my memory is that I had the privilege to be witness to one of the most heroic acts I‰Ûªve ever seen in, like, ever.
And who performed that heroic act?
Why, you did, sir. You. Dr. Sheldon Cooper, and may I add, it is a privilege to know you.
There‰Ûªs no need for compliments, this court is only interested in the facts.
But it is a fact that it‰Ûªs a privilege to know you. Totally. A teardrop rolls down my cheek?
Only a suggestion. A catch in your throat would work just as well.

character: Penny (pretending to be close to tears)
line: But it is a fact that it‰Ûªs a privilege to know you. Totally.
Maybe you should put on your Juicy pants again.
The courtroom.
Pay the cashier. Sheldon Cooper?
Good morning, Your Honour. Dr. Sheldon Cooper appearing in pro se. That is to say, representing himself.
I know what it means. I went to law school.
And yet you wound up in traffic court. Anyway, if it would please the court, I‰Ûªd like to begin with an opening statement.
The court would advise you to make it quick, as the court had a dicey-looking breakfast burrito this morning and just took an Imodium.

Very well, a quick opening statement. Like a milking stool, my case rests on three legs. I will demonstrate that I was improperly instructed in driving by a woman whose lack of respect for society borders on the sociopathic. I will argue that the emergency met the legal doctrine of quod est necessarium est licitum, that which is necessary is legal. But first, I will raise a Sixth Amendment issue. I‰Ûªm unable to confront my accuser, a non-human entity, to wit, a camera. So, to sum up, improper instruction, quod est necessarium est licitum, Sixth Amendment. My milk stool is complete.
Impressive.
Thank you.
Guilty. Pay the cashier.
I object. You‰Ûªre completely ignoring the law.
No, I‰Ûªm following the law. I‰Ûªm ignoring you.
Really? I would point out that I am at the top of my profession, while you preside over the kiddy table of yours.
Dr. Cooper, before I find you in contempt and throw you in jail, I‰Ûªm going to give you a chance to apologize for that last remark.
I am a scientist. I never apologize for the truth.
A police cell. Three people sit on a bench inside. Sheldon points at the one on the end.
That‰Ûªs my spot.
A queue outside the comic book store.
I can‰Ûªt wait to ask Stan Lee why he insists on giving all his characters first and last names that start with the same letter.
Oh, come on, why would you do that?
Bruce Banner, Reed Richards, Sue Storm, Stephen Strange, Otto Octavius, Silver Surfer, Peter Parker, oh, and worst of all, J. Jonah Jameson, Jr.
Okay, I‰Ûªm cutting. I‰Ûªm not gonna talk to Stan Lee after you cheese him off.
Hey.
Sheldon‰Ûªs in jail.
Sheldon‰Ûªs in jail?
You called it.
For what?
What do you think? For doing the same crap he always does, except to a judge. He has to stay in there until he apologizes.
So tell him to apologize.
Oh, gee, thanks, Leonard. That didn‰Ûªt occur to me. If he doesn‰Ûªt apologize by 5 o‰Ûªclock he is going to spend the night in jail.
Oh, no, that‰Ûªs terrible. Ooh, the line‰Ûªs moving. Got to go. Bye.
The police cell.
Excuse me? Excuse me, jailor?
What?
I need to use the restroom.
Knock yourself out. (Points to urinal in cell)
That‰Ûªs the toilet?
Well, it ain‰Ûªt a wishing well.
Please tell the judge I‰Ûªm ready to apologize.
The apartment.
Look at that. To my friend, Leonard, from Stan Lee, Excelsior!
Awesome. Mine says, To my friend, Howard, from Stan Lee, Excelsior!
Mine says, To Raj, from Stan Lee.
That‰Ûªs ‰Ûªcause you pissed him off about his character names.
Hey, I didn‰Ûªt even mention Dum Dum Dugan or Green Goblin, Matt Murdock, Pepper Potts, Victor Von Doom, oh, and worst of all, Millie the Model.
We‰Ûªre home.
Oh, hey, buddy. How‰Ûªd it go?
You know very well how it went.
Yeah, but we all want to hear it from you.
I was found guilty and fined $533.
I‰Ûªm going to write you a cheque for that. As long as you promise to put it in your drawer and never cash it, like the others.

I also now have three points on a driver‰Ûªs licence I do not yet possess, and I was forced to issue an undeserved apology, simply because I refuse to urinate in a stainless steel bowl in front of criminals.
Plus, you didn‰Ûªt get to meet Stan Lee.
Okay, that‰Ûªs enough, Howard. The poor guy‰Ûªs had a tough time. He had to spend the entire afternoon in jail wearing that suit.
You‰Ûªre right, so it would be cruel to mention that after he finished signing autographs, Stan Lee took Stuart and us out for gelato.
You had gelato with Stan Lee?
He said we could call him Stan.
Except for Raj.
Well, I hope you‰Ûªre satisfied, Penny. You are responsible for all the evil that has befallen me today.
Okay, I realize that‰Û_
Not finished. It is because of you that I now have a criminal record, and it is because of you that I missed out on having gelato with Stan Lee.
Okay, maybe you‰Ûªll have another chance to have‰Û_

No, no. I will never have another chance to have gelato with Stan Lee because opportunities to have gelato with Stan Lee come but once in a lifetime. The moving finger writes, and having writ, moves on!
Did he just somehow give me the finger?
Not just the finger. The moving finger.
The comic book store.
Hey, Stuart.
Oh, hey, Penny. Wow. Hi.

Nothing. I‰Ûªm just getting ready to close up and head out.
Ah. Cool. Got any fun plans?
Oh, yeah. Big night tonight. Gonna share a can of tuna with the cat.
Oh, nice.
Not even my cat. I just feed it. Some nights it doesn‰Ûªt even show up.
Oh, okay. Well, I was hoping, um, you could do me a favour.
Sure, yeah, name it.
Well, I‰Ûªm kind of responsible for Sheldon missing Stan Lee, and I really want to make it up to him. So I was hoping you could give me his phone number so maybe I can arrange for them to meet.
Oh, I‰Ûªm sorry, I don‰Ûªt have his phone number.
Hmm. Damn. All right. Thank you.
Mm-hmm. Wait. I have his address.
Really? Great!

Then why did you tell me you had it?
I don‰Ûªt know. Just chatting. You‰Ûªre looking at a guy who could very well get stood up by a stray cat tonight.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Stuart. Thanks anyway.

Yeah?
