What kind of deal?
I will give you the address if you go to my cousin‰Ûªs wedding with me.
You‰Ûªre extorting a date out of me?
I kind of have to. The cousin who‰Ûªs getting married is the cousin I usually go to weddings with.
Can I bring Leonard?
Sure. What the hell.
Deal.
We‰Ûªll tell people he‰Ûªs your cousin.
Outside Stan Lee‰Ûªs house.
This is Stan Lee‰Ûªs front door. We were on Stan Lee‰Ûªs curb, then we were on Stan Lee‰Ûªs walk, and now we‰Ûªre at Stan Lee‰Ûªs front door.
Yup.
Oh, Lord, you just rang Stan Lee‰Ûªs doorbell. At Stan Lee‰Ûªs house. We‰Ûªre about to go in and have milk and cookies with Stan Lee.
Okay, sweetie, I don‰Ûªt know if we‰Ûªre gonna have cookies, or he‰Ûªs just gonna say hi, or really what‰Ûªs gonna happen, so just let me talk, and we‰Ûªll‰Û_
Yeah?
Are you Stan Lee?
Oh, damn.
Hi. I‰Ûªm Penny. This is my friend, Sheldon.
We‰Ûªre not friends at the moment. Depends on how this goes.
Right, right. Anyway, Sheldon here is a huge fan of yours, and he was supposed to meet you the other day at the comic book store, but he kind of ended up in jail.
I see. And you thought you‰Ûªd just come over to my house uninvited?
You said we were invited.
Oh, no, no, I said I‰Ûªm inviting you to come with me to Stan Lee‰Ûªs house.
You know, you fan boys are unbelievable. Do you think you can just ring my doorbell any time you want? I mean, why don‰Ûªt you just come on in and watch the Lakers game with me?
Well, I‰Ûªm not much of a sports fan, but thank you.
I‰Ûªm sorry. He doesn‰Ûªt really understand sarcasm.
Well, I‰Ûªll give him something he‰Ûªll understand. Joanie, call the police!
Nice to meet you.
The apartment.
Fantastic Four, Daredevil, Invincible Iron Man, Happy Hogan, Curt Connors‰Û_
Would you just let it go?
And worst of all, Fin Fang Foom.
Hey, where‰Ûªve you been?

I‰Ûªll tell you where I‰Ûªve been. You boys may have had gelato with Stan Lee and gotten autographed comics, but I saw the inside of his house and got an autographed application for a restraining order.
Sweet.
Plus, I get to hang out with him again at the hearing. This is going to look great hanging next to my restraining order from Leonard Nimoy.
The stairwell. Leonard is carrying a large box.
Why do I always have to carry the heavy stuff?

Well, it‰Ûªs very simple. In our ragtag band of scientists with nothing to lose, I‰Ûªm the smart one, Wolowitz is the funny one, and Koothrappali is the lovable foreigner who struggles to understand our ways and fails. That leaves you, by default, as the muscle.
One more floor, and I‰Ûªd be the pulled muscle.
Oh, it‰Ûªs about time, I‰Ûªm starving.
Uh, well, we didn‰Ûªt actually get Chinese food.
Why not?
Don‰Ûªt panic, this is better.
Oh, no, you didn‰Ûªt trade the food for magic beans, did you?

Of course not. And, technically, magic beans would be food, although eating them would be quite a waste, since you could plant them and overnight have a giant beanstalk, which would provide enough roughage for a small city.
Yeah, sometimes I don‰Ûªt listen, sometimes I just watch your jaw go up and down.
We were on our way to the Chinese restaurant when we thought we saw Adam West, so we followed him.
Who‰Ûªs Adam West?
Who‰Ûªs Adam West? Leonard, what do the two of you talk about after the coitus?
My guess is, ‰ÛÏHey, four minutes! New record!‰Û That‰Ûªs why I‰Ûªm the funny one.
Anyway, we followed the guy to this garage sale, and they had the coolest stuff.
They were closing up. We got this whole box for sixty bucks.
We didn‰Ûªt even get to go through it all. There could be anything in here.
There a new girlfriend in there? ‰Û÷Cause you might need one.
No. But there is an original final draft Ghostbusters script with actual slime stains! (Raj whispers to Leonard) Oh, you‰Ûªre right, it‰Ûªs Ghostbusters 2. Never mind.

Oh, my God. An Alf doll. When I was 11 my mother got me one to help me sleep after my dad left. I used to pretend that my dad had moved to the planet Melmac, and Alf was going to bring him back to me. But he never did. Where‰Ûªs my daddy, puppet? Where is he?
That is so sad.
No, what‰Ûªs sad is that you don‰Ûªt know Adam West was TV‰Ûªs Batman.
The same
Here‰Ûªs Spock‰Ûªs head with no body. Here‰Ûªs Mr. T‰Ûªs body with no head. Oh, yeah, here‰Ûªs Spock‰Ûªs body with Mr. T‰Ûªs head. I pity the fool who‰Ûªs illogical.
Okay, I‰Ûªm just gonna go home and make a grilled cheese and window-shop on eHarmony.
Okay, bye.
Okay.
Ooh, look, an Indiana Jones connect-the-dots.
And an Aquaman action figure.
Looks like someone drew a penis on him.
Huh? That‰Ûªll come off.
You see what you‰Ûªre doing? Stop that.
Fascinating.
What?
It appears to be a Lord of the Rings ring.
Oh.
It‰Ûªs even got the Elvish engraving on it.
It‰Ûªs not Elvish. It‰Ûªs the language of Mordor written in Elvish script. One Ring to
One Ring to find them.
One Ring to bring them all.
And in the darkness bind them.
Holy crap, are we nerdy.
The Cheesecake Factory
So, I was doing some checking on the ring.
Hold on. Sheldon, is there ketchup on that table?

Yes, there is. Oh, here‰Ûªs a fun fact, ketchup started out as a general term for sauce, typically made of, uh, mushrooms or fish brine with herbs and spices. Some popular early main ingredients included blueberry, anchovy, oyster, kidney bean and grape.
No, that‰Ûªs okay. I‰Ûªll get it.

Listen, I was looking at the ring, and it seemed a little weird. No copyright notice on it. So, I took it down to this buddy of mine who deals with, shall we say, the seedy underbelly of the collectibles world.
Seedy underbelly?
You know, your black market phasers, your screen-worn Lieutenant Uhura panties, that kind of stuff.
Who‰Ûªs this mysterious buddy you suddenly have?
Just a guy. I know a guy.
Is it Eddie Crispo?
No, I can‰Ûªt tell you who it is. Stop asking.
Who else could it be? It has to be Eddie Crispo.
I know lots of dangerous people, okay?
Name one.
Eddie Crispo. Anyway, he said this isn‰Ûªt a replica. It‰Ûªs the real deal.
If you‰Ûªre suggesting that that is the actual ring of power forged by Sauron in Mount Doom, I look at you with an expression of exhaustion and ever so slight amusement.
He‰Ûªs not saying it‰Ûªs a magic ring. You‰Ûªre not, are you?

No, but it‰Ûªs close. Look at the markings inside. Those are production markings. Nine rings were made for use in the Lord of the Rings movies. Three were given to members of the cast. The rest were destroyed. Except one. One was stolen. Gentlemen, this is the one ring.
Mine!
No, it is not yours. We all went in on the box together.
Well, yes, but I found it in the box, and the laws of maritime salvage clearly state that the finder of a sunken treasure is the owner of the treasure.
How is this maritime salvage?
Other than the lack of water, how is it not?
Wait, wait. Sheldon, stop being crazy for a second. How much is something like this worth?
Well, it‰Ûªs tough to say since it‰Ûªs hot, but on the underground market, my guy figures‰Û_
Your guy Eddie Crispo?
Yes. He figures ten, maybe 15 thousand.
Okay, that‰Ûªs a lot of money. The wise thing to do is invest it in something practical. Like a jet ski.
Why do you want a jet ski?
All the wealthy and beautiful people in movies ride Jet Skis. That can‰Ûªt just be a coincidence.
We can‰Ûªt sell it. We have to keep it and love it and polish it, and only take it out occasionally when we go to the park and re-enact our favourite scenes from the movies.
It‰Ûªs sad how great that sounds.
Guys, it‰Ûªs stolen. It should go back to Peter Jackson. He made the movies, it belongs to him.
Fine. He can have it back as long as he promises to make me a hobbit in his next movie.
There are no Jewish hobbits.
Clearly, you‰Ûªve never been to my house for dinner on Rosh Hashanah.
We are not blackmailing Peter J‰Û_ All right, where‰Ûªs the ring?
You mean my ring?
What are you doing?
The ring was unguarded, it was just sitting on the table, anyone could have taken it. Proof? I did.
Give me that.
Look, let‰Ûªs be reasonable. We all want to do different things with the ring, but your ideas are stupid, and I want a jet ski.
I found it. The ring is mine. I don‰Ûªt understand why in this group I never get my way.
You always get your way.
I‰Ûªll stipulate to that if you give me the ring.
Hey, guys. Enjoying your food that I actually brought you instead of promising food, but bringing you a box of random crap?
Yeah, it‰Ûªs delicious, the sarcasm‰Ûªs a little stale, though. Hey, how about this? Until we figure out what to do with the ring, Penny holds on to it.
What ring?
This ring.
Looking for something?
Will you hold on to this for a couple of days?
Why?
It‰Ûªs a prop from a movie, and we‰Ûªre kind of fighting over it.
Okay, just to be clear, the first piece of jewellery my boyfriend gives me is a prop from a movie, and I don‰Ûªt even get to keep it?
If you had gone out with me three years ago, by now, you‰Ûªd have my great Aunt Ida‰Ûªs brooch that she smuggled out of occupied Belgium in a cat.
How am I looking now?

Penny and Leonard are asleep in Leonard‰Ûªs bed. Sheldon creeps in and tries to take the ring from round Penny‰Ûªs neck, but she turns over. He tries to make buzzing fly noises to get her to turn back, but she turns all the way the other way. He then uses an extender with a claw on the end to lif the ring from Penny‰Ûªs chest. As he tries to remove it, she wakes up, screams, and punches him in the face.
Ow! You hit me! I‰Ûªm bleeding!
What was that?
Sheldon tried to take the ring and I punched him.
That‰Ûªs my girl.
The cafeteria.
So, Sheldon, how‰Ûªs it feel to get beaten up by a girl?

åÊ It‰Ûªs not the first time. I have a twin sister whose assaults began in utero. If only I‰Ûªd had the presence of mind to reabsorb her, then I‰Ûªd have a mole with hair in it instead of a tedious yearly Christmas letter.
Gentlemen, have you come to the realization that the only reasonable course of action is to sell the ring and divide the money?
No.
I was afraid of that. (Opens his laptop to reveal an Indian looking man on a webcam.) Go ahead.
Greetings from Mumbai. I am Raj‰Ûªs attorney, Venkatesh Koothrappali.
Also my cousin.
You brought a lawyer?
Don‰Ûªt answer that. I‰Ûªll get straight to the point. My client‰Ûªs prepared to surrender any interest he has in the ring in exchange for two Kawasaki Jet Skis.
We‰Ûªre not giving him two Jet Skis.
Look, we‰Ûªre big boys, why don‰Ûªt we just cut to the chase and meet in the middle? One Kawasaki Jet Ski, done and done.
No Jet Skis.
All right, forget the Jet Skis.
Forget the Jet Skis? That was our line in the sand! What happened to ‰ÛÏtear them a new one?‰Û
What can I say? They played hardball. We lost.
You‰Ûªre useless.
I told you that when you hired me.
I‰Ûªm signing off now.
Call your mother, she worries.
Okay, just so you know, if we‰Ûªre bringing in cousins who are lawyers, prepare for shock and awe.
You know what? I am ending this. Penny didn‰Ûªt want to hold the ring anymore. She gave it to me, I have it. I‰Ûªm sending it back. Where‰Ûªs the ring?
You mean this ring? Next time be aware of your surroundings while urinating in a public men‰Ûªs room.
Give me that.
No, it‰Ûªs mine.
It‰Ûªs all of ours. (They begin to struggle over the ring.)
Okay, now, this is ridiculous!
Then let go!
I‰Ûªm not letting go, you let go.
I say this ring belongs to the last person who can hold on.
Fine. But can‰Ûªt we go home and start this?
Sure. Let go of the ring.
All right, it starts now.
You do realize there‰Ûªs a giant bug movie marathon tonight on the Syfy Channel. (They start to move away from the table while all still holding the ring.)
Wait, my laptop. (They go back for it.)
The stairwell. The guys are coming up the stairs, all still holding the ring.
You know, there‰Ûªs a point when this becomes idiotic.
And it wasn‰Ûªt when we were driving like this?

I would advise the three of you that resistance is futile. I have endless patience. I once spent two-and-a-half hours on hold with Hewlett-Packard customer service just to complain about their customer service.
You want to talk about endless patience? Penny made me watch all five seasons of Sex and the City.
There are six seasons, dude.
Oh, crap!
No, no, no, the sixth season is great. We go to Paris with Carrie and get our heart broken, and then Mr. Big shows up, we don‰Ûªt know if we can trust him again. It‰Ûªs a wild ride.
Door. (Leonard tries to unlock the door and drops the keys.)
Okay, everybody, and plie. And relevae.
Whatcha doin‰Ûª?
Last one holding the ring decides its fate. I know, it sounds silly.
No, no, no, no, no, no, you are my boyfriend. Nothing you do is silly to me.
Thank you.
FYI, this is a bag from Victoria‰Ûªs Secret.
I‰Ûªm out.
The apartment. The three guys are still holding the ring. Howard is on the phone.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Ma, I have to stay late at the office.
No, he‰Ûªs doesn‰Ûªt! He‰Ûªs lying to you!
Will you be quiet?
Well, if you want privacy let go of the ring. I‰Ûªm so glad we came to this gentile strip club! Howard, here‰Ûªs more bacon to tuck into the shiksa‰Ûªs G-string!
I‰Ûªll call you back.

I think it‰Ûªs lovely you call your mommy and let her know you‰Ûªre going to be late for dinner. From what I know about these things, if a woman doesn‰Ûªt breast-feed on time, it‰Ûªs very uncomfortable for her boobies.
Don‰Ûªt you talk about my mother‰Ûªs boobies!
If you‰Ûªre offended, let go of the ring and go on home to your mother‰Ûªs boobies.
Excellent, excellent. Tire each other out, the ring will be mine. Howard, why don‰Ûªt you go after Raj‰Ûªs mother?
Why don‰Ûªt we go after your mother?

Go ahead. I have no illusions about my mother. She is a kind, loving, religiously fanatical right-wing Texan with a slightly out-of-scale head and a mild Dr. Pepper addiction. Anything you‰Ûªd like to add?
That‰Ûªs not gonna Better pull out the big gun.
You‰Ûªre right. Let‰Ûªs talk about your grandmother.
No! I call no Meemaws.
Think about this. The only way your mother was born was your Meemaw had sex.
I don‰Ûªt want to hear this.
Then let go of the ring and walk away.
Never.
All right. I‰Ûªll bet your Meemaw didn‰Ûªt just have sex to have your mother. I bet she had sex because she liked it.
Stop it!
Yeah, Meemaw did the nasty.
I said stop it!
We‰Ûªre getting to him.
Waterfalls!
What?
Waterfalls. Crashing waves. Babbling brooks.
What are you doing?
Subliminal messaging. I‰Ûªm going to make you want to pee. Dripping faucets. Leaky gutter. Peeing.
It‰Ûªs, it‰Ûªs not working, dude.
Oh-ho-ho, it‰Ûªs working all right. I have to pee.
Then let go of the ring and go.
No, actually, I wouldn‰Ûªt mind going, too.
Fine. Um, on the count of three. One, two‰Û_
Wait, just to clarify. When you get to three, do we stand up or do we pee?
We stand up.
Excellent choice.
Three.
Something tells me this was a bad day to wear suede shoes.

Sometime later. The guys are on the settee. Howard is seen asleep, he is not holding the ring. The camera pans along to where Sheldon and Raj still hold the ring. Raj, also asleep, lets go and cuddles up to Howard.

I‰Ûªve done it! I‰Ûªve won! The ring is mine! It‰Ûªs mine! (He runs to the bathroom) We‰Ûªre going to clean it up and make it pretty. My own. My love. My precious. (He looks in the mirror and has turned into golem. He screams and wakes up, still on the settee.) Where‰Ûªs the ring?
It‰Ûªs in a FedEx box on its way back to where it came from.
The fires of Mount Doom?
Peter Jackson‰Ûªs office in New Zealand. It wasn‰Ûªt ours.
You quit the game! You had no right to take it.
I came in here, you guys were all sleeping. The ring was on the floor. No one was touching it.
Well, so then we start the game over until there‰Ûªs a winner.

There wasn‰Ûªt ever going to be a winner. There was going to be a selfish, petty person with a ring and three people who used to be his friend. Is that really what you guys want? ‰Û÷Cause if it is, fine, I don‰Ûªt want anything to do with you. And I don‰Ûªt know what happened in that bathroom, but I am not cleaning it up! (Goes to his bedroom. Takes a box from under his bed. Takes out the ring.) My precious.
Leonard and Penny are asleep in Leonard‰Ûªs bed. The extender and claw reaches across and pulls down the sheet revealing the ring on a chain round Leonard‰Ûªs neck.
I knew it. Give us the precious!
NEVER!
Ugh, gotta go back to dating dumb guys from the gym.
The university cafeteria.
Okay in Avatar when they have sex in Pandora they hook up their ponytails, so we know their ponytails are like their junk.
Yeah, so?
So, when they ride horses and fly on the birds, they also use their ponytails.
What‰Ûªs your point?
My point is, if I were a horse or a bird, I‰Ûªd be very nervous around James Cameron.

It amazes me how you constantly obsess over fictional details when there are more important things in the real world to worry about. For example, why wasn‰Ûªt William Shatner in the new Star Trek movie?
Hey, Sheldon, I was up in the administration office, and I happened to overhear the name of the winner of this year‰Ûªs Chancellor‰Ûªs Award for Science.

And you want to rub my nose in the fact that my contributions are being overlooked again? I am the William Shatner of theoretical physics. All right, I‰Ûªll play. What self-important, preening fraud are they honouring this year?
Oh, I‰Ûªm so glad you asked it like that. You.
I won?
You won.

I won! This is astonishing. Not that I won the award, no one deserves it more. Actually, I guess I misspoke. It‰Ûªs not astonishing, more like inevitable. I‰Ûªm not sure what to do first. Maybe I should call my mother. Wait! I know, I‰Ûªm going to conduct an interview with myself and post it online.
Well, good for him.
Yeah, the one thing the William Shatner of theoretical physics needed was an ego boost.
The apartment. The guys are watching Avatar in 3D. All are wearing 3D glasses except Raj.
Didn‰Ûªt it look like that spear was going to go right through your skull?
No.
Hey, you didn‰Ûªt want a Slurpee at 7-Eleven, you don‰Ûªt get glasses.
Oh, that will be another congratulatory call for me. Uh, mute, please.
Uh, hang on, flaming arrow.

Hello? Oh, Chancellor Morton, how are you, sir? Yes, I was expecting your call (aside) three years ago. I see. Wait. What happens if I choose not to give a speech? Uh-huh. And if I don‰Ûªt want to forfeit the award? Well, you‰Ûªve got that tied up in a neat little bow. All right. Thank you. (Hangs up) Problem.
What?
They expect me to give a speech at the banquet. I can‰Ûªt give a speech.
Well, no, you‰Ûªre mistaken. You give speeches all the time. What you can‰Ûªt do is shut up.
Yeah, before the movie, you did 20 minutes on why guacamole turns brown. It turned brown while you were talking.
I am perfectly comfortable speaking to small groups. I cannot speak to large crowds.
What, to you, is a large crowd?
Any group big enough to trample me to death. General rule of thumb is 36 adults or 70 children.
Sheldon, congratulations. Brought you cheesecake from work. You know, ‰Ûªcause of your award, not because a busboy sneezed on it.
I‰Ûªm not accepting the award.
Why not?
Turns out the great Sheldon Cooper has stage fright.

That‰Ûªs no reason to back out. You know, I once got a pretty big honour in high school, and I was terrified about appearing in front of a big crowd, but I went through with it, and you know what? The world looked pretty darn good sitting on a haystack in the back of a Ford F-150 as a member of the Corn Queen‰Ûªs court.
Thank you. Yeah, I‰Ûªll bear that in mind if I‰Ûªm ever nominated for the Hillbilly Peace Prize.
Sheldon, you‰Ûªre being ridiculous.
Am I? Let me tell you a story.
Where‰Ûªs 70 children when you need ‰Û÷em?
I was 14 and graduating summa cum laude from college. Summa cum laude is Latin for with highest honours.
I just love how you always skip over the part where no one asks.

I was valedictorian and expected to give an address. Even now, I can remember that moment when I walked up to the podium and looked out at the crowd. There must have been thousands of people. My heart started pounding in my chest. I began to hyperventilate. My vision became blurry, and before I knew it‰Û_ oh, dear. (He faints.)
Oh, my God.
Sheldon? Sheldon, are you okay?
Don‰Ûªt trample me.
The stairwell. Sheldon is on the phone.

Come on, Mother, you know why I can‰Ûªt accept the award. With all due respect, I don‰Ûªt think praying will help. No, I have not heard the song, Jesus, Take the Wheel. No, no, no, no, no, no, no, you don‰Ûªt need to start singing it. Yes, I‰Ûªll buy it on the iTunes, Mother. Good-bye, Mother. (Enters apartment. The others are sitting as if waiting for him.) Hello.
Sit down, we want to talk to you.
Am I in trouble? Did my mother call you?
Just sit.
We think we can help you with your stage fright.
Oh, I doubt that. I haven‰Ûªt figured out a way, and I‰Ûªm much smarter than all of you.
Yes, but you‰Ûªre not smarter than all of us put together.
Oh, I‰Ûªm sorry, that is what I meant.
Okay, your problem is, you‰Ûªre trying to do this all by yourself.
We can help you. We can be your team. Like, uh, Professor Xavier and his X-Men.
I do like the X-Men.
Did I see X-Men?
Yeah, we watched it last week. You said you liked it.
Oh. I say a lot of things, sweetie. So, how about it, Sheldon?
I don‰Ûªt know. If you‰Ûªre my X-Men, what are your powers?
Okay. Well, I am going to take you shopping, get you a nice suit. Might give you more confidence.
That‰Ûªs not exactly a mutation that would get you into Xavier‰Ûªs School for Gifted Youngsters, but go on. Leonard?
I thought I could try to analyze you and get to the root of your anxiety.
What qualifies you to attempt to understand my mind?
My mother is a highly regarded psychiatrist, and I‰Ûªve been in therapy ever since she accused me of breast-feeding co-dependently.
Raj says he can teach you, what did you call it? I don‰Ûªt know, some Indian meditation crap.
I see. Well, I assume, since the rest of you have set the bar so low, you‰Ûªre saving the most impressive contribution for last. Go ahead, Howard. Dazzle me.
My power is the ability to pretend like I give a damn about your piddly-ass problems. And that‰Ûªs 24-7, buddy.
And I appreciate the pretence.
So, what do you say, Sheldon? Are we your X-Men?
No. The X-Men were named for the X in Charles Xavier. Since I am Sheldon Cooper, you will be my C-Men.
Oh, that‰Ûªs not a good name.
The apartment. Raj is lighting candles. Indian music is playing.
Okay, Sheldon. I‰Ûªm going to be leading you through a series of meditation exercises. These methods come from the ancient gurus of India and have helped me overcome my own fears.
And yet, you can‰Ûªt speak to women.
True, but thanks to meditation, I am able to stay in the same room with them without urinating. Now, close your eyes.
Okay, but don‰Ûªt punch me.
What?
When I was little, my sister would say to me, close your eyes, you‰Ûªll get a surprise, and then she‰Ûªd punch me.
I‰Ûªm not going to punch you.
That‰Ûªs what my sister used to say.
Do you want to do this or not?
I‰Ûªm sorry. Proceed.
All right. Imagine yourself in the one place you feel most at home. Where is that?
Sim City. More specifically, the Sim City I designed, Sheldonopolis.
Okay, you‰Ûªre in Sheldonopolis.
Where exactly? Sheldon Square? Sheldon Towers? Sheldon Stadium, home of the Fighting Sheldons?
Whatever you like.
I thought this was supposed to be a guided meditation.
Fine. You‰Ûªre in Sheldon Square.
Really? This time of year? It‰Ûªs a bit nippy.
Then, put on a sweater.
Suppose I could run downtown and pick up something at Shel-Mart.
Yeah, whatever. Just go buy a sweater.
You know, the nice thing about Shel-Mart is I own it, so I get a 15% discount.
You own the damn thing. Just take a freaking sweater!
Look, I didn‰Ûªt turn a profit last quarter by taking product off the shelves willy-nilly.
All right. You‰Ûªve paid for a sweater, and you‰Ûªre in Sheldon Square.
Hang on. It‰Ûªs a cardigan. I have to button it. Oh, no.
What now?

A Godzilla-like monster is approaching the city. I have to get my people to safety. People of Sheldonopolis, this is your mayor. Follow me. If the children can‰Ûªt run, leave them behind. Oh, the simulated horror! (Sound of door slamming) Raj? Just as I suspected. Meditation is nothing but hokum.
A clothing store.
I question your premise. How is a new suit going to prevent me from passing out in front of a ballroom full of people?
It‰Ûªll give you confidence. You know, sometimes when I‰Ûªm feeling all stressed out about something, I go out and buy a cute top or a fun skirt and I have a whole new outlook on life.
Don‰Ûªt you eventually realize you‰Ûªre just the same stressed out person in a cute top or a fun skirt?
Yeah, that‰Ûªs when I buy shoes. Now, let‰Ûªs see what we‰Ûªve got. Ooh! This is nice.
It‰Ûªs only one colour.
Yeah, so?
That‰Ûªs a lot of money for only one colour.
Fine. Why don‰Ûªt you pick out what you like.
Hmm. (Cut to Sheldon exiting changing room in a loud check suit). This is pretty sharp.
No, you‰Ûªre wrong.

character: Sheldon (now in a sparkly green suit with rhinestones)
line: This is great. I had a suit like this when I was six. (Cut to Sheldon exiting in a white dinner suit with tails) Okay, I think we have a winner.
Where the hell d‰Ûªyou find that?
In the prom department.
It‰Ûªs ridiculous.
Says the former member of the Corn Queen‰Ûªs Court.
Please just try this one on.
Okay. But anything I put on now is only going to suffer in comparison. (Goes into changing room. Comes out in black suit looking terrific.) This is absurd. I look like a clown.
The apartment.
So, Sheldon, how you doing?

That‰Ûªs how you start a psychotherapy session? How am I doing? I was promised a riverboat journey into the jungles of my subconscious. Instead, I get the same question I hear from the lady who slices my bologna at Ralph‰Ûªs.
I‰Ûªm sorry, I‰Ûªll start again.
Would it be helpful to you if I told you about my dreams?
Um, I don‰Ûªt know, maybe.
I recently had a dream that I was a giant. But everything around me was to scale, so it all looked normal.
How did you know you were a giant if everything was to scale?
I was wearing size a million pants.
Why don‰Ûªt we just talk?

Ah, the talking cure. Classical Freudian, good choice. If it will help speed things along, uh, my answers to the standard Rorschach ink blot test are A, a bat, B, a bat, C, a bat, and D, my father killing my mother with a hypodermic needle.
Why don‰Ûªt I just start? Sometimes people have trouble accepting accolades if, on a subconscious level, they don‰Ûªt feel they deserve them. Do you think maybe that‰Ûªs what‰Ûªs happening here?

Really, Leonard? You‰Ûªre just going to try to recycle Adler‰Ûªs doctrine of the inferiority complex? I could probably get that from the woman at Ralph‰Ûªs. And she‰Ûªd let me taste some pieces of cheese for free.

But it could be part of your problem. Let me give you an example. And you think my presence will help with that?
Well, I do. Next to you, I‰Ûªll look like a catch.
I‰Ûªm not going out tonight, Raj.
All right. Would you mind if I went to your room and downloaded some Asian pornography?
Very much.
Doesn‰Ûªt have to be Asian.
Don‰Ûªt worry. You‰Ûªll meet a girl someday.
No, I won‰Ûªt.
Yes, you will, and she‰Ûªll be beautiful, and kind and sexy and funny and everything you ever wanted in a woman.
You really think so?
I do, and you‰Ûªll fall hopelessly in love and give her your heart. And she‰Ûªll take it and grind it into pathetic, little pieces.
But we‰Ûªll have sex first, right?
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
Mmm, mmm, mmm. That‰Ûªs Eye-talian.
So, um, was Leonard okay with you coming over?
Oh, yes. In fact, he said, I‰Ûªm fine, I don‰Ûªt care. And he in no way said it in a manner which would lead one to believe that he was covering up feelings of anguish and betrayal.
Well, good.
I‰Ûªm also pleased to report that he‰Ûªs all cried out over you.
He‰Ûªs been crying?
Oh, I believe that was something else I wasn‰Ûªt supposed to mention.
Oh, God, I feel terrible.
Do you have a stomach ache, too?
No. Why, do you?
No.
Why did you ask if I had one, too?
Just making polite dinner conversation. Your turn.
All right. So, what‰Ûªs new in your life?
Well, my new shoes are not made for running.
Have you been running?
No. It‰Ûªs just a suspicion I have. Mmm, mmm, mmm.
I‰Ûªm so glad you like it.
I do. Leonard never cooks for me.
Well, maybe that‰Ûªs ‰Ûªcause Leonard can‰Ûªt cook.
You can‰Ûªt cook and you made me this.
Whatever. Ooh, I‰Ûªm gonna get the cheesecake out of the fridge.
Oh, Lord, I‰Ûªm in Jewish hell.
The apartment.
Look at this. Do you think she‰Ûªs really doing that or is it PhotoShop?
I‰Ûªm pretty sure Martha Stewart never got naked with a room full of big, fat Japanese guys.
You don‰Ûªt know that. Prison changes people.
Hey, where you been?
I told you, walking.
For an hour and a half?
I got lost.
How could you get lost? Your phone has GPS.
Satellites are down. Solar flares.
There are no solar flares right now.
Yes, there are.
Dude, I‰Ûªm an astrophysicist. If there were solar flares, I‰Ûªd be all up in it.
I‰Ûªm sorry. I misspoke. What I meant to say was my battery died.
What the hell was that about?
I don‰Ûªt know. Do you think this is really Hillary Clinton doing it with Oprah?
Oh, we really need to get you a girl.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom. Leonard is asleep.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (knock, knock, knock) Leonard, (knock, knock, knock) Leonard.
Oh, just come in!
Thanks for seeing me on such short notice.
What do you want, Sheldon?
Maybe this isn‰Ûªt a good time.
Tell me why you woke me up or I swear to God I will kill you.
Do you really think death threats are an appropriate way to begin this conversation? Sometimes your lack of social skills astonishes me.
What do you want?
You may want to sit down.
I‰Ûªm in bed!
Point taken. You may want to sit up.
Sheldon!
I‰Ûªve been seeing Penny behind your back.
Okay, when you say seeing Penny, what exactly does that mean?

We had dinner last night. She made me spaghetti with little hot dogs cut up in it. Well, little hot dog. I gave up the other five hot dogs to a real dog. A real, big dog. A hell hound. Tangential to the primary story. How about I circle back to it?
Fine. Why did you have dinner with Penny?
I told you, she made spaghetti with little hot dogs. I like spaghetti with little hot dogs.
Then why did you have Chinese food with us?
I didn‰Ûªt want to upset you. Howard made it very clear that my allegiance should be to male comrades before women who sell their bodies for money.
Is it possible he said Bros before Hos?
Yes, but I rephrased it to avoid offending the hos.
Sheldon, I don‰Ûªt care if you want to be friends with Penny.
Oh. Well, so the emotional turmoil that‰Ûªs been keeping me from achieving REM sleep was entirely unjustified?
Yes.
Well then as my meemaw would say, looks like we butchered a pig, but nobody wanted bacon.
I guess not.
And now, as promised, the tangent. Sheldon and the Hell Hound, or How I Lost My Hot Dogs.
The laundry room.
Oh, um, I, I can come back.
D-don‰Ûªt be silly. We‰Ûªre neighbours, we‰Ûªre going to run into each other, may as well get used to it.
Yeah, I guess you‰Ûªre right.
You used to it yet?
Nope.
Me neither. Oh, Sheldon seemed think that I would be upset about you hanging out with him. But I just want you to know it‰Ûªs fine.
Oh, oh, good, because, um, his mother called me.
His mother?
Yeah, she wants me to take him shopping for sheets and towels.
I was going to do that.
Oh, well, then you, you do it.
No, I don‰Ûªt want to do it. You can do it.
Okay, you can take him for shoes.
I just took him for shoes.
Well, all I know is he says they hurt his feet.
Fine. I‰Ûªll take him for shoes next Saturday.
Oh, no, no, no, a bunch of us from work are going to Disneyland next Saturday and Sheldon wants to come.
You‰Ûªre taking him to Disneyland?
Well, he heard me making plans on the phone. Was I going to say no?
All right. But let me know if you‰Ûªre going to stuff him with junk food. I don‰Ûªt want to bring home a nice dinner for him and see it go to waste.
We‰Ûªre going to Disneyland. He‰Ûªs going to eat junk food.
All I‰Ûªm saying is give me a heads-up.
Okay, whatever.
And don‰Ûªt let him go on Space Mountain after he eats. He‰Ûªll say he can handle it, but I promise you‰Ûªll end up with churro puke on your shoes.
All right, got it. Is there anything else?
Yeah, don‰Ûªt let Goofy near him. He‰Ûªll have nightmares and I‰Ûªll have to deal with it.
What‰Ûªs the problem with Goofy?
Wish I knew. He‰Ûªs fine with Pluto.
The apartment.
Hey, do you think the elastic woman in The Incredibles needs to use birth control or can she just be a diaphragm?
Well, that‰Ûªs it. We‰Ûªre officially out of things to talk about.
We‰Ûªre home.
It‰Ûªs ten o‰Ûªclock, where have you been?
We stayed for the California Adventure water show. It was pure Disney magic.
I was going to see that with him.
How was I supposed to know that?
It‰Ûªs all right. I‰Ûªll see it again with you.
And I have food here. You said you were going to call.
I know, I know.
I can still eat.
No, you already threw up once. Go put on your PJs and brush your teeth.
Okay, but just don‰Ûªt fight
We‰Ûªre not fighting.
Just go.
Aren‰Ûªt you going to thank Penny for taking you to Disneyland?
Thank you, Penny.
You‰Ûªre welcome, sweetie.
Want a cup of coffee?
Oh, um, I should probably get going.
Come on. It‰Ûªs just a cup of coffee.
Yep, okay.

character: Howard (to Raj, who has whispered to him)
line: Oh, yeah, the whole thing seems a little twisted to me, too.
What am I smelling?
Sheldon‰Ûªs churro on my shoes.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
He‰Ûªs such an angel when he‰Ûªs asleep.
Yeah. Shame he has to wake up.
I think we can do it.
Smother Sheldon in his sleep? Wouldn‰Ûªt that be wrong?
No, be friends. You and me.
Oh. Sure. Absolutely.
Good. I‰Ûªm glad.
Here‰Ûªs an idea. I‰Ûªm just throwing it out there, friends who have sex.
Good night, Leonard.
Kidding. Just a couple of friends goofin‰Ûª around.
No, Goofy, no.
The university cafeteria.
Hold.
What?
Explain your sneeze.
I‰Ûªm sorry?
Do you have allergies?
No.
Is there too much pepper on your salad?
I don‰Ûªt put pepper on salads.
I‰Ûªve heard enough. Sit over there.
Oh, come on. I don‰Ûªt want to sit by myself.
That‰Ûªs what Typhoid Mary said, and clearly, her friends buckled.
Guys, help me.
Sheldon, come on.
Yeah, it‰Ûªs just one sneeze. (Raj sneezes) You‰Ûªre on your own.
See you, buddy.
Oh, Leonard, I have something for you. Per our roommate agreement, this is your 24-hour notice that I will be having a non-related female spending two nights in our apartment.
When you say non-related female, you still mean human, right?
Of course. Pets are banned under the roommate agreement, with the exception of service animals, such as seeing eye dogs and, one day, cybernetically-enhanced helper monkeys.
Are you planning on kidnapping a woman?
Sarcasm?
Yes, but mixed with genuine concern.
For your information, I‰Ûªll be playing host to Dr. Elizabeth Plimpton.
The cosmological physicist from Princeton?

Yes. And until you acquire a surgical mask, please address your comments to me through a napkin. We‰Ûªve been corresponding for years about our mutual interest in gravitational wave signatures of inflatons in the early universe. And now she‰Ûªs under consideration for a position at our university.
Why didn‰Ûªt you tell me you knew Elizabeth Plimpton? I am a huge fan of hers!
I didn‰Ûªt realize I was obligated to share my connection with things you‰Ûªre a fan of, but very well. You enjoy Canadian bacon. I‰Ûªve been to Toronto.
Okay, fine. Where is she going to sleep?
My room, of course.
Holy crap! (Through napkin) Holy crap!
Yeah, um, I have a two-part question.
Go ahead.
A, are you kidding me? And B, seriously, are you freaking kidding me?
A, I rarely kid. And B, when I do kid, you will know it by my use of the word bazinga.
So you‰Ûªre saying the two of you are going to be sleeping in the same bed?
Yes. Bazinga. Leonard?
Thank you. Why is a world-renowned scientist staying in our apartment instead of a hotel?

Well, she doesn‰Ûªt care for hotels. And who can blame her? Windows that don‰Ûªt open, multi-user linens, keys shaped like credit cards, as if one walks around with unassigned slots in one‰Ûªs wallet. All right, I believe I have time for one more question. Yes, Raj?
When can I sit with you again?
When I‰Ûªve seen two consecutive negative throat cultures spaced 12 hours apart. You know the drill. All right, if you‰Ûªll excuse me, I am off to start a prophylactic course of antibiotics.
I can‰Ûªt believe he‰Ûªs friends with Elizabeth Plimpton.
I can‰Ûªt believe they let him into Canada.
Whoa, whoa, whoa. You heard the man. Where‰Ûªs your throat cultures? Kidding. Sit down.
The lobby
Hey, Sheldon.
Oh, Penny, excellent. I have a question about these maxi pads. Are the wings truly functional or have I fallen victim to marketing hype?
What? What are you doing with, what?
The stock boy at Walgreens was frustratingly uninformed on the subject.
Sheldon, what are you doing with maxi pads?
I have a lady friend who will be staying with me for a few days.
Oh. What?
I want her to feel at home. I also bought scented soaps, pantyhose, Midol, calcium chews and what is apparently a yogurt specifically designed to regulate the female bowel.
Wait, wait, hold on, back up. You‰Ûªre having a woman stay with you?
Yes. Why does that seem to flabbergast everybody?
Oh, no, no, no, no. I‰Ûªm not flabbergasted. I‰Ûªm puzzled. Yeah, let‰Ûªs go with puzzled.
A word of warning. My guest is a noted physicist and the leading expert on quantum cosmology, so please try to avoid wasting her time with female jibber jabber.
Female jibber jabber?
Shoe sales, hair styles, mud masks, gossip about your friends Brad and Angelina.
Oh, they‰Ûªre not my friends.
I‰Ûªm not surprised, considering the way you talk about them behind their backs.
The apartment.
She‰Ûªs here, she‰Ûªs here. How do I look? Do I look smart?

Oh, good grief. This isn‰Ûªt about you. Coming! Now listen, one of the great minds of the 21st century is about to play host to one of the other great minds of the 21st century. So pay attention. Years from now, my biographer might ask you about this event.
Oh, I have so many things to tell your biographer.

Ah, Dr. Cooper, thank goodness. I completely forgot your address. But then I remembered that I‰Ûªd written it on my hand. Lucky for me, I didn‰Ûªt confuse it with what I‰Ûªd written on my other hand, which are the coordinates for a newly discovered neutron star. ‰Û÷Cause if I tried to go there, I‰Ûªd be crushed by hypergravity. Anyway, hello.
Hello.
Nice to finally meet you in person.
I would imagine it is. This is my friend and roommate, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.

Hi-lo. Oops. I started to say hi, and then I switched to hello in the middle. It came out hi-lo. Duh. Uh, it‰Ûªs nice to meet you. I‰Ûªve read both your books and most of your papers. I‰Ûªm Leonard, I live
I apologize. He‰Ûªs only an experimental physicist.

No need to apologize. Some of my best friends are experimental physicists. Well, not my best friends, but I know them. My best friend is a molecular chemist named Wendy. I‰Ûªm sorry, I‰Ûªm rambling. Hi-lo.
Are you hungry, thirsty? Can I offer you anything?
No, she‰Ûªs my guest. If anyone should offer her anything, it should be me. Elizabeth, can I get you something? Perhaps a feminine hygiene product or a bowel-regulating yogurt?
Interesting choices. Based on my current needs, I guess I‰Ûªd pick the yogurt.
Excellent. If the yogurt works, I bought some delightful scented candles.
Look, it‰Ûªs you.
A little later.
Thank you so much for opening up your home to me.
Well, who wants to stay in a hotel? With windows that don‰Ûªt open, those crazy card-shaped keys.
I‰Ûªm so glad you understand.
No, he doesn‰Ûªt understand. I understand.
Well, I understand, too.
You‰Ûªre just misappropriating my understanding.
Oh, (blows a raspberry). I think any university would want you. Except, of course, any university that had already had you. Because they would‰Ûªve already wanted you before they, you know, got you.
From the mind that brought you hi-lo. Let me show you to your room.
All right. I guess I am tired. Good night, Leonard.
Uh, sleep night. I mean, obviously, good night. I started to say sleep tight, then I changed my mind in the middle. I swear to God, I‰Ûªm smart.
Get it together, man.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.

All right, let me show you some of the features of the room. First, windows. Conventional. Open, closed, open, closed, halfway open, or halfway closed, depending on your philosophical bent. Over here is my comic book collection. Feel free to browse. There‰Ûªs a box of disposable reading gloves on the night stand.
Good to know.
What if there‰Ûªs a disaster that destroys all the USB ports?
Then there‰Ûªs really no reason to live, is there?
Can I ask a question about your roommate?
He‰Ûªs an odd duck, isn‰Ûªt he?
What‰Ûªs his relationship status?

Well, there was a misbegotten adventure with a waitress who lives across the hall. It ended as inexplicably as it began. They had very little in common, except for carnal activity. That‰Ûªs why I acquired these noise-cancelling headphones. If you decide to use them, please clean the ear pieces afterwards with the Wet Wipes you‰Ûªll find in the bathroom. They‰Ûªre in the drawer labelled Wet Wipes.
Okay.

Good. I‰Ûªll leave you to your night time ablutions. I‰Ûªve e-mailed you the morning bathroom schedule. You‰Ûªll also find a laminated copy in your welcome packet. It‰Ûªs on the back of the emergency escape route diagram.
How thoughtful.
Sleep well, my friend.
You, too.
Oh, let me just get one thing. It‰Ûªs my backup emergency supply kit. The living room escape route doesn‰Ûªt pass through here. Now, good night. And if there‰Ûªs an apocalypse, good luck.
Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom. There is a knock on the door.
Yes?
I saw your light on.
Is everything all right?
Yeah, I just couldn‰Ûªt sleep.
Me neither. Oh, look what I‰Ûªm reading. It‰Ûªs you.
I thought you already read it.
I did, but it‰Ûªs been a while, and I wanted to sound smart over breakfast.
Aw, you‰Ûªre smart.
Oh, good. Wasn‰Ûªt sure it was coming across.
What chapter are you on?
Uh, six.
Oh, the extragalactic distance ladder. Want to know a little secret?
Sure.
I wrote the section on the Wilson-Bappu Effect completely naked.
Really? Uh, sure doesn‰Ûªt read that way.
Here, let me show you. When we consider the brightness of pulsating variable stars, we start to see (removes robe) a possible explanation for some of the discrepancies found in Hubble‰Ûªs constant.
Wow. You really make science come alive.
The living room.
Vocal test. Morning vocal test. Second vocal test. Second morning vocal test.
Morning, Sheldon.
Morning.
Morning, Sheldon.
Morning. I trust you had a pleasant night.
More than pleasant.
Excuse me, I‰Ûªm going to relieve myself.
How do you take your coffee?
Black.
Okeydoke.
Pee for Houston, pee for Austin, pee for the state my heart got lost in. And shake twice for Texas.
Something his mother taught him.
All right, Elizabeth, the bathroom is yours. The seat is down, and has been sanitized for your protection.
That‰Ûªs very thoughtful, but I think I‰Ûªll finish my coffee first.
Ah, so the yogurt didn‰Ûªt work. I‰Ûªll fire off a critical e-mail to the manufacturer.
Oh, good, you‰Ûªre up. Look, my car won‰Ûªt start. I need a ride to work.
Did you once again ignore your check engine light?
No, Mr. smarty-pants. I ignored the fill gas tank light.
Leonard, Penny wants to exploit any residual feelings you have for her in order to get a ride to work.
Oh, yeah, sure, let me just put this in a travel mug.
Hello.
Hi.
Oh, Penny, this is Dr. Plimpton, a leading expert on quantum cosmology. Dr. Plimpton, Penny is a waitress who doesn‰Ûªt understand the role gasoline plays in the internal combustion engine.
Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you, too. Are you enjoying your stay?
Yes, very much.
Good.
Wonderful. Meaningless pleasantries accomplished. Elizabeth, Leonard‰Ûªs bathroom time is coming up, and believe me, you do not want to follow him.
Excuse me.
Okay, well, I guess I should get dressed so I can take everyone to work. You and Sheldon and Sheldon‰Ûªs friend, Dr. Plimpton, who you just met. It‰Ûªll be fun. Like a clown car.
Hang on.
Hmm? Yeah? What? Huh?
We just broke up.
What, uh, you and me? Yeah, we did. Not too long ago. How are you doing with it?
Not as good as you apparently.
I, um, I don‰Ûªt follow.
You know what? It‰Ûªs, it‰Ûªs none of my business. If you want to sleep with Sheldon‰Ûªs doctor buddy right after we stopped seeing each other, go for it.
Well, now‰Û_
Excuse me. I‰Ûªm uncomfortable with you recommending that Leonard pursue having intercourse with Dr. Plimpton, who I assure you has better things to do.
I‰Ûªm not recommending it. I‰Ûªm saying it already happened.
That‰Ûªs preposterous. Tell her, Leonard.
Well‰Û_
No.
Come on. It wasn‰Ûªt my fault.
The implication being that you somehow tripped and fell into her lady parts?
You know what? I‰Ûªm just gonna take the bus to work.
Penny, I can still drive you.
Oh, no, no, it‰Ûªs okay. You might slip on a banana peel and get me pregnant.
I must say, I‰Ûªm shocked by this betrayal.
I didn‰Ûªt betray Penny.
Not Penny, me!
How am I betraying you?
Elizabeth‰Ûªs my friend, and you‰Ûªre playing with her!
Yeah, I guess I did.
The cafeteria. Raj drinks from a hip flask.
What the hell are you doing?
Relax, it‰Ûªs Nyquil.
You still have a cold?
Maybe, but I don‰Ûªt care. That‰Ûªs the great thing about Nyquil, it‰Ûªs like ten-percent booze. I call it the nighttime sniffling, sneezing, coughing, so you can talk to girls medicine.
Are you having trouble sleeping? ‰Û÷Cause, boy, I was up all night.
Did you get a cold, too?
No, but I was awake all night.
If you want, I can give you some of my mom‰Ûªs sleeping pills.
She won‰Ûªt notice they‰Ûªre missing?
She doesn‰Ûªt know she takes them.
No, that‰Ûªs okay. It was something else keeping me up last night. And again this morning. And, I didn‰Ûªt mind. I was up last night. I was up this morning. I didn‰Ûªt mind. Those are your clues.
Ooh, ooh. Did the pigeon on your windowsill have more babies?
No.
Were you up making another stop-motion Lego movie?
No.
‰Û÷Cause let me tell you, it‰Ûªs not enough to make the Legos move, they also have to capture your heart.
Okay, I‰Ûªll give you one more clue. It involved another person.
Did you get a Japanese love pillow?
How is a Japanese love pillow another person?
It is if you love her and give her a name.
Dr. Plimpton, I‰Ûªd like you to meet my colleagues, Dr. Rajesh Koothrappali
Hi.
And not-a-doctor Howard Wolowitz.
Hi.
I‰Ûªm a big fan of your work.
Thank you.
And of course, you‰Ûªve already introduced yourself to Dr. Hofstadter.
Hey, you.
Hey, you.
Boy, I‰Ûªm kind of tuckered out. How are you feeling, Elizabeth?
You know what? I am a little tired. Would you be a dear and get me a cup of coffee?
Sure. Black, right?
Actually, now I think I want it hot, brown and sweet.
Coming right up.
Raj‰Ûªs apartment.
What?
What do you mean what? It‰Ûªs Halo night.
I can‰Ûªt. I‰Ûªm too sick. Go away.
That‰Ûªs why we moved Halo night here. Look, I brought my mom‰Ûªs chicken soup.
I‰Ûªm not hungry.
Don‰Ûªt send him away. Let him in.
Who‰Ûªs that
I bought a parrot.
Yeah, right. Dr. Plimpton?
Hi. Howard, right?
Uh, yeah.
Can I ask you a question, Howard? Do you like role-playing games?
Yeah, sure. In fact, I‰Ûªm a dungeon master.
Not tonight. Tonight you are a delivery man. You brought soup, but uh-oh, Raj and I don‰Ûªt have enough money to pay you. So we‰Ûªll have to come to some other kind of arrangement.
Beg pardon?
You two figure out the details, I‰Ûªm going to go change into something I don‰Ûªt mind getting ripped off my milky flesh.
What the frak?
Go away. She wants New Delhi, not Kosher deli. Besides, you have a girlfriend.
We broke up weeks ago.
Why didn‰Ûªt you say anything?
I was waiting for the right time. This is the right time.
Hey, who‰Ûªs ready for Halo?
Oh, this is like a nightmare. Get lost!
He‰Ûªs right. The numbers are shaky enough as it is.
I don‰Ûªt understand.
Oh, good. Leonard‰Ûªs here.
Good?
Elizabeth? What‰Ûªs going on?
What‰Ûªs going on is you and Howard are my moving men and Raj is my new landlord and I don‰Ûªt have enough money to pay any of you.
Is she suggesting what I think she‰Ûªs suggesting?
Yep. Welcome to the Penthouse Forum.
Okay, show of hands. Who‰Ûªs up for this? (Only Howard raises his hand.)
We‰Ûªll all be naked in front of each other.
I‰Ûªm out.
Everybody ready?
Follow my lead. Almost. We‰Ûªre, we‰Ûªre going to go out into the hallway and, uh, make a dramatic entrance.
Oh, good. It‰Ûªs so much better when everyone commits.
Run. Run, run, run. Don‰Ûªt look back.
I thought we had something special.
So, you say you can‰Ûªt pay your rent?
The lobby.
Oh, Leonard?
Hey.
I found these in the dryer. I‰Ûªm assuming they belong to Sheldon.
Thanks. It‰Ûªs really hard to find these in his size. So, listen. I‰Ûªve been meaning to talk to you about the other morning.
You mean you and Dr. Slutbunny?
Yeah, I wanted to explain.
Well, you don‰Ûªt owe me an explanation.
I don‰Ûªt?
No, you don‰Ûªt.
So you‰Ûªre not judging me?
Oh, I‰Ûªm judging you nine ways to Sunday, but you don‰Ûªt owe me an explanation.
Nevertheless, I‰Ûªd like to get one on the record so you can understand why I did what I did.
I‰Ûªm listening.
She let me.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
Okay, Babydoll Pink, let‰Ûªs see if you can cover up the fact that I got my dad‰Ûªs feet.
It‰Ûªs just two degrees, Sheldon. I just want to turn up the thermostat two degrees!
Yes, if we lived in a teakettle.
Aw, screw the roommate agreement!
You know what, go to Hell and set their thermostat.

character: Penny (after a knock on the door)
line: Who is it?
Leonard.
Hang on.
Can I sleep on your couch tonight?
Uh, well, you can try, but the people across the hall are being very noisy.
You heard that, huh?
Apparently, the one fella tried to adjust the thermostat, then the other fella went bat-crap crazy.
So you agree, he‰Ûªs nuts.
Well, not as nuts as the guy who chooses to live with him.
Believe it or not, he was worse when I met him.
Oh, I do not believe that.
Excuse me, I‰Ûªm looking for Sheldon Cooper‰Ûªs apartment.
Oh, I bet you‰Ûªre here to check out the room for rent.
Yeah.
Run away, dude.
What?
Run fast, run far. (End of flashback.)
That should have been my first clue.
Moments later.
So Sheldon‰Ûªs last roommate tried to warn you off?
For all I knew, he was the crazy one. He had this really deranged look.
Well, yeah, he‰Ûªd been living with Sheldon.
Sure, it makes sense now. (Flashback. Past Leonard is getting out of the lift). Anyway, I went upstairs and knocked on the door.
Yeah?
Dr. Cooper?
No, you want the crazy guy across the hall.
In retrospect, that was clue number two.
Yes?
I‰Ûªm Leonard Hofstadter. I called you about the apartment. You said‰Û_
I know what I said. I know what you said. I know what my mother said on March 5, 1992. What is the sixth noble gas?
What?
You said you‰Ûªre a scientist. What is the sixth noble gas?
Uh, radon?

Hello, Amy Farrah Fowler. I‰Ûªm sorry to inform you that you have been taken in by unsupportable mathematics designed to prey on the gullible and the lonely. Additionally, I‰Ûªm being blackmailed with a hidden dirty sock.

If that was slang, I‰Ûªm unfamiliar with it. If it was literal, I share your aversion to soiled hosiery. In any case, I‰Ûªm here because my mother and I have agreed that I will date at least once a year.
Interesting. My mother and I have the same agreement about church.
I don‰Ûªt object to the concept of a deity, but I‰Ûªm baffled by the notion of one that takes attendance.
Well, then you might want to avoid East Texas.
Noted. Now, before this goes any further, you should know that all forms of physical contact up to and including coitus are off the table.
May I buy you a beverage?
Tepid water, please.
Good God, what have we done?
The apartment. A robotic arm is extracting some Chinese takeaway from a bag controlled by Howard.
And now the kung pao chicken.
Alright.
Smooth.
And finally, my moo shu pork.
Whoo-hoo!
Ah, there you have it, gentlemen. Our entire dinner unpacked by robot.
And it only took 28 minutes.
Impressive, but we must be cautious.
Why?
Today, it‰Ûªs a Chinese food retrieval robot. Tomorrow, it travels back in time and tries to kill Sarah Connor.
I don‰Ûªt think that‰Ûªs going to happen, Sheldon.
No one ever does. That‰Ûªs why it happens.
Hey. Is the food here? Ooh. What‰Ûªs that?
That, dear lady, is the Wolowitz Programmable Hand, designed for extravehicular repairs on the International Space Station.
Ah, cool.
Ask me to pass the soy sauce.
Oh, does that come up much on the space station?
Mostly with Asian and Jewish astronauts.
All right. Pass the soy sauce.
Coming up. (Starts typing rapidly)
So how‰Ûªs work?
Oh, it‰Ûªs not bad. Kind of hungry.
Yeah, we all are.
Just wait.
You realize, Penny, that the technology that went into this arm will one day make unskilled food servers such as yourself obsolete.
Really? They‰Ûªre going to make a robot that spits on your hamburger?
I thought you broke up with her. Why is she here?
Okay, here we go. Passing the soy sauce. Put out your hand.
Oh ha-ha, oh. That‰Ûªs amazing.
I wouldn‰Ûªt say amazing. At best, it‰Ûªs a modest leap forward from the basic technology that gave us Country Bear Jamboree.
Hey, Sheldon?
Yes? (Howard types. The hand puts up two fingers to Sheldon.) Peace?
No, not peace. Hang on.
A few moments later.
Does NASA know you‰Ûªre using that thing as a napkin holder?
You kidding? They still think it‰Ûªs in a secure locker at JPL.
You stole it?
Borrowed. The trick is to carry it out to your car like you own it.

Excuse me. Oh. Amy‰Ûªs at the dry cleaners, and she‰Ûªs made a very amusing pun. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt care for perchloroethylene, and I don‰Ûªt like glycol ether.‰Û Get it? She doesn‰Ûªt like glycol ether. Sounds like either. (Taps in reply) L-O-L.
Who‰Ûªs Amy?
His girlfriend.
Sheldon has a girlfriend?
She‰Ûªs not my girlfriend.
How long has this been going on?
Four months.
She‰Ûªs not my girlfriend.
Are you telling me, for the past four months I have been asking you what‰Ûªs new and you never thought to go with Sheldon has a girlfriend?
She‰Ûªs not my girlfriend.
Ah, du-du-du-du-du. How did they meet?
Raj and I entered Sheldon‰Ûªs information on a dating site, and it spit out Amy Farrah Fowler.
Oh, my God! Sheldon and Amy.
Or, as we call them, Shamy.
Shamy. I am so digging the Shamy.
All right, everyone pay attention. Yes, I have a friend named Amy Farrah Fowler. Yes, she is female. Yes, we communicate on a daily basis, but no, she is not my girlfriend.
Okay, well, what do you communicate about?
Well, my work in physics, her work in neurobiology, and most recently, the possibility of our having a child together.

character: Penny (spits out drink explosively. Howard types. Robot arm hands Penny a napkin)
line: Thank you.

Amy pointed out that between the two of us, our genetic material has the potential of producing the first in a line of intellectually superior, benign overlords to guide humanity to a brighter tomorrow.
I‰Ûªm guessing that future historians will condemn us for not taking this opportunity to kill Sheldon.
Okay, I have a question.
Yes, Penny.
You don‰Ûªt even like people touching you. How are you going to have sex?
Why on Earth would we have sex?
Oh, honey, did your mom not have the talk with you? You know, when your private parts started growing?
I‰Ûªm quite aware of the way humans usually reproduce, which is messy, unsanitary, and based on living next to you for three years, involves loud and unnecessary appeals to a deity.
Oh, God.

Yes, exactly. Consequently, if Amy and I choose to bring new life into this world, it will be accomplished clinically, with fertility experts in a lab with petri dishes. Which reminds me, you have broad hips and a certain corn-fed vigour. Is your womb available for rental?
Still digging the Shamy?
Look, Sheldon, before you race off to the fertility clinic, you might want to think about, uh gee, I don‰Ûªt know, maybe actually spending some time with her.
You mean dating?
Yeah.
I can‰Ûªt date Amy.
Why not?
She‰Ûªs not my girlfriend.
Okay, look, don‰Ûªt think of it as dating a girlfriend. Think of it as, uh, getting to know the future mother of your child.
Oh. I hadn‰Ûªt considered that. I suppose she will have to have access to our progeny. And you don‰Ûªt think I can achieve the required intimacy via text messaging?
Probably not.
Huh. It would appear as if the phone companies have been lying to me.
The hallway.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
You do realize I stand on the other side of the door waiting for you to finish knocking three times.
I know. I can see the shadow of your feet under the door.
Yeah, my point is it‰Ûªs a waste of time.
If you‰Ûªre looking for an example of a waste of time, I would refer you to the conversation we‰Ûªre having right now.
What do you want?
I‰Ûªve decided to take your advice and have arranged to go on a date with Amy Farrah Fowler.
Oh, that‰Ûªs great. Have fun.
Wait. You have to drive me.
What?
You know I don‰Ûªt drive.
Well, go ask Leonard.
I did. He said, and I quote, ask Penny, it was her cockamamie idea.
Leonard said cockamamie?
Actually, I‰Ûªm paraphrasing. Having been raised in a Christian household, I‰Ûªm uncomfortable with the language he used. And to be honest, I‰Ûªm not entirely comfortable with cockamamie.
Okay, fine. When‰Ûªs the date?
Now.
Now?
Hurry. We‰Ûªre going to be late.
Sheldon, did it ever occur to you that I might have other plans?
I‰Ûªm sorry. Do you have other plans?
Well, no, not per se, but‰Û_
So this conversation is as pointless as your door-knocking soliloquy?
Let me get my cockamamie keys.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom. Howard is being massaged by the robot hand.
Oh, God, that feels so good. Yeah, that‰Ûªs the spot. Oh, baby.
Howard, dinner‰Ûªs ready!
I‰Ûªll eat later. I‰Ûªm busy! Oh, yeah. Just like a real hand. Hmm.
Penny‰Ûªs car.
Thank you for driving me.
You‰Ûªre welcome.
I wish you weren‰Ûªt wearing flip-flops. It‰Ûªs dangerous to drive in flip-flops.
Sheldon.
Sorry. I just don‰Ûªt want to be yet another flip-flop fatality.
Can I ask you a question?
Given your community college education, I encourage you to ask me as many as possible.
Yeah. Well, my question is, and I‰Ûªm pretty sure I know the answer, is this your first date?
That depends. Does square-dancing with my sister at a Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown count as a date?
No.
Then, this is my first date.
Okay. Well, then, there‰Ûªs a couple of things you should probably know.
I have a master‰Ûªs degree and two doctorates. The things I should know, I do know.
My point is, I know more about dating than you, and if you were as smart as you think you are, you would listen to me.
If you know so much, how come I have a date tonight and you have nothing better to do than drive me to it?
Fair point.
The apartment.
You know, there‰Ûªs something I‰Ûªve always wondered about Aquaman.
Yeah?
Where does he poop?
What?
What would a toilet look like in Atlantis? How would you flush it? And when you did flush it, where would the poop go?
Hold that thought. Hey, Howard, what‰Ûªs going on? What? Hold on, Howard, Howard, slow down. The robot hand is stuck on your what? (To Raj) You‰Ûªre not going to believe this.
Penny‰Ûªs car. Amy is now in the back seat.
So, um, Amy, Sheldon tells me you‰Ûªre a neuro something-or-other.
Neurobiologist. Your check engine light is on.
Yeah, it‰Ûªs okay.
But the light indicates‰Û_
Don‰Ûªt bother. I‰Ûªve wasted many an hour tilting at that particular windmill.

Ah. Well, your hair looks very nice.
Are you a homosexual?
No, no, I was just giving you a compliment.

Guys, how ‰Ûªbout some music?
Oh, no, I wouldn‰Ûªt care for that. Amy?
No, thank you.

No.

Muggles.

Yes.
Penis first?
Yes. Now, help me!

Please, before my mother walks in, just get this off me!
Okay, let‰Ûªs see.
No, no! Don‰Ûªt touch, the program is paused.
Well, then let‰Ûªs un-pause it.
No, no! I loaded the wrong program. The hand thinks it‰Ûªs holding a screwdriver in outer space. If you continue the program, it‰Ûªs gonna start twisting.
A-All right, um, how about this. When, when Winnie the Pooh got his head stuck in the honey tree, his friends all grabbed onto him and pulled and pulled.
You do what you want, I‰Ûªm not touching another man‰Ûªs honey tree.
All right, uh, forget pulling. How about we get an electric saw and cut it off?

Well, then what do you want us to do?
I‰Û_
Howard, I made cookies for you and your little friends!
That‰Ûªs great, Mom, thanks!
I‰Ûªll bring them up with some Hawaiian Punch!

A restaurant.

Big night? The winter solstice is a big night. It‰Ûªs over 14 hours in Southern California.
That‰Ûªs an amusing factoid.
Thank you.

Apparently, a semi-incestuous Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown didn‰Ûªt count.
So, um, Amy, what about you? Do you date much?

Once a year. It‰Ûªs a deal I made with my mother in exchange for her silence on the matter, as well as the occasional use of her George Foreman Grill that seals in the flavour without the fat. How about you, Penny? Do you go on many dates?
Uh, yeah, I wouldn‰Ûªt say many. A few. (Sheldon laugh‰Ûªs strangely). What‰Ûªs (imitates Sheldon‰Ûªs laugh)
Your characterization of approximately 171 different men as a few.

Simple extrapolation. In the three years that I‰Ûªve known you, you were single for two. During that time, I saw 17 different suitors. If we work backwards, correcting for observation bias and postulate an initial dating age of 15‰Û_

My mistake. Now, assuming the left side of a bell curve peaking around the present, that would bring the total up to 193 men. Plus or minus eight men.
Remarkable. Did you have sexual intercourse with all of these men?

Oh.

Based on the number of awkward encounters I‰Ûªve had with strange men leaving her apartment in the morning, plus the number of times she‰Ûªs returned home wearing the same clothes she wore the night before‰Û_
Okay, Sheldon, I think you‰Ûªve made your point.
So we multiply 193, minus 21 men before the loss of virginity, so 172 times 0.18 gives us 30.96 sexual partners. Let‰Ûªs round that up to 31.
Okay, Sheldon, you are so wrong. That is not even close to the real number. I‰Ûªm gonna need a drink over here.
This is very interesting. Cultural perceptions are subjective. Penny, to your mind, are you a slut?
No! No! No. Let‰Ûªs just all finish our dinners, okay?
This is an interesting topic. How many sexual encounters have you had?
Does volunteering for a scientific experiment in which orgasm was achieved by electronically stimulating the pleasure centres of the brain count?
I should think so.
Then 128.
A hospital,=.
Okay, come on. Almost there.
Don‰Ûªt tug. No tugging.
Next time, take your own advice.
Excuse me, could you help us out?
My, my, my. What do we have here?
I slipped and fell.
Yeah, we get that a lot. What is this?
It‰Ûªs a robot arm.
Where‰Ûªs the rest of the robot?

‰Û÷Cause that‰Ûªs all you needed, right?
Can you please just help me?
All right, all right. Hang on, stay calm. (Over PA system)  I need an orderly with a wheelchair. I got a robot hand grasping a man‰Ûªs penis out here.
You think you could be a little more discreet?
I‰Ûªm sorry, we don‰Ûªt have a code for robot hand grasping a man‰Ûªs penis. Why is it hooked up to a computer?
Uh, it‰Ûªs what controls the arm.
But it‰Ûªs frozen.
Did you try turning it off and back on again?
No, you see, it‰Ûªs more complicated than that. (Nurse switches off computer) No, wait! (The hand lets go) Winnie the Pooh is out of the honey tree.
Now can we have cookies and Hawaiian Punch?
The stairwell.
You were right. This was a very productive evening. I saw a whole new side of Amy Farrah Fowler tonight.
I did not have sex with 31 guys.

I‰Ûªll be happy to check the math, but numbers don‰Ûªt lie, Penny. In any event, now that Amy and I have spent quality time together, I feel much more confident proceeding to the next stage of our relationship.
And that is?
Using in vitro fertilization and a surrogate uterus to gift humanity with our progeny.
You‰Ûªre still on that?
In these uncertain times, doesn‰Ûªt humanity deserve a gift?
Okay, you know what? I‰Ûªm gonna come at this in a whole new way. Sheldon, if you try to make a baby with Amy in a petri dish, I‰Ûªm gonna tell your mother on you.
That‰Ûªs no threat. My mother‰Ûªs always wanted a grandchild.
Really? Your deeply religious born-again Christian mother wants a test-tube grandbaby born out of wedlock?
Curses.
If I‰Ûªd thought of that in the first place, I could‰Ûªve saved myself this whole night.
Well, it‰Ûªs not that late. You could still go out and look for number 32. Good night.
Hey, Howard, what‰Ûªs up?
I‰Ûªve decided not to procreate.
Yeah, yeah, great. Howard, uh, slow down. What do you mean it happened again?
The apartment. Sheldon has a series of whiteboards across the room.
Whatcha doin‰Ûª there? Working on a new plan to catch the roadrunner?
The humorous implication being that I am Wile E. Coyote?
Yes.
And this is a schematic for a bird-trapping device that will ultimately backfire and cause me physical injury?
Yes.
What I‰Ûªm doing here is trying to determine when I‰Ûªm going to die.
A lot of people are working on that research. So what is all this?
My family history factoring in longevity, propensity for disease, et cetera.
Interesting. Cause of death for Uncle Carl was KBB. What‰Ûªs KBB?
Killed by badger.
How‰Ûªs that?

I don‰Ûªt think you need to worry about death by badgers being hereditary.

Not true. The fight or flight instinct is coded genetically. Instead of fleeing, he chose to fight barehanded against a brawny member of the weasel family. Who‰Ûªs to say that I don‰Ûªt share that flawed DNA?
You can always get a badger and find out.
But seriously, even if I disregard the Uncle Carl factor, at best I have 60 years left.
That long, huh?
60 only takes me to here. I need to get to here.
What‰Ûªs there?
The earliest estimate of the singularity, when man will be able to transfer his consciousness into machines and achieve immortality.
So, you‰Ûªre upset about missing out on becoming some sort of freakish self-aware robot?
By this much.
Tough break. You want eggs?
You don‰Ûªt get it, Leonard. I‰Ûªm going to miss so much, the unified field theory,åÊ cold fusion, the dogapus.
What‰Ûªs a dogapus?
A hybrid dog and octopus. Man‰Ûªs underwater best friend.
Is somebody working on that?
I was going to. I planned on giving it to myself on my 300th birthday.
Wait a minute. You hate dogs.
A dogapus can play fetch with eight balls. No one can hate that.
The apartment.
What do we owe you?
It came to $28.17. Let‰Ûªs say six bucks apiece.
Here you go.
Thank you.
What?
Never mind. I got it.
Oh, you wanted me to pay.
It‰Ûªs no big deal.
No, no, no, no. You‰Ûªre right. We‰Ûªre not going out anymore, I should pay for myself. (After Raj whispers to Howard, and Howard laughs) What?
He said if he had woman parts, he‰Ûªd eat for free the rest of his life.

It‰Ûªs okay, you can owe me.
Okay.
Sheldon, six bucks.

Not for me. Thursday is now Cruciferous Vegetable Night. Tonight‰Ûªs selection, brussels sprouts.

It‰Ûªs a small price to pay.
For what?

Sorry, sorry, sorry, sorry, sorry.
In order to live long enough to fuse my consciousness with cybernetics, I need to change my diet.

Correct.
So you want to turn yourself into some sort of robot?
Essentially, yes.
Okay, here‰Ûªs my question. Didn‰Ûªt you already do that?
Flattering, but sadly, no. I‰Ûªm also planning to begin an exercise regimen designed to strengthen my cardiovascular system. AKA jogging.
Wait. Honey,have you ever run before?
Certainly. I‰Ûªve run from bullies, dogs, angry chickens, and one particularly persistent P.E. teacher determined to bend me over and give me a scoliosis test.
You‰Ûªre right, Penny jogs. Maybe you guys can run together.
That‰Ûªs an excellent idea. Yeah, if we chat, it will create the illusion of time going faster.
No, it won‰Ûªt. Um, how does he know I jog?
Oh, he watches you from his car with high-powered binoculars.
Oh, my God, that is so creepy!

Leonard‰Ûªs bedroom

I have pain radiating from my navel to my lower right abdomen. I‰Ûªm nauseated and feverish. I believe I may have cholera.
