How are you doing on the young lady front? I hear you‰Ûªre in some sort of a long distance situation?
Uh, yeah, it‰Ûªs Raj‰Ûªs sister. It‰Ûªs kind of tough. She‰Ûªs in India. Also, her parents aren‰Ûªt happy she‰Ûªs dating someone white.

Oh, that‰Ûªs a funny turn, isn‰Ûªt it? You never think about it going the other way. Well, you can‰Ûªt force things. You need to figure out if you‰Ûªre in a relationship or if you‰Ûªre just calling it one. It‰Ûªs like they say, a cat can have kittens in the oven but that don‰Ûªt make ‰Ûªem biscuits.
And that reminds me of another saying. You can lead a chicken to Crisco, but you can‰Ûªtmake your mother fry it.
Sheldon, you pester me one more time about chicken, I will put you over my knee right here in this restaurant.
Please pester her. Please, for me.
The stairwell.
So, Mrs. Cooper, what did you think of the sushi?
It was good. The only thing that would have made it better is if it was cooked and if it was beef. Sheldon, when is your landlord going to fix the elevator?
I don‰Ûªt know. Lately we‰Ûªve been talking about converting it into a missile silo.
Your son seems to think we need to launch a pre-emptive strike on Burbank.
Get them before they get us.

character: Raj (Sitting against their front door, drinking a beer)
line: Hey, look who decided to show up.
Raj, what are you doing?
I couldn‰Ûªt find you guys so I bought six new friends. Three, sadly, are dead.
Mom, you remember Rajesh? Rajesh, my mother.
Of course. Mrs. Cooper. So nice to see you again.
Well, it‰Ûªs so nice to see you, too. I thought it was our Indians that had the occasional alcohol problem.
We don‰Ûªt say that, either. I‰Ûªll make you a list.
Oh, that would be mighty white of you. So, Raj, what pain are you trying to cover up with alcohol?
Nothing, I‰Ûªm fine.
Are ya?
No. (Bursts into tears)
That‰Ûªs better. Now tell me what‰Ûªs bothering you.
I‰Ûªm so lonely.

Oh, yes, born alone, die alone. It‰Ûªs a tragic human condition. Now, Raj, if you‰Ûªll excuse my mother, she‰Ûªs about to make a pecan pie that‰Ûªll be so good I‰Ûªll almost forget how she blew it with the fried chicken.
Sheldon, your friend is hurtin‰Ûª. What do we do when someone‰Ûªs hurtin‰Ûª?
Offer them a hot beverage.
And when they‰Ûªre drunk as a skunk, what beverage do we offer?
Coffee.

And what do we do it with? (Sheldon fixes a large false smile.) Now you listen to me. I know you feel like you can‰Ûªt find someone, but there‰Ûªs a lock for every key. Back home, there‰Ûªs a girl works at the Wal-Mart. Tall, tall girl. Woman could hunt geese with a rake. Thought she‰Ûªd never find a man, then one day, wouldn‰Ûªt ya know, Harlem Globetrotters come to town. Long story short, today that woman travels the world with a semi-professional basketball player and two beautiful mixed-race babies.
I didn‰Ûªt get a lot of that because of your accent, but the general tone was soothing and somehow I feel better.
I‰Ûªm not going to get my pecan pie, am I?
You want some Oreos?
Double Stuf?
No, regular.
Nice. Kick a man when he‰Ûªs down.
The laundry room.
I‰Ûªm glad we‰Ûªre finally getting to do something together, just the two of us.
Sure. One thing you really miss when you‰Ûªre on vacation is laundry.
Careful, you‰Ûªre using too much Downey. You know if my clothes get too soft it makes me sleepy.
Well, this takes me back. Me doing your laundry, you next to me criticizing.
It is nice, isn‰Ûªt it?
Mrs. Cooper. Hi!
Oh, hello, darlin‰Ûª.
Sheldon, you didn‰Ûªt tell me your mom was coming.
It was in my weekly e-mail blast. Right between beet season is finally here, and uh-oh, red stool from beets leads to cancer scare.
So, how‰Ûªve you been?
Good, good.
I hear that Leonard has a new girlfriend. How are you doing with all that?
Oh, fine. You know, it‰Ûªs been a while. I‰Ûªm getting back out there.
Let me ask you, when you get back out there, are you wearing this? (Holds up a skimpy top)
Well, it‰Ûªs super cute on. That top has paid for itself in free drinks like ten times what it cost.
Yes, Penny has a lot of her money tied up in promiscuity futures.
Hon, you think maybe the reason why you‰Ûªre having trouble finding a guy to settle down with is because you‰Ûªre letting them ride the roller coaster without buying a ticket?

Oh, they don‰Ûªt always get to ride the roller coaster. Sometimes they only get to spin the teacups. Now I‰Ûªm going out tonight. Would it be crazy to ask you to look at the outfit I‰Ûªm going to wear?
Oh, not crazy at all. And don‰Ûªt beat yourself up. When I was your age, you could have me for a car ride and a bottle of strawberry wine.
Now that will not be in this week‰Ûªs e-mail blast.
The apartment.
So, this spring, I get to go to the International Space Station.
Oh, my word, a trip to the heavens. If you ever want to live there eternally, I‰Ûªve got a good book you could read.
Thanks, but I watch the Charlie Brown Christmas special every year, so I get the gist.
I bet your mom is really proud of you.
Nope. She says if I don‰Ûªt back out she‰Ûªs going to go on a hunger strike. It would take years before she‰Ûªd be in any kind of danger, but still.

I‰Ûªve got a treat for us tomorrow, Mom. I‰Ûªm taking you to see Saul Perlmutter give a lecture about his Nobel Prize-winning work in cosmology. And the best part is, at the Q and A afterward, I‰Ûªve worked up a couple of Q‰Ûªs that will stump his sorry A.
I don‰Ûªt know, Shelly. I thought we could do a little sightseeing.
What sight is better than your little boy embarrassing a Nobel laureate?
Come on, Sheldon, we‰Ûªll take your mom to see the Hollywood sign, the wax museum, the Walk of Fame.
Ooh, maybe a little Rodeo Drive.
Well, I can‰Ûªt spend twelve thousand dollars on a handbag, but it‰Ûªs free to look upon those who do with righteous condemnation.
What do you say?
What do I say? I say you people need to stop ruining my mom‰Ûªs visit with your sushi, and your sadness and your slutty shirts. Stop it.
He‰Ûªs not talking about your shirt. Your shirt is fine.
The kitchen.
These are delicious.
The trick to pancakes is bacon grease. I cook everything in it.
Everything? Aren‰Ûªt you worried about your health?
Oh, doctors are always changing their mind. One week bacon grease is bad for you. The next week we‰Ûªre not getting enough of it. Good morning, Shelly.
Mom, I want to apologize for my behaviour last night.
Apology accepted.

Great. Now, you‰Ûªre going to love the Perlmutter lecture. Look, he will be stating that the universe is older than 6,000 years, but I thought you could stick your fingers in your ears and hum Amazing Grace during those parts.
I am still going out with your friends.
But I apologized. And that was hard for me because I didn‰Ûªt do anything wrong.
Shelly, I hung out with you in enough dusty lecture halls while you were growing up. I want to go sightseeing. So why don‰Ûªt you have some pancakes, get dressed and come with us.
I‰Ûªm not going, and you can‰Ûªt make me.
You‰Ûªre right, I can‰Ûªt. Have a nice day.
Well, I‰Ûªm going to stand here until you change your mind.
Well, then you are going to stand there all day.
I‰Ûªm just gonna take my bacon grease and slide over there.
I can‰Ûªt believe my own mother is abandoning me.
I am not abandoning you. Sheldon, abandoning you is leaving you in a basket on a church doorstep. I am going to Hollywood and thank a wax Ronald Reagan for his service to our country.
We appear to be at a crossroads in our relationship, Mother.
Well, I guess we are.
Sorry. Syrup.

All right, Mom. When you‰Ûªre at the Ripley‰Ûªs Believe It Or Not Museum, if they have an exhibit about a mother who threw away a chance to spend the day with the world‰Ûªs most wonderful son, believe it, because it‰Ûªs true. (Grabs pancakes and snatches syrup from Leonard‰Ûªs hand)
I hadn‰Ûªt‰Û_
Amy‰Ûªs apartment.
That lecture was a waste of time. I made more accurate diagrams of the expansion of the early universe on the nursery wall with the contents of my diaper. (Sneezes)
Are you getting sick?
No, I‰Ûªm just allergic to people who get Nobel Prizes for no good reason.
Sheldon, is it possible that your foul mood, or, to use the clinical term, bitchiness, is because your mother isn‰Ûªt making you a priority?
No. Or to use the clinical term, nuh-uh.
Are you sure? The infant-mother pair-bond is the building block of primate psychology.
Oh, there it is. It always comes back to monkeys with you. Just monkeys, monkeys, monkeys.
Sheldon, we‰Ûªre all animals. And granted, there are aspects of you that are extraordinary, but when it comes to emotions and relationships, you‰Ûªre just like everybody else.
Are you trying to suggest that my emotional problems are no different than those of a stupid person?
Actually, some research indicates that by not over-thinking, the less intelligent handle emotions better. (He sneezes again) Sure you‰Ûªre not coming down with a cold?
Oh, yes, the common cold. Just like everyone else. You‰Ûªd love that, wouldn‰Ûªt you?
A church.
Oh, this one‰Ûªs sweet. You know, for your rosary rattlers.
Mrs. Cooper, we say Catholics, not rosary rattlers.
My goodness, it‰Ûªs a wonder you people in California can talk at all.
This is like the worst Hollywood tour ever.
What are you gonna do? She wanted to see churches.
Hey, they have wine here, don‰Ûªt they?
Hey, none of our gods have abs like that.
Yep, that‰Ûªs the last Jew who did sit-ups. And look where it got him.
Hey, while we‰Ûªre here, why don‰Ûªt we all do some praying? Let‰Ûªs put a little church in this church.
Oh, I‰Ûªm not sure we should.

It‰Ûªs easy. I‰Ûªll show you how. Lord, Mary Cooper here. Coming to you from Gomorrah, California. I want to thank you for the blessing that is my little Shelly. I also want to thank you for the continued strength not to coldcock him with my Bible. All right, Penny, your turn.
Okay, um, hey, God. What‰Ûªs up? Um, I‰Ûªm good, but, uh, it would be a big help to my family if you could get my brother to stop cooking meth. But no cops. Be cool.
She also goes a little overboard on the love thy neighbour. Could probably use that chat you had with Mary Magdalene. Leonard, you‰Ûªre up. Wasserman, you‰Ûªre on deck.
Okay. I don‰Ûªt know, it‰Ûªs probably a little late to ask you to make me taller. Oh, um, if you could help out with me and my girlfriend. She‰Ûªs all the way in India. That would be great.
Hear that? Girl trouble. Turns out we were both wrong on that front. How about you?
Oh, me? No. Thanks, I‰Ûªm good. I‰Ûªm really just trying not to burst into flames.
Rajesh?
He says he‰Ûªs having trouble dropping those last five pounds.
Huh, I might have gone with the talking-to-girls thing.
No, you only get one wish.
A park bench. Sheldon is sitting. A stranger sits next to him.

Look at the two of us. Me, a highly regarded physicist. The kind of mind that comes along once, maybe twice in a generation. You, the common man, tired from your labours as a stockbroker, or vacuum cleaner salesman, or bootblack. But deep down inside, apparently we‰Ûªre just two peas in a pod. A regular pea, and the kind of pea that comes along once, maybe twice in a generation. Rain. Another great equalizer. Falling on the head of the brilliant and the unremarkable alike. (The stranger puts up an umbrella) Smarty-pants.
The kitchen.
Oh, Mrs. Cooper, it smells so good.
You take notes, darlin‰Ûª. The real way to get a man is with melted cheese and cream of mushroom soup. He‰Ûªll die at 50 but his love will be true.
I need a tissue.This one got wet.
Here.
Thank you. Yeah, I‰Ûªve learned something today. You and I, in so many ways, other than intelligence and what counts, we‰Ûªre the same. (Sneezes)
Sweetheart, are you sick?
I hope so, because if this is well, life isn‰Ûªt worth living.
Oh, sugarpie, you are burning up. We‰Ûªve got to get you to bed.
Okay.
Don‰Ûªt worry. Mama‰Ûªs here to take care of her baby.
And just to be clear, only her baby and not these other people.
Of course.
Can I have tea with honey and toast with the crust cut off?
You can have whatever you want.
Thanks, Mom.You‰Ûªre the best.
Sheldon‰Ûªs bedroom.
Boy, last time I put VapoRub on you, you didn‰Ûªt have hair on your chest.
I know, it filled in last year. I didn‰Ûªt get to spend a lot of time with you on this visit.
And whose fault was that?
Yours.
Shelly, you‰Ûªre not eight years old any more. We have to have a different relationship.
No, we don‰Ûªt. The one we have works great.
Sweetheart, you are a grown man.
Or maybe I‰Ûªm part of a new species, that lives for hundreds of years, which means I‰Ûªm still basically a toddler.
Oh, I so should have taken you to Houston.
Does this mean you‰Ûªre not going to sing Soft Kitty?
No, I will always sing you Soft Kitty. (Sings) Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur‰Û_
Mrs. Cooper, were we supposed to take that pie out of the oven?
Get out!
Well, that was rude.
Well, I know, but he means well. Sing.
Happy kitty, sleepy kitty‰Û_
What are you trying to pull, Mom? From the top.
This is what I‰Ûªm talking about. (Sings) Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur‰Û_
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.

And reverse the spin on the antiproton, and gamma becomes alpha, multiplied by a matrix of negative I comma zero, and there we have it. Conclusive proof that I am absolutely worthless after nine o‰Ûªclock.
Sheldon, Sheldon.

Hmm. (Looks outside office door. Corridor lamp sparks and goes out. Corridor is bathed in an eerie glow) All right, all right. I see what‰Ûªs going on. A little pre-Halloween hijinkery. A ghostly moan, a rattling of chains, a witch‰Ûªs cackle. The trifecta of haunted house clichÌ©s. Instead of eek, I say yawn.
Sheldon.

Oh, the walls are dripping blood, which looks nothing like a phenolphthalein indicator exposed to a sodium carbonate solution. (Reading message on wall) See you in hell Sheldon. The most frightening thing about that is the missing comma. (A luminous skeleton rushes towards him) Ah. Okay, all right. That one was clever. Skeleton with phosphorous on a zip line. Come on out, merry pranksters. Take a bow.
You should‰Ûªve seen your face.
Yes, there‰Ûªs nothing quite like the slightly widened eyes of mildly startled.
Come on, admit it. We got you, Sheldon.

Please, fright depends on an element of surprise. The simple fact is, because I am much smarter than you, and able to anticipate your actions, it is highly unlikely that you two rubes could ever surprise me. (Leonard creeps out behind him wearing a Star Trek Balok mask)
He‰Ûªs probably right.
We can‰Ûªt beat him. He‰Ûªs just too smart.
Gentlemen. (Turns and sees Leonard. Screams and faints).
Who had money on faints?
I had pee his pants.
Hang on. Looks like everyone‰Ûªs a winner.
The comic book store.
Oh. Watch out, Sheldon. This little boy Casper is a g-g-g-ghost!
Droll.
Not as droll as a grown man passed out in a puddle of his own urine.
That was pretty droll. With a hint of ammonia.

Yes, enjoy your japes, gentlemen. You think you‰Ûªve poked fun at a milquetoast academic. Well, you‰Ûªve forgotten one thing. I am also a son of the Lone Star state. I‰Ûªm Texas through and through. And we know how to settle scores down there. If you doubt me, ask Mexico.
Hot girl, nine o‰Ûªclock. Don‰Ûªt everybody look at once!
What is she doing in a comic book store?
I don‰Ûªt know, she might be lost. Doesn‰Ûªt matter. Watch and learn. Hi.
Hi.
Um‰Û_ it-it-it‰Û_ (returns to guys) Shut up.
Are you getting this Next Men?
Uh, yeah. It‰Ûªs issue number 21. First appearance of Hellboy.
I know. I‰Ûªve been looking for it for years.
Sorry.
Hey, if I pretended to hit on you, could I distract you enough to sneak it away?
Yes, but you‰Ûªd be using your superpowers for evil.
Damn, I‰Ûªm forbidden by my Kryptonian father to do so. I am Alice.
Leonard.
You are very cute, Leonard.
Thanks. You, too. You know, go ahead and take it.
No, no. No, no, I, I, I did evil. Would you be open to a trade?
Uh, yeah, yeah, sure, I guess.
Okay. Here. This is my number, call me.
Sorry, palm‰Ûªs a little sweaty. What‰Ûªs that word?
Alice.
Oh, right, your name. That makes more sense than penis.
Later.
Did we just see you pick up a girl in a comic book store?
‰Û÷Cause if you did, you get your picture up there on the Wall of Heroes.
No, I don‰Ûªt think I picked her up. Besides, I have a girlfriend.
Doesn‰Ûªt matter. This is the closest anyone‰Ûªs ever come. You‰Ûªre going on the wall, my friend.
Entering the apartment building.
Be sure to check the mail.
How many times are you gonna tell me? What‰Ûªs with you?
Nothing. It‰Ûªs not suspicious that I‰Ûªm fixating. It‰Ûªs consistent with my personality.
Right.
Hey, guys.
More Halloween candy? Didn‰Ûªt you just buy a bunch of it yesterday?
Oh. Yeah. That‰Ûªs gone. It‰Ûªs a rough month when Halloween and PMS hit at the same time.
Leonard doesn‰Ûªt have time to chat, he has to get the mail.
Will you relax? I‰Ûªll get it in a minute. Hey, how was work?
Open the mail!
Excuse me. (Sheldon holds fingers in ears) A couple of circulars, nothing important.
What‰Ûªs with him?
Hang on. (Sheldon opens mail box. A loud horn blows and a balloon with Leonard‰Ûªs face on pops out. Sheldon faints again.) You might be from Texas, but I‰Ûªm from New Jersey.
The apartment. Leonard is with Alice.
Check it out. Jim Lee drew this of me two years ago at Comic Con.
What are you wearing?
Well, you know, it‰Ûªs Comic Con. I‰Ûªm Lion-O from ThunderCats.
Wow, you must have gotten so laid.
No. But Jessica Alba did rub my furry belly.
Want to see a comic I draw?
You‰Ûªre kidding. You have your own book?
Yeah. It‰Ûªs kinda based on my life.
Cool. Oh, look. That‰Ûªs you having sex with a guy in the top half of a Chewbacca costume. Comic Con?
You‰Ûªd think, but no.
You‰Ûªre very talented. This is really good. Did you do‰Û_ (she kisses him.)
So, can I trade you my comic for the Hellboy?
You can have my car.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.

character: Sheldon (creeps into office carrying a box)
line: Oh, dear. (Reaches into box, picks up a snake) Oh, dear. (Puts snake into Raj‰Ûªs top drawer) Oh, dear, oh, dear. Oh, dear, oh, dear. Oh, dear. Oh, dear. Purell, Purell, Purell, Purell.
Good morning, Sheldon.
It is, isn‰Ûªt it? Oh, bother. Isn‰Ûªt that just always the way? You go to staple something, and you‰Ûªre out of staples. Gosh, I wish I‰Ûªd known that earlier today when I was at Staples.
You have a thing of paper clips right there.
well, no, no, I need something more permanent to join these papers. Say, don‰Ûªt you keep staples in your top desk drawer?
I don‰Ûªt know. Maybe.
Be a lamb and check.
All right. (Opening drawer) Who do we have here?
It‰Ûªs a snake. A terrifying snake.
Oh, did some bad man put us in a drawer?
Stop talking like that. You‰Ûªve been rendered speechless by fear.
Let‰Ûªs go to the biology lab and find you some nice yummy mice.
I tried to scare an Indian with a snake. Come on, Cooper. You‰Ûªre better than this.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. There is a knock.
It‰Ûªs open.
Hey, you got a minute?
Yeah, sure, come on in.
Thanks.
Want some mac and cheese?
No. Lactose. Gas.
Glass of wine?
No. Sulfites. Migraines.
Okay, well, I‰Ûªd offer you Halloween candy, but that‰Ûªs gone. So, what‰Ûªs up?
Okay, we used to go out, right?
Oh, my God, that‰Ûªs where I know you from.
I‰Ûªm dealing with a situation and it‰Ûªs kind of about my love life, so I know that might be weird for us to talk about, but in this area, as you know, all my other friends are just so stupid.
All right, what‰Ûªs going on?
So, you‰Ûªre okay talking about this?
Yes.
You‰Ûªre sure it‰Ûªs not weird.
It‰Ûªs okay.
You know what, if you ever want to talk to me about a problem in your life with a guy, then I would be fine with that.
Okay, good, because there‰Ûªs this one guy I used to date who‰Ûªs about to be force-fed wine and cheese if he doesn‰Ûªt get to the point.
Okay, uh, here it is. Is it cheating if a guy has a girlfriend‰Û_
Yeah, probably.
Come on.
I‰Ûªm sorry, go ahead.
I met this girl, and she‰Ûªs great. We have a lot in common.
Did you guys do it?
No. We just made out a little.
Oh, look at you, you bad boy. Did you tell her about Priya?
Well, I was gonna, but there were too many tongues in my mouth.
That‰Ûªs gross.
Here‰Ûªs the thing, I, I‰Ûªm not one of those guys who sneaks around and sleeps with more than one woman.
Well, good for you.
The problem is, I want to be one of those guys.
So sleep with the new girl and lie to Priya.
Oh, that‰Ûªs not who I am.
All right, then break it off with the new girl.
Now, let‰Ûªs not do anything rash. She‰Ûªs really hot.
If you like this girl so much, why don‰Ûªt you just end things with Priya?
Priya and I are in love. I think we could get married someday.
Leonard, you‰Ûªre looking for a way to sleep with both women and have everybody be happy about it.
Now we‰Ûªre getting somewhere.
What does your gut tell you?
Go ask Penny; she‰Ûªll know what to do.
The apartment. Sheldon is adjusting a device on his arm.
Hello, Howard. I‰Ûªve realized that you scaring me was all in jest. Allow me to say, job well done. (Grabs his own hand. Electrocutes himself.) Perfect.
What are you doing?
Science. You wouldn‰Ûªt understand.
Hey, well, see you. I‰Ûªm going out. (Starts to go out. Doesn‰Ûªt.)
I thought you were leaving the apartment.
Yeah, me, too. I can‰Ûªt make up my mind.
Are you concerned because the world is filled with big dogs and bullies?
No. I‰Ûªm having a moral crisis.
Well, if it‰Ûªs of any help, I‰Ûªve read all the great moral philosophers, including Dr. Seuss.
Oh, what the hell. I‰Ûªm supposed to go see that girl from the comic book store, Alice, but I don‰Ûªt know if I should, because I‰Ûªm going out with Priya, but she‰Ûªs in India.
All right. So the topic at hand is sexual fidelity. Probably won‰Ûªt be relying on Seuss here. Although One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish might be surprisingly applicable. Go on.
Well, they say at the end of your life, you regret the stuff you didn‰Ûªt do more than the stuff that you did, and I‰Ûªm pretty sure Alice is the stuff I want to do.
You know, the German philosopher, Friedrich Nietzsche, believed that morality is just a fiction used by the herd of inferior human beings to hold back the few superior men.
That actually does help.
It‰Ûªs worth noting that he died of syphilis.
Screw it, I‰Ûªm going.
On your way home, will you pick up some orange juice?
Do you mind? I‰Ûªm questioning a lot of things in my life right now.
Is one of those things your fondness for orange juice?
No.
Great. Tropicana, no pulp.
Howard‰Ûªs house. Sheldon rings the doorbell.
Hey, Sheldon.
Who is it?
It‰Ûªs me, Sheldon, Mrs. Wolowitz.
That‰Ûªs not my mom, it‰Ûªs Bernadette.
Really? That‰Ûªs very unsettling.
Hi, Sheldon.
Hi.
What‰Ûªs up?

It just occurred to me that I never formally congratulated you on your pending nuptials. So I hopped on the first bus and hightailed it down here to shake your hand. Put ‰Û÷er there, you old so-and-so.
Well, I, I‰Ûªm gonna see you at work in 12 hours, don‰Ûªt you think it could have waited until then?
Holy smoke, why didn‰Ûªt I think of that? You‰Ûªre a better man than I, Howard Wolowitz. You put ‰Û÷er there, you son of a gun!
Whatever. (Takes his hand. Starts to be electrocuted) My‰Û_ oh‰Û_ it‰Ûªs‰Û_ (Clutches heart and collapses)
Oh, my God, Howard! What did you do?
It was a harmless Halloween prank. Look.
Howard has a heart condition! You know that!
Well, I thought he made that up. Isn‰Ûªt hypochondria a common idiosyncrasy of Jewish people?
This is adrenaline, we‰Ûªre gonna have to inject it into his heart.
We are?
You are. I‰Ûªm not strong enough to get it through his chest plate, and we‰Ûªve only got one shot.
Oh, no! I can‰Ûªt!
Hurry! We‰Ûªre running out of time!
Okay.
Just do it!
Oh, God! One, two, three!
Trick or treat, bubbeleh.
What? No. You mean this was all a ruse? Oh, how could I be so stu‰Û_ (puts hand to forehead. Electrocutes himself).
Alice‰Ûªs apartment. Alice and Leonard are kissing.
Damn it, I can‰Ûªt. I can‰Ûªt, I can‰Ûªt do this.
Uh, is it my tongue stud? ‰Û÷Cause if that freaks you out, you‰Ûªre in for a real surprise later on.
No, no, no. I, I can‰Ûªt do this. Believe me, I really want to.
But?
But I kind of have a girlfriend.
Are you kidding?
You‰Ûªre cool with you and me just being friends, right?
I don‰Ûªt believe this.
Wait, I don‰Ûªt, which part?
I‰Ûªm so stupid. I thought for once I‰Ûªd met a good guy, but you‰Ûªre just another jackass.

Oh, no, no, you have it wrong. No. I, I was going to be a jackass, but I stopped myself. I stayed a good guy, so, I‰Ûªm gonna pass on the sex. But you should know, that‰Ûªs not a comment on your hotness but on my goodness. That‰Ûªs kind of my superpower. I‰Ûªm, like, Captain Good Guy.
Leonard being ejected into the corridor.
It‰Ûªs okay. Did the right thing. You idiot!
The apartment. Leonard is on skype.
Hey, Priya.
Hey, sweetheart. How‰Ûªs it going?
Uh, not so good. We have to talk.
Oh, sounds serious. What‰Ûªs up?
Okay, uh, here it is. I met this girl and I kissed her, and I feel terrible about it. But it‰Ûªs done, it‰Ûªs never gonna happen again. And I am so, so sorry.
Leonard, relax. It‰Ûªs okay.
It is?
Yeah, these things happen. They happen to everybody.
Oh, my God, you are amazing. I mean, I don‰Ûªt deserve you. Wh, what do, what do you mean everybody?
Leonard, I didn‰Ûªt know if I should tell you, but I kind of cheated on you, too.
Uh, kind of?
A couple of weeks ago, I slept with my ex-boyfriend. So, I guess we both messed up a little.
No, no, I messed up a little. You messed up a lot.
Well, it‰Ûªs not a competition.
Oh yeah, it is, and you won. I, I, I‰Ûªm, I‰Ûªm sorry, I have to go. I don‰Ûªt believe this.

character: Sheldon (leaping out of the base of the sofa)
line: Bazinga, punk. Now we‰Ûªre even.
The apartment.
So, Bernadette, how goes the hunt for bridesmaid dresses?
Well, if you don‰Ûªt mind looking like an orange traffic cone, great.
Girlfriends, I have the answer to our dress problems.
Really?
Twelve years ago, my cousin Irene and her entire family died in a horrific carbon monoxide accident the night before her wedding.
That‰Ûªs horrible.

Yes and no. All those bridesmaids dresses remain unused and available to us for free. So it seems that cloud of odourless deadly gas had a silver lining after all. Check it out, still in the bags. The gowns, not the bridesmaids.
I don‰Ûªt know. Dead people‰Ûªs dresses?
Yeah, and cap sleeves? U-u-uh.
Uh, I was hoping you wouldn‰Ûªt notice. Irene was always a slave to a good bargain when it came to clothes, and sadly as it turned out, space heaters.

Ladies, please. These four walls once housed an intellectual salon where the mind received nourishment as well as the stomach. But through no one‰Ûªs fault, Penny, the quality of dinner conversation in this apartment has declined. And again, I‰Ûªm looking at no one in particular, Penny.
Fine. What would you like to talk about, Sheldon?
What would you like to talk about, Sheldon? Why do you hate us?
I‰Ûªve prepared a number of topics that should appeal to both the advanced and novice conversationalists.
Okay, that time you looked at me.
Who didn‰Ûªt? Your skin is like alabaster. Do you even have pores?
Topic one. Faster-than-light particles at CERN, paradigm-shifting discovery or another Swiss export as full of holes as their cheese? And converse.
All right, who wants to go to my apartment and look at bridal magazines?
Oh, me.
Through no one‰Ûªs fault, Sheldon, we‰Ûªre leaving.
Wait for moi.
You‰Ûªre leaving?
Sheldon, sometimes you forget, I‰Ûªm a lady. And with that comes an oestrogen fuelled need to page through thick glossy magazines that make me hate my body.
Ah. New topic. Women, delightfully mysterious or bat-crap crazy?
Totally. What‰Ûªs wrong with cap sleeves? If you have the right figure for it, they‰Ûªre adorable.
The cafeteria.
Hey, Amy, what brings you to our neck of the woods?
Your neurology department loaned me a culture of prions for my research on bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
She popped by to borrow a cup of mad cow disease.
It‰Ûªs hard to make degenerative brain maladies hilarious, and yet somehow you do it.
That‰Ûªs fun to have in a lunchroom.
The real fun starts when you get to pick the rat you‰Ûªre going to feed it to, and maybe you choose the beady-eyed little mother who‰Ûªs been biting you all week.
Please, we‰Ûªre eating. Can we get that off the table and change the subject?
Can we? Stand back while I turn this conversation into a conver-sensation.
This time, it‰Ûªs your fault.
I have 100 alphabetized topics from artichoke, come on, people, it‰Ûªs just a giant thistle, to zzz, the onamona-poetry of sleep.
Amy, how long would it take for that mad cow disease to kill me?
I don‰Ûªt know, four or five years.
No, it‰Ûªs not gonna do it.
Oy. Bernadette keeps texting me pictures of Penny in bridesmaid dresses.
They‰Ûªre out shopping right now?
Yeah.
Just the two of them?
I guess.
That‰Ûªs cool, that‰Ûªs cool.
Why are they asking me about this stuff? What guy knows what a sweetheart neckline is? (Raj raises his hand)
The apartment. Leonard is horseracing on a Kinnect game.

Leonard‰Ûªs coming down the home stretch! Come on, horsey, you can do this! Damn. Come on, thigh muscles, you can do this! Yes! First place. I would have been a great jockey if I weren‰Ûªt too tall. And scared of horses. Sheldon, you‰Ûªre up.
What?
Come on, it‰Ûªs your turn. We said we‰Ûªd get more fresh air.
Sorry. I‰Ûªm a little distracted. I can‰Ûªt seem to get in touch with Amy. I tried e-mail, video chat, tweeting her, posting on her Facebook wall, texting her, nothing.
Did you try calling her on the telephone?
The telephone. You know, Leonard, in your own simple way, you may be the wisest of us all. Voice mail. Curiouser and curiouser.
If you‰Ûªre worried, we can go over there and see if she‰Ûªs all right.
Okay. You know, I heard in the news a bobcat has been spotted in her neighbourhood.
I don‰Ûªt think Amy was eaten by a bobcat.
Who thinks Amy was eaten by a bobcat?
You do?
Leonard, I was just mentioning an interesting local news item. Now, thanks to you, I‰Ûªm worried Amy‰Ûªs been eaten by a bobcat.
Forget about the bobcat.
How can I? You won‰Ûªt stop talking about it.
Amy‰Ûªs apartment. Amy is playing the harp.
Everybody hurts, sometimes everybody cries. Everybody hurts, sometimes.
She sounds weepy. I don‰Ûªt like weepy. Let‰Ûªs go.
Uh, she‰Ûªs your friend. Step up.
(Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Bye.
Where are you going?
I‰Ûªm single, I don‰Ûªt need this crap.
Sheldon, what are you doing here?
You didn‰Ûªt respond to any of my electronic communications.
I wanted to be alone.
Would you like to talk about it? And keep in mind that no is a perfectly viable answer.
Sheldon, my world is crumbling around me.

Point of order. As you‰Ûªre in distress, it would be customary for me to offer you a hot beverage. But I‰Ûªm a guest in your home, so it would be customary for you to offer me a beverage. How do you want to proceed vis-a-vis beverages?
It doesn‰Ûªt matter. Nothing matters.
If you‰Ûªd like to take your mind off what‰Ûªs troubling you, uh, word on the street is a bobcat has been spotted.
Penny and Bernadette went shopping for bridesmaids dresses without me.
And that made you feel sad?
Yes.
I knew it. Just keep going, I guess I‰Ûªm good at this.
It‰Ûªs just, I thought they liked hanging out with me, but I guess I was fooling myself.
When they were over here, did you fail to offer them a beverage? ‰Û÷Cause I can see how that could stick in someone‰Ûªs craw.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm going to ask you something, and I‰Ûªd like you to keep an open mind.
Always.
At this moment, I find myself craving human intimacy and physical contact.
Oh, boy. You know ours is a relationship of the mind.
Proposal. One wild night of torrid lovemaking that soothes my soul and inflames my loins.
Counterproposal. I will gently stroke your head and repeat, aw, who‰Ûªs a good Amy.
How about this? French kissing, seven minutes in heaven culminating in second base.
Neck massage, then you get me that beverage.
We cuddle. Final offer.
Very well. Oh, boy. (They cuddle, awkwardly.)
I‰Ûªm just saying, second base is right there.
The cafeteria.
Mm, I‰Ûªm thinking about adopting some quirky affectation, like a pipe or a monocle or a handlebar moustache.
For all those girls out there looking for the Indian Monopoly man?
This is not a safe place. You can‰Ûªt share anything here.
The two of you need to get your women in line!
What?

Last night I was strong-armed into an evening of harp music and spooning with an emotional Amy Farrah Fowler. This on a night that I had originally designated for solving the space-time geometry in higher-spin gravity and building my Lego Death Star. And why? Your gal pals, Penny and Bernadette, went out shopping for some wedding nonsense without Amy, an action they took with no thought or regard as to how it would affect me, the future of string theory or my Lego fun time.
What do you want us to do about it?
You clearly weren‰Ûªt listening to my topic sentence, get your women in line! You make them apologize to Amy and set things right. I am a man of science, not someone‰Ûªs snuggle bunny!
Why do I have to talk to Penny? She‰Ûªs not my girlfriend.
You invited her to lunch four years ago. Everything about her is on you, you make it so!
The apartment.
Moo-shu is Penny.
Thank you. Where‰Ûªs Sheldon?
Oh, he was up late last night, so I gave him an early dinner and put him to bed.
That‰Ûªs so sweet.
Yeah, but now he‰Ûªs gonna be up at dawn and want to play.
So, listen, guys, the reason he was up late is because he was taking care of Amy. She‰Ûªs kind of upset.
Why?
Her feelings got hurt because you guys went dress shopping without her.
I told you that would happen.
Okay, look, this is her first time being a bridesmaid and she‰Ûªs just getting a little crazy with it.
She keeps on telling us stories about bridesmaid traditions in other cultures, and they‰Ûªre all about getting naked and washing each other.
Yeah, and she keeps trying to figure out if our cycles have synced up so we can call ourselves the Three Menstra-teers
We thought it would be easier to look at dresses one time without her. I feel terrible.
I know. Me, too. We‰Ûªll talk to her. Hey, wait, how did she find out?
Raj did it. And he says he would do it again. Okay, I‰Ûªm sorry. You sent me the picture, I wasn‰Ûªt thinking.
Oh, Howie.
Well, hey, I‰Ûªm usually pretty good at not blabbing. You tell me tons of stuff about these guys, and I never repeat it.
What do you tell him?
Oh, you know, just pillow talk. You guys have nothing to worry about.
Hold on, did you talk about us when we were dating?
No. All your little secrets are fine.
Yes, absolutely fine.
I‰Ûªll tell you later.
Amy‰Ûªs lab. Amy is dissecting a brain.
Come on, tumour. Come on, tumour, Mama needs an aggressive little glioblastoma. Yay, brain tumour! Probably not the same reaction you had when you got the news.
Hi.
Hello.
What are you doing here?
Well, look, we just wanted to apologize for not bringing you with us the other day.
That‰Ûªs not necessary, it‰Ûªs like Sesame Street says, one of these things is not like the other, one of these things should die alone.
Look, come on, Amy, look, let us make it up to you. We‰Ûªll have a girl‰Ûªs night, we‰Ûªll do whatever you want.
We can go down to the Korean baths and do that thing you were talking about where we wash each other.
With-with loofah mitts, no hands.
It‰Ûªs okay. I‰Ûªm glad this happened. I can stop pretending that some beautiful girl and her cute-in-
Amy, we‰Ûªre really sorry.
Yeah, we feel awful.

Don‰Ûªt. I‰Ûªll be okay. You‰Ûªre not the first girls I thought were friends with me who ended up shunning me. It‰Ûªs like elementary school, junior high, high school, undergrad, grad school, and that semester abroad in Norway all over again.
Oh, come on, Amy.
You don‰Ûªt get it. Look at this brain.
I don‰Ûªt really want to.

This is us. Bernadette, you are the analytical, scientific left hemisphere. Penny, you‰Ûªre the creative, spontaneous right hemisphere. And where‰Ûªs Amy? She‰Ûªs right here, the sad little tumour no one wants to go dress shopping with.
Amy, you‰Ûªre not a tumour. Penny, tell her she‰Ûªs not a tumour. (Penny is vomiting in the dustbin).
The apartment, Sheldon is building his Lego Death Star. Phone rings.

Did you know that when Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone, he proposed answering it with ahoy? Ahoy. I like it. Amy? Is that you? Have you been drinking? I‰Ûªm sorry, I bet my sweet what? Well, all right. We‰Ûªre on our way.
What‰Ûªs going on?
It would seem Amy is drunk in a liquor store parking lot.
Really? Amy?
Leonard, be glad you can‰Ûªt keep a woman. They are a handful.
A liquor store parking lot.
Oh, look. It‰Ûªs Sheldon and little Leonard. Hi, little Leonard.
Hi, Amy.
Hey, Cuddles.
Cuddles?
Yes, Cuddles. We cuddled. Grow up, Leonard.
Amy, what are you doing here?
Well, I came here to get a bottle of wine like Penny taught me to do when you‰Ûªre sad.
Yeah, but why didn‰Ûªt you go back to your apartment?
Didn‰Ûªt you go to high school, Leonard? Parking lots are where all the cool kids hang out. Not that the rat bastards ever invited me.
Maybe we should get you home.
Oh, hang on, hang on, hang on. Sheldon, what would it take for you to go into that liquor store, buy a bottle of hooch, take me across the street to that motel, and have your way with me?
Yeah, Sheldon, what would it take?
I‰Ûªm begging both of you, please, let‰Ûªs go.
Okay. Come on. Upsy-daisy.
Whee! Ooh, finally someone found second base.
Amy‰Ûªs lab. She is dissecting a brain.
I know how you feel. I got a knife slicing through my frontal lobe, too.
Hi.
What do you want? Do you want me to give the friendship bracelet back?
I never gave you a friendship bracelet.
When we first met, I made one and pretended you gave it to me. You can have it back if you want.
No, you made that for you, I want you to have it.
We know you‰Ûªre upset, and you have every right to be, but if it‰Ûªs okay with you, we‰Ûªd like a second chance to make things right.
We are really sorry, and we were trying to think of some way to show you how much we care about you.
Which is why it would mean so much if you would agree to be the maid of honour at my wedding.
What? Wait, is this some kind of practical joke? Like in Norway, when my friends trapped me in a sauna with a horny otter?
No. I, I want you to be the maid of honour.
Oh, my gosh. No one‰Ûªs every asked me to be the maid of honour before. Well, that‰Ûªs not true. Once, but then they all died.
So is that a yes?

Yes. Yes. Oh, my gosh, I, I have so much to do. There‰Ûªs the bridal shower and the bachelorette party. What should we do for the bachelorette party? Oh, I know, we‰Ûªll go to a Native American sweat lodge, we‰Ûªll take peyote, roll around in the mud, and paint fertility symbols on Bernadette‰Ûªs naked body. So that‰Ûªs happening.
Yeah, sure, sure. Vegas is fun, too.
I feel like crying. Of course, I could just be hormonal. Oh, wait. Maybe our menses are finally syncing up. Bernadette? No? Penny?
Sorry.
Really?
Okay, yeah.
Yay!
A bridal store.
Maid of honour Amy Farrah Fowler‰Ûªs amazing behind-the-scenes wedding video, take one.
We‰Ûªre just trying on dresses, do we really need to record this?
I‰Ûªm sorry, are you the maid of honour?
I am the bride.
So no. And action.
What do you think?
I love it!
What are you, a nun? Come on, bestie, let‰Ûªs see some skin.
Oh, Amy! Looking sexy!
You think they don‰Ûªt have mirrors in there? I know how I look.
Oh! Bernadette, you look beautiful!
You do.
Thank you.
Not Penny beautiful, but beautiful.
Come on, bestie, you‰Ûªre up.
Give me a minute.
What is taking you so long? (Opens door. Penny is in her underwear)
Oh, Amy! Get the hell out of here!
‰ÛÒ Sorry, sorry. (Swings camera away. Then back again)
Oh, God. Amy!
Sorry.
The lobby.
Hey.
Oh, hey. You work the lunch shift?
Yeah. I‰Ûªve got eight pounds of salmon that‰Ûªs about to go bad. Do you know how to cook it?
Not really.
Damn it. Should have liberated the iffy chicken. What are you and Professor Fussyface up to tonight?
Star Wars on Blu-ray.
Haven‰Ûªt you seen that movie, like, a thousand times?
Not on Blu-ray. Only twice on Blu-ray.
Oh, Leonard.
I know, it‰Ûªs high-resolution sadness.
Well, I‰Ûªm going to take myself out to a movie tonight. You want to go?
Really? Do we do that?
What do you mean?
You know, we haven‰Ûªt spent time alone together since we broke up.
Oh, it‰Ûªs not a date, Leonard. It‰Ûªs just a man and a woman hanging out, and not having sex at the end of the night.
Sounds like most of my dates.

character: Sheldon (off, voice heard through apartment door as they approach)
line: Oh, dear Lord, get away from me, you monster!
What is that about?
Well, he‰Ûªs smart and crazy enough, he may have actually created a monster. (They enter. Sheldon is by the window.)
Shoo, shoo! Be gone!
What the hell is going on?
There‰Ûªs a bird outside the window, and he won‰Ûªt go away. That is the hell that is going on. We have no worms or seeds here. Shoo, shoo.
Really? On top of everything else, you‰Ûªre afraid of birds?

It‰Ûªs called ornithophobia. And someday it will be recognized as a true disability, and the landlord will be required by law to put a giant net over the building. Which is unfortunate, because I have a fear of nets.
So movies, yes or no?
Movies, yes.
Great. I‰Ûªll see you later. And remember, he‰Ûªs more afraid of you than you are of him.
That doesn‰Ûªt help.
No, I was talking to the bird.
(Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird. (Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird. (Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird.
Sheldon, just ignore him.

Good idea. Attention is what birds want. (Pulls curtain) Oh, much better. All right. Now I‰Ûªll just get along with my life. (Bird squawks) Make a pot of tea, Leonard. It‰Ûªs going to be a long night.
The apartment.Sheldon is trying to scare the bird away making cat noises.
The bird‰Ûªs still there?
Quick, what does a hawk sound like?
I don‰Ûªt know. Scree-scree.
Please, that‰Ûªs a seagull. If you‰Ûªre not going to help, don‰Ûªt help.
Sorry. Do you think I‰Ûªm overdressed?
It depends on the activity. For a prostate exam, yes. If you‰Ûªre playing Vegas, I‰Ûªd add sequins.
I‰Ûªm going to the movies with Penny. I don‰Ûªt want her to think that I think it‰Ûªs a date.
Do you think it‰Ûªs a date?
No, but she might think I think it‰Ûªs a date even though I don‰Ûªt.
Or you might think she thinks you think it‰Ûªs a date even though she doesn‰Ûªt.
Are we overthinking this?
Not at all.
You‰Ûªre right. I‰Ûªm fine. I‰Ûªm wearing this.

Really? A blazer? All right. (Leonard takes off blazer and heads back to his room. Sheldon dials phone) Yes, hello. This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Yeah, I‰Ûªm at 2311 North Robles Avenue. Yeah, I‰Ûªd like to report a dangerous wild animal. A blue jay. I‰Ûªm sorry, this is Animal Control. I don‰Ûªt understand the laughter. No, the bird is not in my home. If he was in my home, I obviously would have called 911. Sir, I have no doubt that there are things that you‰Ûªre frightened of. Being stuck in a dead-end public service job? Or your wife stepping out on you because you‰Ûªre stuck in a dead-end public service job? Or spiders? Don‰Ûªt you think I tried making cat noises?

character: Leonard (returning in a tee shirt and backwards cap)
line: Too casual?

For an audience with the queen, yes. For an evening of passing a bottle of fortified wine around a flaming trash can, you look great. (Leonard leaves again. Sheldon draws a picture of a cats face and returns to making cat noises at the window.) What am I thinking? Whiskers!
The cinema.
Oh, hey, if we hurry, we can make the new Jennifer Aniston movie.
Oh, yeah, sure. There‰Ûªs also an amazing documentary about building a dam on river in South America.
Okay, but the Jennifer Aniston movie has Jennifer Aniston, and she‰Ûªs not building a dam.
Can‰Ûªt argue with that. I‰Ûªll get the tickets.
Okay.
Actually, you know what? I think it‰Ûªs about time I pick a movie we see.
You pick plenty of movies.
No. You always picked, and it was always the same. An hour and a half of beach houses in the rain until the woman turns around and realizes love was here all along.
But come on, that is a great movie, and it starts in ten minutes.
I hate those movies.
No, you don‰Ûªt.
Yes, I do. The only reason I went is because you wanted to see them, and I wanted to have sex. To this day, I can‰Ûªt see a Sandra Bullock movie poster without getting both bored and aroused.
Okay, so while we were going out, how often would you pretend to like things just to have sex with me?
All the time.
You‰Ûªre kidding.
Does this sound familiar? I‰Ûªd love to go shoe shopping with you. Hiking? It‰Ûªs great. It‰Ûªs two a.m., of course I want to go to Korea Town and sing karaoke with your friends. Who wouldn‰Ûªt?
Okay, we were going out. You were going to get sex anyway.
Really? You would have slept with me after a three-hour documentary on dams?
No. No woman would.

See? Now, that‰Ûªs the great thing. We‰Ûªre out as friends. This is not a date. Sex is off the table. So, let‰Ûªs go learn why hydroelectric power might not be the environmental bargain you think it is. Sorry. Spoiler alert.
All right, fine.
Thanks. Tickets are eleven bucks. Not a date.
The apartment.
Come on, Sheldon, Star Wars.
I‰Ûªm pushing play.
A minute.
If we don‰Ûªt start soon, George Lucas is going to change it again.
This would go a lot faster if you put your trade school diploma to work and helped me set up this high frequency tone generator.
I have a Masters degree from M.I.T.
Yeah, but you‰Ûªve got a can-do attitude and that‰Ûªs what‰Ûªs important.
I really don‰Ûªt get your problem with birds.
The question you should be asking is what is their problem with me? My first memory, a hummingbird dive-bombing my stroller to get at the apple juice in my sippy cup.
Hummingbirds are pretty.
Hummingbirds are the vampires of the flower world.
Still my first choice for an ankle tattoo. Or a dolphin, I go back and forth.
Age seven, a blood-thirsty chicken chases me up a tree. Age twelve, a magpie tries to steal the retainer out of my mouth. Age sixteen, a parrot in a pet store called me fat ass. Need I go on?
Yes, please. This is way better than the movie.
All right, Sheldon, your bird death ray is ready.

It‰Ûªs not a death ray. It‰Ûªs just a little ultrasonic blast to scare him off. Trust me, if I had a death ray, I wouldn‰Ûªt be living here. I‰Ûªd be in my lair enjoying the money the people of Earth gave me for not using my death ray. All right, and in three, two, one. (Switches on. All the windows shatter. The bird doesn‰Ûªt move.)
That is one tough birdie.
A bar.
Come on, you enjoyed the movie. I saw you tearing up when the village got flooded, and everyone had to relocate.
No, I was thinking how come they get to leave and I can‰Ûªt.
I‰Ûªm going to get some fries. You want anything?
Uh, no, thanks.
Are you sure? Because you always say no, and then you eat half my fries.
I just eat the little crispy ones you don‰Ûªt like.
No, I love them. I save them for the end, but they‰Ûªre gone because you ate them. And why did I let you eat them?
To get sex.
Exactly. But this is not a date. So I ask again, would you like anything?
All right, I‰Ûªd like an order of fries.
Great. That‰Ûªll be five dollars. I am having the best time. I‰Ûªm so glad you suggested we do this.

character: Penny (accidentally nudging the man sitting behind her)
line: Oh, sorry.
No problem.
What you writing there?
A screenplay. Its about a guy whose roommate is having sex and tells him go to a bar and work on his screenplay.
It‰Ûªs a working title.
Oh.
I‰Ûªm Kevin.
Oh. Penny. Nice to meet you.
I‰Ûªll let you get back to your date.
Oh, no, no. This isn‰Ûªt a date, no. Right?
Uh, right.
So have you written anything I might have seen?
That depends. How much time do you spend on Yelp?
The apartment.

This is ridiculous. I‰Ûªm a grown man from Texas. This isn‰Ûªt a terrifying bird like a swan or a goose. It‰Ûªs just a blue jay. (Opens window) That‰Ûªs a pretty big blue jay. (Closes window. Goes to cabinet. Comes out wearing a Boba Fett helmet and a broom) One, two, three. (Opens window) Go! Shoo! Am-scray, ird-bay! (Bird flies in window) Bird in the apartment! Bird in the apartment! (Sees the bird sitting in his place) No!
The bar.
So it is an amazing documentary. They need the electricity from the dam, but at the same time they want to preserve the environment.
You‰Ûªre kidding me. Uh, can I see you for a sec over here?
Oh, yeah. Sure. Just one sec?
No problem.
What‰Ûªs up?
I know what you‰Ûªre doing.
What am I doing?
You‰Ûªre going out of your way to talk to that guy because I said we weren‰Ûªt on a date.
No, I‰Ûªm talking to him because he‰Ûªs cute.
Come on, he‰Ûªs not that cute.
Yes, he is. With his dorky T-shirt and his little hipster glasses.
I wear dorky T-shirts and glasses.
Yes, but when you‰Ûªre tall and have great cheekbones, you‰Ûªre doing it ironically.
If that‰Ûªs so, what if I start talking to a girl?
You should.
I‰Ûªm serious. I‰Ûªll do it.
Good! Go! There are some girls right over there. What are you waiting for?
They‰Ûªre in a group. I‰Ûªm scared.
The apartment.
Sheldon, what do you expect us to do?

Look how sweet he is. Come over and say hi. Come on. You can do it. Don‰Ûªt be scared. Come on. Oh, just pet the bird, you big baby!
I did it! I actually did it. Okay, now flush him.
The bar.

Laura.

Laura.

When you were telling Kevin about your acting career, did you mention your long-running role as Waitress in a local production of The Cheesecake Factory?
Did you tell her about your lucky asthma inhaler?
Oh, yeah? Spell asthma.
A‰Û_ S‰Û_ Take me home.
Maybe I‰Ûªm not done hanging out with‰Û_ (Laura has gone) You‰Ûªre right, it‰Ûªs getting late.
The apartment. Sheldon has the bird on his arm.

My phone‰Ûªs on the desk over there. Take a picture of us together. Make it good enough to go on a mug, a mouse pad, and a calendar. If you were a dove, I‰Ûªd call you Lovey-Dovey. Oh. Who am I kidding? This isn‰Ûªt a moment for strict adherence to the literal. You‰Ûªre just my little Lovey-Dovey, aren‰Ûªt you?
Guess you gotta have hollow bones to get some sugar around here.

Yes. It should have a big picture of him, and the words, is this your bird? Not anymore. We‰Ûªre going to have so much fun together. You can carry messages to all my enemies. I can tie a string to your leg and fly you like a kite.
If you‰Ûªre keeping him, I‰Ûªve got a cage you can borrow. One of the test monkeys slipped on a banana peel and broke his neck. It was both tragic and hysterical.

Nonsense. No. Lovey-Dovey doesn‰Ûªt sleep in a cage. No. Lovey-Dovey sleeps in his very own nest, which I‰Ûªm going to get off the windowsill and put in my room. Isn‰Ûªt that right, LD? (Opens window. Bird flies out.) No. Where are you going? Come back, Lovey-Dovey! This is your home now! I already ordered 20 pounds of bird feed off of Amazon! He‰Ûªs gone.
I‰Ûªm sorry, Sheldon.
How could he do this to me? Get back here, you stupid bird, so I can love you!
The stairwell. They ascend without talking.
Okay. So, we went out, saw a movie, met some nice people, said horrible things about each other in public, all in all, a pretty magical night.
Okay, I‰Ûªm not innocent in all this, but you basically called me stupid, you asthmatic dumbass.

I know, I, I, I crossed a line. And I‰Ûªm sorry. No, no, no, hang on. I really mean it. And it‰Ûªs not like when we were going out, I‰Ûªd just apologize for everything so we could end up in bed. This is a 100% sex-is-off-the-table I‰Ûªm sorry.
All right. Thank you. I‰Ûªm sorry, too.
Just to be clear, sex is off the table, right?
Way off.
Maybe we‰Ûªre not ready to hang out as friends.
I don‰Ûªt know. Up until the last part, I was kind of enjoying take-charge Leonard with a little backbone. Picking the movie, knowing what he wants, a little cocky.
Really?
Yeah.
Well, then, I‰Ûªm putting sex back on the table. What do you think about that?
Ooh. Maybe I like it.
You do? Because if that‰Ûªs what you like, I can be that guy. I swear, I‰Ûªll be anything you want me to be.
Good night, Leonard.
I am such an asthmatic dumbass. I had a weird night.
Mine was great. I‰Ûªm going to be a mommy. (Reveals nest with an egg in it.)
The comic book store.
It‰Ûªs amazing people keep coming to comic book stores instead of just downloading comics digitally.
It‰Ûªs probably for the best. For a lot of these guys, the weekly trip here is the only chance their mom has to go down to the basement and change their sheets.
Oh, that reminds me, I get fresh sheets tonight. Yay.
Well? What do you think of New Comic Book Night? Magic, huh?
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm disappointed. As a brilliant man, you‰Ûªre entitled to a vice. I could understand frequenting an opium den or hunting your fellow man for sport. But this? Lame-o.
Well, A, comic books employ storytelling through sequential art, a medium that dates back 17,000 years to the cave paintings of Lascaux, and B, you play the harp. Like that‰Ûªs cool.
Can I help you find anything?
A comic that depicts a woman whose bosom can‰Ûªt be used as a floatation device.
Sorry. Most of the guys who come in here like big boobs. Couple of them have big boobs.
Hey, look, the new Warlords of Ka‰Ûªa expansion pack is out.
A new one? Unbelievable. They just keep making up more cheesy monsters, slapping them on cards and selling them at 25 bucks a pop. It‰Ûªs like a secret tax on guys who can‰Ûªt get laid.

They‰Ûªre not even trying. Remember the Satanimals pack with the Hellephant? Why, absurd. What was he, a bad elephant who died and went to hell? What could an elephant possibly do that would cause him eternal damnation?
Wild West and Witches? What kind of loser cares about a showdown between Billy the Kid and the White Wizard of the North?
A total loser. Obviously a guy with a six-shooter beats an old man with a magic wand.
Well, ho-hold on. What if the wizard casts a Helmet of Confusion spell on Billy the Kid‰Ûªs cowboy hat?

What? Please! This is Billy the Kid we‰Ûªre talking about. I mean, the wizard would get shot between the eyes before he could ever get out the words, what the hell is Billy the Kid doing in the mystic realm of Ka‰Ûªa?
Leonard, what‰Ûªs the deal with Sheldon‰Ûªs friend Amy? Are they a couple?
Couple of weirdos. Why?

Well, I mean, she didn‰Ûªt look through me with soul-sucking, ball-shriveling hatred and contempt. I like that in a woman. Could you run it by Sheldon if I could ask her out?
Sure. I guess.
Stuart, settle an argument for us. Who would win, Billy the Kid or the White Wizard?
If I tell you that, I‰Ûªm robbing you of the hours of fun you could have for the magical, rootin‰Ûª tootin‰Ûª low price of $24.95.
I‰Ûªll take one.
Mmm, make it two.
I hate all of you and myself. Three.
I‰Ûªll ring it up. Like shooting nerds in a barrel.
The apartment.
Hey, can I talk to you about something? It‰Ûªs a little awkward.

I know what this is about. Given the professional standstill you‰Ûªre at, you‰Ûªre wondering if this is the appropriate time to abandon your research and focus on teaching. Yes. And if I may suggest, consider changing disciplines. Yeah, to the humanities, perhaps history. One of the advantages of teaching history is that you don‰Ûªt have to create things, you know, you just have to remember stuff that happened and then parrot it back. You could have fun with that.
Yeah, that‰Ûªs not it. Stuart‰Ûªs kind of interested in Amy.
Oh, of course he is. She‰Ûªs very interesting. Did you know, when she was 14, she severed the webbing between her own toes?

I‰Ûªm not sure how to respond, Leonard. I don‰Ûªt own Amy. Can‰Ûªt own a person. At least not since? 1863. President Lincoln freed the? Slaves! Come on Leonard, if you‰Ûªre going to teach history, these are the kind of facts you‰Ûªll have to know.

The question is moot. There is no way that Stuart, an impoverished peddler of picture books, would be at all appealing to Amy Farrah Fowler, a noted neurobiologist capable of performing surgery on her own feet with nothing but nitrous oxide from cans of whipped cream as anesthesia.

Fine. The record shall so reflect. Now, getting back to the problem at hand, what to do with a washed-up experimental physicist.

Oh, Leonard. Lots of people love you and want to help you, but they can‰Ûªt until you admit the problem.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.

Hey, you know, my mom smoked pot when she was pregnant with me, and I turned out just fine. Hey, look, I have peach schnapps. Thank God.

character: Amy (reading a text on her phone)

Amy, little vixen. Just working it under all those layers of wool and polyester.
What are you going to do? Doesn‰Ûªt he know you have a boyfriend?

The apartment. They are playing Warlords of Ka‰Ûªa.

Very.

Annie Ogly.

And may I point out it is the three of you who are obsessed with Stuart and Amy, not me. I think you need to ask yourselves who‰Ûªs really being ridiculous here. (Walks away with spurs jangling)
It‰Ûªs you.
You are.
Totally you.
The cafeteria.
Hey, guys, check it out. The deluxe limited edition Wild West and Witches expansion pack in the signed and numbered collector‰Ûªs tin.

Ooh, a sheriff‰Ûªs badge.

With a hologram? Nice. Hey, do you see this?

You‰Ûªve got to be kidding me. You friended Stuart on Facebook?

Don‰Ûªt be silly. I‰Ûªm a fan of anything that tries to replace actual human contact.

You‰Ûªre so full of it.

Sheldon, why don‰Ûªt you just acknowledge that you have feelings for Amy and you don‰Ûªt want her going out with other men?
And unfriend Leonard Hofstadter.
Here‰Ûªs a radical thought. Go old-school, challenge Stuart to a fight. I mean, nothing makes the ladies hotter than two skinny white guys swatting at each other with their eyes closed.
And unfriend Howard Wolowitz.

Penny‰Ûªs apartment door. Sheldon knocks three times.
Who do we love?
Penny. (Knock, knock, knock)
Who do we love?
Penny. (Knock, knock, knock)
Who do we love?
Penny.
Hello, Sheldon. Come on in.
Thank you.
What‰Ûªs up?

A date. You and me. Dining, dancing, perhaps you‰Ûªd like to take in a prizefight.
God, are you trying to make Amy jealous?

I am not trying to get her back. But, out of curiosity, what is a way?

All right, honey, let me tell you a story. There was a guy I liked, and I never told him how I felt. Eventually, he started going out with someone else, and I always regretted it. Do you see where I‰Ûªm going with this?
I believe I do.
Mm.
I‰Ûªm the guy.
You‰Ûªre not the guy.
