I call everyone sweetie.
You tramp.
Look, Sheldon, all I‰Ûªm saying is strap on a pair and go talk to Amy.
Strap on a pair? Of what, skates?
Oh, sweetie, you are so not the guy.
A cinema.
If you‰Ûªre bored, you can go. I understand.
No, I‰Ûªm having a nice time.
Don‰Ûªt patronize me.
Excuse me. Excuse me. Pardon me. Pardon me. Excuse me. Hi, Stuart.
Hi, Sheldon.
Pardon me. Excuse me.
Sheldon, what are you doing here?
The thought of you sitting in a darkened theatre with a character like Stuart is repellent. No offence, Stuart.
None taken. Although repellent is kind of a, kind of a strong word.
I‰Ûªm sorry this causes you discomfort, but based on the currently established parameters of our relationship, I can put myself in any repellent situation I want.
Um, again‰Û_
Stuart, please. You‰Ûªre being rude.
Anything else?
I believe I would like to alter the paradigm of our relationship.
I‰Ûªm listening.
With the understanding that nothing changes whatsoever, physical or otherwise, I would not object to us no longer characterizing you as not my girlfriend.
Interesting. Now try it without the quadruple negative.
You‰Ûªre being impossible.
Hi, Stuart.
Fine. Amy, will you be my girlfriend?
Yes.
Well, that‰Ûªs enough of that. Sorry to interrupt. You two enjoy your date. Here‰Ûªs a dollar for your troubles. Get yourself some Sour Patch Kids.
Outside Amy‰Ûªs apartment.
So, other than you taking your relationship to the next level with another guy, this was nice.
Yes, well, thanks for seeing me to my door.
Oh, you‰Ûªre welcome.
(Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Let‰Ûªs wrap things up out there.
Um, good night, Stuart.
Good night.
Take the hint, Stuart. The lady said good night.
How did you get into my apartment?
Wow. Is that the kind of nagging I can expect now that you‰Ûªre my girlfriend? Good thing I drew this up.
What‰Ûªs that?

I present to you the relationship agreement. A binding covenant that, in its 31 pages, enumerates, iterates and codifies the rights and responsibilities of Sheldon Lee Cooper, here and after known as the boyfriend, and Amy Farrah Fowler, here and after known as the girlfriend.
It‰Ûªs so romantic.
Mutual indemnification always is. Why don‰Ûªt you start perusing while I set up my notary stamp.
Feel free to retain a lawyer.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment. The girls are playing twister.
Penny, I said right hand red.
Yeah, I heard you. I got red.
Bernadette, left foot yellow.
We should play limbo next. No one beats me at limbo.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Bernadette.
That‰Ûªs my boyfriend. It‰Ûªs open!
I got a splinter.
What do you want me to do about it?
Relationship agreement Section 4, Boo-boos and Ouchies. You have to take care of it.
I should‰Ûªve gotten a lawyer.
Looks like it‰Ûªs just us playing. (Penny snores) Penny? (Penny snores louder) Penny, we‰Ûªre out of wine!
You should probably drive.
The apartment.
Hi. Did Sheldon change the Wi-Fi password again?
Yeah, it‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPenny already eats our food, she can pay for Wi-Fi.‰Û No spaces.
Okay. If you can‰Ûªt get me to stop eating your food, what makes you think you can get me to stop using your Wi-Fi?
I believe that you‰Ûªre capable of great change. Like when I finally got you to stop saying Valentimes Day.
You want to hear something weird?
Sure.
In the year 2000, Pope John Paul II was named an honorary Harlem Globetrotter.
What are you talking about?
You asked Penny if she wanted to hear something weird.
Yeah, because I have something weird to tell her.
Oh. I thought it was a game.
What‰Ûªs yours?
There‰Ûªs this guy, Jimmy Speckerman, who used to torment me in high school. He sent me a message through Facebook. He‰Ûªs in town and wants to have drinks.

Okay, Penny, if it were a game, here are your choices. An e-mail from an old acquaintance, or the head of one of the largest religious institutions in the world slam dunking to Sweet Georgia Brown. Pick.
Just do it, ‰Ûªcause he‰Ûªs not gonna let it go.
Basketball Pope.
And that‰Ûªs how it‰Ûªs done.
What are you gonna do about your bully? Are you gonna see him?
I don‰Ûªt know.
Is this the fellow who peed in your Hawaiian Punch?
No, that was a different guy.
Was he the one who wedgied you so hard, your testicle reascended, and you spent your whole Christmas break waiting for it to come back down?
No, that was a different, different guy.
Was he the one who used your head to open a nut?
No.
Oh, oh, oh. Was he the one who made you eat your arm hair?
No, but, actually, that was this guy‰Ûªs sister.
All right, well, what do you think he wants?
I don‰Ûªt know.
You know, the holidays are just around the corner. Maybe he wants to see if he can lodge the other testicle up there.
I told you. That was a different guy.
Hmm. That‰Ûªs too bad. We could have spent New Year‰Ûªs Eve waiting for the ball to drop.
The apartment.
It‰Ûªs two a.m. What are you doing up?
Nobel Prize acceptance ceremony streaming live from Stockholm.
Sure. You want to see what all the scientists are wearing this year.

Look at these men. They‰Ûªve managed to win the top science prize in the world with no more understanding of the quantum underpinnings of the expansion of the early universe than God gave a goose. You should pay attention, Leonard. Someday this could be you up there.
Thanks.
So, what‰Ûªs got you up? Did you have a bad clam?
I didn‰Ûªt have clams.
I don‰Ûªt watch you 24 hours a day. I don‰Ûªt know what you do.
It‰Ûªs this Jimmy Speckerman thing. I can‰Ûªt decide if I should agree to see him or not. Of course that might be because the last time I ran into him, he made me floss with my own shoelaces.
Wear loafers. Look at Dr. Saul Perlmutter up there, clutching that Nobel Prize. What‰Ûªs the matter, Saul? You afraid someone‰Ûªs going to steal it? Like you stole Einstein‰Ûªs cosmological constant?

You know what? I am tired of living in fear of this guy. I‰Ûªm gonna go see him and finally say all the things I should have said in high school. You know, pick on someone your own size, you did not have sex with my mother, and yes, I do know why I‰Ûªm hitting myself.‰Û
Oh, now Perlmutter‰Ûªs shaking the King‰Ûªs hand. Yeah, check for your watch, Gustaf. He might have lifted it.
Penny‰Ûªs bedroom.
I love this dress. How come I never see you wear it?
‰Û÷Cause when I wear it, it‰Ûªs a shirt. So, what‰Ûªs Howard doing tonight?
Oh, they all went with Leonard to confront his childhood bully.
Oh, terrific. High school quarterback against four mathletes.
When Leonard gets back, I‰Ûªd love to check his serotonin levels. Do you think he‰Ûªd let me draw a syringe full of his blood?
Hmm, he‰Ûªs not crazy about needles, but if you get him to go jogging, it‰Ûªll just pour out of his nose.
I don‰Ûªt think I can meet the girl who was always mean to me. Tammy Bodnick. One time while I was in gym class, she stole all my clothes and left an elf costume in my locker.
Oh, that‰Ûªs awful.
Worst part was, it was too big.
That‰Ûªs nothing. In ninth grade, the girls put Rogaine in my hand lotion. Within six months, the nicknames began to fly. I think the one that hurt the most was Gorilla Fingers Fowler.
Wow. You poor thing.
What about you?
Oh. I don‰Ûªt know. I guess my school was a nice place. We didn‰Ûªt really have bullies.
Come on, no one ever gave anyone mean nicknames or picked on them or put gum in their hairy knuckles so the school nurse had to use peanut butter to get it out?

No, we weren‰Ûªt really like that. I mean, look, we played pranks on each other, but it was never mean. Like, okay, this one girl, Kathy Geiger, got really good grades, so we blindfolded her, tied her up and left her in a cornfield overnight.
Oh, my God, that‰Ûªs awful.
No, it was funny. Everyone laughed.
Did Kathy Geiger laugh?
Uh, probably. It‰Ûªs hard to say. She kind of had an ear of corn in her mouth.
Who would have thought Fuzzy Fingers Fowler is best friends with a bully?
What? I was not a bully.
Kind of sounds like you were. And maybe a felon.
Shh. That‰Ûªs how you wind up in a cornfield.
A bar.
Is that him over there?
No.
How about that guy? He looks like he‰Ûªd hate you.
You know, I can really do this by myself.
Hey, we‰Ûªre here to support you, buddy.
No, you‰Ûªre not. You‰Ûªre here to see if I get my underwear pulled over my head.
You wore underwear? You fool.
So, have you figured out what you‰Ûªre going to say to him?
You bet. I am going to make him apologize for all the crap he pulled on me in school.
That‰Ûªs quite a list. I can‰Ûªt read your handwriting, what‰Ûªs that word?
Scrotum.
What‰Ûªs that one?
Uh, stapled.
Leonard.
Oh, hi.
Holy crap, man, it‰Ûªs good to see you.
Yeah. You, too. Uh, Jimmy, this is Sheldon and Raj and Howard.
Hi. Fellas. Hey, can I get a beer? Wow. Look at you. Little Leonard Hofstadter. I hear you‰Ûªre a big-time scientist now.
And there‰Ûªs the first zinger. Ouch.
I‰Ûªm doing okay, I guess.
Okay? Come on, I read online you‰Ûªre a physicist at a university, you won some medal.
The Newcomb medal.
Yeah, congratulations.
Congratulations? The Newcomb medal? Oh, please. That‰Ûªs the scientific equivalent of a smiley face sticker on your homework.
From what I read, it sounded like a big deal.
Oh, good Lord, are we going to stand here and listen to him tear Leonard apart like this?
Hey, I won a Newcomb medal, too.
My point.
You should have seen this guy back in the day. Huh? He was so little, he could fit in just about anywhere. Lockers, trash cans. Oh, man, how did you get inside that backpack?
Oh, I can‰Ûªt take all the credit. You helped a lot.
Yeah. We were practically a comedy team.
Like the Black Death and Europe.
Jimmy, I‰Ûªm kind of curious why you wanted to see me.
Okay, here it is. I have this great money-making idea. I just need a gear head to get it to the finish line.
Technically, Howard‰Ûªs the gear head. Leonard‰Ûªs just a dime store laser jockey.
What‰Ûªs the idea?
This is just between us, right?
Right.
Okay. What do you think about a pair of glasses that makes any movie you want into 3D?
That sounds amazing. First movie I‰Ûªm watching, Annie.
How exactly would these glasses work?
How the hell should I know? That‰Ûªs why I need a nerd.
I don‰Ûªt think something like that‰Ûªs even possible.
Aw, come on, you can figure it out. You‰Ûªre like the smartest guy I‰Ûªve ever known.
The smartest? All right, you know, I may not have a firm grasp on sarcasm, but even I know that was a doozy. Leonard, you can‰Ûªt live in fear of this man forever.
Sheldon, I got this.

You clearly don‰Ûªt. What my spineless friend lacks the courage to say is you‰Ûªre a terrible person who took advantage of his tiny size, his uncoordinated nature and his congenital lack of masculinity.
Sheldon.
Leonard, I platonically love you, man, but face it, you‰Ûªre a mess.
I don‰Ûªt understand.
I think what he‰Ûªs trying to say is that maybe in high school you picked on me a little bit.
A little bit? The man Super Glued Hershey‰Ûªs Kisses to your nipples.
That‰Ûªs funny because those aren‰Ûªt the kind of kisses you want on your nipples.
What is that?
This is a list of your heinous acts against Leonard. One of which is certainly the cause of him wetting his bed well into his teens.
14 is not, oh , yeah, never mind.
What‰Ûªs this word?
Nancy. You called me Nancy for three years.
You really need to work on your penmanship.
Oh, man, I, I don‰Ûªt know what to say. I always thought we were just having some fun.
It wasn‰Ûªt fun for me.
You‰Ûªre being too kind, Leonard. You ruined him.
Come on, guys.
That was pretty badass, dude.
I help the weak. It‰Ûªs yet another way I‰Ûªm exactly like Batman.
Hey, for the record, Jimmy wasn‰Ûªt the reason I wet the bed. That one has my mother written all over it.
Penny‰Ûªs bedroom. Penny is on the phone.
Anyway, I‰Ûªm really sorry I made fun of your stutter in high school.
You‰Ûªre doing great.
Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Oh, God, just finish the sentence. Okay, well, I‰Ûªm sorry you feel that way. Bye. No one wants to hear my apologies.
I think your mistake is doing it over the phone. If they could look into your eyes, they‰Ûªd melt.
Penny, it doesn‰Ûªt matter what you did in the past. You‰Ûªre a good person now.
That‰Ûªs easy for you to say. You weren‰Ûªt just called a b-b-b-b-bitch.
Perhaps you could assuage your guilt through altruism. Which word‰Ûªs tripping you up? Assuage or altruism?
Both.
You‰Ûªll feel better by doing something nice for someone.
I actually knew that.
I never doubted you.
Every other week I serve at a soup kitchen downtown.
Ooh, I can‰Ûªt do that. If I stand over a steaming pot, my hair just goes boing! What else could I do?
There‰Ûªs Habitat for Humanity, building houses for the poor.
Okay, come on, I don‰Ûªt even have my own house, I‰Ûªm going to build one for someone else?
How about donating some of your clothes?

Oh, my God, that‰Ûªs perfect. ‰Û÷Cause I have so many clothes I don‰Ûªt wear, and they‰Ûªre just taking up space, and I go shopping to buy more stuff and I have no place to put it. This will totally fix that.
What about helping people?
And helping people.
The apartment.
Here‰Ûªs your cocoa.
Oh, half and half instead of whole milk?
Yes.
Heated to precisely 183 degrees?
Yes.
Seven little marshmallows, no more no less?
You got one for good luck. (Knock on door) I‰Ûªll get it.
One for good luck. Must be the kind of math they do at Princeton.
Hey.
What are you doing here?
I want to apologize for stapling your balls and throwing you naked in the girls‰Ûª locker room, stuffing that parrot down your pants. What‰Ûªs this word?
Laxative.
Oh, right. Junior prom. That was not cool, man. I am so, so sorry.
Really?
Yeah. I just hope you can forgive me.
Uh, yeah. Sure, I guess.
You‰Ûªre a beautiful guy.
Well, yeah, thanks, Jimmy.
Okay, I got to go.
Are you okay to drive?
Yeah, yeah, yeah. I drive better drunk. You know, it makes you pay attention.
No, no, no, come on in. I‰Ûªll make you a cup of coffee.
I wouldn‰Ûªt be imposing?
No.
Yes.
Sheldon, we can‰Ûªt let him drive.
Then take away his keys and make him wander the streets with the other drunks.
You remember Sheldon and Raj and Howard.
Not really, no. It‰Ûªs funny, huh, Leonard? Back in school, I was the winner and you were the loser. And now we‰Ûªre reversed. You‰Ûªre the winner.
You‰Ûªd think a winner could make a decent cup of cocoa.
You mind if I use your bathroom?
Yeah, just back there.
How about that? After all these years, your big bad high school bully finally apologizes.
Yeah. It kind of rekindles your faith in the basic goodness of people.
You know what would be nice?
What‰Ûªs that?
As a symbolic gesture to all the bullies who‰Ûªve tormented us for years, we open our home to Jimmy and once he‰Ûªs asleep we kill him. I said it would be nice, I didn‰Ûªt say we should do it.
The clothing bank.
Ah, I feel just like Mother Teresa. Except for the virgin part. That ship sailed a long time ago.
I think Mother Teresa would have washed the clothes first.

Yeah, well, I bet her laundry room wasn‰Ûªt down five flights of stairs. You know, giving really is better than receiving. I used to think it was such a cliche, but it seems to be the‰Û_ oh, look at these cute jeans someone just threw away.
Donated.
Yes, to a poor waitress who loves a boot cut.
Penny.
Come on, they would be so cute on me, and, ah, they go great with this sweater!
I don‰Ûªt think Mother Teresa‰Û_ Oh, that is adorable.
The apartment.
Leonard.
Yeah.
In case it comes up again, this right here is an imposition.
What was I supposed to do? He needed a place to sleep it off.
You‰Ûªre soft. This world‰Ûªs going to chew you up and spit you out.
When did I have tacos?
Morning, Jimmy.
Oh, there it is, tacos.
Man, I tied one on.
Yeah, you did. So, uh, listen, it was great to see you again. And , and, and thanks for the apology.
What apology?
For all the crappy stuff you did to me in high school.
Geez, you‰Ûªre still harping on that? What a puss.
That‰Ûªs my French toast.
It‰Ûªs good. You really know your way around a kitchen, Nancy.
I‰Ûªm not going to say I told you so, but we could have killed him.
I might kill him right now.
The Dark Knight has your back. He‰Ûªs scared, but he has your back.
Okay, Jimmy, it‰Ûªs time for you to go.
Yeah, all right, let me just finish this.
No, you‰Ûªre done. I want you out of my apartment right now.
Well said, Boy Wonder.
Or what?
Don‰Ûªt answer that. It‰Ûªs a trick question. I speak from experience.
I‰Ûªm not afraid of you any more, Jimmy. Now get out! (Pushes him) Uh-oh.
Running down the stairwell.
You did it, Leonard, you stood up to your bully.
Yeah, I feel pretty good about myself. You think we can outrun him?
I don‰Ûªt need to outrun him, I just need to outrun you.
The clothes bank.
I don‰Ûªt feel good about this.
Then sit in the car and keep it running.
You were right, a whole new load.
Come on, yoga top. Mama needs a new yoga top.
Check it out, Bernadette, suede boots, your size.
God, they‰Ûªre cute. Oh, why did they have to be cute?
Wait, wait, wait, guys, just hang on.
What is it, the fuzz?
Look at us. What are we doing?
I was gleefully following you to a life of crime, looking forward to the day we might be cell mates. I don‰Ûªt know about Bernadette.
You know, this is wrong. Let‰Ûªs put everything back. Here.
It‰Ûªs okay, I serve soup to poor people!
The apartment.
Completely empty box. If you‰Ûªd like to examine it?
Mm-hmm. Yep. I see nothing in this box but a wasted childhood.
Little snarky there, cello lessons. And we have this completely ordinary cylinder. If you‰Ûªd like to examine it?
Ordinary, yet I sense it is dripping with magical potential.
Oh, dear Lord. A man pops out for a moment to evacuate his bowels and catch up on the adventures of the Caped Crusader, only to emerge and discover his apartment has been transformed into a cabaret.
Sheldon, he‰Ûªs just practising for his cousin‰Ûªs birthday party.
As I was saying, empty box, empty cylinder, and, ooh, voila. (Pulls out a goldfish in a jar)
I‰Ûªm telling you, dude, there‰Ûªs a seat on the Hogwarts Express with your name on it.
This is how you‰Ûªre going to entertain your little cousin and his friends? By lying to them?
How is this lying?
A magic show is an inherently deceitful proposition. This is an ordinary top hat. You‰Ûªve chosen that card freely. I do not have a set of lock picks lodged in my keister.
Can‰Ûªt you just enjoy the wonder, Sheldon? Why must you peek behind the curtain? Or up the butt?

If we poison the critical thinking faculties of children by telling them that rabbits come out of hats, then we create adults who believe in astrology and homeopathy and that Ryan Reynolds was a better choice for Green Lantern than lovable rogue Nathan Fillion.
Sheldon, he‰Ûªs just gonna do a few magic tricks for some kids. I really don‰Ûªt think they‰Ûªre gonna end up liking the Green Lantern movie.
Don‰Ûªt be so hard on him. It‰Ûªs natural to be a little cranky when you have a quarter in your ear!
Coins lodged in body parts is not a source of amusement. When I was five, Billy Sparks put a Mexican peso up my nose.
How is that not amusing?
It‰Ûªs still there. Takes me 45 minutes to get through airport security. (Storms out)
Look, I made Sheldon disappear. Ta-da.
Next time, you should open with that.
The Cheesecake Factory.
Ooh, look who‰Ûªs out on a date. Pasadena‰Ûªs favourite power couple, Shamy.
And that is the answer to the question, what is wrong with eating at The Cheesecake Factory?
So, are we celebrating anything special tonight?
Oh, yes. Our relationship agreement specifies that the second Thursday of every month, or the third Thursday in a month with five Thursdays, is date night.
That is so hot.
All right, without objection, the minutes of the previous date are considered read and agreed to. Any new business?
How was your day?
Superb. This morning I made a palindrome with my Alpha-Bits. Nice hat, Bob Tahecin.

Sounds like you hit the ground running. I have a bit of good news myself. My most recent paper on how a cooperative long-term potentiation can map memory sequences in dendritic branches made the cover of Neuron.
Ooh! Speaking of good news, somebody just hit 100 Twitter followers.
That‰Ûªs nice. Anyway, I‰Ûªve been dreaming of this day for a long time.
Yeah, me, too. Triple digits, I‰Ûªm not gonna lie, feels pretty good.
Sheldon, I‰Ûªm the sole author on a paper being published in a distinguished journal that may change the course of my field.
Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Ooh, 101! Air‰Ûªs getting a bit thin up here.
So, are we ready to order?
Give me a minute. I‰Ûªm gonna go wash up.
Well, that‰Ûªs odd. We both washed up when we came in. It‰Ûªs probably a euphemism for urination.
Sheldon, what is wrong with you?
Not much. Although, I can be faulted for being overly fond of koala bears. I don‰Ûªt know what it is, when they smart munching on eucalyptus, I just melt inside.
Okay, Amy just told you some exciting news, and you acted like it was no big deal.
Oh, I see why you‰Ûªre confused. No, her news sounded important, but what you‰Ûªre forgetting is, it was an achievement in the field of biology. That‰Ûªs all about yucky, squishy things.
Honey, she‰Ûªs upset. You‰Ûªre her boyfriend. You have to at least try to be excited by the things she‰Ûªs excited by.
What if they simply don‰Ûªt excite me?
Well, just smile and think about koalas.
She‰Ûªd see right through that. We go to the zoo all the time. She knows my koala face. And for future reference, it‰Ûªs this.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Oh, you have a lot of magic stuff.
Yeah. I started when I was a teenager. I thought I could show a girl a few tricks and invite her up to my bedroom to see the rest of the act.
Did it work?
Ah, let‰Ûªs just say the only wand that ever saw any action was this one. Oh, look what my mom made us for the act.
Ooh. I like the fabric. Where‰Ûªd she get it?
Well, she cut up one of her old bathing suits. She made these two vests and half a dozen napkins.
Has she tried on the vest yet?
I just gave it to her!
I hope it fits, she has a tricky figure! She‰Ûªs short and stacked, like me!
She‰Ûªs not stacked like you, Ma! She never steps on hers!
Listen, Howie, maybe I‰Ûªm not the best choice to be a magician‰Ûªs assistant.
You‰Ûªll do fine. Hand me those rings? See? You nailed it.
You know, i-it‰Ûªs just that I‰Ûªm not that comfortable with little kids.
Well, that‰Ûªs because you haven‰Ûªt been around them much. This is good practice. I mean, you are gonna be a mom someday, right?
Mmm, yeah, sure.

Oh-ho-ho! I haven‰Ûªt seen this trick in years. It‰Ûªs called the dove pan. You let everyone see the pan is empty, but there‰Ûªs a secret compartment in the lid. And then you open it and produce a live‰Û_ Don‰Ûªt look in there.
The apartment.
Oh, a little Red Dead Redemption, huh?
Yes.
How come you‰Ûªre not doing a mission? You‰Ûªre just wandering around.
Had a rough night. I thought I‰Ûªd go for a walk and clear my head.
Some people go outside and do that.
It‰Ûªs after nine o‰Ûªclock, at this hour the streets of Pasadena are teeming with drunken sailors and alley cats.
You want to talk about it?
No. I think I‰Ûªll just go in this saloon and drink my troubles away.
You know digital alcohol is never a solution. What‰Ûªs going on?
Hard as this may be to believe, it‰Ûªs possible that I‰Ûªm not boyfriend material.
Glad I was sitting down for that. Did you and Amy get in a fight?
Amy had a fight. I was being perfectly reasonable. I‰Ûªm gonna have a whiskey. Do you want anything?
No, I can‰Ûªt. I‰Ûªm playing Grand Theft Auto later. Look, I‰Ûªm no expert in women.
I‰Ûªll say.
That‰Ûªs not necessary when someone‰Ûªs trying to help you.
I‰Ûªm sorry. It‰Ûªs the alcohol talking. Go on.
Sometimes with women you want to listen to what upsets them and then show them that you can grow and change.
Nuts to that. What else you got?
I don‰Ûªt know what to tell you. Buy her something.
How does that work?
Well, you skip over any attempt to repair your emotional connection and you win back her affection with an empty financial gesture.
Well, that approach has Sheldon Cooper written all over it.
Glad I could help.
It‰Ûªs appreciated. And if you ever manage to find a woman again, I‰Ûªll be glad to return the favour.
The birthday party.
And now, all the rings are magically linked together. My fiancee‰Ûªs wearing a magic ring, too. It made all my money disappear.
Oh, ah, right. (Bangs drum and cymbal) And now, the great Howdini‰Ûªs next miraculous illusion.
When are we gonna have cake?
After you‰Ûªve been thoroughly amazed.
But we want cake now.
Well, you‰Ûªre not getting cake right now, capisce?
Okay. Okay. Now, my lovely assistant is going to bring me an ordinary pitcher of milk.
I know how you do that trick.
Do you know how to pipe down?
Okay, we‰Ûªre going to roll up this newspaper.
It‰Ûªs a fake pitcher.
You got wax in your ears? The man said it‰Ûªs an ordinary pitcher. Howdini.
Okay, we‰Ûªre going to stick this in here (puts newspaper into trouser waistband) and then I‰Ûªm going to pour in the milk. I hope this works, because I didn‰Ûªt bring a change of pants.
Look, I Googled it. It‰Ûªs a fake pitcher.
That‰Ûªs it. No cake for you. Anyone else want to join the No Cake Club?
She‰Ûªs just kidding, boys and girls. Everyone gets cake.
Not him.
Just give me the pitcher. Behold! Wrong pitcher.
Bernadette‰Ûªs car.
I told you I‰Ûªm not good with kids.
Yes, you did. Oh, I think my crotch is starting to curdle.
The thing is, my mother worked full-time. I had to take care of my brothers and sisters.
Yeah, so?

Ugh, it was horrible. With their snotty noses and their poopy diapers and their little shrieky voices, always complaining. I don‰Ûªt want to get dressed. Joey keeps spitting in my mouth. This isn‰Ûªt the way Mom makes waffles. Well, okay, put your hand in here. Let‰Ûªs see how you like this waffle!
All right, settle down. Red light. Red light, red light! Okay, we‰Ûªre fine.
I‰Ûªm sorry. I know it makes me sound like a bad person, but I just don‰Ûªt like children.
Yeah, no, we all got that. But don‰Ûªt you think it‰Ûªll be different when the child is ours?

Right, when it‰Ûªs our kid that‰Ûªs ruined my body and kept me up all night and I‰Ûªve got no career and no future and nothing to be happy about for the next 20 years, sure, that‰Ûªll be completely different.
Well, yeah.
A jewellery store.
I don‰Ûªt think there‰Ûªs anything in this jewellery store that Amy would appreciate more than the humidifier we were just looking at at Sears.
Oh, my God, now I know what I sound like to you when I say stupid stuff.
Ooh, a pocket watch.
Okay, I don‰Ûªt think Amy wants a pocket watch.
No, but maybe she wants a man with a pocket watch.
Still saying stupid stuff. Ooh, does she like bracelets?
Well, she‰Ûªs very fond of her silver one that says allergic to penicillin. Maybe they have a dressier version of that?
Well, how are we doing this afternoon? Are we looking for anything special? Perhaps a ring for the lady?
(Snorts) Trust me, we are not a couple.
Excuse me. I don‰Ûªt see why you get to snort derisively and point that out. You‰Ûªd be lucky to land a fella like me.
Fine, go ahead.
(Snorts) Trust me, we are not a couple.
My apologies. How can I help you today?
He‰Ûªs in trouble with his girlfriend and needs to buy her a present.
Great, trouble with girlfriends is what‰Ûªs putting my daughter through USC.
Ooh, are these real diamonds?
Yes. Channel set baguettes, 20 points total weight.

Remarkable. Diamonds, crystallized carbon. Every day, people go to the grocery store and come home with sacks full of carbon in the form of charcoal briquettes that they toss in their barbeques and set on fire. But just because you‰Ûªve got some carbon with the atoms stacked neatly, you expect me to plunk down thousands of dollars.
Actually, that‰Ûªs only 750. Everything‰Ûªs on sale.
Really. Talk to me about that pocket watch.
The apartment. The guys are playing Donkey Kong Jenga.
I‰Ûªm still trying to wrap my mind around it. I always thought I‰Ûªd be a dad someday.
Oh, me, too. You‰Ûªre so caring. I‰Ûªve often pictured you guiding a young boy into manhood.
There you go, Howard. Sounds like Raj‰Ûªll have your babies, problem solved.
Hey, just because a man shows caring for another man doesn‰Ûªt mean he‰Ûªs displaying the love that dare not speak its name. Did she definitely say she didn‰Ûªt want kids?
Yeah, she doesn‰Ûªt like them. And from what I saw, the feeling was mutual.
What are you gonna do?

I don‰Ûªt know. I can‰Ûªt see a life where I don‰Ûªt have kids. I mean, people have kids. I mean, even Donkey Kong had Donkey Kong Jr. So he could teach someone how to kidnap princesses and throw barrels at Italian plumbers.
You know, there‰Ûªs no guarantee even if you have kids that you‰Ûªre going to like them.
Wow, that‰Ûªs rough. Where‰Ûªd you get that?
It‰Ûªs right off the dust jacket of my mom‰Ûªs last book.
Maybe me and Bernadette aren‰Ûªt right for each other.
Look, Howard, I‰Ûªd say there‰Ûªs a lot of fish in the sea, but I watched you dangle your hook in the water for years. Do not throw her back.
I don‰Ûªt want to, but this is kind of a deal breaker.
What‰Ûªs your mom going to say if you call off the wedding?
Huh, it‰Ûªll kill her. On the other hand, if I don‰Ûªt give her grandchildren, that‰Ûªll kill her, too. So, either way, on the Mom front, I‰Ûªm golden.
Penny‰Ûªs apartment.
What time did you tell Amy to be here?
Eight o‰Ûªclock. (Sheldon checks pocket watch) Sheldon, that pocket watch is ridiculous.
Nonsense. I look like a train conductor. Under what pretext did you lure her here?
I said, hey, want to come over and hang out?
Good, good, if you had said something clever, she might‰Ûªve gotten suspicious.
Hey.
Hi.
What‰Ûªs he doing here?
Okay, he wants to talk to you.
Well, I don‰Ûªt want to talk to him. And I‰Ûªm pretty disappointed in you, too. Although we both know that won‰Ûªt last.
Sheldon, you‰Ûªre up.
Thank you. Amy, I‰Ûªd like to apologize. Your accomplishment was impressive. And I‰Ûªm proud of you.
We both know that‰Ûªs your koala face.
I told you.
Okay, look, he bought you this.

Jewellery? Seriously? Sheldon, you are the most shallow, self-centred person I have ever met. Do you really think another transparently manip..oh! It‰Ûªs a tiara! A tiara! I have a tiara! Put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me.
You look beautiful.
Of course I do, I‰Ûªm a princess, and this is my tiara!
You‰Ûªre right, the tiara was too much.
Howard‰Ûªs bedroom.
Howard! Bernadette‰Ûªs‰Û_ Oh, she slipped right by me.
Here‰Ûªs your vest back.
You should keep it. You could wear it again sometime.
Where?
I don‰Ûªt know, hunting?
Don‰Ûªt forget to talk to her about this mishegas where I don‰Ûªt get grandkids!
Don‰Ûªt worry, Ma. I will, as soon as I can figure out a way to bring up such a sensitive issue!
I guess you talked to your mom, huh?
I was upset. My mom can be a pretty good shoulder to cry on, if the smell of Bengay doesn‰Ûªt burn your eyes.
Look, it‰Ûªs obvious having kids is really important to you, and I think I came up with a solution.
Really? That‰Ûªs great. What?
Well, seeing as how I make way more money than you anyway, what if I work and you stay home with the kids?
Me?
Yeah. You know, you‰Ûªll watch Barney and pull Cheerios out of their noses and go on play dates, and I‰Ûªll work and have conversations with people my own age and enjoy my life.
Yeah.
Yay, so we‰Ûªre good.
Yeah, we‰Ûªre good.
You know, I don‰Ûªt know if this counted as a fight, but how about some make-up sex?
I would love that. But what is that behind your ear? Oh, look, it‰Ûªs a condom.
The stairwell.
You feel like trying something new for dinner? Maybe Indian, Tex-Mex?
You ever wonder how humans would be different if they evolved from lizards instead of mammals?
Okay, let‰Ûªs talk about that.

As you know, lizards, cold-blooded animals, lack the ability to sense temperature. But they do move more sluggishly when it‰Ûªs cold. So, lizard weathermen would say things like, bring a sweater, it‰Ûªs slow outside. I love my mind.
We all do. Now, how about dinner?

Oh, I would assume we‰Ûªd enjoy insects or smaller lizards. We could also pull each other‰Ûªs tails off and grill them, they‰Ûªll just grow back. Oh! My life-size cardboard Mr. Spock is here! I know he wouldn‰Ûªt care for an outburst of human emotion, but, oh goodie, oh goodie, oh goodie. Commander Spock requesting permission to be unfolded.

character: Leonard (seeing Penny‰Ûªs door open and the girls inside)
line: Excuse me.
Permission granted, Commander.
Which is why the more intelligent the monkey, the more faeces they fling.
Excuse me, Amy. Penny, do you have plans for dinner tonight?
Why, you guys going somewhere?
No, I mean just you and me.
You mean, like a date?
Not like a date, a date.
Ooh!
Ooh!
Um, o-okay. Sure.
Ooh!
Ooh!
Oh, no! They sent the wrong Spock! Live long and suck it, Zachary Quinto.
Penny‰Ûªs bedroom.
This is so exciting. If Leonard and Penny get back together, Howard and I can go on double dates with them.
How come you never invite Sheldon and me on a double date?
Mm, uh‰Û_ How‰Ûªs it going in there, Penny?
Just a sec. (Emerges in revealing slinky green dress) Too much?
Yes.
No.
Okay, just hang on.
You just can‰Ûªt handle her raw sexuality, can you?
When did you and Leonard break up?
Uh, about two years ago.
Why do you think he asked you out again?
I don‰Ûªt know.
Maybe he‰Ûªs dying. That would be so romantic.
He‰Ûªs not dying.
Too bad. If he were, she could just throw him in bed and ride him right up until he flatlines.
How about this?
Maybe.
Come on.
Yeah, okay, no.
Do you think you‰Ûªll sleep with him tonight?
Absolutely not. Look, we‰Ûªre just gonna have dinner and, you know, see how it goes.
If he were dying, would you sleep with him?
What?
Assuming he were dying of something that couldn‰Ûªt be sexually transmitted. You know, like a spear wound to the head.
Okay, he is not dying.
How do you know? Are you a doctor?
You can make-believe, though. Sometimes Howard and I pretend that his arrhythmia is acting up and I‰Ûªm a sexy cardiologist. And the naughty part is I‰Ûªm not in his HMO network.

That‰Ûªs a good point. My time is much too valuable. You know, perhaps I should find someone to do it for me. You know, someone with a rudimentary understanding of science, but whose real talents lie in menial labour.

A proof that algebraic topology can never have a non self-contradictory set of abelion groups. I‰Ûªm just a blonde monkey to you, aren‰Ûªt I?

Sheldon‰Ûªs office.

A University corridor.

Dr. Cooper‰Ûªs office.

University corridor.

And there you have it, prefrontal cortex reasoning versus limbic lust. If this were a boxing match, they might call it the thrilla adjacent to the amygdala. If you were a brain scientist, you would be busting a gut right now.

Howard and Bernadette‰Ûªs Bedroom.

The apartment.

I‰Ûªm not saying you don‰Ûªt have attractive qualities. Your choice of friends is impeccable, you‰Ûªre a good sleeper, and last but not least, you buy the grapes I like. You‰Ûªre a real catch compared to some snoring guy with a fridge full of lousy grapes.
None of this matters. I trust that Penny cares about me, and nothing‰Ûªs gonna happen with this guy.
Well, unless of course he‰Ûªs a skilled hypnotist.
What?
While unlikely, it‰Ûªs still a statistical possibility. She might be performing sexual acts with him and not even know it.
Now you‰Ûªre just being ridiculous.
Am I? The mind‰Ûªs a mysterious thing, Leonard. He could be having the time of his life while she thinks she‰Ûªs a chicken pecking for corn.
The university basement.
Look at us, sneaking around in the middle of the night like a couple of cat burglars.
I think we‰Ûªre more like ninjas.
I don‰Ûªt want to be a ninja, I want to be a cat burglar.
Fine, I‰Ûªll be a ninja, you be a cat burglar.
No, we both have to be the same thing. Okay, we‰Ûªre ninjas.
Thank you.
But next time, we‰Ûªll be cat burglars.
It‰Ûªs locked.
Are you sure?
Yes, I‰Ûªm sure. Now, you stand guard, I‰Ûªm going to‰Û_
It‰Ûªs locked.
Just keep an eye out. I‰Ûªll have this open in a minute.
When did you learn how to pick locks?
When I was starting to do magic in junior high, I thought I could be an escape artist like Harry Houdini.
How did that work out?
Pretty good. I managed to escape friends, popularity, and every party thrown in a twelve mile radius. There. Ready?
Hold on, hold on.
What?
Sheldon is a very smart man, and he obviously wants to keep this a secret.
Yeah, so?
What if it‰Ûªs booby-trapped?
Don‰Ûªt worry, I‰Ûªm one step ahead of him.
Great, what‰Ûªs your pl‰Û_ (Howard pushes him inside)
Are we good?
Yeah. Huh. Forty-three? What the hell does that mean?
I don‰Ûªt know. The solution to an equation?
Maybe. It‰Ûªs a prime number. Encryption systems are built on prime numbers.
What kind of secret does Sheldon have to encrypt?
He‰Ûªs always been very cagey about what he puts in his egg salad to make it so tasty.
It‰Ûªs paprika.
Really? Well, oh, okay, one mystery solved.
The apartment.
Okay, good night.
Thanks, Cole. See you at school.
See you.
I‰Ûªll be right back.
I thought you left a long time ago.

character: Leonard (rushing to catch up with Cole)
line: ‰Û÷sup?
Hey.
You, uh, moving into the apartment on the fifth floor?
No, I was just visiting a friend.
Oh, cool. That cute blonde on four?
Yeah. You know her?
I, well, I see her around. I like to keep my distance because her boyfriend is a pretty scary dude.
Really?
Yeah. He‰Ûªs ganged up.
She told me he‰Ûªs a scientist.
That‰Ûªs the name of his gang. The Scientists. They are crazy.
Well, thanks for the tip.
No problem, brother. Stay frosty. (Cole leaves. Leonard spots Penny watching.) We‰Ûªre still dating, right?
The cafeteria.
Oh, hello, Dr. Hofstadter.
Hey, Alex, and call me Leonard. Dr. Hofstadter is my father. And my mother. And my sister. And our cat. Although, I‰Ûªm pretty sure Dr. Boots Hofstadter‰Ûªs degree was honorary.
May I join you, Leonard?
Sure.
Thanks.
Hey, Alex, let me ask you something. My girlfriend knows this guy at school. He‰Ûªs got an English accent.
Ooh, I love English accents.
Yeah, you all do. Anyway, I feel like he‰Ûªs hitting on her. She says he‰Ûªs just being nice and that I should trust her.
It‰Ûªs probably harmless. You know how it is. I‰Ûªm sure you get hit on all the time.
Right. Because girls are always like, ooh, that guy owns two Star Trek uniforms and gets a lot of ear infections. I got to get me some of that.
I don‰Ûªt know, I bet it happens more than you realize.
Trust me, it doesn‰Ûªt.
You sure? You‰Ûªre cute, you‰Ûªre funny. Maybe you‰Ûªre getting hit on, and you don‰Ûªt even know it.
Really?
Yep, pretty sure.
Okay, I got to get back to work. Thanks for listening.
No problem.
Hope-hope no girls rip my clothes off on the way.
Raj‰Ûªs office.
Come on, we‰Ûªre smart guys. We can figure this out.
Forty-three. What is forty-three? Besides my mom‰Ûªs neck size.
It‰Ûªs the atomic number for technetium.
That stuff‰Ûªs radioactive.
Do you think he‰Ûªs building a bomb?
Ah, it took him two years to put together that Lego Death Star, I‰Ûªm not worried.
Ooh, this could be something. forty-three is the number of calories in half a cup of fat-free yoghurt.
Why would you know that?

I‰Ûªm sorry. We can‰Ûªt all eat whatever we want and still stay thin. Wait, in the Hitchhiker‰Ûªs Guide to the Galaxy, isn‰Ûªt forty-three the answer to the question of life, the universe,and everything?
That‰Ûªs forty-two, dumb-ass.
Hey, hey. Feelings.
We should stop. I‰Ûªm exhausted.
Yeah, me, too. We‰Ûªve got more important things to do. Who cares what stupid forty-three means?
Not me.
Let‰Ûªs go home. You want to get something to eat?
Sounds good.
What the balls is forty-three?
I have to know!
The stairwell.
Hi.
Hey, shouldn‰Ûªt you be out with your gang, spray painting equations on the side of buildings?
Come on, I‰Ûªm sorry.
I just can‰Ûªt believe you don‰Ûªt trust me.
I do, of course I do.
Then why did you embarrass me in front of my friend, who, by the way, knew exactly who you were?
Really?
Your picture‰Ûªs on my refrigerator.
Oh. You know, I‰Ûªm really starting to not like this guy.
What is your problem? Do you use up all your thinking at work and then have none left over for when you get home?

I don‰Ûªt know. It-it-it‰Ûªs hard sometimes. Everywhere you go, guys hit on you, even if I‰Ûªm standing right there. And they‰Ûªre all taller than me. Why is everyone taller than me? You know what, this is all in my head. It‰Ûªs my problem, not yours.
Leonard, why do you always do this? Listen to me, you‰Ûªre the one I‰Ûªm with. You know I love you, so will you please relax because you‰Ûªre driving me crazy.
You know that‰Ûªs the first time you ever said that you love me.
Yeah.
We‰Ûªre just supposed to pretend it‰Ûªs not a big deal?
That‰Ûªs exactly what we‰Ûªre gonna do because you‰Ûªre about to make me cry, and we both know if I start crying, you‰Ûªre gonna start crying.
You‰Ûªre right, you should go.
All right.
She loves me. (Receives text) Hey, it‰Ûªs Alex. Nice having coffee with you. If you want to talk more, I‰Ûªm always available. Smiley face, smiley face. What a friendly girl.
The cafeteria.
Okay, picture‰Ûªs up. Looks like the camera‰Ûªs working.
That‰Ûªs good quality video.
It better be. It‰Ûªs the spare camera for the Mars rover.
How did you get your hands on that?
Million dollar camera, ten dollar lock.
Oh, my God, here he comes. This is it.
What the hell is that thing?
I don‰Ûªt know.
This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Experimental log. Wormhole generator test forty-four.
Wormhole generator test? (On screen a wormhole appears)
The first forty-three parallel universes I‰Ûªve checked proved to be empty. I see no reason to suspect universe number forty-four will be any different. (Puts his head in the wormhole)
Oh, my God!
Holy crap!

character: Sheldon (with an alien creature stuck to his face)
line: Oh! It‰Ûªs eating my face!
Aah! It‰Ûªs eating his face!
I found your webcam and replaced the video feed. You two should be ashamed of yourselves.
Sheldon, we‰Ûªre really sorry.
Yeah, really sorry.

Sorry? You may not realize it, but I have difficulty navigating certain aspects of daily life. You know, understanding sarcasm, feigning interest in others, not talking about trains as much as I want to. It‰Ûªs exhausting. Which is why, for twenty minutes a day, I like to go down to that room, turn my mind off and do what I need to do to recharge.
But what are you doing in there?
And what does forty-three mean?
You don‰Ûªt need to know, you don‰Ûªt deserve to know, and you will never know.
Yeah, well, I know how to make your egg salad now.
The room in the basement. Sheldon enters, takes out a box, takes a beanbag from the box, then starts playing keepie-uppie,
One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight‰Û_ Drat. I‰Ûªm never going to get to forty-three again. One, two, three, four‰Û_ Rats.
The cafeteria.
They are not.
They are, too.
Your hypothesis is completely disconfirmed by all the data. You‰Ûªre just clinging to it out of intellectual stubbornness.
No, you‰Ûªre displaying a shocking ignorance of the subject matter. Mummies and zombies are the exact same thing.
Oh, yeah? Mummies are wrapped in bandages.
That‰Ûªs called a fashion choice.
All right, you brought this on yourself. Sheldon, get him.

If a zombie bites you, you turn into a zombie. However, if a mummy bites you, all you turn into is some schmo with a mummy bite. So, like a zombie, that‰Ûªs been eaten from the waist down, you, sir, have no leg to stand on.
Good boy. Here‰Ûªs a cookie.
Oh, thank you.
Hey, fellas, what‰Ûªs going on?
Oh, mummies and zombies again.
Oh, they‰Ûªre not the same thing.
You get a cookie, too.
Thanks. Guess who picked up his new car this morning?
Congratulations. Does it have that new car smell?
Yep. For as long as I can keep my mother out of it. If you want to check it out later, it‰Ûªs parked right out front, space 294.
I‰Ûªm sorry, 294?
Yeah.
That‰Ûªs my parking spot.
Why do you have a parking spot? You don‰Ûªt have a car. You don‰Ûªt even drive.
It doesn‰Ûªt matter. That‰Ûªs my spot.
Maybe they reassigned it because you never use it.
Well, I‰Ûªm not using my nipples, either. Maybe they should reassign those.
Sheldon, someday, if you get a car, I‰Ûªm sure they‰Ûªll give you another parking space.

I don‰Ûªt want another parking space. I want my parking space. It‰Ûªs perfect. It‰Ûªs a corner spot, cutting the risk of door-dings in half. It‰Ûªs a mere 28 steps from the building entrance. The nearby tree provides shade on hot days and is also home to a delightful squirrel. Which is fortuitous because most squirrels are real jerks.
Fun story. Meanwhile, you still don‰Ûªt have a car.
Don‰Ûªt try to change the subject. This is about a parking space. It has nothing to do with cars.
Are you listening to yourself?
I always listen to myself. It‰Ûªs one of the great joys of my life. Now, get your car out of my spot.
Nope.
Very well. You leave me no choice.
The parking spot. Sheldon is trying to push Howard‰Ûªs car out of the spot.
What are you looking at, you stupid squirrel?
The apartment.

President Siebert, listen to reason. Yeah, I understand I don‰Ûªt use the parking spot, but that‰Ûªs not the point. I‰Û_ Yes, I‰Ûªm aware you told me not to call you at home, but you didn‰Ûªt answer the door. And I know you were there, because I saw you through the mail slot. Yeah, well, that‰Ûªs some salty language. May I remind you that you‰Ûªre the president of a major university, not the president of the Potty Mouth Club. There it is again. Do you kiss your mother with that mouth? Oh, well, I‰Ûªm sorry for your loss. Good night, sir. Unbelievable. He says Wolowitz deserves my spot because he‰Ûªs a high-profile asset to the university.
Well, he‰Ûªs not wrong. Howard did go to the International Space Station.
Yeah, that was five weeks ago. How much longer is he gonna milk that cow?
Sheldon, let it go. It‰Ûªs not a big deal.

No, no, this is a slippery slope, Leonard. It starts with a parking space, where does it end? It‰Ûªs like my dad always said, first they say you can‰Ûªt drink and drive, next thing you know, you can‰Ûªt let your 10-year-old take the wheel while you sleep one off in the backseat.
All that story does is make me feel bad for your mother.
Leonard, you‰Ûªre my best friend. Why don‰Ûªt you ever take my side?
Because I can never understand your side.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.
Give it back.
I‰Ûªm sorry, but could you be more specific?
My Iron Man helmet. Koothrappali saw you take it. Give it back.
Oh, that. Well, see, I wanted it, and you weren‰Ûªt using it. Apparently, those are the rules we live by now. Payback, it truly is the B word, isn‰Ûªt it?
Sheldon, that is a five hundred dollar limited edition collectible, and I want it back.
I‰Ûªd love to help you out, but unfortunately (puts helmet on), I‰Ûªm using it.
Fine. I‰Ûªm taking your diploma.
Go ahead. That‰Ûªs the only doctorate you‰Ûªll ever get. It smells funny in here.
The apartment stairwell.
We‰Ûªre so proud of you, Amy. Your first bikini wax.
Yeah. So, how you doing?
A little sensitive, but not bad. Does it always take that long?
Uh, no, they usually don‰Ûªt have to go out and get more wax.
I feel like I‰Ûªm five pounds lighter.
Really? Only five?
Hey, anybody want a drink?
Sure.
Okay. So, did you spend last night hearing about this silly parking space fight, too?
For hours. Fortunately, I couldn‰Ûªt understand most of it ‰Ûªcause Sheldon was wearing that stupid robot mask.
Howard was so angry I had to mash up Benadryl in his ice cream to get him to fall asleep.
I guess this is what we get for being with two testosterone-fueled alpha males. At some point, they‰Ûªre bound to lock horns.
I‰Ûªm assuming these are some kind of horns they bought at Comic-Con?
I‰Ûªm really sorry they took Sheldon‰Ûªs spot away. He shouldn‰Ûªt have to suffer just because Howard‰Ûªs such a big deal now.
I know, Sheldon should just let Howard have his little moment in the sun.
What‰Ûªs that supposed to mean?
Well, I mean, Howard‰Ûªs never gonna go to space again, but Sheldon will always be a genius.
You‰Ûªre right. And I‰Ûªm sure Sheldon will get a fancy parking spot again, if and when he makes a worthwhile contribution to science.
If and when?
Okay, maybe we should change the subject. Um, Amy, how are your lady parts? Still chilly down there?
Hang on. None of Sheldon‰Ûªs theories have ever been definitively proven. My husband actually went to outer space.
That‰Ûªs an impressive accomplishment. He‰Ûªs now an inspiration to millions of Americans who know you don‰Ûªt have to be special or even qualified to go into space.
You know, I remember the first time I got a bikini wax. My sister did it with melted Crayolas and duct tape. It‰Ûªs a bad idea.
Gosh, Amy. I‰Ûªm sensing a little hostility. Is it maybe because, like Sheldon‰Ûªs work, your sex life is also theoretical?
Damn.

Yeah, well, at least when we do make love, Sheldon won‰Ûªt be thinking about his mother. And yes, that is a cleverly veiled reference to Howard‰Ûªs lifelong obsession to crawl back into her spacious womb.
Anyway, to this day, I still can‰Ûªt see a box of crayons without crossing my legs.
I don‰Ûªt have to take this. I‰Ûªm gonna go home and have sex with my husband right now. Maybe I‰Ûªll let him do it to me in the parking spot. Which sounds dirty, but I didn‰Ûªt mean it that way,
The stairwell.
Sheldon?
Cookie.
I don‰Ûªt have any.
Well, I‰Ûªm not giving it away. (Enters apartment. Howard is sitting naked in his spot with a laptop on his lap)
Hi Sheldon.
He‰Ûªs in my spot. Leonard, make him stop being naked in my spot.
Howard, what are you doing?
He wasn‰Ûªt using it. And I needed a nice cool piece of leather to wiggle my naked ass on.
Get off there.
Give me back my Iron Man helmet.
Give me back my parking space.
You don‰Ûªt need a parking space. You don‰Ûªt have a car.
You don‰Ûªt need an Iron Man helmet. You‰Ûªre not Iron Man.
Well, we appear to have reached an impasse. And you know, I have to say, I thought you‰Ûªd be more upset that your laptop is sitting on my junk.
I didn‰Ûªt pick up on that. That‰Ûªs a nice touch.
Mmm.
The parking spot. Sheldon is spraypainting out Howard‰Ûªs name and replacing it with his own.
This is so exciting. I‰Ûªm feeling all tingly. Although that could just be my newly defoliated bikini zone.
Keep a lookout. This place is swarming with campus security. They will not hesitate to scold us.
Freaking pigs.
Oh, yeah. Okay, now, pull your car into the spot and let‰Ûªs get out of here.
Wait, I‰Ûªm leaving my car here?
Yes, and be sure and put on the emergency brake. Really makes these things tough to budge.
Before I park, come in the back seat. I want to show you something I had done today.
All right, colour me intrigued.
What do you think?
I think you‰Ûªre high on paint fumes. And boy, that‰Ûªs a lot of Band-Aids.
Howard and Bernadette‰Ûªs apartment.
Okay, Howard‰Ûªs mother is in, like, every one of your wedding photos.
What can I tell ya? She‰Ûªs a big girl. Wherever you look, there she is. More coffee?
No, Leonard‰Ûªs taking me to a physics lecture, and coffee‰Ûªll just keep me awake. (Knock on door) Oh, I‰Ûªll get it.
Oh, looks like someone‰Ûªs on Team Bernadette. Where‰Ûªs Howard?
He‰Ûªs not here. What‰Ûªs wrong?
He had my car towed. It cost me two hundred dollars to get it back.
Oh, no. Where was it parked?
In Sheldon‰Ûªs spot.
That doesn‰Ûªt make sense. Sheldon doesn‰Ûªt have a spot. Was it maybe in Howard‰Ûªs spot?
Don‰Ûªt play dumb with me, sister. You tell your husband he owes me two hundred dollars.
Well, that doesn‰Ûªt make sense, either.
Why not?
Because I‰Ûªm the one who had it towed.
You?
Didn‰Ûªt see that one coming, did ya?
Oh, yeah? Well, you‰Ûªre not gonna see this coming. (Swings handbag. Bernadette ducks. Penny is hit in the face)
Ow! Ow!
Oh, my God,
Are you okay?!
You idiot, what the hell do you have in there?!
Just my wallet, keys and a coffee can full of change I‰Ûªve been meaning to take to the bank.
Don‰Ûªt move. I‰Ûªll get some ice.
Are you okay?
Get away from me or I swear to God I will rip out what‰Ûªs left of your pubes!
Here.
Thanks. Ah!
Amy, you think maybe this has gotten a little out of hand?
Gee, you think?
I do. Penny, Bernadette and I are sorry.
You hit her! What did I do?
You had my car towed.
You were parked in Howard‰Ûªs spot.
I was parked in Sheldon‰Ûªs spot.
Sheldon doesn‰Ûªt have a spot.
Guys, I think I need to go to the emergency room.
Okay, let‰Ûªs go.
I‰Ûªll drive. You can see where the tow truck scratched my car.
The tow truck didn‰Ûªt scratch your car.
How do you know?
‰Û÷Cause I did it!
The parking spot. Sheldon has set up his office in it.
Morning, Professor Stevens. Don‰Ûªt look at that whiteboard. That‰Ûªs my math, not your math. Keep walking, nosey.
What the hell are you doing?
Oh. You said I‰Ûªm not using my space, so I‰Ûªm using it.
Okay, you need to move now.
No, I don‰Ûªt.
You can‰Ûªt stay there forever.

Actually, I have a plastic baggy strapped to my leg that says I can. Give up, Wolowitz. You‰Ûªve chosen to tangle with a superior intellect you can‰Ûªt defeat. There is nothing you could possibly do to‰Û_ (Howard starts sounding his horn. Sheldon puts on earphones)
Those aren‰Ûªt gonna help you, Sheldon,
Oh, yes, they are. I mean, what?
I‰Ûªm warning you, Sheldon!
Your threats are empty, nothing can move me. (Howard starts pushing his chair with the front of the car) Stop that.
Get out of my spot.
No. That‰Ûªs it. I am calling campus security. You prepare for the scolding of your life.
What are you idiots doing?
He‰Ûªs trying to kill me, Leonard. Video games and rock music have desensitized him to violence.
Would you please talk some sense into your lunatic roommate?
You‰Ûªre both acting like lunatics. It‰Ûªs just a parking spot.
It‰Ûªs not just a parking spot. He can‰Ûªt handle the fact that I‰Ûªm a bigger deal than he is now.

Oh, preposterous. I have been solely responsible for this university‰Ûªs six loop quantum gravity calculations, I have changed the way we think about Bose-Einstein condensates, and I am also the one who got Nutter Butters in the cafeteria vending machine. Maybe you missed that news while you were floating around like a goof in outer space. Now, if you‰Ûªll excuse me, I have work to do.
Can you believe this guy?
What I don‰Ûªt believe is that you tried to run him over.
Oh, like you‰Ûªve never thought of doing that. Don‰Ûªt hate me just because I lived the dream. (Horn beeps. Sheldon is sitting naked in Howard‰Ûªs car.)
Hey, sweet ride.
What are you doing in there?
Just breaking in your new car.
Stop that. You stop that.
You know what they say? Revenge is a dish best served nude.
Sheldon‰Ûªs office.
Hey, got a minute?
Oh, of course, come in. (Raj opens door to reveal Howard) This is an authentic Chinese throwing star, and I must warn you, I have seen many people throw them in movies.
Calm down. Howard has something he wants to say to you.
All right. Sheldon, when this whole thing with the parking space started, I had no idea just how much of a crazy bastard‰Û_
Howard, that‰Ûªs not how we practiced it.

I had no idea how much that spot meant to you. Anyway, I called President Siebert and told him it‰Ûªs not worth fighting over the spot, so you keep it, and I‰Ûªll park in the structure across the street.
Well, Howard, thank you. It‰Ûªs quite a gesture on your part. You‰Ûªve shown yourself to be the bigger man.
Thank you.
Which I find totally unacceptable. I must be the bigger man. Therefore, you may use my spot until such time as I learn to drive or get a Batmobile.
Wow, okay. Well, thanks. I don‰Ûªt know what to say.
There is nothing to say. Except I‰Ûªm the bigger man. I‰Ûªm not kidding. Say it.
Just say it.
You‰Ûªre the bigger man, Sheldon.
Oh, stop. And I believe this is yours. FYI, if you wear that into a bank, they will tackle you to the ground.
The cheesecake factory.
I‰Ûªd like to propose a toast, to burying the hatchet.
To burying the hatchet.
You know, I‰Ûªm kind of glad this happened.
Me, too. In some weird way, I kind of feel like it brought us closer.

character: Penny (with two black eyes and a plaster across her nose)
line: Yeah, everybody‰Ûªs happy, great.
A dry cleaners.
Can I help you?

Yes. According to information I gleaned from Yelp, you had great success when a santeriasuzy37 brought you a pair of leather slacks stained with chicken blood. I believe I may have a similar problem. This cushion experienced a nude revenge wiggle.
A what?
A naked man sat on it. Now, here‰Ûªs my concern, his diet is rich in fatty deli meats. What test do you have to detect lipid residue?
Lipid what?
Lipid residue. An anal autograph. A colon calling card, if you will.
Tuesday okay?
Don‰Ûªt rush it. We may be dealing with befoulment on a molecular level.
Let me write you a ticket.
Is that your son?
Uh-huh.

Looks like that laptop‰Ûªs seen better days. If you‰Ûªre interested, I‰Ûªm selling this. It‰Ûªs only two years old, 16 gigabytes of RAM, Intel core i7 processor, and I can personally guarantee it has spent less than 20 minutes resting on an astronaut‰Ûªs penis.
The apartment.
Is anyone else troubled by the Spider-Man theme song?
Why would it trouble you? It‰Ûªs, like, your third favourite cartoon theme song.
It is, right behind do-do-do-do-do Inspector Gadget., and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, heroes in a half-shell.
Turtle power!
However, the Spider-Man lyrics posit that Spider-Man, Spider-Man does whatever a spider can.
Yeah, so?
I can think of many things Spider-Man can‰Ûªt do that a spider can. One, crawl in your ear and die. Two, legally leave Guatemala without a passport. Three, have sex with a spider.
an we change the subject? Spiders give me the jeebie-jeebies.
It‰Ûªs heebie-jeebies.
I know, but that sounds anti-Semitic. Anyway, I was thinking we could have a little film festival tonight. The theme, movies that killed their franchises.
Oh. Like Jaws 4, Indiana Jones 4, Daredevil 1.
Penny‰Ûªs working tonight, I‰Ûªm in.
Not me. I‰Ûªm having dinner with Bernadette and her parents.
Fun. We know how much you love that.
It‰Ûªs torture. Especially with her dad. We have nothing in common.
You know what I like to do when I‰Ûªm forced to speak with those beneath my intellectual station? I bring up an interesting topic, like the difference between Spider-Man and spiders.
Thanks, Sheldon. I‰Ûªll try that with my father-in-law.

No, you can‰Ûªt use that one. That‰Ûªs mine. Uh, try this one for an ice-breaker. Uh, despite popular lore, there is no place in the continental United States, Alaska or Hawaii from which one can dig straight through the centre of the earth and come up in China.
Great, thank you.
Actually, you can‰Ûªt have that one either. It‰Ûªs too good. Sorry.
What about you, Sheldon? Do you have any plans tonight?

Sadly, yes. Amy‰Ûªs taking me to a memorial service. It‰Ûªs for one of her colleagues who is of Asian descent, so my planned conversational gambit is to casually remark that no matter how deep they dig his grave, he‰Ûªll never make his way back to China.
That should lighten the mood.
What can I say? I put the fun in funeral.
Amy‰Ûªs apartment.
(Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Oh, right, funeral. (Knock, knock, knock) (solemnly) Amy.
Hello, Sheldon.

You can‰Ûªt talk, you‰Ûªre paralyzed. I get right up in Santa‰Ûªs big, fat face and say, well, well, well, jolly old Saint Nick, we meet again. Yeah, I believe the last time we spoke was in the Baybrook Mall in Galveston, Texas, when I was five years old, isn‰Ûªt that right?

My mother dragged me there and she plopped me down on your lap and you asked me what I wanted for Christmas. And I told you, my Pop-Pop, because that was the year my grandfather died. I missed him and I wanted him back.

Pop-Pop was the only one in my family who encouraged me to pursue science. But you didn‰Ûªt bring him back, did you? No, instead, I got Lincoln Logs. Ladies, ladies, please. We‰Ûªre not here to talk about Penny, okay? We‰Ûªre here to talk about me. Uh, I mean Einstein Von Brainstorm. Oh, darn it! All right, I guess the cat‰Ûªs out of the bag. Let me explain what‰Ûªs going on. Ricardo is really Leonard.

Yes, Leonard, I am insecure. Happy?

Well, I do.

Come here. Tell you a secret?

Thank you, Dr. Cooper.
